webTitle: Sheringham the big difference

fields.headline: Sheringham the big difference
fields.standfirst:
Tigana's men match United in passing but visitors show finishing class
Richard Williams on a day to beat all others in the FA Cup
fields.trailText: Sheringham the big difference on the day.
fields.body:
Manchester United's return to the FA Cup could so easily have seen them drop out of it again. For a time here yesterday the masters of the passing game were themselves given a lesson in the passing arts as Fulham made a distinguished though ultimately brief contribution to this season's competition.

Eighteen months after United's previous appearance in the Cup, when they won the trophy a 10th time, Sir Alex Ferguson's side met a rather more demanding challenge than Newcastle United had offered them at Wembley in 1999. In the end they were spared a replay by another of those cool finishes that are Teddy Sheringham's hallmark, but not before the Nationwide leaders had achieved a quality of performance which will surely be enhancing the Premiership next season.

A year ago United passed up the FA Cup in order to compete in the Fifa world club championship in Brazil, an exercise designed to help England's bid to host the 2006 World Cup. All of which seemed long gone yesterday as Ferguson's players found themselves chasing the shadows of not Necaxa or Vasco da Gama but a Fulham side whose football has been honed first by Kevin Keegan and latterly by Jean Tigana.

When Ole Gunnar Solskjaer put Manchester United in front after only seven minutes the danger of an anticlimax was obvious. At that point Fulham, like so many of United's Premiership opponents, appeared tentative to the point of diffidence. For a time they seemed anxious not to offend.

Yet once Fabrice Fernandes had brought the scores level with the most impertinent of free-kicks, all that changed. For the rest of the first half and the early part of the second United struggled to keep track of the bewildering pace, accuracy and imagination of Fulham's football.

Louis Saha, Tigana's £2.1m signing from Metz, was inspired and Luis Boa Morte, the former Arsenal striker now on loan to Fulham from Southampton, was not far behind him. Working in tandem these two, Frenchman and Portuguese, shrugged aside United's midfield and consistently threatened to turn their centre-backs inside-out.

As Ferguson admitted later: "That's the toughest time Gary Neville and Wes Brown have been given this season. Fulham's front two were fantastic for them and their team as a whole were never overawed.

"Once they scored I was glad to get to half-time and sort out one or two things. And while I didn't think we were under so much pressure in the second half, there was a point near the end when I would have settled for a replay at Old Trafford."

Certainly this appeared the most likely outcome until Sheringham, newly recovered from a hamstring injury, came off the United bench to spare Ferguson that chore. And after performing so well earlier in the game Fulham were understandably downcast at losing the tie in the 89th minute.

"Well though we played," said Lee Clark, "this was a reminder that if you make a slight mistake against opponents of this class you'll be punished for it. Teddy Sheringham had one shot and scored from it. That was the difference between the teams today."

Clark's point was well made. All the menace achieved by Saha and Boa Morte was scarcely reflected in the number of saves Raimond van der Gouw, keeping goal for United in place of the flu-stricken Fabien Barthez, had to make.

Fulham pulled aside the curtain of United's defence often enough but without opening the windows. Audacious runs by Saha or Boa Morte should have set them up for more than one goal but too often the finishing was awry.

Nevertheless the fact that Fulham had gained a sufficiently strong grip of the tie by half-time to force Ferguson to reorganise his strategy said much for the level of performance achieved by Tigana's side. Even before Nicky Butt departed with a bruised hip the industry of Clark and Nicolas Sahnoun, frequently augmented by Saha or Boa Morte dropping deep, was threatening to overwhelm United in midfield.

In the second half, however, the switching of Phil Neville to midfield, with David Beckham and Ryan Giggs tucking in from the flanks, forced Fulham to operate in narrower corridors of space than they had enjoyed hitherto. Gradually United began to reassert their own passing game and once an exhausted Boa Morte had been substituted Fulham looked increasingly less likely to pull off a famous victory.

A draw looked the fairest result. Solskjaer's goal, swiftly dispatched into the far corner of the net after Beckham had caught Clark in possession, was nicely balanced by Fernandes's cheekily chipped free-kick, which had been advanced 10 yards by Jeff Winter after he had cautioned Roy Keane for delaying it.

The tie was approaching a weary, scrappy conclusion when Lee Chadwick, who had just come on for Beckham, worked the ball to Sheringham, whose left foot did the rest.

"For me this was a real cup-tie day," said Ferguson. "Maybe we could have gone to Yeovil and had a similar game. This is the FA Cup."

Certainly he looked happy to be back and so, in the end, did his team.

webTitle: Round-up

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Sunderland's supporters have already made the long journey to Crystal Palace twice this season - once for a game that was called off, then for one they lost. Now they will have to travel again after their team struggled in the third round's only scoreless tie so far.
fields.body:
Sunderland's supporters have already made the long journey to Crystal Palace twice this season - once for a game that was called off, then for one they lost. Now they will have to travel again after their team struggled in the third round's only scoreless tie so far.

They had reason to be grateful even for that as Mike Riley rejected two late Palace penalty appeals. But after Hayden Mullins was sent off for throwing a punch at Gavin McCann, Sunderland should have risen to the challenge rather than allowing Aleksandrs Kolinko the chance to show off in the visiting goal.

Palace's draw was one of First Division clubs' few highlights. Blackburn made hard work of beating the Conference side Chester 2-0 thanks to late goals from Martin Taylor and Marcus Bent, but the top half of the division boasted only two other winners in Bolton and Wolves.

Saturday's three games between First Division clubs were all settled by the odd goal, with Tranmere, Stockport and Sheffield Wednesday beating Portsmouth, Preston and Norwich .

Lou Macari was named manager of the month last week, so it was perhaps inevitable that his Huddersfield side would go down 2-0 to Bristol City . It was the only victory for Second Division sides over teams from the league above them, although Bournemouth, in losing 3-2 at home to Gillingham, provided the only defeat. QPR came close to joining them, requiring a last-minute penalty from Gavin Peacock to secure a 3-3 draw at struggling Luton.

The third flight was, however, boosted by draws for Wycombe and Notts County at Grimsby and Wimbledon respectively, while Third Division Scunthorpe and Cardiff earned replays from Burnley and Crewe.

webTitle: Young Doherty earns his Spurs in defence

fields.headline: Young Doherty earns his Spurs in defence
fields.trailText:
Leyton Orient 0 - 1 Tottenham
Doherty earns his Spurs in defence.
fields.body:
Who says the FA Cup has lost its capacity to shock? Forget Dagenham and Redbridge or Kingstonian, here was real proof that the truly unexpected still happens. For the first time in nine months Tottenham won away.

Given that David Ginola's winner at Leicester last April came in the 90th minute, it was fitting that Gary Doherty's decisive header on Saturday arrived deep into injury-time. Fitting, too, that the 20-year-old Irishman should be the player cruelly to deny Leyton Orient a lucrative replay.

As Spurs judder along, interspersing humdrum displays with occasional surges of inspiration, the performances of youngsters such as Doherty and Ledley King at least fill their fans with hope for the future. Alton Thelwell has also impressed and there are others bubbling under.

Having not started for Spurs until a visit to Ipswich nine days ago, the versatile Doherty has been a revelation. He struggled in attack at Portman Road but, since shifting to centre-back, has scored twice in two matches.

"I was upset with my performance at Ipswich," said Doherty, a £1m signing from Luton last April. "I knew I didn't do well enough and I let a lot of people down playing up front. But now I have fitted into centre-back I've been really enjoying it." Player and club see his future there.

He also contributed an important lunging block to deny Scott Houghton.

If Doherty seems unfazed by his new status it is hardly surprising, having won three Ireland caps and made his Premiership debut as a substitute at Old Trafford. King, an England Under-21 international, has likewise settled well in midfield. Here he showed glimpses of his strength and steady passing and hit the post with a header.

"It's always great to have a crop of young players coming through," said Rebrov, who at Dynamo Kiev saw the benefits of a fruitful youth policy. In buying Doherty, Matthew Etherington and Simon Davies among others while developing King, Thelwell and Luke Young, Tottenham have planned deliberately for the future.

The present, though, is not as rosy as the fans would like. Orient made life hard with an organised, tigerish performance, but the quality of most of Tottenham's play hardly screamed Premiership. They showed few sparks of ingenuity and, without Stephen Carr, lack consistent width.

Not that they looked in danger of losing. Neil Sullivan, whose handling was impeccable, made only one significant save. At the other end Stephen Clemence and Oyvind Leonhardsen should have scored and Rebrov was twice denied by Ashley Bayes.

"I'm reasonably pleased with my contributions in recent games," said Rebrov, who was dropped for Doherty at Ipswich. "I think I've come through an initial adaptation period and shaken off my injury so there are grounds for optimism."

Rebrov was shocked at how hard life could be against a Third Division side. "In Ukraine," the striker said, "even when you are playing a team lower down the Premier League, the top few sides don't expect to encounter a real challenge."

Orient provided a stiff enough challenge to suggest they are capable of winning promotion. When Bayes saved from Rebrov in injury-time it seemed they had done enough, but Doherty headed in a Darren Anderton corner.

Spurs will hope they do not wait nine months for their next away win. Orient are realistic enough to know that another 12,000 crowd is unlikely for the LDV Vans Trophy tie against Wycombe tomorrow.

webTitle: Wise move to stave off transfer

fields.headline: Wise move to stave off transfer
fields.trailText:
Chelsea 5 - 0 Peterborough
Wise move to stave off transfer.
fields.body:
The Chelsea fans left Dennis Wise in no doubt as to their feelings. There were cheers every time he touched the ball, and if he did anything so important as take a corner he received a standing ovation. He may have asked for a transfer after being dropped for last week's home win over Aston Villa but few here intend to let him leave without a struggle.

Barry Fry, the Peterborough manager, had an original interpretation of Wise's recent removal from the Chelsea first team. "He makes a great difference, and Zola's a class act," he said. "When we watched them last week those two were missing; Claudio's tactics of saving his best players for us was a tremendous compliment."

Wise saw things differently, of course, but if he was feeling unsettled it did not show in his performance here. Fry rated him "the best player on the park" and Gianfranco Zola felt likewise. "I think Dennis is outstanding. He is the soul of this team," he said. "I can't even think about him leaving.

"Let's put it another way: he played fantastically and hopefully he's going to play fantastically for us all season.

"I knew that he had a few concerns about the way we're playing, and especially his position. But we had so many injuries we were forced to play differently.

"Now those players are coming back so everybody is going to go back to his position.

"Nobody wants him to go, especially the manager. As far as I know he wants to build a team around him. He knows how important he is for the team. We love Dennis and we'll do anything we can to get him to stay."

But any team built around a 34-year-old will not last long, and Claudio Ranieri has hinted of late that he is ready to promote Chelsea's more youthful talents. Five of yesterday's squad were under 23.

Much has been made of Peterborough's youth programme over the past few seasons, and two graduates, Simon Davies and Matthew Etherington, moved to Tottenham last year, but those who remained were simply outclassed.

Once in each half they came close to scoring, but sadly they looked close to conceding throughout the remaining 88 minutes.

"At the end of the day they're just too good for us, which we expected," said Fry. "I don't think I can fault my lads in any way, shape or form, and they'll all be better for the experience."

Mark Tyler, their impressive young goalkeeper, is unlikely to be feeling so philosophical after conceding five. But for him and some profligate finishing it would have been many more.

Wise himself missed the best chance of the opening period, his shot deflected wide by Tyler, before Zola calmed any lingering nerves by lofting the ball over the keeper in the 37th minute.

Chelsea's recalled captain, controlling the game from midfield, provided a perfect pass to set up the second and seal victory.

The Posh passing improved after theinterval but they were still helpless as twice in three minutes Chelsea picked them apart down the right before scoring from centres first low then high. Zola's scrappy second five minutes from the end provided a familiar tinge to proceedings: Peterborough also conceded five on their only previous visit to this ground, in 1965.

 Chelsea's 27-year-old defender Christian Panucci is on the verge of signing for the French champions Monaco, according to L'Equipe.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Solano remains the talk of the Tyne

fields.headline: Solano remains the talk of the Tyne
fields.trailText:
Newcastle 1 - 1 Aston Villa
Solano the talk of the Tyne again.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at St James' Park
fields.body:
Amid all the toil and effort, Tyneside belatedly flickered into life yesterday with two goals and a flash of brilliance as the beaten finalists from the past three seasons fought out a predictable stalemate.

Trailing to Steve Stone's strike, Newcastle restored the equilibrium when Nolberto Solano rammed a stunning volley through a crowded area with 10 minutes remaining. On Wednesday next week, the Toon will have to do without their suspended Peruvian genius and Kieron Dyer as they start from scratch in pursuit of a fourth-round tie against Leicester City.

"It was a typical, fiercely contested match," said the Newcastle manager Bobby Robson, "but we did well given that a lot of my players were exhausted after playing Tottenham five days ago. Gary Speed was legless; that must be a reflection of the festive games."

It could hardly be down to premature celebration. The Geordies have not lost an FA Cup tie anywhere other than Wembley for four years, although that record was endangered by Stone's close-range finish after a tepid first half. But Solano has been nothing short of inspirational this season; with 10 minutes remaining, he watched the substitute Stephen Glass's cross loop high from George Boateng's headed clearance and emphatically crashed a volley past David James from just outside the area.

"I was praying it was going to land for anyone but him when it dropped out of the sky," said the Villa manager John Gregory. "But he can't play in the replay. Isn't that wonderful?"

Solano almost won the tie with a vicious free-kick from near the right touchline in stoppage time. But the home support's howls of frustration turned to sighs of relief when Darius Vassell sliced over an open goal seconds later.

Such excitement was absent during a first half that was more humdrum than humdinger. The visitors marginally made the brighter start and might have taken the lead after 10 minutes as Dion Dublin stooped to meet Paul Merson's first-time cross. Steve Harper dived full stretch to his right and palmed the ball around the post.

Frustrated by the tedium, the home support took instead to baiting their former favourite David Ginola. He was clearly desperate to impress, but Andy Griffin dumped him on his backside after four minutes and his afternoon hardly improved thereafter. The same defender scythed him down horribly on the quarter-hour; Ginola, battered and bruised, spent the rest of the half stumbling to the floor or back-healing the ball out of play.

Yet his only flash of genius helped put Villa ahead. Nine minutes after the break, Ginola back-heeled the ball to the marauding Gareth Barry, who cut inside Griffin and crossed for Stone to thump his volley beyond Harper.

"Steve was by far our best player on the day and he'll take particular delight in that goal, being a Geordie," said Gregory.

Villa might have expected to bask in counter-attacking intent yet appeared to lose their poise. Against the wall of claret and blue, Clarence Acuna headed Solano's cross wide of the far post and Shola Ameobi, fed by Dyer, struck the outside of a post. Then came the Peruvian's party piece and a frantic finish.

Their re-match assured, both managers can now turn their attentions to adding to their increasingly threadbare squads. Robson has taken Sheffield United's left-back Wayne Quinn on a month's loan with a view to a permanent transfer, but has given up waiting for Didier Domi to return from Paris.

Gregory remains hopeful of completing the club-record £9.5m signing of Juan Pablo Angel from River Plate. A phone call from Argentina yesterday may have resurrected the deal, although he said: "I'm not confident, but it's not dead."

Should compromise not be reached between the player's agent and Fifa, Gregory may have to suffice with a glimpse of the Angel of the North on his journey home.

Solano almost won the tie with a vicious free-kick from near the right touchline in stoppage time. But the home support's howls of frustration turned to sighs of relief when Darius Vassell sliced over an open goal seconds later. Such excitement was absent during a first half that was more humdrum than humdinger. The visitors marginally made the brighter start and might have taken the lead after 10 minutes as Dion Dublin stooped to meet Paul Merson's first-time cross. Steve Harper dived full stretch to his right and palmed the ball around the post. Frustrated by the tedium, the home support took instead to baiting their former favourite David Ginola. He was clearly desperate to impress, but Andy Griffin dumped him on his backside after four minutes and his afternoon hardly improved thereafter. The same defender scythed him down horribly on the quarter-hour; Ginola, battered and bruised, spent the rest of the half stumbling to the floor or back-healing the ball out of play. Yet his only flash of genius helped put Villa ahead. Nine minutes after the break, Ginola back-heeled the ball to the marauding Gareth Barry, who cut inside Griffin and crossed for Stone to thump his volley beyond Harper. "Steve was by far our best player on the day and he'll take particular delight in that goal, being a Geordie," said Gregory. Villa might have expected to bask in counter-attacking intent yet appeared to lose their poise. Against the wall of claret and blue, Clarence Acuna headed Solano's cross wide of the far post and Shola Ameobi, fed by Dyer, struck the outside of a post. Then came the Peruvian's party piece and a frantic finish. Their re-match assured, both managers can now turn their attentions to adding to their increasingly threadbare squads. Robson has taken Sheffield United's left-back Wayne Quinn on a month's loan with a view to a permanent transfer, but has given up waiting for Didier Domi to return from Paris. Gregory remains hopeful of completing the club-record £9.5m signing of Juan Pablo Angel from River Plate. A phone call from Argentina yesterday may have resurrected the deal, although he said: "I'm not confident, but it's not dead." Should compromise not be reached between the player's agent and Fifa, Gregory may have to suffice with a glimpse of the Angel of the North on his journey home.  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: School of science survives pits visit

fields.headline: School of science survives pits visit
fields.trailText:
Watford 1 - 2 Everton
School of science survives pits visit.
fields.body:
Watford exercise a curious mystique in English football. Perhaps it is the likeable, honest personalities at the helm, Sir Elton John and Graham Taylor; perhaps the enduring image of a family club, prudent in their housekeeping. It is just a shame about their football.

The fund of goodwill enjoyed by the club that Elton and Graham built seems inexhaustible, a fact that was illustrated when many neutral voices murmured in assent as Taylor claimed his side had suffered "a bit of rough justice" in losing to Everton. The same sentiment was expressed after defeat by the Merseyside club in a poor 1984 Cup final. Image had again triumphed over substance; Everton, then as now, deserved to win.

True, Walter Smith's side left it indecently late, with Steve Watson a highly improbable matchwinner thanks to his thrusting header, and also true that this Everton are a pale shadow of Howard Kendall's emerging team of 1984. But at Vicarage Road they demonstrated a superior will and ultimately superior football.

It is not often in their declining league season that Everton can argue that they were dragged down to the level of their opponents. But here in a first half of ballooned balls in which three consecutive passes were an absolute bonus, they were.

Watford, direct, combative and featuring physically imposing figures at front and back - Gifton Noel-Williams and Darren Ward - suckered Everton into playing their industrial game, while Allan Neilsen's thoughtful movement looked incongruous amid his more limited team-mates. But when the Premiership side finally got Smith's message and started to play, the home side fell apart.

After Tommy Mooney prodded Watford ahead midway through the first half, Everton woke up leaving Smith relieved about Stephen Hughes's ferociously struck equaliser and overjoyed at Watson's late winner. But he was too canny to view victory here as a watershed in their fragmented season and offered only the modest hope that this success would soon "get us a bit of consistency and confidence".

The return of Kevin Campbell and - possibly - the still talismanic Paul Gascoigne against Tottenham next Saturday would certainly help. Smith was relieved, too, to see Duncan Ferguson complete 90 minutes even if Everton will soon lose Joe-Max Moore to suspension after the striker followed Watford's captain Robert Page off the pitch late on after second cautions.

Both managers believed Rob Styles had been overzealous in brandishing eight yellow cards in all, six to Everton. For Watford partisans, that deepened the injustice. But their football here deserved no reward.

webTitle: Leeds come through a desert

fields.headline: Leeds come through a desert
fields.trailText:
Leeds 1 - 0 Barnsley
Leeds come through a goal desert.
fields.body:
There were a few raised eyebrows when Robbie Keane agreed to be repatriated from Italy as Leeds seemed to have an abundance of quality strikers. But the statistics do not bear this out.

Leeds are not scoring enough goals and, as a result, the pressure is on the Irish striker to come up with the goods.

If they do not start to come up with goals quickly, Leeds will not qualify for Europe again next season after a 12-month period in which more than £35m will have been invested in players, with an additional £13m due on Keane in the summer.

In their past 12 matches they have scored more than once on a single occasion, a record that has left them nearer relegation than a European-qualifying place in the league with Alan Smith netting once in the past 19 matches, Michael Bridges and Harry Kewell injured and Darren Huckerby at Manchester City.

Mark Viduka scored his 14th of the season as the problem continued against Barnsley. His ninth-minute strike guaranteed a place in the fourth round but, even with Keane pushed in behind the front two, that is the way it stayed despite a number of first-half chances. And it left Leeds to experience one or two uncomfortable moments late in the second half.

Viduka admitted that the attackers are not doing sufficient damage: "We could have been more convincing up front and I would have liked my general play to be better," he said. "We should have been further ahead at half-time."

The Leeds manager David O'Leary stressed he did not want to offer excuses but revealed he does not like to play with three central strikers. "We don't have any width and the players who can provide it are not fit," he said.

Barnsley did produce three on-target attempts in their one good spell late in the game and their striker Neil Shipperley believed they merited a replay. "We looked good in the second half, played some great stuff and deserved something."

webTitle: Kanoute double spares Hammers

fields.headline: Kanoute double spares Hammers
fields.trailText:
Walsall 2 - 3 West Ham
Kanoute double spares Hammers.
fields.byline: Adrian Milledge at the Bescot stadium
fields.body:
Take a corrugated pitch, add an in-form Second Division side, sprinkle liberally with Premiership players susceptible to succumbing to lower-league opponents and finish off with a goalkeeper in inspired form: this encounter had all the ingredients for a Cup shock.

That West Ham did not ultimately choke on the West Midlands recipe was down to a diverse trio: a yeoman Englishman, a prodigy and a French wizard.

It was the latter two, Joe Cole and Frédéric Kanouté, whose combination of precocious skills and incisive finishing were responsible for the most appetising fare, but when the going became tough, as it invariably does when the Second Division leaders Walsall are up against it, who better to provide the necessary roughage than Stuart Pearce?

At 38 the lure of playing in the final remains as strong for the defender as it was when he made the first of his two appearances in the competition for Coventry City in the early 1980s. Perhaps his hunger is fuelled by memories of defeat in two Wembley finals, with Nottingham Forest and Newcastle United, but he knows the Hammers' recent record does not bode well for his chances of appearing at the Milennium stadium in May.

In the past 10 years the Londoners have totted up a dozen failures against below-stairs opposition in either the FA or League Cup, which is why Pearce greeted Saturday's victory with undisguised relief. "West Ham have made a habit of getting turned over in the past so hopefully we are on our way to eradicating that," he said. "Nevertheless we will have to play a lot better than this if we are to go all the way."

That proviso says more about the perfectionist in Pearce than it does about Saturday's performance. Had the Walsall goalkeeper Jimmy Walker not produced two spectacular spells of defiance in which he pulled off six improbable saves, the Hammers would have been home after an hour.

By then Cole had played a part in both goals, Kanouté backheeling the teenager's pass into the path of Frank Lampard for the first before heading home his right-wing cross for the second.

Between times Walsall, who played their part in an always absorbing Cup tie, kept the match alive courtesy of Darren Wrack's first-half equaliser and Brett Angell's scrambled effort after Kanouté appeared to have settled matters with a blistering drive from distance.

However, had Angell proved more accurate in the second minute when he wastefully headed over a cross from the impressive Spanish left-back Zigor Aranalde, Walsall might well have served up an all-too-familiar and unpalatable dish for the visitors.

webTitle: Christie helps Smith buy time

fields.headline: Christie helps Smith buy time
fields.trailText:
Derby 3 - 2 WBA
Christie helps Smith buy time.
fields.body:
Jim Smith is not ready for the golden clock and retirement speeches just yet but, like all gentlemen of a certain age, he is at the stage now where he has started giving thought to what might have been. "Bloody hell," he wheezes. "All these years and I've never even had a sniff of the FA Cup final."

Though that may not be strictly true - Smith was in charge of the Portsmouth side that memorably took Liverpool to penalties in the 1992 semi-finals - it is an inescapable fact that the competition has generally hurled more brickbats than bouquets in his direction.

This year may well be his last hurrah and, should he flounder again, Derby's durable old manager will no doubt hand over to Colin Todd at the end of the season with the irksome thought gnawing away at the back of his mind.

The portents are not good. Manchester United, Chelsea and Liverpool have hogged the trophy like a doting grandparent over the past two decades and the days when a team such as Coventry or Wimbledon could break with protocol to spark their own Wembley knees-up are becoming but a waning memory.

Derby are among those lurking behind the aristocracy but their longevity depends on which of their Jekyll and Hyde tendencies they display from now on. Will it be the team that airily swept West Brom aside for the opening three-quarters of this game or the one that hobbled to the finishing line like a cross-country runner with a pebble in his sock?

From three goals up to clinging on for the final whistle, this was a banana skin that Derby slipped and slithered upon before finally regaining their foothold just as it looked as though they would end up on the seat of their pants.

A couple of close-range finishes from Malcolm Christie, sandwiching Stefano Eranio's first goal of the season, did not flatter the Premiership side as the game entered the stage where West Brom should have been turning their thoughts to damage limitation.

Instead Derby were culpable of what Smith later described as showboating - the bewildering Georgi Kinkladze even surrendered possession with a back-heel on the edge of his penalty area - and West Brom promptly nabbed two goals back via headers from Bob Taylor and Lee Hughes. Cue 10 minutes of deeply unnecessary tension, although Albion's manager Gary Megson complained that his side lacked the passion and desire to exploit Derby's weaknesses fully.

Derby dropped their guard and had the fat lip to show for it. The damage remained superficial but if West Brom had completed the recovery then Smith's face, a rich shade of red at the best of times, would have been positively claret.

webTitle: Weaver mends frayed nerves

fields.headline: Weaver mends frayed nerves
fields.trailText:
Man City 3 - 2 Birmingham
Life's never easy at Maine Road.
fields.body:
Manchester City ought to print a public warning on their match tickets stating that 90 minutes inside this ground can seriously damage your health.

Joe Royle's side are renowned for their unpredictability and they were at their nerve-shredding best against their First Division visitors, establishing a 3-0 lead at half-time and then doing their level best to throw it away.

"I'd love to enjoy a nice easy win, but that never happens with City," said Royle. Whether he can guide his team through the Cup minefield to their first major trophy for 25 years is impossible to predict, but it is unlikely that they will survive very long if they reproduce their second-half showing against Birmingham.

Before they lost their way, though, the home team had looked well worth their half-time lead. Indeed, their first goal, from Andy Morrison, was as good a header as anybody is likely to score between now and Cup final day.

The 30-year-old defender, starting only his third game for City since a career-threatening knee injury 15 months ago, rose above the Birmingham defence to guide the ball past Ian Bennett. "It has been a long road," said Morrison. "For a while, I thought I'd never get back."

Morrison's goal was overshadowed by Darren Huckerby's solo strike, however. Huckerby collected the ball on the far touchline and beat two defenders before scoring his second goal in three games since arriving at Maine Road in a £3.2m transfer from Leeds.

When Shaun Goater scored from the penalty spot to make it 3-0, that should have been it, but the home side allowed Birmingham to give the Maine Road supporters their fortnightly dose of anguish through goals from Martin Grainger and Dele Adebola.

Indeed, the visitors would have earned a replay had Marcelo's 25-yard strike not been tipped behind for a corner by the home goalkeeper Nicky Weaver, who made amends for his mistake at Coventry on New Year's Day.

"It was a magnificent save," said Trevor Francis, the Birmingham manager, who sounded almost thankful to Weaver for enabling his side to make their exit from the Cup. "I'm not too disappointed. We have a Worthington Cup semi-final on Tuesday and that's more important to us." For Royle, however, the dream of Cardiff in May still lingers.

 The Manchester City striker Paulo Wanchope scored Costa Rica's first goal, from a tight angle, in their 5-2 win over Guatemala in a World Cup qualifier in Miami on Saturday.

webTitle: Warnock sinks seething in south

fields.headline: Warnock sinks seething in south
fields.trailText:
Southampton 1 - 0 Sheffield United
Warnock left seething in the south.
fields.body:
Neil Warnock does not expect a backlash from the Football Association following his outspoken attack on the referee David Elleray at the end of this match.

"Why should I be in trouble with the FA?" the Sheffield United manager said. "I was only speaking the truth. We were not beaten by Southampton, we were beaten by the referee."

He continued his attack on Elleray when asked what mark he would be giving the official. "Glenn Hoddle will be giving him 10 out of 10," Warnock replied, "so he will come away with an average mark of five."

Referees have come under attack from a number of managers recently, including - since Christmas - the former England bosses Bobby Robson, Terry Venables and Hoddle, who was upset after Southampton's defeat at Liverpool on New Year's Day. None, however, has been more stinging than this and the FA is unlikely to turn the other, already blotchy, cheek.

After a late penalty had decided this very competitive and physical match, Warnock said: "From where Elleray was positioned he needed binoculars to see it. But he gave the penalty before Beattie hit the ground. It stinks.

"They conned him all afternoon and he was off the pace throughout the game.

"I'm totally disappointed and deflated. Elleray also refereed Southampton's recent match against Spurs and if he does any more games here they will be safe in a month."

But Warnock did not have too many complaints about Elleray's decision to show Bobby Ford the red card for foul language immediately after the goal. "He's a school teacher, isn't he? And I warned my players that if they used bad language they would get 100 lines."

Warnock's words, however, did not disguise the fact his side never had any ambition of winning this match. They came for a replay and competed hard. But once Jason Dodd had scored from the spot they never looked capable of getting back into the game.

Elleray's ability to get up people's noses with his officiousness is infamous but his penalty decision seemed a fair one.

United's goalkeeper Simon Tracey could only parry a fierce drive from Wayne Bridge and then brought down James Beattie as the forward closed in on the loose ball.

Southampton were always the more likely to score and Jo Tessem and Beattie both hit the post before the goal.

"It made a change not being the underdogs," said Hoddle. "We knew it would be an awkward game, that it would be physical and that we would have to keep our discipline. And we did just that."

United's goalkeeper Simon Tracey could only parry a fierce drive from Wayne Bridge and then brought down James Beattie as the forward closed in on the loose ball. webTitle: Reds alert despite Fowler's absence

fields.headline: Reds alert despite Fowler's absence
fields.trailText:
Liverpool 3 - 0 Rotherham
Reds alert despite Fowler's absence.
fields.body:
Although many believe it is a question of when rather than if Robbie Fowler leaves Liverpool this season, the Anfield chief executive Rick Parry was publicly saying yesterday that the club wants Fowler to stay despite the recent signing of the Finnish striker Jari Litmanen from Barcelona.

Speaking on BBC Radio 5 Live, Parry underlined the beliefs of the manager Gérard Houllier as he said: "In order to compete, given the number of matches that we have, we need four strikers, as Manchester United and Arsenal have shown.

"The way of modern football is that sadly they will pick up injuries, there will be tiredness and they will all play games. We need four strikers and I think the ideal outcome for us, without a doubt, would be Robbie happy and performing at his peak. There's no question about that."

Whether or not Fowler is feeling any happier with his lot in life is a moot point, as he missed his side's ultimately emphatic victory over Second Division Rotherham in order to recover away from the fans' gaze from the facial injuries he picked up when he was attacked in the early hours after a night on the town.

Liverpool, rewarded with a tough trip to Leeds in the fourth round of the FA Cup, had seemed destined for an awkward afternoon when they failed to impose early authority over a spirited Rotherham team given boisterous support by their 7,000 travelling fans.

But once Emile Heskey's 47th-minute diving header was fumbled en route to goal by the previously excellent Ian Gray, there was an air of inevitability to what followed - even though Igor Biscan's dismissal for a second bookable offence left Liverpool to play the last 28 minutes with only 10 men.

First Dietmar Hamann fired low from the edge of the area after 73 minutes to capitalise on an opportunity created by Danny Murphy's determined run. Then two minutes later Heskey drove home his second to emphasise the gulf in class as Rotherham tired in the closing stages.

webTitle: Lack of fire cracks old joke of York

fields.headline: Lack of fire cracks old joke of York
fields.trailText:
Leicester 3 - 0 York
Lack of fire cracks old joke of York.
fields.body:
Passion will make a comeback one of these post-post-modern days, but for the moment irony still rules. This is why Robbie Savage can be named one of the Premiership's top 20 "babes".

It may also help explain why the final goal of this match was scored by Richard Cresswell, Leicester's former York striker - though as Cresswell pointed out, this may not be irony so much as "a bit of a coincidence" - and why a heavy defeat wrung nothing more intense from the York players than a wry smile.

"I was expecting an organised team," said Peter Taylor. But those of us expecting a Cup-fighting team in the grand old York tradition were disappointed. The visitors set out to spoil and when that strategy broke down they offered little else. They didn't even require Simon Royce, Leicester's reserve goalkeeper, to muddy his knees.

York's recent record does not inspire confidence and they certainly had little to spare on Saturday. Lining up with their striker Colin Alcide in the centre of their defence and an on-loan 22-year-old alone up front, they can hardly have convinced themselves that they were capable of putting up a fight.

Yet they could have taken the lead. Twice in the first half forwards broke clear only to drag their shots wide. Such circumstances reveal an absence of self-belief as much as a lack of technique.

Chris Iwelumo should not be entirely devoid of either. The Afro-Scottish striker, on loan from Stoke, had scored two goals in the previous three York games and can boast of a season in the Danish Superleague, even if it ended in relegation.

When Matt Jones presented him with the ball in the 36th minute, the goal loomed. Did someone mention the freedom of York, Match of the Day credits, Cup immortality? Iwelumo dragged his shot wide of Royce's far post.

Leicester quickly put an end to the pantomime. Pressing hard down the flanks, they scored three goals in a quarter of an hour, starting as they had so often threatened to do by converting a corner.

Leicester are a big side, but that did not excuse York leaving Gary Rowett unmarked at the far post. The defender obliged by scoring his first goal for Leicester, a half-volley with his weaker foot.

Kevin Hulme then went into the back of Trevor Benjamin to give away the penalty. This hardly indicated passion or even frustration. It looked more like stupidity.

Alan Fettis, York's Northern Ireland international goalkeeper, had kept the score half respectable, but Cresswell beat him with a diving header, his first goal for Leicester.

"Our organisation was spot on," said the York manager Terry Dolan. Before next time, though, he should do something about the other qualities needed for progress in the Cup. Passion would be a good place to start.

webTitle: Jones wakes sleeping Wolves

fields.headline: Jones wakes sleeping Wolves
fields.trailText:
Nottm Forest 0 - 1 Wolves
Jones wakes sleeping Wolves.
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor at the City Ground
fields.body:
There is a tide of thought in the Black Country that Wolves have been dormant for so long it is time someone took a stick and gave them a sharp prod to check they have not actually slipped into a coma.

The task of wielding the said implement has proved an onerous one for longer than they would care to remember at Molineux but, for now at least, there are definite signs of response.

A breakaway goal by Adam Proudlock three minutes from the end of this all-Midlands affair earned Wolves a fourth-round trip to Wycombe or Grimsby and gave their new manager Dave Jones a winning start.

For Jones, however, the result was only the subplot to the main drama. Making his return to management after the end of a lengthy personal ordeal when the case against him of alleged child abuse collapsed, this was always going to be more than just another match.

"I knew how our own supporters would react to me but I didn't know about other people and, yes, I was nervous coming to the ground," he said.

"I can't thank everyone enough. There has been nothing but good wishes from everyone, which was a great feeling because my family were all here too. What they have been through over the last 12 months I wouldn't put anyone through."

Presumably Jones did not hear the taunts emanating from A-block. His family, however, might be advised to keep their distance when Portsmouth visit Molineux next Saturday. "With my Southampton links they think I'm a scummer anyway," he said.

In truth it was an insipid affair. Forest had the glut of chances but, inexperienced and injury-ravaged, their lack of presence in attack served only to emphasise why David Platt is so keen to recruit a forward. A £2.5m bid for Ipswich Town's David Johnson was turned down last week and unless Platt finds someone soon it may undermine the rest of their season.

Wolves, it would seem, have less of a problem up front. Proudlock was loaned to Clyde at the start of the season and after scoring five goals in six games north of the border he has now scored six times for Wolves and is drawing inevitable, if somewhat tiresome, comparisons with Steve Bull.

After a tepid opening half the 19-year-old became the pivotal figure. First he turned a snap shot beyond Dave Beasant only for the ball to ricochet off the post and into the goalkeeper's arms. Then, with eight minutes remaining and Forest pushing more bodies into attack, he sprinted clear of the home defence but aimed his shot too close to Beasant.

The winning goal was a similar break. Tony Dinning hoofed the ball out of his own defence and Proudlock was off and running again. This time he showed the composure to manoeuvre the ball on to his right foot, stepping inside Christian Edwards and Jermaine Jenas before picking out the bottom right-hand corner with a precise drive from 20 yards.

"He's similar to Steve Bull in that he knows where the goal is," said Jones. "He's got a big future and if he's half as successful as Bully he will be a hero here."

Chris Bart-Williams, Forest's leading scorer despite forging an impressive new role as a ball-playing centre-half, saw a free-kick headed off the goal-line by Kevin Muscat, and David Freeman had a curling left-foot effort tipped over by the goalkeeper Michael Oakes.

Apart from that, however, if Forest were not running down cul-de-sacs they were finding blind alleys. "We had a lot of possession but you never really thought we looked like scoring," admitted Platt.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Ipswich are too wise to be caught out by Morecambe

fields.headline: Ipswich are too wise to be caught out by Morecambe
fields.standfirst: Premiership high flyers bring a day of sunshine to the seaside
fields.trailText:
Morecambe 0 - 3 Ipswich
High flyers bring sun to the seaside.
fields.body:
Official records will forever insist that 5,923 spectators wedged into Christie Park to watch Ipswich Town still Morecambe's FA Cup challenge. The truth is that the crowd was at least three higher. On such a momentous day in Morecambe's history, minor details such as not having a ticket were not about to stand in the way.

The main gate, heavily patrolled by stewards, 15 minutes to kick off. A man in a wheelchair, his colleague in a woolly hat and a small boy.

The right of the disabled supporter to free admittance was quickly conceded, but the prospects of those accompanying him hung in the balance.

"Well, where's your ticket?"

"I don't need one. I'm pushing him."

"And what about the boy?"

"He doesn't need one either - he's carrying his blanket."

The stewards conceded without a fight. Over on the open terraces, where he once lurked incognito, overcoat collar up and cap yanked down, the ghost of Eric Morecambe would have chuckled.

Morecambe, in the third round for only the second time, will forever contend that they should have had a first-half penalty when Hermann Hreidarsson hauled back Mark Quayle. They will tell of the chance that fell immediately afterwards to Ryan Zico Black, who dallied for, oh, surely half a minute at least, before Ipswich's goalkeeper, Richard Wright, collected the ball off his twitching right foot.

But then it will be time to pull back the blanket of nostalgia and concede that Ipswich proved their superiority without the merest hint of ostentation.

A non-League ground for a third-round tie is as threatening to the Premiership elite as "abroad" was to George Eliot: "that large home of ruined reputations". But Ipswich's players have been inured by a grounding in the lower leagues. As Morecambe's manager, Jim Harvey, recognised, there were no unpredictable egos for Morecambe to rub up the wrong way.

Harvey, Northern Ireland's No2, bracketed Ipswich's manager, George Burley, with Alan Curbishley at Charlton and David Moyes at Preston as young British managers worthy of imitation. "Sometimes, on days like these, you can expose an ego or two," he said. "Not with Ipswich."

BBC Radio Lancashire had recorded that Ipswich arrived in the splendour of the England RU coach and optimistically suggested that they would have been unsettled by a walk through the crowd on their way to the visitors' dressing room. In truth, they were probably more unsettled by the coach.

Marcus Stewart gave Ipswich a 15th-minute lead, after Alun Armstrong's shot had been repelled. "I played on a worse ground than this for four years with Bristol Rovers," was his response.

Ipswich adapted before half-time, content to ride out the passionate opening salvos. But they dominated thereafter: Armstrong headed a second after Fabian Wilnis's burst to the goalline and Hreidarsson and Martijn Reuser missed chances before Jermaine Wright volleyed a third from Jamie Clapham's cross.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: End of the jolly green giantkillers

fields.headline: End of the jolly green giantkillers
fields.trailText:
Bolton 2 - 1 Yeovil
End of the road for the jolly green giantkillers.
fields.byline: Ian Whittell at the Reebok Stadium
fields.body:
Yeovil's latest, and possibly last, FA Cup adventure as a non-League club may have ended in a last-gasp defeat but it earned the Conference team and their striker Warren Patmore an unexpected new admirer.

Colin Hendry, the Scotland captain who is on loan at Bolton, was not allowed to play in the tie by his club Coventry but was so impressed by Patmore that he asked for the 29-year-old striker's shirt after the game.

The veteran Premiership defender might not have been so ready to join Patmore's unofficial fan club had Michael Ricketts not spared Bolton the embarrassment of a replay visit to Huish Park with his winning goal in injury-time.

Patmore's well-taken effort midway through the first half had many believing that Bolton may be about to become the 21st League victim of Yeovil's FA Cup giant-killing history.

However, the timing of John O'Kane's scrambled equaliser just before half-time set the tone for a second period of total domination by the home team and an inevitable, if last-gasp, winning goal.

"Bolton deserved to win, no doubt about it with all the chances they had," conceded Patmore. But the Yeovil players were more gutted by the timing of their winner, in the 92nd minute.

"We had matched them for so long," Patmore said. "This Cup run has been great for all of us and for the club. It was just unfortunate the way it ended."

Yeovil also claimed, with reasonable justification, that both Bolton goals were questionable.

"For the first goal there was a push in the back and the boys said Ricketts brought the ball down with his arm for the second," said their goalkeeper Tony Pennock. "But that's the way it goes.

"This Cup run has been brilliant, what the FA Cup is all about and now we will concentrate on the league. Hopefully next season we will be the scalps that non-League teams are after."

That looks a near certainty given Yeovil's Manchester United-like stranglehold on the Conference table and, after dismissing Colchester and Blackpool and acquitting themselves so well at Bolton, the Third Division will be no poorer for their presence.

Bolton, too, have promotion as their primary aim this season, a target that looks increasingly likely given Ricketts's astonishing goalscoring record, which now stands at 16 goals this season, 11 of them as substitute.

"I don't like the super-sub tag and by the end of the season it will be gone," said Ricketts. "I'm scoring goals, which is the main thing, but I think the hardest thing in football is to come on as a sub.

"By the time you get used to the pace of the game, it's over. But if I have to live with it, I'll live with it."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Charlton fail to handle Daggers

fields.headline: Charlton fail to handle Daggers
fields.trailText:
Charlton 1 - 1 Dagenham
Charlton fail to handle Daggers.
fields.body:
Moves are afoot to increase promotion and relegation between the Conference and the Third Division to two up, two down. Nobody who watched this game is asking why.

It is no exaggeration to say that Dagenham and Redbridge - total cost of team £5,000 - outplayed and should have beaten the Premiership's seventh-placed team to secure one of the biggest upsets in the FA Cup's long and eventful history.

That they did not finally beat Charlton here was down to a cruelly deflected equaliser, which their performance did not deserve. As a result Alan Curbishley's far from valiant side live to fight another day.

If one is puzzled by how a Conference side can embarrass a team who have just beaten Arsenal and walloped Manchester City 4-1 after drawing 3-3 at home to Manchester United, then just look under the heading "the magic of the cup".

For Dagenham and Redbridge emerged from their short journey through the Blackwall tunnel as if having passed through a magical gateway, transformed from ordinary non-Leaguers to a team endowed with special powers.

Calm, confident and expertly organised, they passed the ball with such fluent accuracy, closed down with such unflagging determination and defended with such stylish solidity that Charlton were left looking like the underdogs they normally are.

Clearly the punter who placed £1,000 at 18-1 on a Daggers victory knew what they were capable of, even if John Salako's deflected 86th-minute equaliser abruptly ended his personal dreams as well as those of his beloved team.

"To be able to walk off after holding the team that drew with Manchester United and see 20,000 fans applauding us, I've got to be a proud manager tonight," said the man behind the near-miracle, Garry Hill.

It is only one of the romantic sub-plots to this towering tale that Hill has never played above Sunday league level. But his managerial skills have proved so sublime that last season his shoestring team of part-timers won the Ryman League Premier Division by 24 points. They are camped comfortably in the top half of the Conference and in the last round of the Cup won at Lincoln. Now this.

The replay a week on Wednesday will prompt some to say the Daggers have missed their chance. But the team contains enough qualities to cast doubt on that conclusion. "We'll give honesty and commitment in the replay," said Hill, "and if we can have a bit of luck, who knows?"

webTitle: Chapple savours another Ks special

fields.headline: Chapple savours another Ks special
fields.standfirst: Godfather of the minnows works the old magic against the Shrimpers
fields.trailText:
Southend 0 - 1 Kingstonian
Godfather of the minnows works the old magic.
fields.body:
Magic is the bit that defies logic and Geoff Chapple, manager of Kingstonian, still has it in the Cup. Ten years after masterminding Woking's 4-2 win at West Brom at the same stage he watched his current charges, 20th in the Conference, hold gallantly out against the side sixth in the Third Division. Southend are his seventh League victims.

Brentford, two rounds previously and also away, were his sixth. Between times Kingstonian won at Southport, third in the Conference. His magic works in other cups too. Chapple won the FA Trophy three times with Woking and the past two years with Kingstonian. He has never lost at Wembley, which is little advantage this year.

"If I knew what it was I would bottle it and never have to work again," he said, having done the television sound test with an old hand's aplomb. "Three egg and chips," he repeated at various volumes for the engineers. He may have enjoyed a few in his time; Chapple has the rounded bearing of an old-time station-master.

He is 55 but hardly looking to retire. "I eat, drink and sleep football," he said, "and would love to manage in the League. But I want to do it with the club I'm at, so I've never applied." His special Ks, serial killers in cups, have come eighth and fifth in the Conference since he took them up in his first season, 1997-98. This year may be a glitch.

"The Conference is the most unfair competition," he said. "One up, three down. I think the League clubs are fearful, as they are of looking outside their own for managers." And he noted three men who did graduate: Ron Atkinson, Martin O'Neill and Barry Fry.

Chapple could scarcely cut a more different image. There was no four-foot standing jump nor touchline somersault as Eddie Akuamoah rifled home an angled shot from an innocent throw-in early on. There was no agitation through the second-half siege, no prepared one-liner afterwards.

"Stand up if you're one-nil up," sang Kingstonian's fans. They were on their feet for 80 minutes and more; and Chapple was on his, impassive by his dug-out. He is known as "the godfather of non-League football".

The goal was a bolt from the blue. "If you'd scored only two this season, you'd have had your eyes shut too," said Akuamoah, sales manager with a publishing company, who has scored freely for the Ks in 350 games, including two in last year's Trophy final. David Webb, Southend's manager, tried to get him to Brentford in 1993 but he stuck to his degree in politics and economics.

The goal also fashioned what followed: a game of two halves - rearguard and frustration in one, nothing in the other. The frustration boiled over just before half-time, when all bar the goalkeepers weighed in and Gary Patterson and Southend's Leo Roget went off. "Animals," raged a home supporter, but it was more Ratty than Rattin.

Kingstonian went to 5-3-1, Southend to 2-4-3 and the barrage began. "They defended with their lives," said Webb, whose son Daniel, 17, hit a post late on. Eddie Saunders, once a Manchester basketball star, was a giant again. But so were they all, defending dangerously deep in front of Gavin Kelly, a keeper on loan who may have shown Spurs how to win away. He is the Ks' sixth this season.

"C'est la vie," said Webb as if Southend might be going into Europe. His front line lacked the commitment that brought him Chelsea's headed winner against Leeds in the 1970 final replay. "We've got big defenders," said Chapple. "I'd have played a bit more football."

He went on: "I paint pictures for them. Even before Brentford it was the possibility of going to Old Trafford. At half-time it was of a Southend bombardment; they were going to have to stand up and be counted."

Chapple, master of magic, had shed a little light on his secret. The Ks, never before in the third round, might even make it work at Bristol City in the fourth.

webTitle: Bellamy sees off Brady bunch

fields.headline: Bellamy sees off Brady bunch
fields.trailText:
Swindon 0 - 2 Coventry
Bellamy sees off Brady bunch.
fields.byline: Adam Sills at the County Ground
fields.body:
The day started with a rallying cry from the Swindon chairman Terry Brady, urging the club to work as a TEAM - after all, Together Everyone Achieves More. It ended with Swindon's manager lambasting his left-back for the two errors that cost the home side the tie.

The scapegoat, Sol Davis, was hauled off by Andy King after 70 minutes of a game in which the harmony and understanding Brady is striv ing for had been more keenly demonstrated by Coventry than Swindon. Gordon Strachan's side took the lead after five minutes through Craig Bellamy, doubled it after 64 minutes and made mice of the potential giantkillers.

Swindon had cause for hope before the game given Coventry's recent profligacy in front of goal. Bellamy's strike was his first in six games, a lapse that has led to criticism of the record £6.5m signing, although his energetic performance at the County Ground should have appeased the doubters.

"I've never experienced people turning on you in seconds and it was really hard at first when the crowd were getting on my back," Bellamy said. "But in a way I've relished the stick. It's made me even more determined. And I'm only 21. I reckon if I can get through this then I can get through anything."

Swindon's fans must feel the same way. They are experiencing third-tier football for only the second time in 14 years, and their memories of the Premiership are only seven years old. Brady has promised the arrival of new players soon, although King said he did not expect to receive any of the record gate receipts of £175,175 from the tie to strengthen his struggling squad.

This was a fourth successive defeat. In contrast, Strachan's side is finding some form, with only one defeat in seven games. "It's another result in our rehabilitation to being a half-decent side again," Coventry's manager said.

Bellamy's calm early finish after Davis had left his goalkeeper helpless with a sorry backpass dampened the chances of a shock. The defender then again conceded possession for Coventry's second, Mustapha Hadji scoring from three yards.

The home side's one glimmer of hope came just after the hour when Danny Invincibile narrowly failed to chip the ball over Chris Kirkland with Gary Alexander waiting to pounce two yards from goal. Within a minute Coventry doubled their lead.

"To get a good run together is vital," said Bellamy. "We feel solid in ourselves, there's the continuity we didn't have at the beginning of the season and the confidence is growing in the team."

Both clubs are one point ahead of their respective relegation zones. The force, however, is most definitely with the Sky Blues.

webTitle: Blades and Saints resume a century of Cup confrontations

fields.headline: Blades and Saints resume a century of Cup confrontations
fields.trailText: Timeless magic of the Cup? Indeed. Look back to 1925 and 1958 to see how two of last weekend's ties made their mark many tournaments ago.
fields.body:
No apologies for the shameless old cliche, because if you have waded this far into the sports pages you will surely agree to the "timeless magic of the FA Cup"; never more so than when coupled with the words "third round". Its particular lustre shone bright this weekend, and simply to hear a few fabled names (Yeovil, Peterborough, Walsall) read out on the radio on Saturday evening stirred the romantic cockles, as did the reprise of legendary ties down the century and beyond: Carlisle v Arsenal, Newcastle v Aston Villa, Fulham v Manchester United.

I recall as vividly as if it was last Wednesday week the last pairing's replayed semi-final at Highbury in 1958. A fellow cub reporter and I clandestinely drove the spluttering Hereford Times's Morris Minor van up to north London at dawn. It was only six weeks after the Munich air crash and as well as (a long story) being Fulham fans we seemed spiritually compelled to make pilgrimage as homage to Jimmy Murphy's makeshift United team.

The Saturday before, the boy who had walked without a physical scratch from the snowy carnage on that German runway, Bobby Charlton, had scored twice in the 2-2 draw at Villa Park. Now in the damp afternoon murk at Highbury the replay had reached a pulsating 3-3 before Fulham's Gibraltar-born goalkeeper Tony Macedo, as athletically thrilling as he could be clownishly erratic, displayed the latter propensity for butterfingered bungling and gifted United two late goals and their rhapsodic place at Wembley.

We drove back to Hereford through the dark in a daze of impassioned and mixed emotions, wondering occasionally whether our inebriate, heavy-handed editor, a dull Dickensian churl misnamed Mr Peacock, had rumbled that the two of us had not spent the day ferreting out a non-existent farming story in the wilds of the Brecon borders.

I thought fondly of Macedo this Saturday. I daresay "Flash" Tony was the league's first "continental" goalkeeper. He should have played for England, but his horrors at Highbury that day meant the only thing he ever safely handled thereafter was Walter Winterbottom's "black spot".

All of 43 FA Cup tournaments later, in this weekend's perennial third-round luck-of-the-draw, there was Southampton v Sheffield United, a historical match-up which only the most erudite of Cup scholars or a remaining handful of grizzled centenarians know represented a red-stripe vintage and foaming special brew.

Sure, the two clubs had met before in the FA Cup: in the 1925 semi-final at Stamford Bridge, when the Saints' right-back Tom Parker (future Arsenal captain as well as Southampton manager) did a Macedo by missing a penalty and scoring the decisive own-goal. All of 38 years later, in 1963, the irrepressible young Terry Paine, a true league great of the century, was beginning his epic spell at the Dell by inspiring the likes of David Burnside and the two Georges, artful and opportunist wire-puller O'Brien and the direct, no-messing Kirby. That Southampton team reached the semi-finals after beating Sheffield 1-0 in the fifth round. But the legend goes back much further than that.

In passing, I wonder how many who revelled in young Paine that day also saw this Saturday's tie? Or, come to that, if there was a single soul at Carlisle on Saturday who had witnessed the third-rounder when the Cumbrians famously held Joe Mercer's Arsenal Cup holders to a goalless draw at Highbury in 1951?

Of course, the Blades-Saints Cup saga dates back a century. In four seasons between 1898 and 1902 United reached three finals and Southampton two. To settle who was pre-eminent, they met in the 1902 final - the "cocks of the north" against the monarchs of the Southern League (of which Southampton were champions six times in eight seasons to 1904). That final at Crystal Palace ended 1-1, with Sheffield winning the replay the following Saturday by 2-1.

Before Christmas, I wrote of the happy spate of privately published sports books. I had no space to mention Hagiography Publishing, a cottage-industry company formed by five dedicated Southampton supporters (def: hagiography = biography of legendary saints).

Their first venture, David Bull's biography of the legendary Ted Bates, Dell Diamond, went to a second edition and has sold 4,500 copies. A life of Paine is in the pipeline, and when the sumptuous Match of the Millennium (Southampton's 100 most memorable games) came out for Christmas it sold 3,000 in 11 days and is already reprinting.

In it, naturally, that cliched and "timeless magic of the Cup" surfs throughout, from the days that most celebrated Saint of all, CB Fry (well, till Terry Paine, that is), marked the Blades' dashing Alf Common in the Crystal Palace final.The misnamed Common, of course, was soon to achieve immortality by becoming the first footballer to be sold for £1,000. That was truly, like the Cup itself in those days, the start of something big.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Dagenham dream of Spurs as Leeds face Liverpool

fields.headline: Dagenham dream of Spurs as Leeds face Liverpool
fields.standfirst: Full draw
fields.trailText: Who plays who in the next round.
fields.body:
Not one Premiership club has been knocked out of the FA Cup so far, but if the third round has been bad for the underdogs the draw for the fourth looks much sweeter. More than half of all top-flight sides have been drawn to play each other, leaving a route to round five wide open for Nationwide hopefuls.

There was, though, mixed luck for the two remaining non-League sides. Far from a big-money pay-day against a glamour side, Kingstonian's reward for beating Third Division Southend is a trip to Second Division Bristol City.

But Dagenham and Redbridge, who came so close to victory against Charlton, will host Tottenham should they win the replay. It was a perfect draw for Dagenham's manager Garry Hill, a Spurs fan. If Charlton win through it would be another all top-flight affair.

Leeds will play Liverpool at home in the most glamorous tie of the round. The clubs' most recent meeting in November became one of the most memorable games of the season, with Leeds winning 4-3. Mark Viduka, whose goal against Barnsley secured Leeds's entry into the draw, scored all four for David O'Leary's side.

Both Manchester clubs face Premiership opposition at home, with City facing Coventry and United hosting West Ham. The winner of Newcastle's replay against Aston Villa will face Leicester, also at home. Ipswich could find themselves involved in a sixth all-Premiership tie after they were drawn away to Sunderland or Crystal Palace.

webTitle: Carlisle head out and across the border

fields.headline: Carlisle head out and across the border
fields.standfirst: Carlisle's manager may be shown door after cup exit
fields.trailText:
Carlisle 0 - 1 Arsenal
Carlisle head out and across the border.
fields.body:
The Cumbrians came in hope, woozy on wishful thinking, and drifted away with frustrated and familiar forebodings. It is half a century since Bill Shankly strode on to the Highbury turf, arms aloft, to hail his Third Division North minnows after a valiant goalless Cup draw. Saturday's defeat to the Gunners could be Carlisle's last ever FA Cup tie.

Rumours persist that should United, currently six points adrift at the foot of the basement division, drop out of the League in May they might slip likewise out of England. A merger with Clydebank has been mooted, the speculation fuelled by David Low's high-profile presence among the new owners. The managing consultant once tried to move the Scots to Dublin.

"It's pure speculation at the moment," said the manager Ian Atkins, who may have taken his own bow to a standing ovation at the final whistle. He will speak to Low and the Scottish property developer Stephen Brown, the public face of the consortium that has bought the club, today and is expected to leave only six months into a two-year contract.

"They may want their own men, who knows? I'll meet with them and see if they want me to be part of Carlisle. It won't be a one-way dialogue; I need assurances from them that they will give me the tools to get away from the bottom of the Third Division and can move on next season."

The new owners have shrouded themselves in secrecy since buying out Michael Knighton's 93% stake in Carlisle United Holdings Limited. The major shareholders are the little-known Gibraltarian investment company Mamcarr. Adding to the intrigue, the seven letters that make up Mamcarr are the first initials of all the Knighton family, plus the middle names of Knighton's wife and daughter. "I'll be sitting down with Mr Low and Mr Brown," said Atkins. "I haven't got a clue about the politics of it all. It's best I stay out of all that."

Matters have hardly improved since the takeover was completed last week. The £15,000 signing of Chesterfield's Michael Galloway fell through on Friday, plunging Atkins's plans into disarray, hardly the ideal preparation for a match against a team 90 positions higher in the league.

The class chasm was blatant from the first. Carlisle huffed and puffed, but their sporadic attacking was too dependent upon crude hoofs upfield. Sylvain Wiltord's smart finish from Patrick Vieira's pass established a lead Arsenal never looked likely to lose.

"I was proud of my team," added Atkins. "We didn't cave in and kept our shape and heads throughout. There were plenty of tackles flying in during the first half. That's the FA Cup - blood and thunder to get the crowd going."

Most of the blood was gushing from a gaping wound just below Vieira's right knee after an horrific two-footed lunge by Richard Prokas, a challenge that infuriated Arsène Wenger.

The referee Steven Lodge deemed the tackle fair and booked Nelson Vivas for protesting. He belatedly clued up to Carlisle's uncompromising approach in the second half and cautioned three players in as many minutes.

Last night Lodge had a change of heart."I didn't even give a foul because from my angle I felt it was a 50-50 challenge," he said. "But when I saw the camera angle on television it looked x-rated. If I'd had the same view I would have sent the player off."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Kaz
fields.trailText: I am green with jealousy. Went to New York in November and it didn't snow (unfortunately), but it was still great. And your photos brought it all back... my pictures are so bad as to be unrecognisable as NY.
fields.body:
Dear Sam,

I am green with jealousy. Went to New York in November and it didn't snow (unfortunately), but it was still great. And your photos brought it all back... my pictures are so bad as to be unrecognisable as NY.

Precisely this time last year I was watching whales in Kaikoura, New Zealand, while on a three month trip. Now I'm presently driving all my mates mad by persistently starting all conversations with... "This time last year I was...".

Just letting you know how annoying you'll be in the future!!

Hope you continue to have a fab trip. Will watch your progress.

Kaz

webTitle: Charities pull funds out of arms firms

fields.headline: Charities pull funds out of arms firms
fields.trailText: Two of Britain's biggest development charities, Oxfam and Christian Aid, will today disclose that they are pulling their pension funds out of arms and tobacco companies and nuclear power. John Ezard reports
fields.body:
Two of Britain's biggest development charities, Oxfam and Christian Aid, will today disclose that they are pulling their pension funds out of arms and tobacco companies and nuclear power.

The charities, which have a combined investment clout of £53m, will launch a socially responsible fund aimed at strengthening their influence over causes they oppose. The initiative is seen as the start of a much wider move by other charities to use their financial muscle on ethical issues.

Last night Martyn Tyler, Christian Aid's financial director, said he thought three other leading UK charities were interested in the scheme.

The specialist ethical investment firm, Friends Ivory and Sime, which is managing the scheme, aim to quadruple the fund to £200m within six months by recruiting other charities. Documents outlining the scheme will be sent to other pension funds today.

Andrew Pendleton, a Christian Aid spokesman, said the linchpin of the scheme was a policy of regular meetings with companies to "encourage them to improve their ethical performance on key issues such as labour conditions, human rights, climate change and other aspects of sustainable development".

Mr Pendleton added: "The aim is to realise the power of pensions, so we can be inside the boardrooms as well as outside them with our placards."

Partly for legal reasons, the Balanced Socially Responsible Investment (SRI) Fund will retain pension investments in firms dealing with genetically modified crops, petrochemicals and controversial labour practices abroad. But Friends Ivory and Sime is understood to be recruiting extra staff to meet 100 companies yearly to discuss policies, with a "heavy focus" on 20 of these firms.

Mr Tyler said: "The ultimate step, if argument does not work, is disinvestment."

The partnership between Oxfam and Christian Aid has taken three years to finalise. Oxfam's pension fund is valued at £40m, while Christian Aid's stands at £13m. The partnership arose out of the realisation that many UK charities are, in effect, subsidising practices of which they and many of their donors disapprove - for instance, investing pension funds worth tens of millions into firms dealing in the arms trade, GM crops, petrochemicals, tobacco, powdered baby milk and mining.

To put their project together, the two charities had to manoeuvre within a thicket of legal and professional restraints. British pension funds control an estimate £850bn of assets and account for 35% of the London stock market. According to the Ethical Investment Research Service, 60% of stocks do not meet ethical criteria.

The charities work within the Pensions Trust, which runs its portfolio on a market basis but offers its 80,000 pension scheme members an ethical option that blacklists ethically-questioned investments.

However, some charities are prevented from investing all their funds in ethical stocks because investment returns from some of these are considered unsound.

Most of the Pension Trust's assets have been jointly managed by financially orthodox firms like Legal and General, Schroders, Fidelity, Capital, and Henderson, together with Friends Ivory and Sime. The new scheme puts the funds exclusively under management by Friends Ivory and Sime.

Mr Pendleton said:"The SRI fund squares with the ethics of the organisation while also fulfilling our fiduciary duty as investors. The principle of the scheme is to use the money we have available to invest, to make our views known to companies that need to improve the way they operate."

webTitle: From: Shane and Babs (7 Jan)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Shane and Babs
fields.trailText: If you get time, go for a beer at Gaylords on Churchgate. It used to be one of the top restaurants in Mumbai. Theres a great German bakery next door where you can buy some lovely cakes and pastries and Gaylords will allow you to eat them in their restaurant.
fields.body:
You're after cheap accommodation in Mumbai. Sorry - we can't help you there, but we can really recommend a hotel in the Colaba area (near the Gateway to India) on Walton St. Our very helpful travel agent found us a gorgeous place called Hotel Cowies. It's a tad expensive, but I think you deserve it after your adventures in India and Nepal.

If you get time, go for a beer at Gaylords on Churchgate. It used to be one of the top restaurants in Mumbai. Theres a great German bakery next door where you can buy some lovely cakes and pastries and Gaylords will allow you to eat them in their restaurant.

Try and book your taxi driver the day before and get a price from him before you go. We paid our driver 400 rupees, which wasn't too bad seeing as the journey to the airport takes a good hour and a half, especially if its a night flight.

Glad to hear we were of some help to you. We're both going back next year but this time we're taking our 19 year old son and his girlfriend with us. We want to show them the real India.

Have a great time for the rest of your journey.
