webTitle: Deals plea to keep peace process alive

fields.headline: Deals plea to keep peace process alive
fields.standfirst:
Unionist hardliners try to force Trimble out of power
                                                  sharing
fields.trailText:
All sides warned yesterday of the danger of the Northern Ireland
                                                  political process falling apart if some consensus on
                                                  demilitarisation, paramilitary decommissioning and policing is
                                                  not found in the next few weeks.
fields.body:
All sides warned yesterday of the danger of the Northern Ireland political process falling apart if some consensus on demilitarisation, paramilitary decommissioning and policing is not found in the next few weeks.

Hardliners within the Ulster Unionists are set to call a crucial meeting of the party's ruling council around the end of the month to try and force the leader, David Trimble, to pull out of the power-sharing Stormont government if the IRA has not made serious progress on disarmament.

Sir Reg Empey, a Trimble ally on the moderate wing, warned: "Everybody is getting sick and tired of the endless dance around the issue. Republicans have got to decide whether they want this process to work or whether they are going to keep on playing games.

"They agreed on paper last May to put their weapons beyond use so why don't they just do it? The longer they drag this out the more difficult they make it to sustain and grow support for the Good Friday agreement."

Republicans, who are blaming Tony Blair for the deadlock, want a substantial security scaledown, particularly in heavily fortified south Armagh, while both Sinn Fein and the largest nationalist party, the SDLP, want a much more radical overhaul of policing than the police bill which could lead to a delay in implementing planned reforms.

Gerry Kelly, the IRA bomber turned senior Sinn Fein politician, claimed: "The British government is in danger of bringing about the breakdown of the institutions and the whole agreement."

The SDLP policing spokesman, Alex Attwood, denied he had less room for flexibility due to heightened pre-electoral competition with Sinn Fein, but insisted his party must be able to offer young nationalists a degree of confidence in the reforms before it could take its seats on the new police board.

He wants assurances on a number of matters, including the neutrality of the future police emblem and the flying of flags, the merger of special branch and CID, the closure of Gough barracks in Armagh, the phasing out of the full-time reserve and entry of garda officers into the new service.

Mr Attwood is also keen to see credible, independent investigations into the murders of lawyers Rosemary Nelson and Pat Finucane, and Portadown Catholic Robert Hamill.

"We want to be able to join the police board and negotiations are far from over," he said. "There are a whole series of meetings going on and progress has been made. But this issue is so central to nationalists that we need to have a credible degree of confidence before we go in, or the whole thing could unravel in months and young Catholics will then not join the new service."

A senior government source denied that reforms would be put on ice if the SDLP refused to nominate representatives to the police board by the end of the month, but agreed any postponement would have practical consequences.

The 19-strong board, of which 10 members will be politicians, is scheduled to be in place by the beginning of February, so that it can oversee the first batch of recruits in April.

"It is over-egging the pudding to say reforms would be shelved," said the source. "However, the SDLP say they want a new police service as soon as possible but they are holding it up."

Sir Reg Empey was critical of the SDLP for not backing the police bill, contrasting it with the risk Ulster Unionists took in sharing power with Sinn Fein even though they were unhappy over the lack of IRA decommissioning.

"The SDLP have not, as yet, had to take a difficult decision as we have done," he said. "It is indefensible for them to continue to hang back. As Patten commission member Maurice Hayes said, 'It's better to have 90% of something than 100% of nothing'.

"They are going to have to make up their minds or the government should call a halt to the reforms. What is the point of going through torturous change if we still don't know if they will support it?"

Tensions within loyalism were also growing as the Shankill Road Ulster Freedom Fighter leader, Johnny Adair, awaited a sentence review commission decision, due tomorrow, on whether he will be let out of jail. Either way there are fears of renewed violence between Protestant paramilitaries which could spill over into attacks on Catholics.

The finger was pointed at the UFF's associates, the Ulster Defence Association, for the murder of a former senior member from east Belfast, George Legge, stabbed and dumped in a field on the outskirts of the city on Saturday after an alleged row over drugs.

And there were fears of a split in the Ulster Democratic Party, the political wing of the UDA/UFF, the biggest loyalist paramilitary grouping in Northern Ireland, with many of its grassroots said to have turned against the Good Friday agreement.

The UDP leader, Gary McMichael, son of the murdered UDA chief John McMichael and a staunch supporter of the 1998 peace accord, said he would have to consider quitting if the party changed its policy.

webTitle: Editors question Bulger ruling

fields.headline: Editors question Bulger ruling
fields.trailText: Senior figures in the newspaper industry have condemned the decision of a High Court judge to protect the anonymity of the killers of James Bulger, writes Jessica Hodgson
fields.body:
Senior figures in the newspaper industry have condemned the decision of a High Court judge to protect the anonymity of the killers of James Bulger, Jon Venables and Robert Thompson.

And media organisations are now gearing up to appeal against the decision after being given leave.

Bob Satchwell, the director of the Society of Editors, said the decision, by judge Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, would impose added restrictions on reporters covering the courts.

"The key principles of justice are that it should be fair and that it should be open," said Mr Satchwell. "There are already too many restrictions on reporting the courts and this is another worrying precedent."

He added that judges taking this ruling into account should remember the judge's use of the word "unique" in describing the case.

"The circumstances are indeed unique and the law should have no truck with others who might attempt to use this appalling tragedy for their own benefit", he said.

Dame Butler-Sloss said no new photographs or details about the new lives of Mr Venables or Mr Thompson could be published because they were at such great risk of attack.

Mr Venables and Mr Thompson, now 18, were convicted of killing toddler James Bulger at the age of 10 at Preston Crown Court.

They were found to have beaten the child to death.

webTitle: Stephen Pollard loses job at Times

fields.headline: Stephen Pollard loses job at Times
fields.standfirst: The Times has confirmed it will not be hiring the columnist Stephen Pollard, in the wake of his crude parting shot to Express Newspapers’ owner Richard Desmond, writes Jessica Hodgson
fields.trailText: The Times has confirmed it will not be hiring the columnist Stephen Pollard, in the wake of his crude parting shot to Express Newspapers’ owner Richard Desmond, writes Jessica Hodgson
fields.body:
Click here for Pollard's final leader

The Times has confirmed it will not be hiring the columnist Stephen Pollard, in the wake of his crude parting shot to Express Newspapers' owner Richard Desmond.

George Brock, managing editor of the Times told MediaGuardian "We have spoken to Stephen Pollard today and we will not be proceeding with his contract to join the staff of The Times."

Mr Brock was not prepared to say why the newspaper's management had revoked the offer of a job.

But is widely accepted that the decision was made after Mr Pollard disguised a message to his former boss in an acrostic in Friday's Express leader column.

Insiders say the Times took a very dim view of what it considered inappropriate behaviour for a leader writer on the paper of record.

Mr Pollard, who was one of the Express's regular leader-writers, used the first letter of every paragraph to spell out the phrase "Fuck you Desmond".

His verbal two-finger salute was hidden within a fairly benign leader column about problems facing the farming industry.

One insider at the Express said "It's very unprofessional. It's the kind of thing you might do when you were starting out on the Harlow Gazette. But not if you are an executive on a paper."

But others berated managers at the Times for having a "sense of humour failure".

Mr Pollard was among the first high-profile journalists to leave the Express after the takeover by Northern & Shell, publishers of celebrity and soft porn titles OK! and Asian Babes.

He was offered a job on the times as a columnist and leader writer on health policy issues in early December.

Mr Brock confirmed that contracts had been signed by both The Times and Mr Pollard.

This now paves the way for a sizeable pay-off to Mr Pollard.

Mr Pollard was not available for comment, but he will be distraught at the news.

In yesterday's newspaper reports he claimed the acrostic was a coincidence.

At the time of leaving the Express he told MediaGuardian that Mr Desmond and his henchmen treated his readers like "imbeciles who want to live on a diet of pap".

webTitle: High court backs Bulger killers' anonymity

fields.headline: High court backs Bulger killers' anonymity
fields.standfirst: Extracts from the verdict
fields.trailText: The killers of toddler James Bulger this afternoon won a high court order protecting their anonymity once they are freed with new identities.
fields.body:
The killers of toddler James Bulger this afternoon won a high court order protecting their anonymity once they are freed with new identities.

Judge Elizabeth Butler-Sloss rejected arguments by newspapers that press freedom and the public's "overriding right to know" would be imperilled. But Dame Elizabeth gave newspapers leave to appeal against her ruling to the Court of Appeal.

"I am compelled to take steps in the almost unique circumstances of this case to protect their lives and physical wellbeing," she said.

The verdict also means that newspapers will be barred from publishing details of the two's time in detention for the next 12 months.

The killer's solicitors argued that the threat of revenge attacks against Jon Venables and Robert Thompson, now both 18, necessitated an injunction barring publicity about the pair after their imminent release from secure local authority accommodation.

The judge said she was "convinced that their lives are genuinely at risk as well as their physical safety if their new identities and whereabouts became public knowledge".

James's mother, Denise Fergus, said she was "disappointed" with decision. "They simply don't deserve it," she said. "What right have they got to be given special protection as adults."

"Both Venables and Thompson have dragged me and my family and the name of James through every court possible in this country and in Europe."

Robin Makin, solicitor for Ralph Bulger, James's father, said such protection would be unnecessary with longer custodial sentences. "If there were adequate punishment, the furore would die down and society would feel less unhappy about the situation," he said.

Venables and Thompson hope to win parole early this year following a ruling by the Lord Chief Justice, Lord Woolf, that they have served the minimum tariff necessary under their life sentences.

The pair were both aged 10 when they beat two-year-old James to death on a railway line in Liverpool in February 1993.

During their time in custody as juveniles, an injunction banned the media from taking or publishing photographs of them or reporting on their progress or treatment.

Summarising her judgment, the judge described how the murder of James Bulger was "a horrific crime and the circumstances unusually shocking and distressing. It caused much public concern and a widespread feeling of moral outrage."

She said there was massive national and international publicity at the time of the murder and during and after the trial. That coverage continued throughout the period of detention of the two boys.

Injunctions restricting publicity came to an end when the boys reached 18 and their lawyers then sought to make those injunctions indefinite.

"I have decided that, taking into account the European Convention on Human Rights, the law of confidence may, in exceptional circumstances be applied to protect individuals who are seriously at risk of injury or death if their identity or whereabouts became public knowledge and that the court has jurisdiction to grant injunctions to ensure their protection," she said.

Dame Elizabeth said information she had received from the Home Office, press reports and judicial observations had "convinced me that these young men are uniquely notorious and are at serious risk of attacks from members of the public as well as from relatives and friends of the murdered child".

She said threats to injure and kill them had been set out in the evidence and reported in the press. "I am satisfied that, although there has been balanced discussion in press articles in recent months, the sense of moral outrage has not diminished and there remains among some members of the public a serious desire for revenge if the two young men are living in the community.

"The Home Office views these threats very seriously and is likely to give Venables and Thompson new identities on their release from detention.

"I am therefore convinced that their lives are genuinely at risk as well as their physical safety if their new identities and whereabouts became public knowledge."

The judge said "certain sections of the press would not wish the two young men to remain anonymous and would wish to have them identified and, if information about them became available, there was a real possibility it would be published".

The Guardian was not among media organisations contesting the case.

webTitle: Teacher unions attack 'paltry' rise

fields.headline: Teacher unions attack 'paltry' rise
fields.standfirst:
Blunkett to authorise above-inflation increase and bonuses as concern grows over school staff shortage

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Blunkett to authorise above-inflation increase and bonuses as concern grows over school staff shortage.
fields.body:
Teachers in England and Wales are to receive pay increases of 3.5-3.7% this year, with extra for those in London and the south-east. The rises will be worth between £840 and £888 to a teacher on an average £24,000 salary.

The increase is above the 3.2% headline inflation rate but comes against a background of heightened anxiety about teacher shortages. Unions attacked the planned increase as "disastrous" last night and said it would do nothing to halt the "meltdown" in recruitment and retention of staff.

The package, which is being finalised by the teachers' pay body and will be announced later this month, will increase the overall wages bill by 3.8-4%.

London weighting, worth between £600 and £2,300 to teachers in and around the capital, will rise by up to a third from April.

The school teachers' review body (STRB) will also rationalise the bonus system for staff in schools in inner cities or with low academic achievement. Headteachers at those schools will be told they can offer "golden handcuff" payments of £2,000-3,000 to encourage staff to join or stay at the school, from their share of a £32m pot unveiled by the school standards minister, Estelle Morris, on Friday.

Some 3,000 teachers in London will receive interest-free loans to help them buy houses, alongside nurses and police officers, in a scheme that has already been unveiled.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, is concerned that the STRB plan goes beyond the 3-3.25% extra for teachers' pay budgeted for by most local councils, but he will accept the package.

The basic deal is in addition to the £2,000 performance-related pay rises being offered to teachers at the top of their scale, earning £23,958. Almost all the 200,000 teachers who applied for the award will receive it.

In a Breakfast with Frost interview yesterday, the prime minister said: "What we have to do is look at extra rewards for teachers teaching in really tough schools.

"We have got to look at how we are improving the retention of these people by offering them the right package, not just in terms of pay but in better working conditions generally."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmaster/Union of Women Teachers, said last night an increase of 3.5% was a "paltry figure" that would be "disastrous".

"That's exactly the same as we were getting for the first couple of years when supposedly we were being held back by Blair making sure he got the economy right first. We have had three years of words - now we want a bit of action. We need double digits for the government to carry any conviction at all."

The NASUWT and the National Union of Teachers have threatened protective industrial action to prevent their members having to cover for lessons where schools have chronic staff shortages.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, said last night: "An overall increase of 3.5% on a starting salary of £16,050 does not help bring teaching in touch with salaries available in other occupations which are running at £18,300. The government knows the problem - it just hasn't got the courage to tackle it. Targeting doesn't deal with the problem that is nationwide."

Mr Blunkett is supporting moves to bring teachers who have taken early retirement back into schools to ease short-term problems. Teachers who took early retirement for reasons other than ill-health can come back part-time indefinitely, or full-time for two terms, without affecting their pension rights.

Schools in Essex, Berkshire, Wiltshire and Waltham Forest, in north-east London, have all reported problems recruiting and retaining staff.

Mr Blunkett has introduced £6,000 training salaries and £4,000 "golden hellos" for staff in shortage subjects.

webTitle: Eriksson to stay at Lazio

fields.headline: Eriksson to stay at Lazio
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson will stay on as coach of Lazio after an emergency meeting at the club this afternoon - despite widespread speculation earlier in the day that he was about to be sacked.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson will stay on as coach of Lazio after an emergency meeting at the club this afternoon - despite widespread speculation earlier in the day that he was about to be sacked.

Eriksson held crisis talks with the club following Sunday's 2-1 home defeat by Napoli amid speculation he would resign or be fired and take over as England coach immediately.

But this afternoon Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti admitted that Eriksson would be staying on - for the time being at least. "I have had a meeting with the coach and he can stay until the end of the season, it's his decision," he said.

"Eriksson is very sad with what has happened to the team and I am very sad as well. We have a very strong team but we don't have the results that we should have.

"Eriksson can stay with the team if he wants to, it's up to him. We'll go further with Eriksson but can't rule out the possibility that he will resign," he added.

Earlier in the day respected media portals in Italy had been predicting Eriksson's downfall, with RAI News 24 looping "Zoff probably the new Lazio coach" on their news headline ticker.

And those predictions looked like turning into fact when Eriksson emerged from a meeting Cragnotti and Zoff looking stony-faced. When asked about the discussions, Eriksson told the waiting reporters: "I do not want to talk about it."

However, he did talk to Swedish newspaper Expressen, telling them: "I quite understand that our fans are disappointed. It is not acceptable that the reigning champions lose at home to Napoli.

"We look very good in training and we have a good spirit in the squad. I don't understand what happened. This was another hard defeat with another decisive own goal. We have to start playing football again like we did before. After all, that was not so many months ago."

Asked if Lazio's lack of drive might be connected to him becoming England coach, Eriksson replied: "I wouldn't want to think that was the case."

webTitle: Svennis, Dennis, and Sean Dundee

fields.headline: Svennis, Dennis, and Sean Dundee
fields.trailText: NOT TAKING FLIGHT
fields.body:
NOT TAKING FLIGHT

As you will definitely have forgotten, ever since the announcement of Sven Goran Eriksson's appointment as England manager, the Fiver has been dutifully waiting at Luton Airport for his arrival. It's not been easy by any means: there's nowhere comfortable to sleep, we've been beaten up, and our 'Welcome Svennis!' banner was stolen by an aggressive, drunken, xenophobic thug (although his colleagues at the Daily Tabloid have since promised to get it off him and send it back).

Sadly, our hell is likely to continue for a while yet. Because after a day in which all informed reports, and a few speculative lies, suggested that Lazio were going to sack Eriksson for losing at home to a totally useless Napoli side, it was announced this afternoon that the not-so-super Swede will be staying on until the end of the season as originally planned. "Eriksson spoke to president Sergio Cragnotti and club officials Massimo Cragnotti and Nello Governatore today," explained a club spokesperson, dropping as many of his bosses' names into conversation as he could. "He remains Lazio's coach."

Given craggy club president Cragnotti's visible anger after yesterday's defeat - "The players still had Christmas cake in their feet. On Monday I will meet with Eriksson to try and understand how this has happened" - this outcome is something of a surprise. Especially as Eriksson had earlier emerged from the meeting looking more miserable than Morrissey on downers, while RAI News 24 - the (only) respected Italian television channel - spent the whole day claiming "Dino Zoff probably new Lazio coach".

So our vigil must continue. Which is intensely irritating, as there appears to be a docusoap film crew coming out of WH Smith and they're heading this way! Fah!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SALE OF THE SEASON

It's the biggest mid-winter sale ever at swanky West London boutique Chelsea's of Chelsea! Which means everything - yes, everything! - must go. Now, how's about this for starters: one temperamental, barely used on-loan Italian defender who modestly claimed today: "In my career, great clubs have always wanted to sign me. So, without being pretentious, if Monaco want to sign me, they want to be winning titles." Yes, we're talking about Mr Christian Panucci. And, yes, Monaco want to sign him on loan until the end of the season. Fantastic!

And we've more - so much more! Now our next sale is real quality - a World Cup winner with the longest tongue in football. No, we're not talking Marcel Desailly. But surely I can tempt you with Frank Leboeuf? Of course I can! Are you interested in making a bid, Monaco general manager Henri Biancheri? You are? Really? But you think our price is too high? Well, come back tomorrow and we'll see what we can do.

Now, our final sale is the pick of the bunch: a 100 per cent pure Englishman, disillusioned with life at Stamford Bridge under Claudio Ranieri. Ladies and gentleman, I give you £2m-rated Dennis Wise! Do I hear interest from Blackburn Rovers? Yes I do! And Manchester City and West Ham as well? Lovely jubbly! Wait hang on there one second I've just had word from managing director Colin Hutchinson that we don't want to sell Wisey after all! "Dennis has a playing contract until 2003 plus the guarantee of a two-year coaching deal when he finishes as a player. He is part of Chelsea. I want him to stay and so does the manager."

But you don't really mean that, do you, Hutchy? "I do not know for certain what will happen at this stage." That's more like it! Come back tomorrow, and we'll see what we can do

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"During the holidays I like to eat lots of sweets. I'm a greedy bloke, but I would happily forgo some sweets to have some more points" - Would that be one sweet per point? Giovanni Vavassori, coach of Serie A surprise package Atalanta, gets his priorities right.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THIS IS A STORY ABOUT STANLEY VICTOR COLLYMORE

So you know what's coming next. Yes, it's another tale of love denied, of hopes quashed, and of certain former England strikers getting a little bit too big for their boots and taking another step towards the scrapheap. Honestly, it's enough to send the Fiver reaching for the valium bottle (if we hadn't emptied it already).

After being told that his services were no longer required at Jim Jefferies' battling Bradford City after all of 10 weeks at the club, Stanley looked set for a bright, if slightly teutonic future this morning at Bundesliga side Vfb Stuttgart. They may be second from bottom in the table, but Stuttgart are a team with a great pedigree (we presume) and Stanley would get to form a mouth-watering strike partnership with former Liverpool star Sean "Heffalump" Dundee! What a treat, and all for the bargain sum of £500,000.

But the move began to look shaky from the moment Stan couldn't actually be bothered to travel to Germany to discuss the deal. He phoned them instead, with his agent crowding around the mouthpiece, and, according to reports, immediately demanded a two-and-a-half-year contract worth 20-grand-a-week. Given Stanley's recent run of luck - the fire extinguisher just leapt into his hand, officer! - Stuttgart politely declined the request and broke the news to Dundee. Which means Stan can return to training in hilarious bandages, and the Fiver to its treble absinthe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Parma are preparing to make a bid for Benito Carbone.

Arsenal have been given first refusal on £19m-rated Real Madrid midfielder Ivan Helguera.

Aston Villa are set to renew their interest in Benni McCarthy.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Nigel Spackman has been confirmed as the new manager of Barnsley. The former Sheffield United boss, who has signed a three-and-a-half-year contract with the Yorkshire club, said: "I have enjoyed my work with Sky and England, it has been good for me, but it is time to get back and get a full-time job, a proper job."

fields.bodyText: NOT TAKING FLIGHT As you will definitely have forgotten, ever since the announcement of Sven Goran Eriksson's appointment as England manager, the Fiver has been dutifully waiting at Luton Airport for his arrival. It's not been easy by any means: there's nowhere comfortable to sleep, we've been beaten up, and our 'Welcome Svennis!' banner was stolen by an aggressive, drunken, xenophobic thug (although his colleagues at the Daily Tabloid have since promised to get it off him and send it back). Sadly, our hell is likely to continue for a while yet. Because after a day in which all informed reports, and a few speculative lies, suggested that Lazio were going to sack Eriksson for losing at home to a totally useless Napoli side, it was announced this afternoon that the not-so-super Swede will be staying on until the end of the season as originally planned. "Eriksson spoke to president Sergio Cragnotti and club officials Massimo Cragnotti and Nello Governatore today," explained a club spokesperson, dropping as many of his bosses' names into conversation as he could. "He remains Lazio's coach." Given craggy club president Cragnotti's visible anger after yesterday's defeat - "The players still had Christmas cake in their feet. On Monday I will meet with Eriksson to try and understand how this has happened" - this outcome is something of a surprise. Especially as Eriksson had earlier emerged from the meeting looking more miserable than Morrissey on downers, while RAI News 24 - the (only) respected Italian television channel - spent the whole day claiming "Dino Zoff probably new Lazio coach". So our vigil must continue. Which is intensely irritating, as there appears to be a docusoap film crew coming out of WH Smith and they're heading this way! Fah! * * * * * * * * * * * * * SALE OF THE SEASON It's the biggest mid-winter sale ever at swanky West London boutique Chelsea's of Chelsea! Which means everything - yes, everything! - must go. Now, how's about this for starters: one temperamental, barely used on-loan Italian defender who modestly claimed today: "In my career, great clubs have always wanted to sign me. So, without being pretentious, if Monaco want to sign me, they want to be winning titles." Yes, we're talking about Mr Christian Panucci. And, yes, Monaco want to sign him on loan until the end of the season. Fantastic! And we've more - so much more! Now our next sale is real quality - a World Cup winner with the longest tongue in football. No, we're not talking Marcel Desailly. But surely I can tempt you with Frank Leboeuf? Of course I can! Are you interested in making a bid, Monaco general manager Henri Biancheri? You are? Really? But you think our price is too high? Well, come back tomorrow and we'll see what we can do. Now, our final sale is the pick of the bunch: a 100 per cent pure Englishman, disillusioned with life at Stamford Bridge under Claudio Ranieri. Ladies and gentleman, I give you £2m-rated Dennis Wise! Do I hear interest from Blackburn Rovers? Yes I do! And Manchester City and West Ham as well? Lovely jubbly! Wait hang on there one second I've just had word from managing director Colin Hutchinson that we don't want to sell Wisey after all! "Dennis has a playing contract until 2003 plus the guarantee of a two-year coaching deal when he finishes as a player. He is part of Chelsea. I want him to stay and so does the manager." But you don't really mean that, do you, Hutchy? "I do not know for certain what will happen at this stage." That's more like it! I'm a greedy bloke, but I would happily forgo some sweets to have some more points" - Would that be one sweet per point? Giovanni Vavassori, coach of Serie A surprise package Atalanta, gets his priorities right. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THIS IS A STORY ABOUT STANLEY VICTOR COLLYMORE So you know what's coming next. Yes, it's another tale of love denied, of hopes quashed, and of certain former England strikers getting a little bit too big for their boots and taking another step towards the scrapheap. Honestly, it's enough to send the Fiver reaching for the valium bottle (if we hadn't emptied it already). webTitle: Reaction to the verdict

fields.headline: 'They just simply don't deserve it'
fields.standfirst: Reaction to the verdict
fields.trailText: Reaction to the verdict
fields.body:
Denise Fergus, James's mother
No matter what corner I turn, I am faced with injustices.

The only shred of hope I had left was that Dame Elizabeth would turn down the application for Thompson and Venables to be given anonymity for the rest of their lives - they just simply don't deserve it.

As children, one can understand them being given some protection but what right have they got to be given special treatment as adults as well?

Both Venables and Thompson have dragged me, my family, and the name of James through every court possible in this country and Europe for which unlimited funds have been made available to them and their lawyers.

This is in complete contrast to the help made available to victims of crime in this country. The European Court of Human Rights has quickly become a friend of criminals and an enemy of their victims.

Sadly, people like me who have lost a loved one through murder will also realise that they too have no rights.

Despite what the government says, the views of victims appear to count for nothing.

If there was such a thing as a living hell, this is what my family and I live daily.

Albert Kirby, the detective who headed the Bulger inquiry
I do understand the anger, certainly with regard to Denise, Jamie's mother. I see her quite frequently. But you must bear in mind their view is understandably a very subjective one. I look at it differently, at the problems that could prevail if this order is not passed.

Robin Makin, solicitor for Ralph Bulger, James's father
People are being released too early. If there were adequate punishment, the furore would die down and society would feel less unhappy about the situation, and this sort of protection would be unnecessary.

John Dickinson, solicitor for Jon Venables
We are cautiously optimistic bearing in mind there is going to be an appeal.

Bob Satchwell, director of the society of editors
The key principles of justice are that it should be fair and that it should be open. There are already too many restrictions on reporting the courts and this is another worrying precedent. If other high profile criminals seek to use the Bulger case as an excuse to claim anonymity, the courts must take full note of the judge's comments.

Chris Stanley, spokesman for prisoner resettlement charity Nacro
This is a welcome decision which will go a long way towards helping two boys safely resettle back into society under supervision and away from the media glare. When they are released, the boys will have served their punishment. We must be strong enough as a country to allow two citizens who have offended so grievously when so young to take up their place in society.

Harry Fletcher, national association of probation officers
The authorities in the secure unit where they have been held have come to a decision that they no longer present a risk to the public. What they also have to take into account is whether the boys have shown sufficient remorse and whether they have addressed their offending behaviour.

webTitle: Spackman made new Barnsley boss

fields.headline: Spackman made new Barnsley boss
fields.trailText: Nigel Spackman was named as the new manager of Barnsley this afternoon, and immediately announced his relief at landing "a proper job".
fields.body:
Nigel Spackman was named as the new manager of Barnsley this afternoon, and immediately announced his relief at landing "a proper job".

Spackman has been out of the game for two years since he walked away from Sheffield United in protest at the sale of his best players, but he signed a three-and-a-half year contract with the Tykes today and has been promised £1m to spend on new faces.

"This was the ideal opportunity to get back into football management because the set up behind the scenes is very good," said Spackman, who has spent the intervening months working as a pundit for Sky Sports.

"In the last three years I've managed to pick up my coaching licences, while the Sky work has been good. It's been a very good time for me.

"But I felt that now the time was right to get a full-time job, a proper job, and that's why I'm here."

Spackman will meet the Barnsley squad for the first time tomorrow as he builds towards his first game in charge against Birmingham at Oakwell on Saturday.

webTitle: Barca escape from hairy scrape

fields.headline: Barca escape from hairy scrape
fields.trailText: According to Canal Plus's latest advert for live football, Real Oviedo striker Oli has an unfair advantage - a "wolf-man's chest". The Asturian's padded hairy rug, so the theory goes, allows for world-beating chest control. But while that may be so, it wasn't enough to prevent Oviedo tumbling to their first home defeat of the season in a sensational match against Barcelona on Sunday. Loads of goals was always the likely outcome in this clash of dire defences and so it proved.
fields.body:
According to Canal Plus's latest advert for live football, Real Oviedo striker Oli has an unfair advantage - a "wolf-man's chest". The Asturian's padded hairy rug, so the theory goes, allows for world-beating chest control. But while that may be so, it wasn't enough to prevent Oviedo tumbling to their first home defeat of the season in a sensational match against Barcelona on Sunday. Loads of goals was always the likely outcome in this clash of dire defences and so it proved.

Oviedo right-back Idrissa Keita has a touch of the Rigobert Songs about him. In other words, he's got dreadlocks and he's absolutely useless. Marc Overmars roasted him every time he got the ball, and Barça could have wrapped it up by half time. They were 2-0 up in just 13 minutes, with goals from Patrik Kluivert and Rivaldo, while Overmars also hit the post (Barças's 16th shot against the woodwork this year).

Barça looked to have sewn it up ten minutes into the second half when the home defence once again went AWOL, letting in Kluivert for his second. But it wasn't all one-way traffic - Tomic and Oli caused the Catalans plenty of problems at the other end - and Raddy Antic's men weren't finished yet.

Victor Onopko pulled one back on 64 minutes, and Ivan Anía, whose mum works in the club shop, hit a tasty curler six minutes later to bring the score to 3-2. Even Oviedo's president Eugenio Prieto, a man with more chins than a Chinese phone-book, looked slightly excited.

Meanwhile, Lorenzo Serra Ferrer looked terrified. He brought on Manu Petit and Luis Enrique to shore things up as Oviedo went for the throat. Luis Enrique, who began his career at local rivals Sporting Gijón, has a special place in oventense hearts. His appearance was greeted with huge roars of derision from the crowd - and a flying sex doll wearing only an Oviedo shirt to spare her rubber blushes.

Try as they might, Antic's side just could not find the equaliser they deserved - although Onopko and Oli both went agonisingly close in the dying minutes.

Barcelona's win keeps them just about in touch with league leaders Valencia and Real Madrid, who both won at the weekend, and closes the gap on Deportivo La Coruña, who fell to a shock 3-1 defeat at Valladolid, where Sergio Pachón was the main man with two goals.

Alaves fail to hit the heights at Madrid

Alavés prepared for the visit of Real Madrid this weekend by welcoming two of its most famous fans, mountaineer Juanito Oiarzabal and athlete Martín Fiz, to the Mendizorroza for one of the season's more bizarre publicity shoots. Jordi Cruyff and league top scorer Javi Moreno were the players there to meet them. Understandably, they didn't seem at all sure what to do with the mountaineer's ice-axe that Juanito presented them with, opting in the end for an awkward cutting-the-net sort of pose.

Ice-pick or not, Alavés couldn't scale the heights (oh, stop it) necessary to overcome Real Madrid on Sunday. Christmas shopping at crusty Camden market seems to have done Raúl the world of good (though somehow I doubt he bought a tie-dye T-shirt or a second-hand Led Zep CD) - he was back on form and hitting the net as Madrid ran out 3-1 winners.

Savio and Guti completed the scoring, but Steve McManaman was absent for the first time in eight games after losing weight (no, really) through a bout of gastro-enteritis. Wonder if the club's newly set up players' help-line includes advice on fattening-up?

Two players who might be phoning for a little chat are Albert Celades and Alberto Rivera, who were involved in an early hours car crash on Madrid's paseo del Prado just before Christmas. Not that they can expect a sympathetic ear - the club has announced this week that the two Alberts will be "sanctioned" - both were found to be over the limit.

Valencia stay top - but their fans still aren't happy.

Giant Norwegian (enough already) John Carew was on target again as Valencia maintained top spot with a 1-0 win against Racing Santander this weekend. Valencia's fans are still not happy, though. Héctor Cúper's side sensationally crashed out of the Cup against Andalucian side Guadix in midweek, losing 6-5 on penalties after a 4-4 draw.

To put the result in context - Guadix are currently bottom of group 6 of Second Division B, had missed eight penalties out of eight this season, and were defeated 6-0 again this weekend. Valencia fans' protests included a pre-arranged walk-out by members of the Gol Gran supporters' club and that age old favourite, the egg throw - Cúper's car was the target this time.

Even Valencia's win, largely thanks (yet again) to Carew and Mendieta, wasn't enough to placate the valencianos, who booed their side from the field.

John Benjamin given a hero's welcome on his return

The big news in San Sebastián this week was the return to Real Sociedad of John Benjamin Toshack. John Benjamin (the Spanish use his middle name as his surname) was given a hero's welcome when he was presented to the fans in midweek and he responded by insisting that there was plenty of time to pull Real out of the relegation zone.

And the one-time manager of Real Madrid and Depor very nearly got off the a winning start. Real Sociedad certainly had the better of their clash with Zaragoza at the Anoeta on Sunday, despite having Sergio Corino sent off five minutes before half-time. It finished 1-1, but Lithuanian striker Edgaras Jankauskas really should have buried the visitors - in a 25-minute spell, he managed to miss three one-on-ones and an open goal. Although Real remain bottom, John Benjamin took "more positives than negatives" from the game.

Just above Sociedad lie Racing, Numancia (who lost 2-0 at Espanyol), and Osasuna who beat Villarreal 1-0. Celta de Vigo, whose fans thought they'd be championship contenders with the summer signing of last season's Pichichi Catanha, have slipped dangerously close to the relegation zone - they're just three points clear of Numancia and Osasuna after going down 1-0 at home against Las Palmas. At the other end of the table Rayo Vallecano and Mallorca conjured up lots of passion, but not actually much quality, in a 2-2 draw.

Finally, two goals - including a fantastic individual second - from Catanha's replacement at Málaga, Dely Valdés, secured a 2-1 home win against Txetxu Rojo's Athletic Bilbao.

A couple of months back, another man with a ridiculously hairy chest, Sky Sports presenter Richard Keys, asked his studio guest John Toshack to comment on Liverpool's chances against Southampton.

Try as he might - and he tried for an hour or more - the apeman Keys simply couldn't get John Benjamin to commit himself. "I don't really know anything about English football", insisted the Welshman. Real Sociedad fans can rest assured that he knows rather more about the game in Spain.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

Celta de Vigo, whose fans thought they'd be championship contenders with the summer signing of last season's Pichichi Catanha, have slipped dangerously close to the relegation zone - they're just three points clear of Numancia and Osasuna after going down 1-0 at home against Las Palmas. At the other end of the table Rayo Vallecano and Mallorca conjured up lots of passion, but not actually much quality, in a 2-2 draw. Finally, two goals - including a fantastic individual second - from Catanha's replacement at Málaga, Dely Valdés, secured a 2-1 home win against Txetxu Rojo's Athletic Bilbao. A couple of months back, another man with a ridiculously hairy chest, Sky Sports presenter Richard Keys, asked his studio guest John Toshack to comment on Liverpool's chances against Southampton. Try as he might - and he tried for an hour or more - the apeman Keys simply couldn't get John Benjamin to commit himself. "I don't really know anything about English football", insisted the Welshman. Real Sociedad fans can rest assured that he knows rather more about the game in Spain.  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: Threats and fights as Lazio lose more ground

fields.headline: Threats and fights as Lazio lose more ground
fields.trailText: In Ancient Rome, the mob would whistle and jeer in disgust if a spectacle failed to meet their expectations - and demand the person responsible pay the ultimate price.
fields.body:
In Ancient Rome, the mob would whistle and jeer in disgust if a spectacle failed to meet their expectations - and demand the person responsible pay the ultimate price.

Two thousands years on, nothing has changed.

Yesterday, Lazio crumbled 2-1 to lowly Napoli in the Stadio Olimpico, leaving their angry fans once more calling for the head of coach Sven-Goran Eriksson. This time they might get their wish.

Lazio were abject. They were two goals down after 37 minutes, had goalkeeper Angelo Peruzzi sent off just before half-time, and were never in the game until Sinisa Mihajlovic - who incidentally is threatening to leave after been barracked by the same Ultra's who used to cheer him - scored a penalty three minutes from time.

Rumours across Rome suggest that club president Sergio Cragnotti will sack Eriksson and put vice-president Dino Zoff in charge for the rest of the season. "Napoli close the Eriksson era," claimed the Gazzetta dello Sport. "After three-and-a-half years of marriage, today Lazio and Eriksson could divorce."

"The players still had Christmas cake in their feet," was Cragnotti's explanation for the defeat. "On Monday I will meet with Eriksson to try and understand how this has happened and to see how we can find the way out of this tunnel."

So will Eriksson go? Not according to Cragnotti's son Massimo. "There is no doubt. Eriksson is our coach and he will remain our coach. We believe in him," he insisted, before adding strangely: "I've talked with Eriksson but I won't say what we talked about."

Sadly, real blood was spilt as Napoli's impressive victory was sullied by fighting, a stabbing and the greatest firework throwing display outside the Chinese new year.

Twelve policeman were injured in riots as they tried - unsuccessfully - to prevent hundreds of fans without tickets boarding trains in Naples. Another copper was rushed to hospital with a glass splinter in his eye after a Napoli supporters' bus was stoned by Roma fans.

Later on, a Napoli fan was stabbed in the thigh. And sixteen more supporters were injured as rival fans spent the game hurling firecrackers at each other.

Fans break into Parma's dressing room - and demand Malesani's sacking

Another man quite literally under threat is Parma coach Alberto Malesani, who needed police protection after irate fans tried to invade the dressing rooms after his side's 2-0 home defeat by bottom-placed Reggina.

Only the intervention of Antonio Benarrivo and Nestor Sensini dispersed the fans, who later surrounded the team bus and demanded Malesani be sacked.

No wonder club owner Callisto Tanz admitted: "This is the worst moment in our recent history. We are at rock bottom." Yet it looks like the fans could get their wish, with club spokesman George Bottaro today admitting: "Never before have we been so close to sacking Malesani."

If he goes, expect former Bologna coach Renzo Ulivieri, Gianluca Vialli and Frank Rijkaard to be on the shortlist to replace him.

Roma - minus Batistuta - rumble on as their rivals drop points

Elsewhere, it was business as usual for runaway leaders Roma, who despite missing the injured Gabriel Batistuta, edged past third-placed Atlanta 2-0 to move eight points clear.

Marco Delvecchio's goal after 42 seconds - his first of the Serie A season - got Fabio Capello's side off to the perfect start. And after Vincenzo Montella's deflected second, the result was never in doubt - even though Roma had Cristiano Zanetti dismissed for a second yellow card.

"I saw a good Roma," said Capello, after the game. "A resolute and careful team. My players had to play a great match against such a strong Atalanta side that beat us in the Italian Cup.

"Of course we have a great lead, but the season is too long to have too much self-confidence. Starting from tomorrow, we must think about our next opponents, Bari, who have been a dangerous team for Roma in the past. It will be a match we must play carefully like we did today."

Meanwhile, Atalanta manager Giovanni Vavassori was in reflective mood after seeing his team go down to their second successive defeat. "During the holidays I like to eat lots of sweets," he said. "I'm a greedy bloke, but I would happily forgo some sweets to have some more points. In the last two matches we have gained nothing."

But like several managers before him, he was quick to praise Roma's performance, and particularly the drive and determination of their midfielder Damiano Tommasi. "Tommasi played another unbelievable match," he admitted. "He ran all over the park, winning countless tackles and scoring a crucial goal when Roma were under fire from Atalanta. He was the man of the match."

There was more good news for Capello's men. Juventus fell further behind after a dramatic 3-3 draw against Fiorentina at the Stadio Delle Alpi, while a late Oliver Bierhoff goal earned AC Milan a 2-2 draw against Internazionale. With their rivals all faltering, it still looks like Roma's Scudetto to lose.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Palestinians reject peace plan as Israelis protest

fields.headline: Palestinians reject peace plan as Israelis protest
fields.standfirst:
 US president outlines last bid for peace
 Palestinian killed in Gaza Strip
 US envoy to hold more talks
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Palestinian negotiators have rejected a Middle East peace plan put forward by US President Bill Clinton last night.
fields.body:
Palestinian negotiators have rejected a Middle East peace plan put forward by US President Bill Clinton last night.

Meanwhile, as another Palestinian was killed in new violence in the Gaza Strip, thousands of Israelis gathered around the walls of Jerusalem.

As night fell, roads into the city were still crowded with heavy traffic, and organisers suggested that they expected up to 150,000 people to join the event, which has been organised to protest against President Clinton's suggestions for the future of the city.

The protesters are demanding that Jerusalem must stay under Israeli rule.

Both events saw Mr Clinton's hopes for peace recede even further.

"We can't accept Clinton's ideas as a basis for future negotiations or a future settlement. Clinton didn't take (Palestinian leader, Yasser) Arafat's reservations into account, and these ideas don't offer our people their legitimate rights," stated senior Palestinian negotiator Ahmed Korei.

Another member of the negotiation team, Hassan Asfour, said that Mr Clinton had failed in his efforts to achieve a final peace because his peace team had been influenced by Israeli positions that the Palestinians rejected.

Mr Clinton had outlined his plans for an Israeli-Palestinian peace accord in a speech to the Israeli Policy Forum in New York, saying that it would "entail real pain and sacrifices for both sides".

Making a final bid to secure a deal before he leaves office on January 20, he told the people of Israel that their land was also the Palestinians' homeland and "there is no choice but for you to divide this land into two states for two people".

Mr Clinton also urged the Palestinians to find the courage to accept his framework for a negotiated settlement and "not hold out for the impossible more". He vowed to use his remaining days in the White House to narrow differences between Israel and the Palestinians, but with less than two weeks left he made no prediction of success.

"We've got a mess on our hands," the president said.

Mr Clinton disclosed key elements of his framework for a negotiated settlement. He said it was a fair deal that "responds to each side's essential needs if not to their utmost desires". He said he was sending veteran US mediator Dennis Ross to the region this week to talk to Israeli and Palestinian leaders again. Mr Ross will seek their approval for an accord that would give the Palestinians a state with its capital in Jerusalem and give Israel a Jewish Jerusalem "that is larger and more vibrant than any seen in history". On Palestinian refugees, a key sticking point, Mr Clinton appeared to hold to his position that they should have the right to return to a Palestinian homeland - not to Israel - or to help in finding new homes, whether in the Arab countries in which they now live or elsewhere.

Israel cannot be expected to take in an unlimited number of refugees and thereby "undermine" its purpose in being, he said.

The president said the incoming Bush administration was not bound by his proposals. "These parameters originated with me and will go with me when I leave office," he said.

Addressing the people of Israel before a largely Jewish audience, Mr Clinton said "you have hardly had one day of peace and quiet since your state was created."

He said "your dream of a homeland has come true," but when the Jewish people started to return home a century ago, they found "it was not vacant. You discovered that your land was also their land, the homeland of two peoples.

"The hard reality is that there is no choice but for you to divide this land into two states for two people.

"Whether it happens today or after more bloodshed, it will happen." Mr Clinton, who has made the search for a peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians his highest foreign policy priority, said: "Sometimes you just have to do the right thing. Sometimes it works out; sometimes it does not."

Mr Clinton praised Mr Barak, whose concessions to the Palestinians have left him trailing in the polls to Ariel Sharon, the rightwing Likud party leader, ahead of Israel's February 6 election for prime minister.

"He has demonstrated as much bravery in the office of prime minister as he ever did on the field of battle," Mr Clinton said in tribute to the former Israeli military chief of staff.

At this late date, Mr Clinton said, "the fundamental question remains: can two people who have gone through this kind of violence still conclude a genuine and lasting peace? I believe with all my heart not only that they can, but that they must."

Alluding to the bloodshed that has gripped the region for months, he said "the alternative to peace is being played out before our very eyes; the only consequence of further delay will be greater loss in blood and tears."

Both sides have already indicated conditional acceptance of his proposals, but bridging the differences presents a formidable challenge.

Mr Arafat is challenging Mr Clinton's omission of the right of nearly 4m Palestinian refugees to return to former homes in Israel left behind at the founding of the Jewish state in 1948.

Mr Barak wants to limit the control over parts of East Jerusalem that he already has offered the Palestinians.

Before Mr Clinton spoke, a senior US official said the administration was not optimistic of reaching a final deal before George W Bush becomes president in less than two weeks. "But we hope to continue to narrow the gap and move them closer together on a foundation on which they can build," the official added.

Mr Ross, expected to go to the Middle East on Tuesday, intends to hold separate talks with Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat to discuss "what is possible and advisable to do in the next 14 days," the official said.

Palestinian security officials said Israeli troops had shot dead a 32-year-old man, Abdel Hamed al-Kharati, as he walked along a road near the Jewish settlement of Netzarim in Gaza. At least 303 Palestinians, 13 Israeli Arabs and 43 other Israelis have been killed since a Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip began in late September.

An Israeli official said Kharati had approached Israeli forces in the dead of night with a suspicious pack on his back on a road where Israeli troops have been attacked in the past. The soldiers had opened fire, the official said.

Yesterday a Palestinian woman was shot dead in the West Bank, witnesses said. Twenty-year-old Fatma Abu Jeifh was driving along a road east of the town of Nablus when she was hit by a bullet fired from a nearby hill manned by Israeli soldiers, her cousin said. The Israeli army denied the Palestinian account and said there had been an exchange of fire in the area at the time.

webTitle: Minister admits watchdog is not Shipman-proof

fields.headline: Minister admits watchdog is not Shipman-proof
fields.trailText: A government minister yesterday admitted its new body to help health authorities and trusts root out failing and criminal doctors would not stop another Harold Shipman.
fields.body:
A government minister yesterday admitted its new body to help health authorities and trusts root out failing and criminal doctors would not stop another Harold Shipman.

The health minister John Hutton's comments came within hours of Tony Blair's assertion that the national clinical assessment authority (NCAA), and the new regular appraisals of doctors, would "make a considerable difference" and give the authorities "the best possible chance" of stopping someone like Shipman, who is suspected of killing more than 300 of his patients.

"It is going to allow us to take action very quickly where either a hospital or a GP practice knows something is wrong or something is revealed about a particular doctor behaving in a particular way," the prime minister said on television. "We will be able to sort out very quickly whether there is a real and substantial difficulty and address the problem.

"Along with the new annual appraisals for doctors ... this will make a considerable difference."

But the NCAA, details of which will be announced today, will be only an advisory body. It can help health authorities and hospital trusts speed up action against suspect doctors, but it cannot initiate anything. It is a watered-down compromise from the assessment centres for dodgy doctors which the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, proposed 18 months ago, and which the British Medical Association rejected as "sin bins', saying they would stigmatise doctors.

Although the BMA wel comes the NCAA instead, it does not believe it will help prevent doctors who are minded to murder. "It is nothing to do with Shipman. To pretend this announcement is something to deal with such cases is misleading," said a spokesman.

Mr Hutton conceded on Sky News later that the NCAA would not be able to weed out potential criminals like Shipman.

"Shipman was a mass murderer," he said. "What we need to make sure is that we have a better set of systems in place to detect concerns about death rates, patients dying in GPs' premises and practices."

The NCAA would "help us deal more promptly with concerns that patients might be expressing about the clinical practices of GPs, and allow us to provide extra support to GPs. We will also be able to reassure public confidence in primary care. I think it is very, very important that we act now to reassure patients and the public about the competence of primary care practices".

If health authorities or trusts feel they have a problem with a doctor, they will be able to ask the NCAA for help. The authority will attempt to speed things up, so that the doctor can be referred for a performance assessment to the GMC, for instance. But crucially, the doctor will not be publicly removed from his job.

A spokeswoman for the Department of Health said the authority would "provide a single central rapid response to cases where concern is raised".

But although the description "alert centre" is being used, those on the alert will still have to be the doctor's employers. Unless they realise something is wrong, then nothing will happen.

webTitle: Commission delays decision on Adair

fields.headline: Commission delays decision on Adair
fields.trailText: A decision is expected tomorrow on the future of jailed loyalist Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair.
fields.body:
A decision is expected tomorrow on the future of jailed loyalist Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair.

Secretary of State Peter Mandelson and Northern Ireland security chiefs fear that his release could heighten tensions on the streets of Belfast, where seven men were shot dead in a bitter loyalist feud last year.

The Northern Ireland sentence review commission said that it still had to consider all the evidence presented to it.

"At this stage in the process, the commissioners believe it will be early tomorrow rather than late today when it (a decision) will come," a spokesman said.

Adiar, the Ulster Freedom Fighters lower Shankill commander, was granted early release in September 1999 under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement after serving less than a third of a 16-year sentence for directing terrorism.

But he was sent back to prison last August after Mr Mandelson revoked his release on the basis of high-grade security evidence that pointed to Adair fuelling tensions in the loyalist feud.

The commissioners spent two days last week hearing submissions from lawyers for the Northern Ireland Office, Royal Ulster Constabulary chief constable Sir Ronnie Flanagan and other senior police officers who are opposed to Adair's release.

Adair's legal representatives made no fresh submissions, claiming that a preliminary decision by the commission to free him meant the onus was on the Northern Ireland office.

It is now up to the three-man body to assess the last of the evidence before reaching its decision, although either side is then free to mount a legal challenge.

"This is a process where you don't know how big the job is until it's finished," the commission spokesman added.

"They are continuing to work. They worked throughout the weekend on the amount of information, which is considerable."

fields.bodyText: A decision is expected tomorrow on the future of jailed loyalist Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair. Secretary of State Peter Mandelson and Northern Ireland security chiefs fear that his release could heighten tensions on the streets of Belfast, where seven men were shot dead in a bitter loyalist feud last year. The Northern Ireland sentence review commission said that it still had to consider all the evidence presented to it. "At this stage in the process, the commissioners believe it will be early tomorrow rather than late today when it (a decision) will come," a spokesman said. Adiar, the Ulster Freedom Fighters lower Shankill commander, was granted early release in September 1999 under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement after serving less than a third of a 16-year sentence for directing terrorism. But he was sent back to prison last August after Mr Mandelson revoked his release on the basis of high-grade security evidence that pointed to Adair fuelling tensions in the loyalist feud. The commissioners spent two days last week hearing submissions from lawyers for the Northern Ireland Office, Royal Ulster Constabulary chief constable Sir Ronnie Flanagan and other senior police officers who are opposed to Adair's release. Adair's legal representatives made no fresh submissions, claiming that a preliminary decision by the commission to free him meant the onus was on the Northern Ireland office. It is now up to the three-man body to assess the last of the evidence before reaching its decision, although either side is then free to mount a legal challenge. "This is a process where you don't know how big the job is until it's finished," the commission spokesman added. "They are continuing to work. They worked throughout the weekend on the amount of information, which is considerable." webTitle: Battle against child abuse 'should focus on prevention'

fields.headline: Battle against child abuse 'should focus on prevention'
fields.trailText: Social workers have called for more resources to be put into the prevention and detection of child abuse rather than historical police inquiries, after it emerged that nearly 100 official investigations are ongoing. David Batty reports.
fields.body:
Social workers have called for more resources to be put into the prevention and detection of child abuse rather than historical police inquiries, after it emerged that nearly 100 official investigations are ongoing.

Moira Gibb, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS), said the continued focus on police investigations into allegations of abuse at residential homes dating back to the 1970s were not necessarily helpful to victims, and gave a false impression of the current threats to child safety.

She added: "We should be putting more resources into the prevention and monitoring of child abuse rather than historical investigations."

Her comments came after the Independent disclosed there are nearly 100 large-scale ongoing police inquiries into allegations of sexual and physical abuse believed to involve about 2,500 children at more than 500 residential and care homes.

The newspaper's report said investigations are being carried out by nearly three-quarters of police forces in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

Tony Butler, chief constable of Gloucestershire and a spokesman for the Association of Chief Police Officers, said the report reflected the scale of inquiries, although the details were 18 months old.

But Mrs Gibb said the survey did not reflect the current care arrangements for children and the improvements in child protection. She said measures introduced in the 1990s, such as rigorous police checks on all staff working with children, had almost driven out systematic abuse within institutions.

"It is unfortunate there is a constant focus on the past failings of social services. We are doing much better now, although there are still individual cases of abuse," she said.

"The number of residential homes is tiny. Most children away from home are now more likely to be in private fostering arrangements or boarding schools."

According to the Department of Health, 65% of children in care in England in 1999 were placed with foster parents whereas only 9% lived in community homes.

Mrs Gibb argued that focusing on abuse in residential homes gave the impression that fostering was safer than being in care. "This might frighten off children who would actually be safer in care," she said.

She added that police inquiries were not necessarily helpful to victims of child abuse. "This does not help people move on in their lives. They have to stay in the mindset of being a victim while pursuing compensation."

webTitle: Doctors support new watchdog

fields.headline: Doctors support new watchdog
fields.trailText: Doctors' leaders have backed a new national body set up to tackle "genuinely dangerous" doctors in the wake of a series of scandals including the Harold Shipman murder case.
fields.body:
Doctors' leaders have backed a new national body set up to tackle "genuinely dangerous" doctors in the wake of a series of scandals including the Harold Shipman murder case.

The national clinical assessment authority (NCAA), announced by health minister John Denham today, will have powers to discipline and suspend "problem" doctors.

It will be able to direct health authorities to take appropriate action against under-performing doctors including the provision of support and retraining to ensure doctors practice safely.

But although Mr Denham said the NCAA would help protect patients, doctors' leaders emphasized that there was no guarantee that rogue doctors such as Harold Shipman, who was convicted of murdering 15 patients and is suspected of killing around 220 more, would be picked up.

"Early warning systems are clearly a positive step but we should be wary of assuming that the NCAA could detect another Shipman. Better systems for death certification and rigorous checking of drugs registers are needed to have a chance of detecting crimes of that appalling nature," said the chairman of the British Medical Association, Dr Ian Bogle.

Mr Denham said: "NCAA is a new approach to the problem of poorly performing doctors.

"Instead of waiting until a problem becomes a scandal or a disaster, the NCAA will work with doctors and the NHS to identify problems early; to offer appropriate support and training to enable doctors to reach a good standard of practice again as swiftly as possible.

"Together with a reformed General Medical Council, and changes to disciplinary procedures the new system will also be able to deal with the genuinely dangerous doctor much more quickly and effectively, before patients are harmed."

Dr Bogle added: "I hope the NCAA will reassure the public that the tiny minority of doctors who have performance problems are being spotted and helped at an early stage."

But Dr John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's general practitioners' committee, warned that the new body needed to be effectively integrated with the range of other recent initiatives aimed at improving GP performance.

"GPs are finding the spate of new initiatives quite daunting because it takes them away from patient care and increases their administrative workload," he said.

"It will be important for GPs to see that this is a supportive system which ensures that doctors' time is used in ways that are of most help to patients."

webTitle: Breathe.com resuscitated

fields.headline: Breathe.com resuscitated
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: Great Universal Stores, owner of top brands including Burberry and Argos, has acquired Breathe.com, reports Guy Middleton.
fields.body:
Great Universal Stores, owner of top high street brands ranging from the luxury fashion label Burberry to Argos discount shops, has saved Breathe.com from oblivion. The retail giant has snapped up the technology and assets of the liquidated internet service provider for £1.4m, and is to maintain it as an ISP.

The fire-sale has saved the 80 jobs of 140 jobs at the company set up by mobile phone millionaire Martin Dawes.

Breathe.com went into receivership in December. Its debts will not be taken on by GUS.

Breathe.com lost £35m in the 18 months preceding its sale. Its founder, Mr Dawes, had severed ties with the company last August.

GUS finance director David Tyler, said the company had acquired Breathe.com for its technology and skilled employees. Breathe is to be maintained as an ISP, he said.

Breathe.com invested heavily in both technology and marketing and offered a range of wireless services.

Breathe took £20m in venture capital in February 2000, and spent millions on a high profile television advertising campaign in a bid to boost subscriber numbers and offer an alternative to companies such as Freeserve, Yahoo and AOL.

However, as an early adopter of unmetered internet access, Breathe suffered from high costs: thousands of users, dubbed "heavy breathers", remained permanently connected to the ISP.

GUS is acquiring a reputation as a bargain hunter among ailing dotcoms. Last September the group acquired loss-making computer e-tailer Jungle.com for £37m, after the company failed to go public. Earlier in the year valuations of as high as £700m were being associated with the company.

Breathe.com's technology is to be used by GUS subsidiary Reality, an e-commerce consultancy the company acquired in May.

webTitle: Orange set to float 15% of shares

fields.headline: Orange set to float 15% of shares
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: Mobile phone operator Orange is set to raise cash by putting 15% of the company's shares up for sale in February, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Mobile phone operator Orange has kicked off a make-or-break year of flotations for telecoms companies.

It will put around 15% of the company's shares up for sale in February, with T-Mobile of Germany, Dutch rival KPN and BT Wireless set to make similar moves before year end.

European telecoms companies are desperate for cash to pay off debts built up through acquiring next-generation mobile phone licences. Last year, the sector borrowed a mammoth £290bn from banks, with £167bn due for repayment over the next 12 months.

"I think it is going to be quite tough. It will not be easy to get the market to take this much paper. I think we will get an increasing amount of discrimination between these offers," said John Tysoe, telecoms analyst at West LB Panmure.

The Orange flotation will be the benchmark for the rest of the telecoms launches, with rivals eagerly watching the market's appetite for mobile phone issues.

"If you cannot sell Orange shares, then you will not be able to sell any of the others," said one analyst.

Michel Bon, chairman of Orange owner France Telecom, said his company is the "architect of the Wirefree future," and will spread its reach beyond Europe.

Because of the battering the telecoms sector has received since the stock market bubble burst in March last year, Orange's value has been reduced from £94bn to £53bn.

Orange operates in 19 countries with a customer base of around 30m, and will use the proceeds of the flotation to expand its geographical reach to 50 countries by 2005.

"Now, with France Telecom's mobile assets combined, and the benefits of the synergies with France Telecom, Orange is a far bigger group with a far bigger opportunity," said Hans Snook, the outgoing chief executive of Orange.

France Telecom bought Orange from Vodafone for £25bn in May last year.

webTitle: ITN wins bid to supply news to Channel 4

fields.headline: ITN wins bid to supply news to Channel 4
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: ITN has won an extended deal to supply news to Channel 4, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
ITN has won an extended deal to supply news to Channel 4, following the announcement that the broadcaster is to extend its contract by a further two-and-a-half years.

The current deal, signed at the beginning of 1999, includes an option allowing Channel 4 to extend the deal.

In a statement, head of news and current affairs at Channel 4 David Lloyd said he had "no doubt" that the contract should go to ITN.

The news will be a blow for Sky News, which has made several attempts to win a terrestrial television news franchise, but was not invited to bid on this occasion.

fields.headline: 'The sense of moral outrage has not diminished'
fields.standfirst: Extracts from the verdict
fields.trailText: Extracts from the verdict
fields.body:
Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, judge
"I am satisfied that, although there has been balanced discussion in press articles in recent months, the sense of moral outrage has not diminished and there remains among some members of the public a serious desire for revenge if the two young men are living in the community."

"The Home Office views these threats very seriously and is likely to give Venables and Thompson new identities on their release from detention."

"I am therefore convinced that their lives are genuinely at risk as well as their physical safety if their new identities and whereabouts became public knowledge."

"In the exceptional circumstances of this case, and applying English domestic law and the right to life enshrined in Article 2 of the European Convention, I have come to the conclusion that I am compelled to take steps in the almost unique circumstances of this case to protect their lives and physical well-being."

webTitle: Commission to de-sleaze election fundraising

fields.headline: Commission to de-sleaze election fundraising
fields.standfirst: New checks on election spending will let smaller players join the political playing field
fields.trailText: New checks on election spending will let smaller players join the political playing field, writes Julian Glover.
fields.body:
Here is some cheering political news, for a change: the business of getting elected in Britain is to become simpler, cheaper and more democratic. However, you could be forgiven for missing that fact amid the media fuss over New Labour's multi-million donors.

While the news has been full of innuendo about the sleazy side of party fundraising, this afternoon, away from the spotlight, Jack Straw will appoint six commissioners to run Britain's new electoral commission, with the aim of cleaning up our politicians' act.

The commissioners will have to work fast, with an election on the cards for May. Their duties are wide ranging, including the rather arcane job of scrutinising electoral law, but the most important task is ensuring that political parties meet a cap on how much they can spend during elections.

This is a vital step. Until now general elections have been run on antique lines that owe more to the age of Anthony Trollope than that of Tony Blair.

Now, parties used to dodging the rules of election spending will have be much more careful.

This should help level out the playing field, allowing small parties a chance to compete with the big boys who are able to raise tens of millions. And it ought to ensure that Britain doesn't follow the pattern of the US, where last year's elections cost over a billion dollars.

The commissioners will also oversee new rules limiting the amount that third parties, such as individual electors or companies, can spend in support of a particular party.

And from February, the commission will insist that parties make available a list of all donations over £1000 to political parties.

All this is good news for voters, even if it is a likely source of red faces at party headquarters as people begin to investigate just how much money is spent on elections and where the cash comes from.

But the commission has its critics. Some point out that the spending limits are generous. A total of £19.77m is allowed to a party putting forward candidates in every seat in Britain (although the limit can be adjusted if the election is called this year). So New Labour will still need its big donors.

That leads to the question of whether political parties ought to be privately funded at all. MPs get a state salary - should they still be expected to fund their election out of private donations?

Until that issue is addressed, raising funds from big business will remain at the forefront of party leaders' minds.
