webTitle: Feature: The blossoming of Swiss architects

fields.headline: The hills are alive
fields.standfirst: Swiss architects have produced some of Europe's most inspired modern buildings. So, says  Jonathan Glancey, let's have no more sneering about cuckoo clocks
fields.trailText: Swiss architects have produced some of Europe's most inspired modern buildings. So, says Jonathan Glancey, let's have no more sneering about cuckoo clocks.
fields.body:
Mention the word "Switzerland" and some people will still chortle about cuckoo clocks, dodgy banks and army penknives. Over the past two decades, however, Switzerland has reinvented at least one aspect of its culture: Swiss architecture is now among the finest in the world, possibly even better than Spain's.

Each time Peter Zumthor completes one of his rare and exquisitely crafted new buildings - the Sogn Benedetg chapel in Sumvitg (1988), the residential home for the elderly in Masans (1993) and the thermal baths in Vals (1996) - I have made a pilgrimage to the land of Heidi and William Tell.

It is extremely uncommon to find such inventive modern architecture so beautifully built and in such exquisite settings. Yet Zumthor, a cabinet-maker turned interior designer then architect, is not alone. Switzerland has produced several of the world's most original and respected architects in recent years, including Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron (best known outside their homeland for Tate Modern and the exquisite Dominus Winery in California's Napa Valley) and Mario Botta, who was, for a brief while, an assistant of the great Swiss architect Le Corbusier.

Their designs are included in the latest pocket-sized architectural guidebook from Ellipsis, written by Thomas Hildebrand and Maya Huber. Don't be put off by the blurb that says that the book, called simply Switzerland, "will appeal to aficionados of the Neue Einfachheit and the Tendenza as well as to the accidental tourist with a penchant for architecture". The grand tour of modern Swiss architecture can be taken safely at home with this excellent guide, as well as by trains and buses that never run late and seem like a dream to us poor Brits, who invented the railway but still can't make it run on time.

Because they love their railways, the Swiss employ their best architects to design their infrastructure. There's Herzog & de Meuron's striking, copper-clad signal box at Auf dem Wolf, Basel (1995), for example - an intriguing monolithic structure that catches and refracts every change of light and weather. The same firm has recently completed a second signal box outside Basel's main station, Münchensteinerbrücke.

The way these architects marry a substantial, crafted architecture to the sensual and ethereal is both surprising and delightful. Their buildings represent, at one level, an attempt to prove that today's architects can readily rival and outmatch the cyberspace fantasies so popular throughout the rest of the world. "If architecture wants to play a significant role in the future," Herzog tells Huber and Hildebrand, "it has to rely on its own qualities; it needs to exploit fully its own potential. What we have is the opportunity to work with mass, with solid and heavy elements, not just with flighty images."

Not that they can't create flighty images: by night Herzog & de Meuron's crystalline factory for Ricola-Europe at Mulhouse-Brunstatt (the other side of the Swiss-French border) changes, to use Herzog's words, "like the surface of water".

By day it has the heroic, sculptural quality of so much Swiss architecture. Maybe this derives from the magnificent, and highly functional farmhouses, notably of the Bernese, that stand like isolated monuments in the landscape, each a fortress, rural factory and home, each beautifully built.

I remember thinking about these structures when visiting Zumthor's boat-shaped Benedictine chapel. I was pleased to read this quote from the architect in Huber and Hildebrand's guide: "To me the presence of a certain building has something secret about it. They seem simply to be here. We do not pay any special attention to them. And yet it is virtually impossible to imagine the place where they stand without them. These buildings appear to be anchored firmly in the ground. They create an impression of being a self-evident part of their surroundings." As with Bernese farmhouses, so with Zumthor's hand-wrought chapel.

If you're lucky enough to travel to Switzerland, try to take in Zurich for two railway stations - the Hauptbahnhof (remodelled by Meili, Peter, Fickert and Knapkiewicz, 1997) and Stadelhofen (bravura architecture and engineering by Santiago Calatrava, 1990) - as well as Chur for the fantastic, filigree roof of its bus and railway station (Brosi and Obrist, 1992) . But above all you must visit the canton of Ticino, home of Mario Botta and some of the world's most distinctive new architecture.

I long to visit the museum, in the medieval town of Giornico, known as La Congiunta (The Marriage), a union between the sculpture of Hans Josephson and the architecture of Peter Markli (1992). This is an utterly uncompromised building with no heating, artificial lighting or flooring. All there is, is the relationship between a sentinel-like architecture composed of severe concrete blocks, daylight, and the sculptures themselves. There are no curators to keep a beady eye on visitors, who must get the key from the local hosteria, 10 minutes away along a Roman road.

This is as good an introduction as any to Ticinese architecture, which is essentially a high game of Platonic forms realised in the most solid local and modern materials set among daunting mountains. Here is Botta's highly regimented headquarters for Swisscom at Bellinzola (1998), here his striped chapel of St John the Baptist at Mogno (1996), built to replace its 17th century predecessor, destroyed by an avalanche. When you see its setting, the words "borrowed time" spring to mind.

Most dramatic of all is the chapel on Monte Tamaro that Botta has designed for the owner of the mountain's cable-car company, in memory of his wife. The stone-clad structure extends as if infinitely along a belvedere into the mountains beyond. Walking alone here, as the cold highland air thins into an ethereal whiteness, one can imagine coming face-to-face with God. If you are tempted to believe that modern architecture is unable to achieve the sacredness of medieval cathedrals, take the train to Rivera and the cable-car up Monte Tamaro.

Ticino offers the most recognisable and homogeneous modern Swiss architecture, yet the sculptural solidity of its buildings is matched throughout the country even in utterly unexpected parts. I must go and see the service buildings that accompany the heroic new, 67km-long Transjurane road from Delemont to Porrentruy (architects Flora Ruchat-Roncati and Renato Salvi). These include intriguing zoomorphic bridgeheads and ventilation shafts, the latter emerging in fields of grazing cows, while cars and trucks growl deep below them.

Switzerland has started to use its wealth intelligently, at least as far as infrastructure goes. Maybe, as Orson Welles said in The Third Man, it had little to offer the rest of Europe for 500 years, but that has begun to change.

fields.bodyText: Mention the word "Switzerland" and some people will still chortle about cuckoo clocks, dodgy banks and army penknives. Over the past two decades, however, Switzerland has reinvented at least one aspect of its culture: Swiss architecture is now among the finest in the world, possibly even better than Spain's. Each time Peter Zumthor completes one of his rare and exquisitely crafted new buildings - the Sogn Benedetg chapel in Sumvitg (1988), the residential home for the elderly in Masans (1993) and the thermal baths in Vals (1996) - I have made a pilgrimage to the land of Heidi and William Tell. It is extremely uncommon to find such inventive modern architecture so beautifully built and in such exquisite settings. Yet Zumthor, a cabinet-maker turned interior designer then architect, is not alone. Switzerland has produced several of the world's most original and respected architects in recent years, including Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron (best known outside their homeland for Tate Modern and the exquisite Dominus Winery in California's Napa Valley) and Mario Botta, who was, for a brief while, an assistant of the great Swiss architect Le Corbusier. Their designs are included in the latest pocket-sized architectural guidebook from Ellipsis, written by Thomas Hildebrand and Maya Huber. Don't be put off by the blurb that says that the book, called simply Switzerland, "will appeal to aficionados of the Neue Einfachheit and the Tendenza as well as to the accidental tourist with a penchant for architecture". The grand tour of modern Swiss architecture can be taken safely at home with this excellent guide, as well as by trains and buses that never run late and seem like a dream to us poor Brits, who invented the railway but still can't make it run on time. Because they love their railways, the Swiss employ their best architects to design their infrastructure. There's Herzog & de Meuron's striking, copper-clad signal box at Auf dem Wolf, Basel (1995), for example - an intriguing monolithic structure that catches and refracts every change of light and weather. The same firm has recently completed a second signal box outside Basel's main station, Münchensteinerbrücke. The way these architects marry a substantial, crafted architecture to the sensual and ethereal is both surprising and delightful. Their buildings represent, at one level, an attempt to prove that today's architects can readily rival and outmatch the cyberspace fantasies so popular throughout the rest of the world. "If architecture wants to play a significant role in the future," Herzog tells Huber and Hildebrand, "it has to rely on its own qualities; it needs to exploit fully its own potential. What we have is the opportunity to work with mass, with solid and heavy elements, not just with flighty images." Not that they can't create flighty images: by night Herzog & de Meuron's crystalline factory for Ricola-Europe at Mulhouse-Brunstatt (the other side of the Swiss-French border) changes, to use Herzog's words, "like the surface of water". By day it has the heroic, sculptural quality of so much Swiss architecture. Maybe this derives from the magnificent, and highly functional farmhouses, notably of the Bernese, that stand like isolated monuments in the landscape, each a fortress, rural factory and home, each beautifully built. I remember thinking about these structures when visiting Zumthor's boat-shaped Benedictine chapel. I was pleased to read this quote from the architect in Huber and Hildebrand's guide: "To me the presence of a certain building has something secret about it. They seem simply to be here. We do not pay any special attention to them. And yet it is virtually impossible to imagine the place where they stand without them. These buildings appear to be anchored firmly in the ground. They create an impression of being a self-evident part of their surroundings." As with Bernese farmhouses, so with Zumthor's hand-wrought chapel. If you're lucky enough to travel to Switzerland, try to take in Zurich for two railway stations - the Hauptbahnhof (remodelled by Meili, Peter, Fickert and Knapkiewicz, 1997) and Stadelhofen (bravura architecture and engineering by Santiago Calatrava, 1990) - as well as Chur for the fantastic, filigree roof of its bus and railway station (Brosi and Obrist, 1992) . But above all you must visit the canton of Ticino, home of Mario Botta and some of the world's most distinctive new architecture. I long to visit the museum, in the medieval town of Giornico, known as La Congiunta (The Marriage), a union between the sculpture of Hans Josephson and the architecture of Peter Markli (1992). This is an utterly uncompromised building with no heating, artificial lighting or flooring. All there is, is the relationship between a sentinel-like architecture composed of severe concrete blocks, daylight, and the sculptures themselves. There are no curators to keep a beady eye on visitors, who must get the key from the local hosteria, 10 minutes away along a Roman road. This is as good an introduction as any to Ticinese architecture, which is essentially a high game of Platonic forms realised in the most solid local and modern materials set among daunting mountains. Here is Botta's highly regimented headquarters for Swisscom at Bellinzola (1998), here his striped chapel of St John the Baptist at Mogno (1996), built to replace its 17th century predecessor, destroyed by an avalanche. When you see its setting, the words "borrowed time" spring to mind. Most dramatic of all is the chapel on Monte Tamaro that Botta has designed for the owner of the mountain's cable-car company, in memory of his wife. The stone-clad structure extends as if infinitely along a belvedere into the mountains beyond. Walking alone here, as the cold highland air thins into an ethereal whiteness, one can imagine coming face-to-face with God. If you are tempted to believe that modern architecture is unable to achieve the sacredness of medieval cathedrals, take the train to Rivera and the cable-car up Monte Tamaro. Ticino offers the most recognisable and homogeneous modern Swiss architecture, yet the sculptural solidity of its buildings is matched throughout the country even in utterly unexpected parts. I must go and see the service buildings that accompany the heroic new, 67km-long Transjurane road from Delemont to Porrentruy (architects Flora Ruchat-Roncati and Renato Salvi). These include intriguing zoomorphic bridgeheads and ventilation shafts, the latter emerging in fields of grazing cows, while cars and trucks growl deep below them. Switzerland has started to use its wealth intelligently, at least as far as infrastructure goes. Maybe, as Orson Welles said in The Third Man, it had little to offer the rest of Europe for 500 years, but that has begun to change. · Switzerland is published by Ellipsis, price £10.

webTitle: Wheels: The Citroen Berlingo

fields.headline: The nice van cometh
fields.standfirst: It may look like a souped-up Post Office van, but the Berlingo could carry a family of five - and a pony, says  Giles Smith
fields.trailText: It may look like a souped-up Post Office van, but the Berlingo could carry a family of five - and a pony, says Giles Smith.
fields.body:
If there is an uglier car on the road than the Citroen Berlingo Multispace, then I would be very keen to see it. A tribute to the elasticity of the welder's art, the Berlingo combines the charm of an electrician's van in a former communist country with the road-tearing elan of a show-dog transporter.

Toying daringly with the conventional wisdom on vehicle dignity, the car slowly rises from front to back, without coming down again. It has a sheer, almost vertical rear end, as milkfloats do. An impressed three-year-old remarked that the Berlingo was "like Andy's car" - which turned out to be an allusion to the animated movie Toy Story 2, in which Andy is indeed driven away to summer camp in a vehicle not a million miles away from a Berlingo. And it's quite right that, in reality, the car looks somehow pixellated, a piece of computer guesswork, not quite true.

All this and it seems to have been named after some kind of cassette-based, teach-yourself language course. ("Do you speaka Berlingo? Learn French in 10 days, or your money back.")

At the same time, though, check out that price. Go for the smallest engine (1.4) and do without the air conditioning, the sunroof, a few of the air bags and a couple of the other fripperies, and a Berlingo can be yours for under £9,000. This is a large car we're talking about - one that could happily seat a family of five and its pony. Or even its giraffe, with the sunroof back. (The Berlingo, like the Citroen Picasso, has one of those gigantic, full-length sunroofs that has the effect of peeling the top right off the car.) It's doubtful that your money could buy you a more capacious vehicle.

Citroen knows it is up to something challengingly unusual with the Berlingo. As it puts it itself: "Why choose an ordinary car when you could have a Berlingo?" Well, for one thing, because an ordinary car doesn't look like a Berlingo and doesn't have humorously square windows of the kind made famous by Wendy houses. And because some people like to get about without being laughed at or having others assume they have come to unblock the drains.

But Citroen seems to prefer to interpret the Berlingo's difference as a fetching quirkiness. Publicity photographs for the car dare to show it on a beach, pored over by five young people of inordinately sunny dispositions - like you might gather some friends, gas up the Berlingo and take off to St Tropez, just for the buzz.

I'm not so sure about this. I find it hard to imagine a journey in a Berlingo that doesn't involve children, livestock and/or some of the larger items of produce from a garden centre. And, even though Citroen has taken the trouble to realise this scenario for me photographically, I find it very hard to imagine someone in a bikini driving one.

Personally, I was very well-covered the day I went in my Berlingo to pick up a Christmas tree. (It was on the scale of a gift from the Norwegian people, but it went in the back easily enough.) A man offered to help carry the tree to the car and I found myself saying: "It's that funny blue thing up there." Life with a Berlingo would, I suspect, be like this a lot: you would keep finding yourself having to laugh it off or apologise for it in advance, a bit like with your mother.

Better really, if one is going to get involved, to accept the car straightforwardly for what it is - which is not a misplaced fun wagon or thickly disguised dream machine but, rather, a highly effective and deeply affordable means of driving a big lump of space around.

Inside, the driver is confronted by the usual prairie of uninteresting plastic and a set of dull but perfectly coherent and usable buttons and clocks. The quietly functional engine was ... well, quiet and functional and at no point tempted me into anything madcap, such as a handbrake turn. But then, one would hardly have stepped into what is, in effect, a high-sided vehicle expecting thrills.

The rear passenger compartment appears to have been modelled on an aeroplane's interior (there are seat-back pockets on the seat in front of you and overhead luggage space in the form of nets above the doors). Except, of course, that there's more leg-room in a Berlingo. And you are never far from an emergency exit: the rear doors slide open, which does nothing to decrease the sense that you are in an adapted Post Office vehicle, but which does, clearly, assist one's passage and makes sitting on one side and getting out on the other an easy manoeuvre, rather than an exhausting feat of contortionism.

And in the end, I guess, these things matter, far more than the overall comeliness of the car. The fact is, right now, I have a Christmas tree to dump and no Berlingo to dump it with. I miss it.

The lowdown
Citroen Berlingo Multispace 1.4i
Price: £8,995
Top speed: 93 mph
Acceleration: 0-62 in 14.6 seconds
Consumption: 36.7 mpg
At the wheel: Alan Titchmarsh
On the stereo: Melody FM
En route for: Water Features R Us

webTitle: Unison suspends Scottish pay strikes

fields.headline: Unison suspends Scottish pay strikes
fields.trailText: Trade union Unison has voted to suspend its campaign of selective Scottish local government strikes for two weeks and to enter talks with the country's councils aimed at resolving the six-month-old pay dispute. Simon Parkerreports
fields.body:
Trade union Unison has voted to suspend its campaign of selective Scottish local government strikes for two weeks and to enter talks with the country's councils aimed at resolving the six-month-old pay dispute.

The union has also indicated that it might be prepared to accept the pay deal currently being implemented by the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) in return for concessions on future wage settlements.

Unison is hoping to secure a guarantee of above-inflation pay increases, with larger raises for the lowest paid and a £5 an hour minimum rate.

Scottish local government organiser Joe Di Paola said: "The employers have indicated that they're prepared to put money on the table." He added that if authorities did meet some of Unison's demands for future settlements, his members might "look more favourably" on Cosla's offer.

Under this offer, council staff will receive a 6.1% raise over 2000-01 and 2001-02, at a cost of well over £200m in wages bills.

The strikes will be called off between January 15 and January 31, but the union has threatened to escalate its industrial action if its wage demands are not met.

A spokeswoman said that Cosla was prepared to discuss future pay settlements, but that any concessions made by authorities would not take effect until the 2002-03 settlement at the earliest.

Cosla vice-president Pat Watters said: "Both sides can now enter serious discussions that will take the whole issue of pay for local government staff forward, and we as employers stand by our commitment to look at issues such as inflation and distribution of pay increases in future years."

Unison is currently the only major town hall union not to have accepted Cosla's pay offer. Despite this, it will have to enter the new talks alongside other major players such as the GMB and Transport and General Workers unions.

webTitle: High court backs Bulger killers' anonymity

fields.headline: High court backs Bulger killers' anonymity
fields.trailText: The killers of toddler James Bulger this afternoon won a high court order protecting their anonymity once they are freed with new identities.
fields.body:
The killers of toddler James Bulger this afternoon won a high court order protecting their anonymity once they are freed with new identities.

The family division president, Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, rejected arguments by media organisations that open justice, press freedom and the public's "overriding right to know the identities of those who committed serious and detestable crimes" would be imperilled. But Dame Elizabeth gave newspapers leave to appeal against her ruling to the Court of Appeal.

She said: "I am compelled to take steps in the almost unique circumstances of this case to protect their lives and physical wellbeing."

It had been argued at the high court that the threat of revenge attacks against Jon Venables and Robert Thompson, now both 18, necessitated an injunction barring publicity about the pair after their imminent release from secure local authority accommodation.

The judge said she was "convinced that their lives are genuinely at risk as well as their physical safety if their new identities and whereabouts became public knowledge".

Venables and Thompson hope to win parole early this year following a ruling by the Lord Chief Justice, Lord Woolf, that they have served the minimum tariff necessary under their life sentences.

The pair were both aged 10 when they beat two-year-old James to death on a railway line in Liverpool in February 1993.

During their time in custody as juveniles, an injunction banned the media from taking or publishing photographs of them or reporting on their progress or treatment.

Summarising her judgment, the judge described how the murder of James Bulger was "a horrific crime and the circumstances unusually shocking and distressing. It caused much public concern and a widespread feeling of moral outrage."

She said there was massive national and international publicity at the time of the murder and during and after the trial. That coverage continued throughout the period of detention of the two boys.

Injunctions restricting publicity came to an end when the boys reached 18 and their lawyers then sought to make those injunctions indefinite.

"I have decided that, taking into account the European Convention on Human Rights, the law of confidence may, in exceptional circumstances be applied to protect individuals who are seriously at risk of injury or death if their identity or whereabouts became public knowledge and that the court has jurisdiction to grant injunctions to ensure their protection," she said.

Dame Elizabeth said information she had received from the Home Office, press reports and judicial observations had "convinced me that these young men are uniquely notorious and are at serious risk of attacks from members of the public as well as from relatives and friends of the murdered child".

She said threats to injure and kill them had been set out in the evidence and reported in the press. "I am satisfied that, although there has been balanced discussion in press articles in recent months, the sense of moral outrage has not diminished and there remains among some members of the public a serious desire for revenge if the two young men are living in the community.

"The Home Office views these threats very seriously and is likely to give Venables and Thompson new identities on their release from detention.

"I am therefore convinced that their lives are genuinely at risk as well as their physical safety if their new identities and whereabouts became public knowledge."

The judge said "certain sections of the press would not wish the two young men to remain anonymous and would wish to have them identified and, if information about them became available, there was a real possibility it would be published".

The Guardian was not among media organisations contesting the case.

webTitle: MoD pressed to move on toxic shells

fields.headline: MoD pressed to move on toxic shells
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence was coming under increasing pressure last night to screen British troops who served in the Balkans and the Gulf war for signs of contamination by depleted uranium used in anti-tank weapons.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence was coming under increasing pressure last night to screen British troops who served in the Balkans and the Gulf war for signs of contamination by depleted uranium used in anti-tank weapons.

With Nato officials preparing to face up to growing concern across Europe about the weapons linked to a spate of leukaemia cases among Balkans veterans, Britain and the US, the only two countries to use the shells, are increasingly isolated in their defence.

Switzerland yesterday joined France, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Belgium, the Netherlands, Poland, and Finland in setting up screening programmes for soldiers who have served in the Balkans.

Official assurances and the lack of hard evidence have failed to dampen public concern among veterans - echoed by the European commission and the UN - about the safety of the weapons. Senior officials will meet in Nato headquarters in Brussels tomorrow to consider how to respond to pressure on governments faced with evidence linking DU shells with cancer. The EU has announced an inquiry into the health risks of the shells.

The Ministry of Defence insisted that ranges in Eskmeals, Cumbria, and the Solway Firth in Scotland, where DU shells were used, were monitored by the health and safety executive. It could not comment on reports they had also been fired at the army's ranges at Lulworth, Dorset.

Though the ministry acknowledges that toxic dust from the shells is harmful if inhaled or ingested in large quantities, a spokesman said it did not believe the shells posed "any significant health risk".

The MoD has asked for an independent study by the Royal Society, which is to report in the spring. However, it has no plans to screen veterans, the spokesman said.

The ministry's stand has not been helped by its failure to warn troops before the Gulf war of the risks of DU in shells used by US AI0 "tankbusters" and British Chieftain tanks.

The Labour MP Paul Flynn yesterday showed the Guardian a letter he received in 1993 from Jeremy Hanley, then a Foreign Office minister, who explained that the omission was due "to the urgency attached to bringing into service such a critical capability which at the start of the crisis was still under development".

Mr Flynn, who was also told in 1993 that DU shells had been used in West Freugh, Scotland, and Foulness in Essex, criticised the MoD for contaminating large areas with radioactive dust - what he called "an unknown hazard with unknown remedies".

Terry Gooding, a Gulf war veteran, described the MoD's refusal to screen for DU contamination as "disgusting". He has a war pension for what the MoD describes as "unspecified and ill-defined" illnesses.

American A10 aircraft fired more than 30,000 rounds of DU shells in Kosovo and more than 10,000 in Bosnia, mainly around Sarajevo.

The Commons defence committee is to meet on Wednesday to decide whether to summon ministers to explain the government's policy. "If it is shown that depleted uranium causes an increase in cancers, then we have got to look at alternative weapon systems and at precautions which could be taken to protect our troops, as well as at how we can clean up the areas where the shells were used," said Bruce George, the committee chairman.

He said no repeat should be permitted of the MoD foot-dragging over Gulf war syndrome in the 1990s, which saw ex-servicemen battling for years to convince ministers that their illness was real.

The Commons defence committee is to meet on Wednesday to decide whether to summon ministers to explain the government's policy. "If it is shown that depleted uranium causes an increase in cancers, then we have got to look at alternative weapon systems and at precautions which could be taken to protect our troops, as well as at how we can clean up the areas where the shells were used," said Bruce George, the committee chairman. He said no repeat should be permitted of the MoD foot-dragging over Gulf war syndrome in the 1990s, which saw ex-servicemen battling for years to convince ministers that their illness was real.

webTitle: Winslet vows not to exploit celebrity status

fields.headline: Winslet vows not to exploit celebrity status
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Actress Kate Winslet told Radio Times she will "never" invite OK! or Hello! into her home, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Actress Kate Winslet says she will "never" cash in on her celebrity status by inviting OK! or Hello! into her home in a Radio Times interview published today.

"People who think they're celebrities appear in those magazines. I suppose I am one now, which I find strange. What is celebrity? It's fake and I'm suspicious of it," Ms Winslet told the Radio Times.

The star of Titanic said she and husband Jim Threapleton had offers for the rights to exclusive photos of their wedding in 1998, but turned them down.

"Boy, is it tempting to take the money, but we sat down over a cup of tea and told ourselves not to be ridiculous," she said.

"You can't sell your private life down the drain. I'd hate to sound a bitch saying that, because some people genuinely need the money, and that's fine. What you're clearly rolling in it, it's appalling," she added.

But she said she had read Catherine Zeta Jones' reasons for selling her wedding snaps to OK! for £1m and can "kind of understand".

"However, if you're doing it, donate the money to charity. I'll say this once: if ever we appear in any of those magazines you'll know we have serious money problems."

Ms Winslet said she "can't stand showbiz stuff". "Admittedly sometimes it's fun at an award show or premiere with endless champagne, limos and frocks, but it would drive me mad to do it constantly."

She also talked about appearing naked in many of her films including Hideous Kinky and Titanic. "That's funny because as a teenager I was physically paranoid and constantly crucifying my own image. Now I don't give a damn although, believe me, I'm not, 'Ooh goody, there's a nude scene.' I'm rigid about the way it's shot," she said.

webTitle: New York Times internet division sheds 69 staff

fields.headline: New York Times internet division sheds 69 staff
fields.trailText: 3pm: Redundancies in online media jobs are continuing as The New York Times Company cuts 69 staff from its internet division, reports Guy Middleton.
fields.body:
Seasonal trimmings of online media jobs continued yesterday as the New York Times cut 69 staff from its internet division.

The company has shed 17% of New York Times Digital's workforce, a move it said would help the division become profitable by the end of 2002.

The job cuts were described by NYTD as "a significant cost reduction initiative".

NYTD operates websites for The New York Times, The Boston Globe and a range of US regional titles owned by the group. It also has a stake in GolfServ, an online content syndicator.

"Since its inception, NYTD has demonstrated a tremendous ability to adapt to the changing internet marketplace," said The New York Times Company chief executive Russell Lewis.

"Today's action is part of that adaptation process and is consistent with its goal of achieving cash-flow profitability for the year 2002," he added.

Last October, The New York Times Company scrapped plans to launch a tracking stock designed to reflect NYTD's performance, citing adverse market conditions.

The New York Times Company is the second large media company to announce new media redundancies in the past week. Last Thursday, News Corp. announced it was to close its new media division with the loss of 200 jobs, as the media giant looked to slash costs.

webTitle: The row over the abolition of community health councils rages on

fields.headline: The row over the abolition of community health councils rages on
fields.trailText: Government proposals to abolish community health councils have proven more controversial than ministers could have imagined. Simon Parker reports
fields.body:
Government proposals to abolish community health councils (CHCs) have proven more controversial than ministers could have imagined. Labour backbenchers are threatening a rebellion over the proposals, the London Assembly has come out in favour of maintaining CHCs and the health councils themselves are appealing strongly against closure.

The controversy over this move could scupper government plans, contained in the health and social care bill before parliament, to give councils the power to scrutinise the work of the NHS. MPs are primarily worried about the patient advocacy and liaison service, outlined in the same bill, which they believe could lack independence. But if the thought of a backbench revolt scares the government into a climbdown on abolishing CHCs, ministers could choose to defer, alter or scrap their entire package of NHS scrutiny reforms.

CHCs were set up 25 years ago as independent bodies with powers to take up complaints from patients. Their ability to highlight poor practice in the health service has since drawn the anger of successive governments, but CHCs as a whole have also been accused of patchy performance, and this has led to their planned abolition. Health secretary Alan Milburn claims his proposals will ensure greater independence of patient representatives from health trusts and boost patient power.

The Local Government Association (LGA) is this week emphasising that CHC abolition and council scrutiny do not have to go hand in hand. A report from officers to the association's ruling executive says: "Widening scrutiny responsibilities does not necessarily mean that CHCs have to be abolished. The two factors can be treated quite distinctly. Indeed, a refocusing of CHCs to become the voice of the patient and user while local authorities scrutinise the overall service would seem a sensible distinction."

The LGA report asks the association's leadership to consider throwing the association's weight behind a campaign to maintain CHCs in a different form. LGA chairman Sir Jeremy Beecham responded: "I don't think a campaign is what's called for. We've got to be clear about what we want doing in the area currently covered by CHCs. The question is whether the patient advocacy role is better based within the NHS or whether some sort of freestanding arrangement is needed. That may or may not be around some form of residual CHC."

The new scrutiny power is important to local authorities because it represents a vital tool in the government's "community leadership" agenda for councils. This is already seeing some authorities redefining themselves as all-purpose problem solvers for their residents. Local government argues that the new scrutiny role will help address the much-vaunted "democratic deficit" in the NHS, while simultaneously giving councils an opportunity to more powerfully represent the views of their communities.

Fortunately for councils, there has not so far been any sign of softening in the government's line toward CHC abolition. But that does not mean that every one of around 700 full-time health council employees faces unemployment. LGA health chair Rita Stringfellow says the government should ensure the expertise of those workers does not go to waste and suggests some could become external advisers to local authority scrutiny panels.

The idea will provide scant comfort for many of those working in health councils, but it does emphasise the LGA's message on this issue. As Sir Jeremy puts it: "It's too easy to blur the distinction between these issues. Whether we maintain CHCs is a different issue from council scrutiny."

webTitle: Football merchanding: Man Utd aims global goal

fields.headline: Man Utd aims for global goal
fields.standfirst: 12pm: Man Utd halves merchandising staff
fields.trailText:
3.15pm: Manchester United has parted company with its merchandising boss as the club pushes to become a global brand, reports Daniel Rogers.
12pm: Man Utd halves merchandising staff
fields.body:
Manchester United has parted company with its merchandising boss as the club pushes for a new drive to become a global brand alongside the likes of Coca Cola and McDonald's.

And it has poached a top executive from Umbro's national sales manager to spearhead the initiative which will make David Beckham an icon everywhere from Beijing to Brasilia.

Ron Gourlay, who starts today as the club's managing director of merchandising, replaces Steve Richards who has left to "pursue his own interests". Gourlay will head up Man Utd's newly-streamlined merchandising division.

Earlier today the club axed 48 merchandising jobs out of 100 in a new strategy to develop as a global brand. A spokesman said the job cuts were the result of closing its Manchester-based warehouse and moving towards partnership deals with overseas partners.

"In line with other global brands we want to stop acting as a one-stop-shop and become a world-wide licensing business. We will link up with companies who can better understand their local markets," he said.

Man Utd made £23.6m last year from merchandising items that range from David Beckham shirts to Man United footballs, gloves, calenders, videos and Ryan Giggs duvet covers. With 30-40m members worldwide, this is soon set to exceed revenue from gate receipts - currently £36.6m.

William Davies, football analyst at Gerrard, said: "Asia is where the growth is, and where the money is. By developing merchandising partnership deals, the club is following the same strategy that has recently seen it link up with partners such as Nike and Vodafone."

The Man Utd spokesman said the key merchandising opportunities lie in countries such as China, Korea and Japan, and in the longer term, in North America.

With a turnover of £116m in 2000, the club is the richest in the world. It also has the largest membership. Its recent tour to Asia was watched by 200m Chinese viewers.

webTitle: 'Don't let the Bulger killing wreck two more lives'

fields.headline: 'Don't let the Bulger killing wreck two more lives'
fields.standfirst:
Angela Neustatter believes her research on rehabilitated offenders shows the Bulger killers can start afresh, given half a chance
Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: It is perfectly possible that Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the killers of James Bulger, could be given new names and identities and live quietly amongst us without anyone knowing.
fields.body:
It is perfectly possible that Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the killers of James Bulger, could be given new names and identities and live quietly amongst us without anyone knowing.

But it can only be possible if, as a society, we decide that compassion, rehabilitation and hope are more important to us than keeping the rage and fury directed at two lads who themselves were victims of hideous childhoods and who then acted out their distorted and disturbed feelings in their dreadful act.

Predictably as the question of the killers' release is raised the populist press steps in with its simplistic relentlessly unforgiving approach, urging us to think of little James's suffering and that of his parents and never to forget that Thompson and Venables are evil incarnate.

Except that all the evidence is they are not, that they have been successfully rehabilitated in a way I have seen is possible, having spent the last year visiting youth jails as research for a book on young offenders, and that they feel remorse, want to pay their price to society by living decent, productive lives.

Of course if the rewards of keeping this desperately sad tale of three victimised children ever alive, our emotional batteries charged up with rage and hatred, are what we want then we should tattoo their names on their foreheads, erect neon signs saying where they live and tacitly support anyone who vents their feelings on them while celebrating the way we have maintained the tradition of the medieval witch hunt.

But surely a nation that prides itself on concern for children can do better than than clinging to cheap notions of original sin and innate evil.

Wouldn't it be so much better to direct our energies to doing something about the far too many children living with the kind of severe deprivation, emotional neglect, lack of nurture the Bulger killers endured - conditions which are known risk factors for delinquency and violence - and campaign for more to be done?

That way we might just prevent another Bulger death rather than ensuring that his memory is enshrined in the wrecked lives of Venables and Thompson.

webTitle: Blair 'proud to have won backing of the wealthy'

fields.headline: Blair 'proud to have won backing of the wealthy'
fields.trailText:
Tony Blair said yesterday that far from being embarrassed he was "absolutely
         proud" to have won the backing of wealthy business people who make donations
         to the Labour party.
fields.body:
Tony Blair said yesterday that far from being embarrassed he was "absolutely proud" to have won the backing of wealthy business people who make donations to the Labour party.

And he rejected calls for state funding of political parties on the grounds that voters would not stand for it.

Mr Blair said on BBC 1's Breakfast with Frost: "I think I probably speak for any political leader of any political party when I say that I would be delighted if we never had to raise a single penny piece in political funding. But I don't think the support is there from the public."

Making a determined effort to regain ground lost because of last week's news of three £2m gifts, the prime minister told David Frost: "Providing the proper transparency and rules are there - and for the first time, we are actually introducing rules - we have got to recognise it is not a bad thing, it is a good thing."

However, as new details about donations emerged, Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, joined demands for more state funding to restore public confidence after what he called the "megabucks" controversy.

"That is not good for the political process," said Mr Kennedy. "It is just going to turn people off. If people felt there was transparency about their politics, they might feel better about politics."

When it emerged yesterday that one of the trio - probably the Anglo-Canadian financier, Christopher Ondaatje- had sent his cheque from the tax haven of Bermuda, the Conservatives renewed their claims of hypocrisy. "Labour has always postured as whiter than white," Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, complained on GMTV's Sunday programme.

But Mr Blair had plainly taken a decision not to apologise when he made his annual new year appearance on the Frost sofa. "I am absolutely proud of the fact that we have got successful entrepreneurs and disaffected Conservatives who look at the state of the Conservative party and say, 'It is hopeless, it is incapable of governing the country properly', and support the Labour party."

Labour activists and MPs have been troubled by the scale of donations made by Lords Sainsbury and Hamlyn, and Mr Ondaatje, ahead of the general election.

Some agree that Millbank initially mishandled the Hamlyn donation . But others are angry that the media has given them no credit for embracing the Nolan/Neill anti-sleaze reforms on party funding which come into force on February 16 - and were resisted by the Tories.

The Labour backbencher Peter Bradley twisted that knife yesterday when he announced that he received a letter from the Metropolitan police confirming that a 10-month investigation into an alleged hacking into Tory party computers had produced no evidence of a crime.

The investigation was launched after the MP for The Wrekin revealed in 1999 that a large donation to Tory funds from the party treasurer, Michael (now Lord) Ashcroft, had come from the tax haven of Belize.

Mr Bradley said yesterday that the claim was a smokescreen to distract attention from the Belize link. He has written to the police asking for details of who requested the investigation, how much it had cost and whether anyone would be charged with wasting police time.

Both the Tory and the Labour parties are fundraising hard in the hope of having all the £15m-£20m election budgets which this week will be officially "capped" for the first time. Yesterday's newspapers reported that Labour's war chest contains £10m and that six gifts between £100,000 and £450,000 have also been received.

Millbank did not comment on the donations other than to say it "has taken a lead in reforming party funding, which is why since 1995 we have declared all donations over £5,000 and banned foreign donors".

Today's Mirror reports that an ally of Margaret Thatcher has donated £1m to Labour. It says a friend of the donor said: "He wants to keep it as quiet as possible, but is resigned to the details emerging at some point before the election. He's always been thought of as a Thatcherite Tory but he has been very impressed with Tony Blair as a strong leader."

webTitle: Leader: We need an inquiry into depleted uranium

fields.headline: The Balkans aftermath
fields.standfirst:
We need an inquiry into depleted uranium

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: We need an inquiry into depleted uranium.
fields.body:
The government should set up a full independent inquiry into the effects of uranium-tipped shells, including the screening of veterans, without delay. The shells have been linked to cancer in soldiers in the Balkans conflicts and the Ministry of Defence has now confirmed that they have been used on firing ranges in the UK.

The government's official position is that there is no case for a separate inquiry because there has been no evidence of any significant risk to British personnel. Officials claim that the health and safety executive has been monitoring the use of weapons on ranges for 10 years without finding any risk to troops or civilians. That may be so, but we don't know the level of monitoring nor what a more detailed survey might have found.

If there is one lesson that ought to have been learned in recent years it is that when there is a potential danger to people, the government should be proactive and go out of its way to allay suspicion. It didn't do this in response to the early worries about BSE, with disastrous consequences. It has taken a more enlightened attitude to mobile phones by publishing a report that sets out the facts (no proven worries for adults yet but children shouldn't overindulge) leaving people to make up their own minds.

The Ministry of Defence should be particularly sensitive as it dragged its feet over what has come to be known as Gulf war syndrome. John Spellar, the junior defence minister, told the Commons at the end of last year: "We are unaware of anything that shows depleted uranium has caused any ill-health or death of people who served in Kosovo or Bosnia." But how would he know unless a proper survey has been undertaken? Until recently the government could also quote the official view of Nato and the United States that there was nothing to worry about.

Now it is different. On Friday the United Nations environment programme (UNEP) admitted it had found traces of radiation at eight sites in Kosovo hit by Nato shells similar to those used by the US in Bosnia and the Gulf war. Last week, Italy started its own investigation after six deaths and 30 cases of similar illnesses. France said on Thursday that four Balkan veterans were being treated for leukaemia and Spain is reported to have sent a team to Kosovo to investigate for itself.

Kevin Rudland, a former Royal Engineer, is the first reported British case of Balkans syndrome. He claims to have suffered debilitating health problems after serving in Bosnia. Meanwhile work done by Dr Chris Busby (reported in yesterday's Observer) on Gulf war battlefields indicates that air samples taken from Iraqi battlefields - where 300,000 rounds of depleted uranium ammunition were used - showed levels of irradiated particles in the atmosphere 20 times greater than in Baghdad.

Britain has adopted an ostrich-like approach compared with the rest of Europe, which has now detached itself from the Nato/US common front. The European Union is expected to announce tomorrow that it will debate the matter while in Britain the Commons defence committee is to summon ministers to explain their attitudes to fears that depleted uranium shells might have caused illnesses among British soldiers.

If they have already done authoritative tests and found no evidence then they should publish the results immediately. If they haven't done proper tests they should instigate some forthwith. This is not just to solve what looks like a serious problem in itself: it is also to demonstrate that the culture of Whitehall towards similar worries now, and in the future, has also changed.

That may be so, but we don't know the level of monitoring nor what a more detailed survey might have found. If there is one lesson that ought to have been learned in recent years it is that when there is a potential danger to people, the government should be proactive and go out of its way to allay suspicion. It didn't do this in response to the early worries about BSE, with disastrous consequences. It has taken a more enlightened attitude to mobile phones by publishing a report that sets out the facts (no proven worries for adults yet but children shouldn't overindulge) leaving people to make up their own minds. The Ministry of Defence should be particularly sensitive as it dragged its feet over what has come to be known as Gulf war syndrome. John Spellar, the junior defence minister, told the Commons at the end of last year: "We are unaware of anything that shows depleted uranium has caused any ill-health or death of people who served in Kosovo or Bosnia." But how would he know unless a proper survey has been undertaken? Until recently the government could also quote the official view of Nato and the United States that there was nothing to worry about. Now it is different. On Friday the United Nations environment programme (UNEP) admitted it had found traces of radiation at eight sites in Kosovo hit by Nato shells similar to those used by the US in Bosnia and the Gulf war. Last week, Italy started its own investigation after six deaths and 30 cases of similar illnesses. France said on Thursday that four Balkan veterans were being treated for leukaemia and Spain is reported to have sent a team to Kosovo to investigate for itself. Kevin Rudland, a former Royal Engineer, is the first reported British case of Balkans syndrome. He claims to have suffered debilitating health problems after serving in Bosnia. Meanwhile work done by Dr Chris Busby (reported in yesterday's Observer) on Gulf war battlefields indicates that air samples taken from Iraqi battlefields - where 300,000 rounds of depleted uranium ammunition were used - showed levels of irradiated particles in the atmosphere 20 times greater than in Baghdad. Britain has adopted an ostrich-like approach compared with the rest of Europe, which has now detached itself from the Nato/US common front. The European Union is expected to announce tomorrow that it will debate the matter while in Britain the Commons defence committee is to summon ministers to explain their attitudes to fears that depleted uranium shells might have caused illnesses among British soldiers. If they have already done authoritative tests and found no evidence then they should publish the results immediately. If they haven't done proper tests they should instigate some forthwith. This is not just to solve what looks like a serious problem in itself: it is also to demonstrate that the culture of Whitehall towards similar worries now, and in the future, has also changed.

webTitle: Toyzone.co.uk seeks new business model in bid to survive

fields.headline: Toyzone.co.uk seeks new business model in bid to survive
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: Toyzone, the UK-based toy e-tailer, is to shift its business model in a bid to save its skin while rival eToys falters, reports Guy Middleton
Jan 3: EToys shuts down European operations
fields.body:
Toyzone, the UK-based toy e-tailer, is to shift its business model in a bid to save its skin while rival eToys falters.

The company, whose shareholders include PR guru Matthew Freud, is exploring "a number" of options, including European expansion, broadening its product range and the possibility of being acquired by an established bricks-and-mortar retailer.

"Just to sit back and say 'we have a business model from a year ago' would be rubbish," said chief executive Paul Miller.

He added that the company had renegotiated its relationships with all of its suppliers, to enable it to make a profit on each e-commerce "basket" sold.

"Standalone, UK-only companies are going to find 2001 very challenging," he acknowledged.

As Toyzone has found, selling toys online isn't always fun. US-based eToys is to wind up its UK operation on the January 19, and last Thursday announced the redundancy of 700 of its 1,000 US-based staff. Both moves are part of a cost-cutting plan that eToys hopes will allow it to shore up its US business.

Toyzone.co.uk shares its name with a UK-based toy retailer, which also has a small stake in the business, however Miller added that it would be wrong to assume that any deal would involve that particular bricks-and-mortar retailer.

The site sells a range of toys including micro scooters, soft toys, Pokemon trading cards and merchandise from the popular series Thunderbirds, including the sought-after Tracy Island, home of the Tracy family of Thunderbirds.

Alongside its retail operation, the site offers interactive games pitched at under-12s.

webTitle: Rebel Heart beaten by Caroline Quentin

fields.headline: Rebel Heart beaten by Caroline Quentin
fields.trailText: TV overnights 2pm: BBC1's Irish independence drama Rebel Heart failed to pull in the punters last night, despite the publicity surrounding its launch, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC1's Irish independence drama Rebel Heart failed to pull in the punters last night, despite the publicity surrounding its launch.

Rebel Heart, which focuses on a young Dubliner - played by James D'Arcy - caught up in the 1916 Easter Uprising, had just 3.9m and a 15% share from 9pm last night.

The lavish period drama was crushed by ITV's Caroline Quentin drama vehicle The Innocent. The first instalment of a two-parter in which Ms Quentin plays the wife of a man accused of raping a close friend, The Innocent drew 9.7m and more than 40% of the available audience from 9pm.

Rebel Heart was also up against a strong Channel 4 offering at 9pm. The terrestrial premiere of cheesy horror film Anaconda, which featured Jennifer Lopez battling a 40-foot snake, had 3m and a 13% share.

Earlier on Sunday evening Lily Savage's Blankety Blank marked its move from BBC1 to ITV by running Antiques Roadshow very close on its debut. ITV's Blankety Blank had 8.4m, 7-7.40pm; while BBC1's Antiques Roadshow drew 8.8m, 6.55-7.40pm.

Feel-good BBC1 comedy drama Monarch of the Glen returned at 8.10pm, with a respectable 7m and one in four viewers. But it was still no match for ITV ratings juggernaut Heartbeat, which had 13.2m.

Channel 4 stalwart Time Team returned in rude good health at 6pm. Tony Robinson and his beardy experts attracted 3.5m - a 15% share - as they went looking for a lost Saxon cemetery in Lincolnshire.

webTitle: Patients should welcome GP watchdog

fields.headline: Patients should welcome GP watchdog
fields.standfirst: The body set up to monitor doctors' performance is a welcome and timely initiative to correct poor clinical practices and drive up quality, writes Patrick Butler
fields.trailText: The body set up to monitor doctors' performance is a welcome and timely initiative to correct poor clinical practices and drive up quality, writes Patrick Butler
fields.body:
So the national clinical assessment authority (NCAA), the body set up with a brief to root out failing and criminal doctors, is not "Shipman-proof". There is no system in the world that could credibly offer such unlikely guarantees.

But to "admit" to this fact, as health minister John Hutton has done, is not the same as admitting, as some of the medical profession have suggested, that the NCAA is therefore mere bureaucratic posturing, or even a Leninist conspiracy to shackle GP freedoms.

The reality is that the point of NCAA is not primarily to stop future Shipmans (although it might uncover or prevent GP murderousness); it is about addressing more mundane (but pressing) matters - raising standards of care and accountability among family doctors.

On the whole GPs don't murder people. But where incompetence, neglect, failure to keep up with medical developments, and other low-level but corrosive failings are left unchecked, patients suffer. In some cases, they die unneccessarily as a result.

Yet it is difficult for health authorities to monitor GP performance, and difficult to act against them in cases of poor performance. The vast majority of GPs are not directly employed by the NHS, and their union - the BMA - is notoriously efficient in defending its members' interests.

The NCAA sits alongside a package of measures introduced by the government in the health and care bill, published just before Christmas, which will enable the NHS to ensure that poor performance by GPs (who are essentially independent contractors "hired" by the NHS) can be addressed and tackled.

This is not as a Daily Mail columnist (Dr Anthony Daniels) puts it, part of what he calls ministers' "campaign to turn doctors into petty clerks", but a welcome and timely initiative to correct poor clinical practices and drive up quality.

Notwithstanding the tiresome paper work that normally accompanies such initiatives, good doctors have nothing to fear from the NCAA, and the accompanying measures. Patients should welcome it.

webTitle: Attack on judge triggers security debate

fields.headline: Attack on judge triggers security debate
fields.trailText: Lawyers demanded action on security for the judiciary today, after a senior judge was attacked by the defendant during a trial at the Old Bailey.
fields.body:
Lawyers demanded action on security for the judiciary today, after a senior judge was attacked by the defendant during a trial at the Old Bailey.

Judge Ann Goddard, 64, was taken to hospital, after a man who is accused of killing his partner with a sword leaped out of the dock and punched her.

He struck several punches before barristers, police and court officials grabbed him.

An immediate inquiry will be held into the incident - including a review of security at Britain's premier court.

Some lawyers have privately expressed concern over security for some time, as numbers of court officials and attendants have been reduced, and one commented today: "This attack was waiting to happen."

The bar council, which represents barristers, said that the attack should put an end to any debate about whether judges' lodgings, which are relatively expensive to run, should be scrapped in favour of hotels.

A spokesman said: "This was an appalling attack which emphasises the real risks that all judges run for society.

"There has been a debate about the need to have special accommodation for judges. We think that this shows that there is no case for making judges stay in hotels or other accommodation."

Judge Goddard has been a familiar figure at the Old Bailey for a number of years - both on the bench and, earlier, as a barrister.

She is among senior Old Bailey judges tipped to succeed the common serjeant of London, Neil Denison, when he retires this year.

Judge Goddard was called to the Bar, Gray's Inn, in 1960, and was made a recorder 19 years later. She has been a circuit judge since 1993.

The judge had just adjourned the case so that the man could consult with his legal representatives.

He is accused of killing his female partner by striking her 44 times, and faces charges of murder or manslaughter.

The first person to reach the judge, Detective Constable John Nicholson, jumped on to the bench and started struggling with the man as he was hitting out at Judge Goddard.

A police officer in court said: "The defendant was sitting in the dock during the 10-minute hearing. There were five male security officers with him.

"He suddenly vaulted over the dock and grabbed a jug of water from the jury bench. He threw it 10 feet towards the judge - but luckily it missed her and it smashed against the back wall.

"Everyone thought he was trying to escape and blocked off the exits - but instead, he ran down the side of the court and on to the platform where the judge sits.

"He punched her and I think there were five or six other punches which connected as we grabbed him and were trying to pull him away."

The officer said: "It was a great shock to everyone. It took us by surprise."

He added: "We don't know what set the man off. The judge had a gash to her left temple. It was about one-and-a-half inches long and would probably need stitches."

The man, who is in his early 30s and from east London, was later remanded, in his absence, in custody to Belmarsh Prison until Friday by another judge.

Judge Goddard was treated for minor head injuries and shock, said a Lord Chancellor's Office spokesman.

A respected senior judge with a reputation as a tough criminal lawyer, Judge Goddard was at the centre of a controversy in 1996 when she allowed a rapist to cross-examine his victim for six days.

She drew criticism for allowing Ralston Edwards to put Julia Mason through the witness box ordeal, in which he forced her to go into intimate details for several days.

Edwards was convicted and given life in prison.

Barristers defended Judge Goddard's decision at the time, saying that the case would have been overturned on appeal had she not allowed him to put his questions.

Ms Mason waived her right to anonymity so that she could launch a campaign to change the law.

Her high-profile case prompted a debate that led to a change in the law last year to prevent alleged rapists from putting their accusers through such an ordeal.

Crime Prosecution Service

webTitle: Bullies prey on half of all children

fields.headline: Bullies prey on half of all children
fields.trailText: More than half of all British schoolchildren have been bullied, a report will reveal this week. Their torment is so severe many victims told researchers it had driven them to attempt suicide. Tracy McVeigh reports.
fields.body:
More than half of all British schoolchildren have been bullied, a report will reveal this week. Their torment is so severe many victims told researchers it had driven them to attempt suicide.

In one of the most detailed studies of the extent of bullying, 7,000 pupils were questioned by the charity Young Voices and Oxford University.

The evidence of the children, aged between 13 and 19, from rural and inner-city schools, is alarming. One in 10 reported severe bullying, including physical violence. Many felt they could not tell anyone what was happening to them as their treatment by other children had sent them into a spiral of depression and misery.

Many went on to become bullies themselves in a desperate attempt to cope with feelings of powerlessness.

"I hated myself. I felt there must be something I'd done wrong or terrible for this to happen. I felt ashamed," said one 14-year-old girl.

Adrienne Katz, of Young Voices, told the Observer: "It's time we listened to what kids are telling us. A glossy brochure sent to the headteacher is not going to help, nor is removing the bully from the class so that you just displace the bullying from the playground to the bus stop.

"Children are telling us that half of schools still do not have an anti-bullying policy and of those who do only half again seem to be effective."

The study found that home life plays a vital part in determining whether a child will be a bully or a victim. "For both the victims and the bullies, parenting was markedly less positive, colder and more controlling. Bullies were far more likely to see aggression at home," said Ms Katz.

Children were far less likely to be bullied if they lived with both parents. Severely bullied boys reported not having a supportive parent and were highly likely to have an absent or unsupportive father.

Of the bullied girls, 79% felt anxious about one parent, and were more likely to say they planned to bring up their own children very differently from the way they were being raised.

Racism seems to be a factor. A quarter of children from ethnic minorities reported being severely bullied, as opposed to 13% of white pupils.

"There are factors which protect children: being bolder and having high self-esteem and positive, warm parenting is overwhelmingly linked to those who are not being bullied," said Ms Katz.

Last year Ian Rivers, of the College of Ripon and York St John, interviewed 190 lesbian and homosexual young adults who were bullied at school and discovered that in later life one in six of them suffered post-traumatic stress disorder, including nightmares and flashbacks, and used drugs to help to get through the day.

Bullying in childhood has also been linked to problems in adulthood such as alcohol abuse, violence against children, marital breakdowns and psychiatric disorders. A 12-year-old bully is three times as likely as other pupils to have a criminal conviction by the age of 24.

Bullying is taking new forms. With one in four children now owning mobile phones, harassment is conducted by phone and email. "They send sick messages to your mobile," one girl said.

It was a campaign of torment by text messaging and silent calls that drove Gail Jones to take an overdose at her Merseyside home last year, her father Glyn believes. She was 15.

Suicide among adolescents has risen in the past decade, and now attempts among under-14s seem to be going up too. According to Professor Keith Hawton of the Centre for Suicide Research in Oxford, girls largely account for the increase in non-fatal overdoses and self-inflicted injuries. They outnumber boys by at least six to one.

In most cases, children are sending out the simple message: "I feel so bad I could die."

Psychologists, who previously thought the concept of death was understood by an individual at puberty, now believe it can develop far earlier in stressed children, at around seven or eight.

Kelly Yeomans, 13, took an overdose of her mother's painkillers in 1997 to end an 18-month bullying campaign against her.

"We keep going over the same question: 'Why didn't she tell somebody?'" her mother Julie said then.

Only months later 15-year-old choirboy Darren Steele's mother asked the same question when her son hanged himself just weeks away from sitting his GCSEs.

In 1996 two schoolgirls were jailed, branded by the judge "contemptible and cowardly", after the overdose death of 16-year-old Scots schoolgirl Katherine Jane Morrison.

One of the most heart-rending cases was that of the 13-year-old Manchester schoolboy Vijay Singh whose parents found the following entries in his diary in 1997:

"Monday: My money was taken. Tuesday: Names called. Wednesday: Uniform torn. Thursday: My body pouring with blood. Friday: It's ended. Saturday: Freedom."

Saturday was the day Vijay was found dead, hanging from the banister of his home by a silk scarf.

webTitle: TV Producer Endemol moves into Latin America

fields.headline: Endemol moves into Latin America
fields.trailText: 10.15am: The Dutch TV producer that originated Big Brother has acquired a majority stake in an Argentinian producer, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Endemol Entertainment, the Dutch TV producer responsible for Big Brother, has made its first move into Latin America with the acquisition of a majority stake in an Argentinian producer.

Producciones y Publicidad makes entertainment programming including magazine shows, talkshows and quizzes for Argentina's commercial TV stations and cable and satellite channels in other south American countries and the US.

Endemol did not diclose how much the P&P deal was worth, but said it may increase its stake in the company in the future. P&P, which was founded in 1996 and is based in Beunos Aires, also has an online subsidiary, P&P Digital.

Endemol is a subsidiary of Spanish telecoms and media giant Telefonica, following a takeover completed in July 2000. The company has a UK arm which produces shows including Changing Rooms, Miss World and Big Brother.

webTitle: The rise and rise of Metro, the free newspaper

fields.headline: Metro discovers Holy Grail
fields.standfirst: In 18 months it has become the sixth-largest national daily newspaper. It is finding new, young readers. And it's free.  Roy Greenslade on a smooth ride for the new freebie.
fields.trailText: In 18 months it has become the sixth-largest national daily newspaper. It is finding new, young readers. And it's free. Roy Greenslade on a smooth ride for the new freebie.
fields.body:
The economic outlook may be less rosy than a year ago but that hasn't stopped the onward march of Metro. The morning paper already distributed free to commuters in five regions will tomorrow be available in the Yorkshire cities of Leeds and Sheffield.

Newsprint costs are going to rise. There are gloomy predictions about falling advertising volumes and revenue. Last time this happened, local weekly frees suffered badly and many were killed off.

So why is Associated Newspapers, publisher of the Daily Mail, willing to expand its unprofitable paper? There appear to be a number of overlapping reasons. The company is certainly wealthy enough to afford the risk. Not that it is much of a risk anyway, given that the cost base is relatively low and the costs are, to an extent, controllable.

Having come so far since the launch of the first Metro in London in March, Associated certainly doesn't want to give any rival the chance to supplant it.

It stole a march on the continental inventors of the concept, Sweden's Modern Times group, by its initial negotiation of an exclusive contract with London underground and, in company with its partners, Trinity-Mirror, it has just forced the Swedes to retire hurt from Newcastle.

Associated is well aware of News International's close monitoring of the venture and knows that Rupert Murdoch is the one owner capable of making a swift intervention if it shows any sign of weakness.

So the Metros of London, Birmingham, central Scotland, Newcastle and Manchester (where the paper is entitled News North West) appear to have a firm future. Almost 800,000 are distributed at train and bus stations daily. The Yorkshire Metro, a partnership between Associated and Regional Independent Media, will add a further 55,000 from tomorrow, growing in March to 75,000.

To put that total in perspective, in strict circulation terms, it places Metro as the sixth largest national morning paper, above the Times and not far behind the Daily Express.

Associated has used formidable muscle to protect and enhance its venture, not least in Manchester where it has lost four court battles with its main competitor, Guardian Media Group, publisher of the Manchester Evening News and the Guardian.

GMG has not only protected its hold on its own Metro title, it is competing directly with Associated's News North West, which gives away some 120,000 copies, by distributing 80,000 Manchester Metros at bins in bus stations and through local bus companies. Associated is forced to spend money employing people to give out copies at traffic lights.

Mike Anderson, Metro's managing director, refuses to make any comment on this bitter newspaper war, or indeed any matter involving his paper. He is doubtless regretting his recent TV and radio interviews in which he launched an intemperate attack on the Manchester Evening News.

Last June, Associated even threatened to launch a free evening paper in Manchester, though a recent report that this might happen soon was swiftly discounted.

It would appear that Anderson's public sabre-rattling conceals a much more rational private negotiation between the two companies in which the more likely outcome will be an agreement eventually giving Manchester a single morning Metro.

The most sensible result would be a joint venture between Associated and GMG on the lines of the ones already in place in Newcastle and Yorkshire. Though Associated has played it tough, it has found it difficult to walk in on regions where there are strong local monopolies.

Newcastle is a case in point, where Trinity's morning Newcastle Journal and Evening Chronicle, jointly selling about 150,000 copies a day, retain the loyalty of Tynesiders.

There has undoubtedly been an impact on the sales of both since the Swedes launched Morning News in January 2000 and Associated-Trinity responded with Metro. With 100,000 of the former being given away on the city's underground system, and more than 60,000 of the latter being distributed too, a relatively small city was saturated with papers.

Even so, the down-turn in sales of the Journal and Chronicle has been very slight. Now, with the Swedes pulling out and agreeing to sell their paper to Associated and Trinity (subject to Department of Trade and Industry approval), the pressure on the paid-fors will probably ease. The reason, similar to experiences in every region where Metro is distributed, appears to stem from the fact that many Metro-readers don't buy other newspapers. Metros are expanding the market. In Newcastle, research shows that the total newspaper audience is greater than it has been for years.

No wonder Steve Brown, managing director of the Journal and Chronicle, is bubbling. He says: "The Metro is here to stay and we are all very excited by its possibilities. We see it as a key part of our product portfolio."

Ignoring the offputting management argot, it is clear that Brown's views mesh with those of Anderson and all at Associated who reel off figures which point to the Metro's appeal to a group they identify as "young urban commuters with a frenetic lifestyle".

In other words, Metro is attracting the newspaper equivalent of the holy grail: a new generation of young affluent consumers. According to researchers, 78% of Metro readers are under 44, one in three are under 24 and some 70% are ABC1.

Even allowing for exaggeration, and noting that the research was done on behalf of Metro, it is impressive. No other national paper can produce a similar readership profile for its advertisers. Then again, and I readily admit to the anecdotal nature of my own experience, I am not convinced that Metro is read in the same way as the paid-for dailies. Most people skim-read it, even on long tube journeys, and they discard it quickly.

Though Metro editor Tim Jotischky enthuses, "We have tapped into the lifestyle of young readers in a way no other paper has managed", it's difficult to find any justification for that claim in the rather bland content.

It is a very professional technical achievement, as one would expect from the Mail stable. It looks good and it is also very clean, leaving no ink on readers' hands.

Metro does provide a digest of national and international news which is presented in a fairly neutral way, though I imagine a competent media studies post-graduate would be able to show all manner of unconscious bias in both selection and presentation.

There is a good page of quizzes and crosswords. The sport, at least in London, isn't comprehensive enough. The listings are barely adequate.

Despite this, as I leave my commuter train at Victoria in the morning, I see scores of people go out of their way to pick up copies from the bins around the station.

On the Northern Line tube, the carriages overflow with Metros, almost all of them showing signs of having been read from cover to cover. Then, at the British Newspaper Library, the repository of every newspaper title you could imagine and more besides, there is a pile of Metros at the entrance and more copies in the refreshment lounge.

During their breaks from the microfiches and fading files of the world's great newspapers, these newspaper addicts inevitably pick up a Metro. Could there be a more auspicious augury for its future?
