webTitle: Lockerbie trial cut short

fields.headline: Lockerbie trial cut short
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: The two men accused of the Lockerbie bombing will not give evidence at their trial, defence lawyers announced today, and the final  submissions will begin at the Camp Zeist court in the Netherlands tomorrow.
fields.body:
The two men accused of the Lockerbie bombing will not give evidence at their trial, defence lawyers announced today, and the final submissions will begin at the Camp Zeist court in the Netherlands tomorrow.

The three Lockerbie judges are now expected to deliver their verdict within weeks. The legal submissions from both sides are expected to last two or three days.

The surprise move by the two lawyers for the two Libyans accused of blowing up Pan Am Flight 103 over the Scottish town means the defence case has lasted less than two days in a marathon 77-day trial which opened in May last year and heard evidence from 235 witnesses.

After months of prosecution witnesses, the defence lawyers finally began their case on December 5 on behalf of Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi, 48, and his co-accused Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, 44.

They both deny the bombing, in which an aircraft exploded over Lockerbie on December 21, 1988 killing 270 people. They have pleaded not guilty to conspiracy to murder, murder and a breach of the 1982 Aviation Security Act.

The defence case began last month with brief evidence about Palestinian terrorism. But the court was then adjourned for a month to give the lawyers more time to gather new evidence believed to be held by the Syrian authorities and believed to implicate a Palestinian liberation group in the bombing. Today the court heard that the Syrians had refused to cooperate - and William Taylor QC for Mr Megrahi and Richard Keen QC for Mr Fhimah then indicated that they did not intend to call the two defendants to give evidence.

The surprise ending of the evidence follows months of legal argument, frequent adjournments and hundreds of witnesses ranging from Lockerbie residents who saw the burning plane drop from the sky to baggage handlers at Frankfurt airport where the bomb is said to have been placed aboard the Pan Am flight bound for London and then to New York.

This week Mr Megrahi had been expected to take the stand as the defence attempted to establish that Palestinian terror groups, and not the Libyans, were responsible for the atrocity.

Then came the announcement in court today that the Syrians had refused to provide any documents which might have helped establish a link between the Lockerbie explosion and the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

After hearing from the two defence lawyers, presiding judge Lord Sutherland said the intention now was to adjourn the proceedings until tomorrow, when final submissions from prosecution and defence lawyers would begin.

Earlier, an FBI agent who turned out to be the final witness in the trial gave evidence. Lawrence Whitaker, 55, based at the FBI's Washington headquarters, told how he had been brought into the Lockerbie inquiry in February 1989 when he was sent to Germany to liaise with the then West German police.

In September that year he was shown round Frankfurt airport with other officers to see the encoding system for baggage and "to give us familiarity with what that area of the airport looked like".

Mr Whitaker told the court today that while being shown round he noticed one man who appeared to be an airport worker and who carried a single suitcase to a baggage rack and used a keypad to encode the destination. "He sent the bag on its way and wandered off. I have no knowledge of where he began or where he went. It was a portion of an event."

He added: "The only point we were making was that we had an individual carrying a bag into the system, and the amount of time to put it into the system was very small."

Later Lord Sutherland formally adjourned the court until tomorrow morning "when submissions for the Crown will be heard".

webTitle: News round-up

fields.headline: News round-up
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger has opened talks with Real Madrid over a possible £19m move for Ivan Helguera. Though the Spanish club are reluctant to sell the midfielder Arsenal are believed to have been given first option.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger has opened talks with Real Madrid over a possible £19m move for Ivan Helguera. Though the Spanish club are reluctant to sell the midfielder Arsenal are believed to have been given first option.

"Arsenal are a big club and there are a lot of great players there, but I have a contract at Real and it is up to them," Helguera told onefootball.com. "The money we are talking about is staggering.

"I'm a professional footballer and would never rule out anything. After La Liga English football is the next best thing and London is a lovely place to live."

Nigel Spackman is likely to be unveiled as Barnsley's new manager this afternoon. Spackman, whose only previous managerial experience at Sheffield United ended in March 1998, replaces Dave Bassett.

Fans have reacted with dismay to the decision to move Manchester United's Premiership clash with Arsenal to the same day as the Worthington Cup final, fearing that it will detract from the main event.

The game has been put back a day to Sunday February 25, so that it can be shown live on television, just hours before the showpiece event at Cardiff's Millennium Stadium. United's game with Everton was one of two Premiership ties on the day of the 1999 final.

webTitle: Mobile phone market: BT Cellnet still in 2nd place

fields.headline: BT Cellnet still in 2nd place
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Telecoms giant BT retained second place in the UK mobile phone market thanks to bumper Christmas sales figures, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Telecoms giant BT has held on to second place in the UK mobile phone market after announcing bumper Christmas sales figures.

Its BT Cellnet division gained an extra 1.5m customers between October and December last year, taking its total customer base to 10.2m.

"BT Cellnet has delivered record growth in a buoyant seasonal market. This is evidence that our ability to predict and respond imaginatively to the buying needs of the public has strengthened," said David McGlade, managing director of BT Cellnet.

The company needed record sales to stay ahead of close rival Orange, which saw its customer total increased to 9.83m thanks to roaring trade over Christmas. Vodafone is the UK market leader with 11.6m users.

Today's figures are a boost for BT as it prepares to launch its wireless division into a crowded stockmarket. Major players such as T-Mobile of Germany, Dutch operator KPN and France Telecom-owned Orange are set for flotations this year.

"Clearly we have to time the offer to get the best value, so we will choose our time carefully," said a BT Wireless spokesman.

BT hopes to raise £10bn from the partial sale of its subsidiary, but the amount of shares on offer may stretch investors' wallets to breaking point. The company is relying on a successful flotation to reduce its £30bn debt mountain.

"There will be a lot of paper coming out which will need to find a home if these companies are going to keep their plans on track," said Peter Caldwell, telecoms analyst at Greig Middleton.

The market reacted positively to BT's news, sending the shares up 2.5%, or 13.5p, to 646p in early trading.

webTitle: Secret files show Chinese leaders split on Tiananmen

fields.headline: Secret files show Chinese leaders split on Tiananmen
fields.trailText: Moderate Chinese leaders favoured a dialogue with the students in Tiananmen Square but were overruled by Communist party elders, a dossier of documents on the crisis in 1989 which led to the Beijing massacre has revealed.
fields.body:
Moderate Chinese leaders favoured a dialogue with the students in Tiananmen Square but were overruled by Communist party elders, a dossier of documents on the crisis in 1989 which led to the Beijing massacre has revealed.

Secret transcripts of the leaders' debate show that the veteran party and army leaders, headed by Deng Xiaoping, were enraged when the students went on hunger strike and erected a statue of "the goddess of democracy".

One said he was revolted by the statue, calling it "neither human nor demon".

Extracts will be published in New York tomorrow as the Tiananmen Papers, edited by the Andrew Nathan and Perry Link. They suggest that there was a real chance of peaceful dialogue between the party and the students until the prime minister, Li Peng, and other hardliners took advantage of the crisis.

"We can't confront the students with inflammatory or antagonistic propaganda anymore ..." the moderate politburo member Li Ruihuan argued earlier in the crisis.

"We should take a sober look at what has caused the strong rebellious streak in the popular mood in recent times. We said there would be no inflation, and then in fact inflation came."

Another, Tian Jiyun, urged "effective measures to clean up government and to accelerate our steps towards democracy."

The documents - amounting to about 15,000 pages in English - are said to have been brought out of China on computer disc by a disaffected official who wishes to "open up the question" of what happened in June 1989.

Some China specialists believe the operation is backed by reformers who want to tilt the balance against the hardliners, including Mr Li, before important party and state congresses in 2002-03, when new leaders will be selected.

The events of June 1989 are still not discussed in China, and many younger Chinese have no clear idea of what happened. Revelations published abroad are likely to circulate on the internet, despite official attempts to block access.

The documents confirm that Mr Li fully earned the epithet of "Butcher of Beijing" for the June 3-4 massacre.

He alarmed the aged leaders by telling them that Taiwanese and CIA agents were manipulating the students, and describing the mainly peaceful protest against the army as a "counter-revolutionary riot".

Deng and the elders, entitled to intervene in the event of a committee stalemate, had no hesitation in approving martial law.

"Give them no mercy!" the retired general Wang Zhen exploded. "These kids don't know how good they have got it. When we were their age we lived in a forest of rifles and a rain of bullets ... "Infantrymen led the way, firing into the air," the army reported to the leaders. "Then the soldiers - with the first two rows in a kneeling position and those in back standing - pointed their weapons at the crowd."

webTitle: Casting news: Sharon Stone ready to play Lana Turner

fields.headline: Sharon Stone ready to play Lana Turner
fields.standfirst: Plus: Mel Gibson signs up for story of Vietnam war bloodbath; Sopranos star goes behind bars for $5m pay cheque
fields.trailText: Plus: Mel Gibson signs up for story of Vietnam war bloodbath; Sopranos star goes behind bars for $5m pay cheque
fields.body:
 The Hollywood Reporter claims that Sharon Stone (pictured) is in talks to star in Stampanato, a film based on the real-life relationship between gangster Johnny Stampanato and actress Lana Turner. The trade paper said that Wayne Wang is in early negotiations to direct the movie. Turner's often violent relationship with Stampanato ended in 1959 when the movie star's 13-year-old daughter, Cheryl Crane, stabbed the gangster to death, reportedly in an effort to protect her mother.

 Gossip site Ain't It Cool News reports that Mel Gibson has signed up to appear in the Vietnam drama We Were Soldiers Once... And Young. The film will tell the story of Hal Moore, an American colonel who led 80 men into a small clearing in the Drang Valley of Vietnam in 1965 where they became involved in one of the bloodiest battles in US Military History. The film is set to be directed by Randall Wallace, who helmed The Man in the Iron Mask.

 James Gandolfini, star of TV's The Sopranos, is to be paid $5m (£3.3m) million to appear alongside Robert Redford in Rob Lurie's prison drama, The Castle. According to Variety, Gandolfini will play the warden of a maximum security military prison who comes across an old adversary - played by Redford - who is now an inmate. Filming is due to start in March.

webTitle: Stan scuppers Stuttgart move

fields.headline: Stan scuppers Stuttgart move
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore's failing career took another stumble today, after a proposed £500,000 move to Bundesliga side Vfb Stuttgart fell apart over the Bradford striker's contract demands.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore's failing career took another stumble today, after a proposed £500,000 move to Bundesliga side Vfb Stuttgart fell apart over the Bradford striker's contract demands.

Collymore, 29, has been told by Bantams boss Jim Jefferies that he has no future at Valley Parade despite only joining the club 10 weeks ago. The relegation-threatened side accepted an offer from Stuttgart over the weekend, but Collymore and lawyer Jonathan Crystal did not even fly to Germany to hold negotiations, and discussions took place over the telephone instead.

It is understood that Stuttgart were willing to offer Collymore a short-term contract until the end of the season with the option of a further year, similar to the one he signed at Bradford upon his arrival from Leicester at the end of October.

But the 29-year-old is believed to have demanded a two-and-a-half year deal, which officials from the German club baulked at due to Collymore's chequered history and wage demands of £20,000 per week.

It now leaves the former Liverpool, Aston Villa and Nottingham Forest forward searching for his ninth club in an 11-season career.

Meanwhile, fellow big-name stars Benito Carbone and Dan Petrescu could also be set to leave Valley Parade.

Jefferies, who has been forced to cut the club's wage bill, is believed to have no time for flair players in his struggling side. The Scot is likely to make an announcement on the players' futures after tonight's FA Cup third round tie at home to Middlesbrough.

webTitle: Clinton's peace pleas fall on deaf ears

fields.headline: Clinton's peace pleas fall on deaf ears
fields.standfirst: Bill Clinton had been hoping to climax his presidency with a Middle East peace deal, but, as Derek Brown explains, even his last-ditch pleading is unlikely to change anything
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton had been hoping to climax his presidency with a Middle East peace deal, but, as Derek Brown explains, even his last-ditch pleading is unlikely to change anything.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton has been reduced to pleading with the Israelis and Palestinians to think again about his bold but naive plan for a final settlement.

His latest public musings about the need for compromise are little more than an acknowledgement that the game is up. Barring a miracle, the treaty that Clinton craved throughout his presidency is not going to be signed before he steps down in just 12 days time.

The Palestinians today explicitly rejected the Clinton formula, which would give them a state but meet few of their other basic demands.

"These ideas don't offer our people their legitimate rights," said senior Palestinian negotiator Ahmed Korei.

The phrase "legitimate rights" is redolent of countless Palestinian statements and speeches. Yasser Arafat and his followers don't just want a country - they want their dignity to be restored.

Specifically, they want Israelis and their American sponsors to understand that they belong to Palestine, even if the land no longer belongs to them.

Since the establishment of Israel in 1948, Palestinians have streamed out of their ancestral lands. Many of them, and their second and third-generation descendants, still feel passionately that their lost homes and farms should somehow be restored to them.

Israel, for obvious reasons, baulks at the idea of accommodating up to 4m Palestians. Clinton backs their objection. Indeed, he seems to take it as axiomatic.

"Israel is a little country, and this will make it smaller," he said of his plan in a weekend speech. He couldn't have put it more badly, from a Palestinian point of view.

Most are prepared to go along with Arafat's de-facto recognition, implicit in the 1993 Oslo peace accords, of Israel's existence and right to security.

But - and this is a vital qualification - they have never accepted, and never will, Israel's right to the lands it conquered in the six-day war of 1967: the West Bank, the Gaza Strip, and East Jerusalem.

The Clinton plan, boiled down to basics, would not shrink Israel, but actually expand it. Swathes of Jerusalem and vital chunks of the West Bank would be recognised internationally, for the first time, as part of the Zionist state.

Israeli troops would still be stationed along the Jordan valley and in other strategically important positions close to West Bank cities.

Thousands of Jewish settlers would remain. The occupation, in short, would continue.

Palestinians find it impossible to think of their country as the truncated and divided land that Clinton is offering them. For them, Palestine is all the land between the Jordan and the Mediterranean.

What is being dangled before them is not much more than 20% of that land. That they should have come so close to accepting the Clinton formula is remarkable.

No less remarkable has been the Israeli government's willingness to contemplate, from the other side of the Middle East looking glass, the establishment of an Arafat-led Palestinian sovereign state.

Israelis, just like the Palestinians, have their own distinctive view of themselves and of the land. For the religious, Israel is a God-given gift that cannot be divided or haggled over.

For the more secular minded, Israel is a tiny, vulnerable sliver of democracy, surrounded by Arab states that are mostly despotic and uniformly hostile.

Most Israelis, whatever their politics, have been shocked by the most emotive issue that has been raised by the Clinton formula: the final status of Jerusalem.

The ingenious but complex idea was that Israel would retain the sprawling Jewish colonies it has spawned since 1967, but that the Palestinians would take back the Arab quarters, including most of the walled Old City.

Crucially, the plan involved the division of the Jerusalem site most holy to Muslims and Jews. The former would control the Haram al-Sharif mosque complex; the latter the Western Wall.

Jerusalem is the most divided and divisive city in the world. Today, after nearly 34 years of Israeli control, the line between Jewish and non-Jewish neighbourhoods is palpable.

Of course it was tempting for the diplomatic wonks of Washington to draw another fine line on the city map, but they ignored the most important division of all, in the hearts and minds of its inhabitants.

Today, thousands of militant Israelis will converge on Jerusalem to assert their eternal claim. Palestinians too have threatened a mass march on the city where Arafat insists he will establish his capital.

Amid such swirling emotions, and with nerves scraped raw by more than three months of violent confrontation, Bill Clinton's pleas for compromise, goodwill and reason, are more irrelevant than ever.

webTitle: Excerpts: Clinton's Israeli-Palestinian peace plan

fields.headline: Excerpts: Clinton's Israeli-Palestinian peace plan
fields.standfirst:
Following are extracts from the US president's address on Sunday 7 January to the Israeli Policy Forum in New York
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText:
Extracts from the US president's address on Sunday 7 January to the Israeli Policy Forum in New York.
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.body:
"Given the impasse and the tragic deterioration on the ground, a couple of weeks ago both sides asked me to present my ideas. So I put forward parameters that I wanted to be a guide toward a comprehensive agreement, parameters based on eight years of listening carefully to both sides and hearing them describe with increasing clarity their respective grievances and needs.

"Both Prime Minister Barak and Chairman Arafat have now accepted these parameters as the basis for further efforts.

"Both have expressed some reservations. At their request, I am using my remaining time in office to narrow the differences between the parties to the greatest degree possible.

"The parameters I put forward contemplate a settlement in response to each side's essential needs, if not to their utmost desires. A settlement based on sovereign homelands, security, peace and dignity for both Israelis and Palestinians...

"Here they are: First, I think there can be no genuine resolution to the conflict without a sovereign, viable, Palestinian state that accommodates Israeli's security requirements and the demographic realities.

"That suggests Palestinian sovereignty over Gaza, the vast majority of the West Bank, the incorporation into Israel of settlement blocks, with the goal of maximising the number of settlers in Israel while minimising the land annex, for Palestine, to be viable, must be a geographically contiguous state.

"Now, the land annexed into Israel into settlement blocks should include as few Palestinians as possible, consistent with the logic of two separate homelands. And to make the agreement durable, I think there will have to be some territorial swaps and other arrangements.

"Second, a solution will have to be found for the Palestinian refugees who have suffered a great deal - particularly some of them. A solution that allows them to return to a Palestinian state that will provide all Palestinians with a place they can safely and proudly call home.

"All Palestinian refugees who wish to live in this homeland should have the right to do so. All others who want to find new homes, whether in their current locations or in third countries, should be able to do so, consistent with those countries' sovereign decisions. And that includes Israel.

"All refugees should receive compensation from the international community for their losses, and assistance in building new lives.

"Now, you all know what the rub is. That was a lot of artful language for saying that you cannot expect Israel to acknowledge an unlimited right of return to present day Israel, and at the same time, to give up Gaza and the West Bank and have the settlement blocks as compact as possible, because of where a lot of these refugees came from.

"We cannot expect Israel to make a decision that would threaten the very foundations of the state of Israel, and would undermine the whole logic of peace. And it shouldn't be done.

"But I have made it very clear that the refugees will be a high priority, and that the United States will take a lead in raising the money necessary to relocate them in the most appropriate manner.

"If the government of Israel or a subsequent government of Israel ever will be in charge of their immigration policy, just as we and the Canadians and the Europeans and others who would offer Palestinians a home would be, they would be obviously free to do that, and I think they've indicated that they would do that, to some extent.

"But there cannot be an unlimited language in an agreement that would undermine the very foundations of the Israeli state or the whole reason for creating the Palestinian state.

"Third, there will be no peace, and no peace agreement, unless the Israeli people have lasting security guarantees. These need not and should not come at the expense of Palestinian sovereignty, or interfere with Palestinian territorial integrity.

"So my parameters rely on an international presence in Palestine to provide border security along the Jordan Valley and to monitor implementation of the final agreement.

"They rely on a non-militarised Palestine, a phased Israeli withdrawal, to address Israeli security needs in the Jordan Valley, and other essential arrangements to ensure Israel's ability to defend itself.

"Fourth, I come to the issue of Jerusalem, perhaps the most emotional and sensitive of all. It is a historic, cultural and political centre for both Israelis and Palestinians, a unique city sacred to all three monotheistic religions. And I believe the parameters I have established flow from four fair and logical propositions.

"First, Jerusalem should be an open and undivided city, with assured freedom of access and worship for all. It should encompass the internationally recognised capitals of two states, Israel and Palestine.

"Second, what is Arab should be Palestinian, for why would Israel want to govern in perpetuity the lives of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians?

"Third, what is Jewish should be Israeli. That would give rise to a Jewish Jerusalem, larger and more vibrant than any in history.

"Fourth, what is holy to both requires a special care to meet the needs of all. No peace agreement will last if not premised on mutual respect for the religious beliefs and holy shrines of Jews, Muslims and Christians.

"Fifth, and finally, any agreement will have to mark the decision to end the conflict, for neither side can afford to make these painful compromises, only to be subjected to further demands ...

"And the end of the conflict must manifest itself with concrete acts that demonstrate a new attitude and a new approach by Palestinians and Israelis toward each other, and by other states in the region toward Israel, and by the entire region toward Palestine, to help it get off to a good start.

"Now, I've got 13 days and I'll do what I can. We're working with Egypt and the parties to try to end the violence. I'm sending Dennis Ross to the region this week. I met with both sides this week. I hope we can really do something. ...

"It could happen. But somebody has got to take the long leap, and they have to be somebodies on both sides.''

That would give rise to a Jewish Jerusalem, larger and more vibrant than any in history. "Fourth, what is holy to both requires a special care to meet the needs of all. No peace agreement will last if not premised on mutual respect for the religious beliefs and holy shrines of Jews, Muslims and Christians. "Fifth, and finally, any agreement will have to mark the decision to end the conflict, for neither side can afford to make these painful compromises, only to be subjected to further demands ... "And the end of the conflict must manifest itself with concrete acts that demonstrate a new attitude and a new approach by Palestinians and Israelis toward each other, and by other states in the region toward Israel, and by the entire region toward Palestine, to help it get off to a good start. "Now, I've got 13 days and I'll do what I can. We're working with Egypt and the parties to try to end the violence. I'm sending Dennis Ross to the region this week. I met with both sides this week. I hope we can really do something. ... "It could happen. But somebody has got to take the long leap, and they have to be somebodies on both sides.'' webTitle: Liberty Surf takeover by Tiscali confirmed

fields.headline: Liberty Surf takeover by Tiscali confirmed
fields.standfirst:
9.30am: Liberty Surf set for takeover by Tiscali
Jan 5: Liberty Surf in UK closure speculation
Jan 4 Liberty Surf tight lipped on merger
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Italian Internet service provider Tiscali has confirmed that it has snapped up French rival Liberty Surf in a £570m deal, reports Dan Milmo.

9.30am: Liberty Surf set for takeover by Tiscali
Jan 5: Liberty Surf in UK closure speculation
Jan 4 Liberty Surf tight lipped on merger
fields.body:
Italian Internet service provider Tiscali has confirmed its leading role in consolidating an overcrowded sector by snapping up French rival Liberty Surf in a deal valuing the company at £570m.

It is the third major acquisition for Tiscali, following its recent purchase of Dutch portal World Online for £3bn and German company AddCom for £18m.

Tiscali said the move will take it to 10.7m registered users and 4.9m active users across Europe, giving it second or third positions in Italy, France, the Netherlands and Belgium.

However, analysts raised fears that Tiscali may have overpaid and overstretched itself in buying the company.

"I don't think Tiscali can continue with a subscriber base in 15 countries and not have a dominant position in any one of them. I expect a shift in focus over the next few months. They have to decide whether they continue to expand or consolidate," said Tareq Robbiati, senior analyst at Lehman Brothers.

Other analysts questioned the value of the deal, at a time when plunging internet stocks have drastically reduced the worth of ISPs. The dramatic change in fortune for the sector has sparked a wave of consolidation which saw the UK's Freserve sold to Wanadoo of France in December.

"Tiscali has overpaid. Liberty Surf is a business which is haemorrhaging cash and only has a small cash component left," said one analyst.

Even the big players in the European market, such as T-Online of Germany, have been hit by fears over the viability of their business models.

UK retail group Kingfisher Plc will certainly benefit from the deal, after accepting £149m for its 37% stake in the company.

"Liberty Surf has been a successful e-commerce venture for Kingfisher. With the European ISP market now consolidating, today's deal enables us to realise this value created for our shareholders," said Geoff Mulcahy, Kingfisher chief executive.

The other main shareholder in Liberty Surf is Euro@web, which is owned by French entrepreneur Bernard Arnault, who invested in doomed online retailer boo.com.

Liberty Surf is the second largest ISP in France, with 600,000 users and a total of 730,000 across Europe, placing it far behind bigger competitors such as Terra Lycos of Spain and compatriot Wanadoo.

webTitle: Number One hit for Channel 4

fields.headline: Number One hit for Channel 4
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Channel 4 pulled off the rare feat of beating ITV and BBC1 on Saturday night with its 100 Greatest Number Ones, topped by John Lennon's Imagine, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4 pulled off the rare feat of beating ITV and BBC1 in the ratings late on Saturday night, with its 100 Greatest Number One Singles. At one point the show had almost 6m viewers, giving it a comfortable lead over Gary Lineker's Match of the Day which got an average of 3.8m viewers.

The show, which culminated with the revelation that John Lennon's Imagine was once again deemed the all time greatest Number One single, pulled in average of 4.1m - one in five viewers - across the marathon four hour period. But it pulled in 5.7m the final 45 minutes from 11.15pm to midnight.

It was enough to seal its place as the most watched programme on any channel, an impressive feat for a Channel 4 show. ITV film The Assassin which was up against the top 100 show for the final 45 minutes pulled in just 2.8m viewers.

The Graham Norton-fronted chart show started out with 2.3m at 8pm and built to a peak of 5.9m - a 38% share - in the quarter hour from 11.30pm.

Earlier on Saturday night ITV drama Mind Games, a one-off about a police psychological profiler created by Lynda La Plante, only managed a so-so 6.7m and a 30% share over two hours from 9.10pm.

But it still got the better of BBC1's Jonathan Creek repeat, which had 5.3m from 9pm, and the return of Simon Nye-scripted sitcom Beast, with managed just 4.2m from 9.50pm.

BBC1 had an equally miserable time with its late evening entertainment output on Friday night.

A cobbled together mix of new and old Harry Enfield material, Tim Nice but Dim's Guide to Being a Bloody Nice Bloke, had 4.5m and a 19% share from 9pm.

They Think It's All Over followed up at 9.30pm with 4.8m. After the Ten O'Clock News, Clive Anderson Now, a new series taking a satirical look at the past seven days, had just 3.6m. Both attracted just one in five viewers.

ITV had more success on Friday night with documentary Some Liked It Hot, a look at the evolution of the British seaside holiday from oral-history specialist Steve Humphries, which had 5.7m and a 28% share, 10-11pm.

Graham Norton's standing as one of the leading faces of Channel 4 was reinforced with Ah-So Graham Norton, a special edition of his popular Friday night entertainment show shot in Japan. The show had 3.6m and a 23% share over 65 minutes from 10.30pm.

Before that, US sitcom Frasier's eighth series opened strongly. An hour-long special focusing on the fall-out from Niles and Daphne finally getting together also pulled in 3.6m.

webTitle: Navidad con anorexia no es Navidad

fields.headline: Navidad con anorexia no es Navidad
fields.standfirst: For many thousands of anorexia and bulimia sufferers in Spain, Christmas celebrations round a food-laden table will have been a nightmare, says Eulölia Furriol
fields.trailText: Las fiestas de Navidad se celebran en España con la familia alrededor de una mesa. Mucha familia y mucha comida. Son días de mucha fiesta. Pero para las casi ochenta mil personas que sufren en España anorexia o bulimia son días de sufrimiento. La mayoría son jóvenes mujeres entre catorce y veinticuatro años. Las personas que sufren anorexia se obsesionan por el cuerpo y tienen pánico a engordar. Las personas que sufren bulimia comen compulsivamente y luego vomitan. Cuatro jóvenes nos cuentan su experiencia con esta enfermedad y nos dan su opinión. Blanca ha superado la enfermedad. Carolina está en tratamiento por anorexia y Lourdes está en tratamiento por bulimia. Carolina y Lourdes van cada día a terapia. Y Rodri es el novio de Carolina.
fields.body:
Las fiestas de Navidad se celebran en España con la familia alrededor de una mesa. Mucha familia y mucha comida. Son días de mucha fiesta. Pero para las casi ochenta mil personas que sufren en España anorexia o bulimia son días de sufrimiento. La mayoría son jóvenes mujeres entre catorce y veinticuatro años. Las personas que sufren anorexia se obsesionan por el cuerpo y tienen pánico a engordar. Las personas que sufren bulimia comen compulsivamente y luego vomitan. Cuatro jóvenes nos cuentan su experiencia con esta enfermedad y nos dan su opinión. Blanca ha superado la enfermedad. Carolina está en tratamiento por anorexia y Lourdes está en tratamiento por bulimia. Carolina y Lourdes van cada día a terapia. Y Rodri es el novio de Carolina.

¿Qué es la anorexia? ¿Y la bulimia?
Lourdes (18 años): Anorexia y bulimia es lo mismo. Es buscar ser aceptada, y no sólo por tu cuerpo sino también por tu personalidad. Quieres ser la persona perfecta. Piensas que dejando de comer se soluciona todo.
Carolina (19 años): Un trastorno mental que afecta a la alimentación. Es pnico a engordar y detrás hay muchas más cosas: pánico a crecer, a afrontar la vida, a fracasar, a querer y no ser correspondido, miedo a ser independiente. Es una vía de escape como puede ser el alcohol, las drogas o el juego.
Blanca (21 años): Es un deseo de superación.

¿Por qué afecta principalmente a mujeres jóvenes?
Lourdes: Creces y miras a las modelos y a la gente guapa. Conoces a chicos y te preguntas si les gustas. Yo pensaba que no valía nada.
Carolina: La sociedad y los padres exigen demasiado a los jóvenes. Ahora hay niñas y niños de seis años también con anorexia.
Rodri: Es más fácil influenciar a los adolescentes. Ellos son bombardeados con mensajes sobre la belleza, el cuerpo, la competitividad, el éxito y no hay mensajes sobre la comunicación o aceptar el fracaso.
Blanca: Yo cambié muy rápido y no lo asumí. Me sentía inferior y quería seguir como antes, como niña. Yo a los once años empecé a tener ideas raras, y a los trece tenía anorexia. Me preocupaba de forma exagerada por mi imagen, por lo que comía, por lo que hacía en general.

¿Cómo prevenir?
Lourdes: Con más información. Cuando enfermas te das cuenta de que hay algo que no funciona pero no quieres cambiarlo. Y no quieres que los demás se den cuenta. Para prevenir puede ser más eficaz hacer campañas de información a los padres.
Rodri: Es muy difícil. En nuestra sociedad vende la imagen y un cuerpo de anuncio. Prevenir es cambiar este chip. Y decir que se pueden hacer mucho daño.
Blanca: No es fácil detectarlo porque cualquier niña hoy hace régimen. Piensas que no te pasará nada por perder un par de kilos. Las campañas no ayudan mucho y pueden provocar el espíritu de contradicción.

¿Cómo afrontar la enfermedad?
Blanca: Lo importante es hablar para admitirlo. Y aceptar ayuda. Es complicado, porque curarte es engordar, y no quieres. Esto es lo más difícil.
Lourdes: Trabajar con los grupos de terapia, oír los testimonios de otras personas. Es imprescindible que te obliguen a ser honesto, a decir toda la verdad de lo que sientes y haces. Todo.
Carolina: Para mí era vivir una enfermedad crónica, curarme o morir. No podía seguir en aquel infierno. Entonces ingresé en un hospital diez horas al día. Tenía diecisiete años, pero desde los catorce ya estaba mal.
Rodri: Afrontarlo es poner la salud por delante de todo. Es imprescindible buscar a profesionales.

¿Y la reacción de las personas de tu entorno?
Lourdes: Sabían que estaba enferma. Además tomaba también drogas y alcohol. Estaba muy mal y no estaba nunca en casa. Mis padres se asustaron. Yo soy de Menorca y vine a vivir a Barcelona con mi hermana para la terapia.
Carolina: Yo era muy irritable e histérica, y gritaba a mis padres. Mi madre todavía hoy tiene miedo a mis reacciones.
Rodri: Las personas del entorno necesitan mucha paciencia y optimismo. Es un proceso muy largo. Es importante informarse para poder ayudar y mantener la calma en los momentos de crispación. Las personas que suffran no quieren ayuda porque no tienen conciencia de que están enfermas. Distorsionan la realidad.
Blanca: Mi familia estaba sorprendida. Fue horrible. En casa había muchos gritos, discusiones y tensión.

¿Cómo vive la Navidad una persona con anorexia?
Lourdes: Con angustia. Para nosotras es engordar. No disfrutas ni dejas disfrutar a tu familia. Con la familia nos volvemos agresivas y no quieres ver a los amigos.
Carolina: Con mucho miedo. Es un infierno. Es contar las horas que quedan antes de comer.
Rodri: Puede ser un reto, una prueba muy difícil. Si están muy enfermas la obsesión por la comida borra todo lo demás.
Blanca: Con miedo a las comidas en familia. Sientes que te pondrán más comida que a los demás, que te miran y te controlan.

Glosario/Glossary

la angustia anguish, distress
la crispación tension, agitation
engordar to put on weight
el régimen diet
la vía de escape way out
fracasar to fail
el trastorno mental disorder
imprescindible essential
el chip way of thinking (colloquial)
el reto challenge
el/la modelo model

webTitle: In brief: Julia and Mel named America's top stars

fields.headline: Julia and Mel named America's top stars
fields.standfirst: Plus: Mr and Mrs Michael Douglas wish you were here; Three-hour Taiwanese film beats US films to top American prize; Two new Batman movies in the pipeline - strikes permitting
fields.trailText: Plus: Mr and Mrs Michael Douglas wish you were here; Three-hour Taiwanese film beats US films to top American prize; Two new Batman movies in the pipeline - strikes permitting
fields.body:
Julia Roberts (pictured) and Mel Gibson are officially America's Favourite Film Stars after winning the top prizes at the People's Choice Awards on Sunday. As Hollywood's most bankable star, Roberts is being slated as a possible Oscar contender for Erin Brockovich, while Gibson appears to have won around the American cinema-going public, after the comparative failure of The Patriot, with the comedy What Women Want (released in the UK on February 2). The People's Choice Awards are chosen by a nationwide Gallup telephone poll, which uses a random sampling of 1,200 individuals who are given no suggestions or nominees and can vote for any person or film they choose for each category. Stephen King's supernatural death row tale The Green Mile won Favourite Motion Picture and Favourite Motion Picture Drama. Jim Carrey was named Favourite Motion Picture Star in a Comedy.

 Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas, soon to be seen in Steven Soderbergh's Traffic, are to appear on ITV's Wish You Were Here, singing the praises of Bermuda in a special March episode, according to the Daily Mirror. The newlyweds, who are hoping to buy a holiday home on the island, will be seen talking about the idyllic lifestyle in the British colony whilst walking along the sun-kissed beaches.

 Edward Yang's epic family drama Yi Yi (aka A One And A Two) was named Best Picture of 2000 by the National Society Of Film Critics on Saturday in New York. The Society, which comprises 50 leading US film critics, gave the three-hour Taiwanese film 34 votes. Steven Soderbergh's Traffic came second and Terence Davies' The House of Mirth took third place. Soderbergh, however, beat Yang in the Best Director category for both Traffic and Erin Brockovich. Other winners included Laura Linney, Best Actress for You Can Count on Me, and Javier Bardem, Best Actor for Before Night Falls. Benicio Del Toro was named Best Supporting Actor for Traffic, while Elaine May won Best Supporting Actress for Woody Allen's Small Time Crooks. Screen Daily has a full list of the winners.

 Warner Bros has confirmed that it is developing two separate Batman films over the next two years. Entertainment Weekly reports that Batman: Year One will describe the first year of the Caped Crusader's existence, while Batman Beyond will be set in the future when a young upstart takes over the Batman mantle from Bruce Wayne. Production on both films, it was reported, will be dependent on the outcome of possible industry strikes this summer, making it unlikely that either will be released for at least two years.

webTitle: Manchester United axes 48 in-house merchandising jobs

fields.headline: Manchester United axes 48 in-house merchandising jobs
fields.trailText: 12pm: Manchester United is cutting its in-house merchandising staff by nearly half reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Manchester United is cutting its in-house merchandising staff by nearly half and moving to develop more partnerships with external operators.

Over the next 12 months 48 jobs are to be axed at Man Utd's Old Trafford headquarters, leaving 50 people in the football club's merchandising operation.

The club is switching to a new strategy of striking partnerships with firms around the world to develop and promote Man Utd-branded products, rather than running a one-stop-shop in-house merchandising operation.

At present Man Utd's merchandising division plans, designs, produces and promotes branded goods for the club.

Peter Kenyon, chief executive of the club, said: "Although this has been a difficult decision to take, the restructuring of merchandising is designed to ensure the business is best placed to meet the challenges of the future. Every effort will be made to find alternative employment for those whose positions are withdrawn in the restructuring."

The club's shops business will be unaffected by the changes.

webTitle: Eriksson on the brink as Lazio lose again

fields.headline: Eriksson on the brink as Lazio lose again
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson is to meet with Lazio chairman Sergio Cragnotti this afternoon amidst intense speculation that his time as coach of the Italian champions is set to come to an end. The emergency meeting was called after Lazio lost 2-1 at home to relegation-threatened Napoli last night.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson is to meet with Lazio chairman Sergio Cragnotti this afternoon amidst intense speculation that his time as coach of the Italian champions is set to come to an end. The emergency meeting was called after Lazio lost 2-1 at home to relegation-threatened Napoli last night.

Cragnotti was forthright in his comments regarding England's next coach after the defeat. "The players still had Christmas cake in their feet," he said. "On Monday I will meet with Eriksson to try and understand how this has happened and to see how we can find the way out of this tunnel."

Eriksson, who was not expected to fully take up his new role until the summer, has been the subject of criticism in Italy ever since he accepted the England role, and his record this season has not helped. Lazio have lost four times in 13 Serie A games this season, and they stand pointless at the foot of their Champions League group.

Earlier, Football Association spokesman David Davies inferred that the FA were aware of Eriksson's fragile position. "We are keeping more than a close eye on Lazio's results," he admitted. "We want Sven-Goran Eriksson to do well and we are disappointed when Lazio do not win."

Davies then re-stated that Eriksson would still be featuring in the build-up to England's friendly against Spain next month, followed by the World Cup qualifying matches against Finland and Albania. "He will be involved in all our key games until the end of the season," he said.

"Adam Crozier will be meeting with them in the next couple of weeks and we will attempt to resolve any uncertainty about the future. We have a good relationship with Sergio Gragnotti and Sven-Goran Eriksson.

But he added: "It has been made clear that Peter Taylor will be in charge for the game against Spain in February."

webTitle: Football ace Ronaldo to testify on sponsor Nike

fields.headline: Football ace Ronaldo to testify on sponsor Nike
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Brazilian football ace Ronaldo is set to reveal whether sponsor Nike forced him to play in the 1998 World Cup Final, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Brazilian football ace Ronaldo will tell official investigators this week whether team sponsor Nike forced him to play in the 1998 World Cup Final, despite him carrying an injury.

Any revelation that the sports brand leveraged its multi-million backing to influence team selection would cause one of the biggest scandals in sponsorship history.

Ronaldo is scheduled to appear before the government's congressional committee in Brasilia investigating soccer corruption on Wednesday.

Officials want to know whether Nike, which sponsors both Ronaldo and the Brazilian Soccer Confederation, insisted that he play in the 1998 final against France.

Just hours before the final the 1997 Fifa player of the year suffered serious convulsions and was left out of the team.

However shortly before kick off Nike's talisman surprisingly re-appeared on the team sheet and turned in a lacklustre performance. Brazil lost 3-0.

Nike and former team coach Mario Zagallo have denied the accusations.

Zagallo claims Ronald begged him to play, assuring the coach he had been cleared by doctors. But it appears the testimonies of other members of the Brazilian camp contradict these claims.

The Nike sponsorship deal was one of the biggest ever signed worldwide and was worth £300m over 10 years.

webTitle: Mad remedies

fields.headline: Mad remedies
fields.standfirst: One drug makes you faint or twitch. Another costs a lot. Guess which one schizophrenics are given.
fields.trailText: One drug makes you faint or twitch. Another costs a lot. Guess which one schizophrenics are given? Jay Rayner reports.
fields.body:
The brave minds that formulated the government's white paper on reforms to the Mental Health Act, published last month, could have done a lot worse than consult a young woman called Emma Harding when they were shaping their grand vision. Ms Harding could have given them a stark and disturbing insight into what their plans might really mean. But in the world of policy and principle people like Ms Harding rarely are consulted. Too much raw human experience, the stuff of which nightmares are made, can get in the way of a good, headline-grabbing ministerial announcement.

Ms Harding is a project worker in the mental health field, a job for which she is well qualified. As well as being trained in psychology she was diagnosed five years ago with schizophrenia. She was placed on a course of medication that had a pretty immediate effect: her blood pressure plummeted like a stone. "I kept fainting a lot and waking up on the floor wondering how I'd got there," she says now. She was moved on to another drug but it too had vicious side effects. She developed pronounced muscle spasms and twitches in her hands and, most worryingly, a condition called oculogyric crisis in which the eye balls roll up involuntarily into the head. "I ended up looking like a zombie and not wanting to socialise with anybody," she says.

And so to a third drug and a third set of side effects: twitching legs and feet, sudden memory loss, restlessness leading to anxiety - a combination that almost lost Ms Harding her job. Unsurprisingly, she stopped taking the drugs which, though detrimental in other ways, had controlled the symptoms of her schizophrenia. Now they came roaring back. "One evening I found myself talking to my laundry basket. I was asking it what it had done with all my friends." She swiftly hospitalised herself.

Many people with schizophrenia will find Ms Harding's story horribly familiar. She had experienced the terrible side effects - some of which, like Parkinsonian shakes and tremors, can be permanent - of a group of drugs known as typical antipsychotics. Happily there are alternatives, a relatively new group of drugs called atypical antipsychotics which have fewer and less severe side effects. Ms Harding's schizophrenia is now controlled by one of them.

But there are many people who, because of plans recently announced by home secretary Jack Straw and secretary of state for health Alan Milburn, will not be as fortunate as Ms Harding. Under the government's new mental health proposals, they will be forced to take the older drugs, regardless of the grim consequences; consequences that many users describe as even worse than the symptoms of schizophrenia itself.

When the white paper was published much of the attention was focused on plans for people with untreatable personality disorders to be locked up without trial, a troubling enough move in itself. But the paper also included another proposal: the introduction of compulsory treatment orders under which people with schizophrenia who, for whatever reason, had stopped taking their medication, could be taken to hospital and be forced to take their drugs.

The problem is that the only drugs that can be given involuntarily to a subject are those that can be administered by injection or, ideally, by depot, a slow release dose inserted painfully deep into the muscle which can seep into the blood stream for a month or more. And the only drugs available in that form are the old typicals with their vicious side effects. The new drugs can be taken by mouth in tablet or jelly form, but in no other way. Injectable forms are under development but none is even close to being ready for use.

Only the woolly-minded would argue that there are no circumstances under which a person with schizophrenia should be forced to take their drugs. While the vast majority of those with the condition, which affects 1% of the population, are going to pose no danger, there will always be a few who, unmedicated, will present some form of risk, if only to themselves. The uncontrollable psychotic, gripped by paranoia, who tries to crash a packed Jumbo jet, may be one such example.

Nevertheless, the state should not be administering drugs that damage the health of already vulnerable people. It doesn't need to happen. The current situation has emerged from a complete failure of what Tony Blair trumpeted in the early days as "joined-up government".

One of the main reasons why people stop taking their medication - the reason why they would need to be the subject of one of the new compulsory treatment orders - is because, like Ms Harding, they can no longer stand the side effects. The solution for most of them is to be switched to the less harmful atypicals.

However, the atypicals are much more expensive than the typicals and, like so many other drugs with a large price tag attached, have been the subject of "postcode prescribing". Their availability is dependent purely on the attitude of whichever health authority the patient happens to find themselves under. One survey of Britain's psychiatrists found that more than half were continuing to prescribe the older toxic drugs for financial reasons.

There is no doubt the atypicals are costly: they account for 16% of schizophrenia prescriptions but 76% of the overall drug costs. But that is to look at the cost of the care of schizophrenia in only the narrowest sense. It takes a far greater proportion of the health and welfare budget to care for someone who refuses to take their medication because of the side effects, if they end up unable to work and needing the attentions of more doctors, more nurses and more social workers.

This is a job for the National Institute of Clinical Excellence (Nice), which was set up specifically, to look at issues such as this. But it was only announced that it would be looking at these groups of drugs as the mental health white paper was published. The logical way forward would have been for Nice to issue a "guidance" giving the green light for mass prescribing of atypicals before the government introduced its heavy-handed proposals for dealing with those with acute mental problems.

However, Nice will not report until the end of this year, by which time the government's proposals will already be working their way towards becoming law.

Many working in mental health are concerned that Nice will ignore the side-effects issue and fail to find in favour of the atypicals. A survey published last month by the National Schizophrenia Fellowship found that more than 60% of those with the illness had never been offered an alternative drug. More than 40% had never received anything in writing about the side effects they might experience. In short, many clinicians seem to be rather poor at listening to the people they are meant to be helping. The government is in danger of repeating the pattern.

Professor Louis Appleby, the national director of mental health, appointed last April, says that neither he nor the government has anything against atypicals. "But we do want Nice to look at this question and reach a guidance." He also says he is a firm believer in people having a say in their treatment "and the white paper serves them better in that respect". There is no reason to doubt the professor's integrity nor to question the commitment of the Department of Health (DoH). The DoH is shortly to launch a major campaign to counter discrimination against mentally ill people. The problem lies with the other signature on the white paper: that of home secretary Jack Straw.

Because whatever the paper may have to say about reform of the Mental Health Act, this was, as far as the Home Office is concerned, a law and order initiative. It was about banging up dangerous freaks and making mad men and women do as they were told. It was about making voters feel safer in their homes.

Since law and order will be one of the major battlegrounds of the coming election, it was simply not on the cards that legislation would be delayed while clinicians reached their judgments about the merits of different drugs. As one person close to the process told me, the competing interests of the DoH and the home secretary were "a very difficult circle to square".

It doesn't look as if that process was ever completed. What has emerged is a fudge of the first order which made for great headlines but, as things stand, does a terrible job of serving those it is designed to help. The result is that more people will end up suffering as Ms Harding did.

webTitle: Pass notes: de Sade

fields.headline: Pass notes: Donatien Alfonse François
fields.trailText: Donatien Alfonse François
fields.body:
Eh? You may know him as the Marquis de Sade.

Appearance: Short and enormously fat, the man who put the Sade into sadism was apparently nonetheless something of a hit with the 18th-century ladies.

But weren't his tastes on the, ahem, rough side? Only if you're going to get sniffy about a bit of sodomy, the odd bout of whipping, the occasional orgy, a spot of coprophilia. Or the prostitutes he dosed up with Spanish fly so that he could stick his nose between their buttocks and smell their farts.

Enough already. I suppose no one stopped him because he was a top French toff? Au contraire, he was sentenced to death twice and banged up eight times, which gave him lots of time to write.

Ah, repentant prisonhouse memoirs? Er, no, actually - pornography about orgies, whipping and sodomy. Then there's that great scene in Juliette, where Pope Pius VI has sex with the depraved heroine on the main altar of St Peter's while hundreds of monks masturbate appreciatively.

I get the picture. So what's the old perv doing in Pass Notes? Well, depending on who you listen to, he discovered the unconscious before Freud, was a top critic of the Enlightenment and forerunner of Nietzsche, was a sexual and political revolutionary, broke the taboo about female desire, etc, etc. Oh, and Geoffrey Rush is playing him in Quills, a new film about his declining years with Kate Winslet as a saucy laundress.

Oh yes? Not what you think. Apparently the poor old Marquis was so fat he was reduced to autosodomy in his last years.

Auto? Don't ask. Anyway, you can't entirely blame him. Apparently his loathing of female private parts and obsession with bottoms stemmed from the fact that his mother didn't love him.

The man in his own words: "Go fuck away the livelong day."

Do say: "Had a good day at the orifice, Count?"

Don't say: "Garçon, there's Spanish fly in my soup."

fields.trailText: Die Schnitzkunst liegt bei uns in der Familie. Mein Ur-Ur-Großvater Wilhelm Friedrich hat vor 150 Jahren den Nussknacker erfunden. Er war Zimmermann. fields.body:
Die Schnitzkunst liegt bei uns in der Familie. Mein Ur-Ur-Großvater Wilhelm Friedrich hat vor 150 Jahren den Nussknacker erfunden. Er war Zimmermann. Dieser Beruf war im Erzgebirge sehr wichtig, denn als die Bergleute noch in den Stollen arbeiteten, mussten die Zimmerleute die Gruben absichern. Als es mit dem Bergbau zu Ende ging, spezialisierten sich die Männer auf Gebrauchsgegenstände. Und bei uns waren das eben die Nussknacker und Räuchermännchen.

An der Arbeit mit Holz fasziniert mich vor allem der Geruch. Er liegt über der ganzen Werkstatt. Außerdem kann man aus Holz eigentlich alles machen, was man sich vorstellen kann. Ich habe eine Idee, setze mich an die Drechselbank und schon wird aus der Idee Wirklichkeit. Ich arbeite am liebsten mit Linden- und Buchenholz. Man kann aber alle heimischen Hölzer verwenden, auch wenn sie vielleicht nicht so schsn aussehen. Die meisten Stücke werden ja auch bemalt.

Was die Zukunft meines Betriebes betrifft, habe ich keine Angst. Der Sohn meines Bruders hat erst vor kurzem seine Lehre in meinem Betrieb abgeschlossen. Auch mein eigener Sohn wird bald mit einer Ausbildung als Schnitzer beginnen. Was ich aber grundsätzlich ablehne, sind Trends, wie sie in Amerika beliebt sind: Nussknacker in Form von Micky Maus, das hat meiner Ansicht nach nichts mit unserer Tradition aus dem Erzgebirge zu tun. Deshalb wird es so etwas in meinem Laden auch nie geben. Bei uns sehen die Nussknacker noch immer so aus, wie sie auch vor 150 Jahren geschnitzt wurden.

Ach übrigens: Für mich ist zwar das ganze Jahr über Weihnachten. Trotzdem ist der Advent nach wie vor etwas besonderes. Wenn ich mein eigenes Haus mit den Holzfiguren schmücken kann, dann kommt alle Jahre wieder dieses Kribbeln im Bauch. Ich habe sehr viele alte Figuren, die ich einst von meinen Eltern und Großeltern geschenkt bekam. Sie sehen besonders schön aus und erinnern mich auch immer wieder an die Anfänge unseres Berufes. webTitle: Temple row overshadows India's mega-pilgrimage

fields.headline: Temple row overshadows India's mega-pilgrimage
fields.standfirst: A dispute over the building of a temple on the site of an ancient mosque hangs over preparations for the largest ever gathering of human beings, writes Luke Harding
fields.trailText: A dispute over the building of a temple on the site of an ancient mosque hangs over preparations for the largest ever gathering of human beings, writes Luke Harding.
fields.body:
Over the next six weeks, around 70 million pilgrims are expected to descend on the north Indian town of Allahabad for the Maha Kumbh Mela, or pitcher festival.

Hundreds of devotees have already taken a dip in the 'sangam', or confluence point, where they believe the Yamuna and Ganges rivers are joined by a mythical underground river, the Saraswati.

The Kumbh Mela is held every 12 years for 42 days. According to Hindu legend, the god Vishnu spilled four drops from a kumbha (pot) during a scuffle. The drops fell to earth at four tirthas, or fords of a river. Festivals are held at each tirtha every three years in four Indian cities, where believers gather to wash away their sins in the water.

The most important tirtha is in the holy Uttar Pradesh state city of Allahabad. Millions of pilgrims from around India are converging on the vast floodplains and riverbanks adjacent to the confluence, where a huge tented city awaits them. On the biggest day of the fair, January 24, 25 million people are expected to bathe.

The festival is famous for attracting holy men, or sadhus, who leave their remote hideaways in forests and caves to trek to Allahabad. The Naga Sadhus smear their naked torsos in ash and lead the bathing. Also present will be a vast media contingent led by Channel 4, along with Hollywood celebrities and other foreign onlookers.

The first mela of the new millennium is as much about politics as it is religion. Representatives of the minority Muslim community have threatened to use force to stop a temple to the god-king Ram being built in the town of Ayodhya. The temple was torn down by a mob of Hindu fanatics in 1992.

This year India's supreme court has prohibited any building on the Ayodhya site. Nevertheless, an extremist Hindu organisation, Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP), has said it will announce a timetable for the construction of a temple on January 21.

Shortly before Christmas, India's prime minister Atal Behari Vajpayee outraged India's Muslim minority and his partners in the coalition government by appearing to back the temple's construction. However, the move delighted the ideological wing of Mr Vajpayee's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata party(BJP).

The BJP had been trying to distance itself from the agenda of its extreme Hindu revivalist allies. But Mr Vajpayee needs votes in the crucial state of Uttar Pradesh, which faces elections later this year. By playing the Ayodhya card, the BJP might woo disillusioned Hindu voters back into its fold, though it will also risk splitting the coalition.

"Atal Bihari Vajpayee has turned hawkish suddenly," said writer Amarsh Misra. "The Ayodyha issue is going to hot up once again and might lead to a realignment in Indian politics and political affairs." He added that the VHP is set to choose a date for the temple's construction in 2002, keeping the issue alive in the leadup to the Uttar Pradesh elections.

But the political dimension of the festival is of less interest to Allahabad's municipal authorities. Their main concern is to prepare their city in time for the visitors - and to prevent any deaths from mass stampedes.

"I only pray there is no major mishap on the main bathing dates - January 14 and 24 - when we expect anywhere between 15 to 25 million people to take their ritual dip," Jiwesh Nandan, the mela's administrator, said. "We, of course, are prepared for all eventualities."

webTitle: Men's health shock

fields.headline: Men's health shock
fields.trailText: Health authorities have been told to improve the appalling state of men's health - which leads to more premature deaths and illnesses than among women - by targeting them for priority care. By Anthony Browne
fields.body:
Health authorities have been told to improve the appalling state of men's health - which leads to more premature deaths and illnesses than among women - by targeting them for priority care.

The Department of Health issued the command after mounting concern that the yawning health gap between men and women is costing thousands of lives.

The health of British men is so bad that each year 20,000 more of them die before the age of 65 than women. They are more likely to suffer heart disease, cancer and HIV. Men aged 20 to 24 are three times more likely to die than young women.

The new policy follows an admission that men suffer because previous health campaigns have targeted women, and men have far too little access to health services.

Health authorities will have to monitor how sick men in their region are and, if they are suffering significantly more than women, take steps to remedy the situation. A Health Department spokesman said: "Health authorities have been told to target all inequalities, including that based on gender. If in a local area men are twice as likely to die from heart disease as women, they will be expected to try and target services at men."

There is growing realisation among politicians and doctors that men's health has been neglected. This month, MPs will launch the first All Party Group on Men's Health to raise awareness and coordinate policies.

Official figures show men are more likely to die than women across all age ranges. They are twice as likely to die in accidents and three times as likely to commit suicide. Young men are almost five times more likely to kill themselves than young women.

Men are more likely to smoke, to have an unhealthy diet, to be overweight, and to expose themselves to sun. They are three times as likely to be alcoholic as women, and four times as likely to be registered drug addicts.

However, men are about half as likely to visit their GP as women. Overall, men can expect to live 74.6 years, five years less than women. An unskilled man can expect to live 11 years less than a professional woman. An unskilled black man lives almost 15 years less than a professional white woman. The excess of premature male deaths is the equivalent of a jumbo jet full of men crashing each week.

Public health minister Yvette Cooper said last summer that the difference between men and women was the "biggest health inequality of all". The government wants to combat the assumption that the poor state of men's health is all their own fault.

There is eight times as much money spent on specific female health issues as on male ones. Women are screened for breast cancer and cervical cancer, and will soon be screened for ovarian cancer. But there is no screening programme for prostate cancer, which kills four times as many men as cervical cancer kills women. Some countries in Europe, and many states in the US, screen for prostate cancer, which this month claimed the life of libel lawyer George Carman.

The government's Health Development Agency, which has appointed its first men's health officer, will be working out ways to raise awareness of health among men, and encourage them to visit their GP more frequently. Surgeries will be asked to open after work and at weekends, as men are more likely to work full-time. Health authorities should make men more aware of health issues by working through betting shops, and opening clinics in pubs and sports centres.

Making men's health a priority has largely been the work of the women health ministers Tessa Jowell and Yvette Cooper.

webTitle: A beautiful day suggests a bright future for Fulham

fields.headline: A beautiful day suggests a bright future for Fulham
fields.trailText: United's victory at rejuvented Fulham was a match which reasserted the FA Cup's unique and ageless appeal.
fields.body:
It was nothing less than a day from heaven. What could be more exhilarating than a stroll down the towpath from Putney Bridge, past the park, watching the scullers skimming by on a fast tide under a china-blue January sky, with Fulham versus Manchester United in the third round of the FA Cup - a fixture combining elements of past, present and future - still to come?

Not, of course, for poor Chris Coleman, lying in his hospital bed contemplating a triple fracture of his right leg. "There's only one Chrissie Coleman," the crowd sang in the first minute of the game, sending a message of good wishes to their stricken captain. "He's an inspirational player," a doleful Lee Clark said afterwards, "and a big influence in the dressing room. It's been a hard week for the players, and not the happiest of new years."

As things turned out, Mohamed Al Fayed did well to get his lap of honour in first yesterday, trotting around the Craven Cottage pitch and waving his Fulham scarf at terraces packed with people who care only that he has given them Jean Tigana and a glimpse of beauty. Let's be honest: if he were the owner of your recently struggling Nationwide League club, you would probably feel the same.

But even in defeat, Fayed and his team's supporters had no need to feel anything beyond the most transitory sense of disappointment. On a day when the slimy surface meant no player could be entirely sure, as he swung a boot at the ball, that his standing foot would support him, the two teams presented us with a match entirely worthy of the day. Fulham provided ample evidence of the credentials that will see them safely promoted to the Premiership, matching their opponents in their ability to play a passing game at high tempo, while United returned to the FA Cup with victory in a match which reasserted the tournament's unique and ageless appeal.

This time last year there were plenty of voices to be heard trying to claim that no one in the game really cared about the competition. Try telling that to Alex Ferguson. "The Cup gives people hope and it gives them a dream," he said afterwards. Try telling it to Clark, who fought like a demon to overcome the absence of two of his regular midfield colleagues - the veteran John Collins and the young Sean Davis - and who was the last man to leave the pitch, having covered the length of the pitch to applaud the home fans for the way in which they had urged the First Division side on against the Premiership champions.

Not that Fulham needed anything in the way of outside assistance. Even though late goals have been their speciality this season, it was always on the cards that the fourth quarter of the match would expose the difference in status and experience, given that the earlier stages were played with unremitting intensity. As Bayern Munich can attest, Ferguson's team know all about the importance of maintaining concentration to the very end in knockout matches, and even beyond.

Further handicapped by the absence of Coleman and Barry Hayles, Fulham needed the maximum effort from every player, and Tigana will have no complaints on that score. Up front, Louis Saha and Luis Boa Morte gave the United defence a series of terrible frights. Time and again the pantherish Saha, currently the most thrilling sight in English football, showed his scalding pace and the sort of balance that allows him to reach out a leg and regain possession of the ball even in the act of losing it, but the clear shooting chances never quite came.

While the Louie Louie brothers were taking the eye, an even more impressive job was being done by Rufus Brevett and Steve Finnan, Fulham's unheralded full-backs. Faced with the challenge of containing David Beckham and Ryan Giggs, both stuck to the task with great honesty and persistence, giving Brevett the pleasure of hearing the "Roo-fus! Roo-fus!" chant celebrating Beckham's substitution after 83 minutes, while Giggs's contribution was reduced to a series of wild, long-range shots.

"Chris's accident knocked the life out of the club for a few days," Clark said. But the spirit and skill he and his team-mates showed yesterday left no doubt that the Fulham revival is for real, and is scheduled to provide further entertainment for at least as long as Tigana remains in charge.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Companies increasingly promoting through web games

fields.headline: Play with me
fields.standfirst: Never before have our inboxes been so assaulted by free games and gifts as companies get clever in promoting their brands. By Imogen O'Rorke
fields.trailText: Never before have our inboxes been so assaulted by free games and gifts as companies get clever in promoting their brands, writes Imogen O'Rorke.
fields.body:
It took more than a couple of flu epidemics to make December 2000 the viral month it was. An advent which started on a voyeuristic bent, with a private email containing details of a couple's fellatial habits being "e-volleyed" around the world, ended with a deluge of corporate viral advertising on a scale hitherto unknown.

Never before have our inboxes been so assaulted with games, prize draws, gifts and a thousand other ways to kill time. They ranged from the genuinely engaging, such as Tongue of Flurry from Icon Medialab - where you have to catch snowflakes on your tongue and spit them out as ice cubes to waste evil snowmen - and freeloader.com's popular Soccermon, to the totally banal: MP3.com's all-singing, all-dancing greetings ("Let it Snow has been composed just for you"). But the bombardment left you thinking, as the season often does, why?

One thing is clear: conventional online advertising such as banners and mailshots to free or paid-for email lists no longer works, so companies are having to resort to smarter ways of promoting their brands. New-style approaches often exploit the British appetite for screen games - the UK leisure software market is now the third biggest after Japan and America. According to MXXI Europe, we now spend three times longer on entertainment sites than on sports sites and more than twice as long on them as we do on travel or retail sites. Last year the numbers visiting entertainment sites more than doubled between January and April and the average visit was 28.8 minutes.

Thomas Cook's snowboard game Powda, which runs until the spring, has been one of the most successful of the season's campaigns. Created for Thomas Cook by NetCandy, it is presented as a Christmas pressie by way of a weblink from TC to the 300,000 customers on its database, it challenges you to get down a mountain, avoiding any rocks, logs, trees and skiers. The winner of a prize draw gets a free holiday, and so far 25% of customers have played.

Alexa Clark, director of customer acquisitions, explains that the direct marketing exercise has threefold benefits. It increases brand awareness among the company's new target group, snowboarding youth, it helps to build up the database as it is passed around among friends (competitors entering the fourth level must pass on their details) and it sweetens up existing punters who think they are being given something for nothing. The high street travel firm says it generated 250,000 new customers through its last viral campaign in the summer, which offered a free booklet about weekend breaks in the UK.

Tangozebra, a technology-based sales and marketing solutions company, claims its Xmas Game, which was sent out to 600 industry and media contacts, had 65,000 hits within three hours. By clicking on a noisy parcel, you activated a banner game that required no plug-ins or streaming; you simply had to navigate Santa in his bobsleigh over the flying rooftops and avoid snowballs to enter a draw and win a hamper.

Martin Pavey of Tangozebra explains that retro games such as Pacman and the "flying defender" model are back in. This year's game campaigns for WCW wrestling and the Royal Bank of Scotland are based on that old viral favourite, Punching the Monkey. The former asks you to punch a wrestler, the latter a pound sign: if you hit the sign within a second you are told your reaction time is "excellent" and are urged to check out the bank's reaction time by hitting on another click-through. It's not exactly The Weakest Link, but it does at least engage impatient web surfers for more than a split second.

The days when people clicked on a flashing banner because it was novel are over, says Pavey. "The thing about email is that it's personal. If you can get some sort of effective reaction from people with a game, then you can start to get them involved."

He is working on a viral pre-campaign campaign for a major trainer company which hopes to use a cool game to tickle the details out of potential customers.

Now banner fatigue is setting in, conventional advertisers are having to learn youth marketing tactics, adapted to the consumers with the shortest attention-spans. Some amusing examples can be found at greenpeasoup.com (which enables those under-age to spend money on the web without a credit card), such as the e-postcards devised by WARL offering you the opportunity to microwave the heads of Smash Hits pop idols, and Splatt, the strangely addictive game in which you have to splat a fly before it makes a mess all over your soup.

"Viral campaigns have to be humorous and funny, otherwise people won't bother passing them on," says Adam Hartley, account manager at CruiseControl, which specialises in the kind of guerrilla and "street" marketing favoured by skateboarding and gaming companies. "Corporate logos are an obvious turn-off for our clients. If they smell a hint of a corporate sell, they'll just press delete."

To promote the Dino Crisis 2 PlayStation game, CruiseControl produced a series of spoof newsreels documenting the aftermath of a Tyrannosaurus attack on the M25 with crushed cars and 40ft-wide footprints left in the fields. And it's not just the kids who are boosting figures. Many of us office workers now prefer to spend our time popping digital zits or slapping a virtual Spice Girl than getting on with boring work, which is why so many businesses have embargoed open internet access.

The virtues of Restlessness, Impatience and Rebellion are starting to replace the time-tested aspirational approach built on the values of Loyalty, Glamour and Authenticity.
