webTitle: Softer drug laws vetoed by Labour

fields.headline: Softer drug laws vetoed by Labour
fields.trailText: The government is to reject swaths of the seminal Police Foundation report on the future of British drugs policy because it fears appearing to be 'soft'. By Kamal Ahmed
fields.body:
The government is to reject swaths of the seminal Police Foundation report on the future of British drugs policy because it fears appearing to be "soft".

In an announcement next month, the government will say it does not agree with seven key findings of the National Commission on Drugs because of lack of evidence that the recommendations will work.

The state-sponsored report sparked debate by calling for a significant relaxation of the drugs laws. But Keith Hellawell, the drugs tsar, will tell ministers that softening their stance on cannabis would send the wrong message to the public.

"We have looked at the report carefully and keep saying to ourselves, 'where's the evidence to support what they are saying?'" said a highly-placed government source.

"Although we back much of what the report says on drugs education and rehabilitation, on the issue of reclassification of hard drugs and on the issue of cannabis in general, we do not agree with the findings."

The move will dismay campaigners who say that Britain has the toughest anti-drugs laws in Europe and that the government should make a clearer distinction between hard drugs such as heroin and cocaine and softer drugs such as cannabis.

Dame Ruth Runciman, who wrote the report, will increase pressure on the government this week when she says that the Home Office is being slow to respond to the recommendations, which were published last March.

She will tell a drugs conference organised by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation that the government is seeking to cherry pick the foundation's ideas, a policy she says will not work. The report provides "a middle ground approach", she will say, and it should be implemented in full.

A government source said: "How long did she take to write the report? About two years. So the fact that we have taken some time to think a lot about what she is saying is reasonable."

He said the government's 10-year strategy on drugs was starting to have results, with evidence that the number of people taking drugs was falling.

But anti-government campaigners point to polls showing that the majority want to see cannabis decriminalised.

Many senior police officers have also admitted that they no longer prosecute people for small scale cannabis offences because it is a waste of resources.

The seven key areas that will be rejected are:

 Making the possession of cannabis a non-imprisonable offence.

 Allowing people to defend themselves against charges of supplying drugs such as ecstasy if they can say that it was only for use by a small circle of friends.

 Reducing the sentences for those convicted of offences involving Class A drugs such as heroin.

 Making more sentences involving softer drugs community based rather than prison based.

 Ensuring that people prosecuted for cultivating a small number of cannabis plants do not face prison.

 Reclassifying ecstasy and LSD from Class A to Class B drugs.

 Reclassifying cannabis from Class B to Class C.

webTitle: Drugs scandal hits Harry Potter film

fields.headline: Drugs scandal hits Harry Potter film
fields.trailText: Security has been increased at the studios where the film adaptation of JK Rowling's best-selling novel is being made after two syringes were found on a disused set
fields.body:
The production of the Harry Potter film is at the centre of a drugs investigation after revelations in today's Sun newspaper that syringes have been found at the studios where the movie - based on the first of author JK Rowling's best-selling books about a schoolboy wizard - is being made.

The paper reports that a huge security clampdown was launched two weeks ago after police received an anonymous allegation that two male workers were taking drugs and two syringes were subsequently found on a disused set where building work was taking place. Security has been stepped up at the Leavesden Studios, near Watford, until filming ends in March.

A spokesperson for Warner Bros admitted that this was "a very serious matter" but added that: "No drugs were found and no direct link to the production has been established." Sources close to the film were keen to stress that none of the cast or crew of the £110m production were suspected. A spokeswoman added: "Our paramount concern is for the safety and protection of the cast and crew of Harry Potter."

Due out in November, the film stars 11-year-old Daniel Radcliffe as the young wizard Harry, as well as an illustrious cast of British stars, including Maggie Smith, Robbie Coltrane and Alan Rickman.

webTitle: Heavenly show begins with dusky red moon in total eclipse - if clouds part

fields.headline: Heavenly show begins with dusky red moon in total eclipse - if clouds part
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: People in Britain, other parts of Europe and Africa will get a chance tomorrow night (weather permitting) to see the greatest show not on earth - a total lunar eclipse.
fields.body:
People in Britain, other parts of Europe and Africa will get a chance tomorrow night (weather permitting) to see the greatest show not on earth - a total lunar eclipse.

At 18.42 Greenwich meantime, the orbiting Earth will begin to creep directly between the moon and the direct light of the sun. The planet's shadow will progressively darken the reflected glory of the moon until 19.49, when the total eclipse begins. The darkness will last until 20.51, but the show won't have ended completely until 21.59.

During the 62 minutes of total eclipse, the only light hitting the moon will be a reddish glow from sunrises and sunsets. Eclipse aficionados are expecting a spectacular sight: there has been no major volcanic eruption for a decade, and the upper atmosphere has little obscuring dust in it to blur or even blot out the celestial spectacle. (The total lunar eclipses after the eruption of Mt Pinatubo in the Philippines in 1991 were barely visible.)

The eclipse may be barely visible anyway, for many. It could well be raining with cloud covering much of Britain. "It's not looking good," said a Met Office spokesman. "By 6pm on Tuesday we are expecting rain to be extending in quite a broad band from Northern Ireland down to Wales and north-west England, down as far as London and the south east. By 9pm we are expecting the rain to have spread across to the whole of England and Wales and Northern Ireland, except for the extreme east of England. There will be clouds running ahead of the rain sofew will get the chance to see [the eclipse] properly."

For those who do catch it, the moon will appear dimmed rather than darkened. Because the Earth spins there is always a sunrise and always a sunset somewhere, and the planet's atmosphere is expected to act as a kind of filtering lens, directing the muted red light of these dawns and dusks to the moon 240,000 miles away.

Scientists think that the moon is likely to turn a brick-red colour as it goes into full shadow - or at least will appear so for those blessed with cloudless skies.

As night will have begun to fall on Europe and Africa at the time the eclipse begins, people in Britain can still hope for a grandstand view. Those on the eastern seaboard of North America will see only part of the show, because moonrise there will not have begun until after the eclipse starts.

The display is a kind of starting gun for a year of heavenly happenings. There will be a total eclipse of the sun on June 21, which will be visible only along a narrow ribbon that crosses Madagascar and southern Africa and ends in the Indian Ocean.

On July 5, there will be a partial eclipse of the moon visible from the Western Pacific, Australia and Asia, and there will be an annular eclipse of the sun - darkness surrounded by a thin ring of brightness - visible from Costa Rica and Nicaragua.

On December 30, people in the western hemisphere will once again see the Earth's shadow crossing the face of the moon.

The next total lunar eclipse after tomorrow, visible in its entirety from Britain, will occur in November 2003. But on May 16 that year there will also be a total lunar eclipse to be seen from the UK as the moon sets - the moon will be very low in the sky and disappear while in eclipse.

webTitle: Eriksson called in for crisis talks

fields.headline: Eriksson called in for crisis talks
fields.trailText: England's manager-in-waiting Sven-Goran Eriksson is to hold crisis talks with the Lazio chairman Sergio Cragnotti today after the Italian champions lost 2-1 at home to struggling Napoli and slipped 11 points behind the leaders Roma.
fields.body:
England's manager-in-waiting Sven-Goran Eriksson is to hold crisis talks with the Lazio chairman Sergio Cragnotti today after the Italian champions lost 2-1 at home to struggling Napoli and slipped 11 points behind the leaders Roma.

Reports from Italy said angry fans had called for Eriksson's dismissal, and Cragnotti's press spokesman said: "There will be a meeting between the chairman and Eriksson to talk about what happened [against Napoli yesterday] and how to resolve the crisis."

Cragnotti's son Massimo, the Lazio managing director, continued to support Eriksson publicly after Napoli had earned their first away victory of the season. The day was marred by violence involving both sets of fans.

The Football Association is due to hold further talks with Lazio this month to discuss Eriksson's availability, with a friendly against Spain looming on February 28 and two World Cup qualifiers in late March.

Stan Collymore's turbulent career was in disarray last night after Bradford City made it clear he has no future at Valley Parade and a proposed move to VfB Stuttgart collapsed.

Before tonight's FA Cup game with Middlesbrough, and little more than six weeks since he was appointed manager, Jim Jefferies has already seen enough of Collymore to deduce that the striker is likely to be a liability.

"We don't see Stan in our plans any more," said Jefferies. "There has been no problem and it's purely a football matter. I just feel the way ahead for Bradford is something different to what Stan can offer."

Privately, however, Jefferies will concede that he has been dismayed by the work-rate of a player he attempted to sign during his time in Scotland.

Collymore travelled to Stuttgart at the weekend for talks but the Germans were unimpressed with his personal demands.

Arsène Wenger has opened talks with Real Madrid over a possible £19m move for Ivan Helguera. Though the Spanish club are reluctant to sell the midfielder, Arsenal are believed to have been given first option.

"Arsenal are a big club and there are a lot of great players there, but I have a contract at Real and it is up to them," Helguera told onefootball.com. "The money we are talking about is staggering. I would never rule out anything."

Fans have reacted with dismay to the decision to move Manchester United's Premiership clash with Arsenal to the same day as the Worthington Cup final, fearing that it will detract from the main event. The game has been put back to Sunday February 25 so that it can be shown live on television.

Christian Dailly will today complete a move to West Ham. Blackburn will receive £1.7m and Marc Keller in return.

webTitle: Soccer star tackles burglars

fields.headline: Soccer star tackles burglars
fields.trailText: The footballer Duncan Ferguson has been praised by police for acting "bravely and responsibly" after tackling two burglars at his home, leaving one of them requiring hospital treatment for head injuries.
fields.body:
The footballer Duncan Ferguson has been praised by police for acting "bravely and responsibly" after tackling two burglars at his home, leaving one of them requiring hospital treatment for head injuries.

The 29-year-old Everton striker discovered the break-in when he returned to his home near Ormskirk, Lancashire, early yesterday after his team's victory over Watford in the FA Cup on Saturday.

Inspector Steve Sansbury, of Lancashire police, said officers were called to a report of a break-in and found one of the alleged offenders "detained" by the homeowner shortly after 1am. A second suspect had managed to escape.

"The householder has been interviewed by Lancashire police and we are satisfied that he acted both bravely and responsibly on encountering these intruders at his home," Insp Sansbury said.

"There is no suggestion of any police action against the homeowner."

A 21-year-old man captured by Ferguson was arrested and taken to hospital with head injuries. Insp Sansbury said he would be formally interviewed after his release from hospital.

The former Scottish international, known affectionately by fans as "Duncan Disorderly", became the first British professional footballer to be jailed for an offence on the pitch after he was convicted in 1995 of headbutting a rival defender while playing for Glasgow Rangers. He served 44 days in Barlinnie prison.

webTitle: Fox Network's new reality show slammed

fields.headline: Fox Network's new reality show slammed
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Fox Network could be heading for controversy after reality show Temptation Island was slammed by religious groups. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Fox Network could be heading for further controversy, after its latest reality show, Temptation Island, was slammed by religious groups.

The show, a follow-up to the hugely successful Survivor, actively encourages people to cheat on their partners.

In the series, four couples will be banished to the beaches of Belize with 26 young, attractive singles.

The details and the participants of the show are being kept secret, but trailers for the show make the tone clear.

webTitle: Strong box office and more awards for Traffic

fields.headline: Strong box office and more awards for Traffic
fields.trailText: After receiving rave reviews, Steven Soderbergh's drugs expose attracts big crowds in the USA despite fears that downbeat subject matter would put off audiences
fields.body:
Steven Soderbergh's much-hyped drug saga, Traffic (pictured), failed to knock Cast Away from the top of the American box office chart despite much critical acclaim, according to estimates released today. Screen Daily reports that the Tom Hanks shipwreck drama has now earned $143.5m (£95.4m) after spending a third week at number one.

Traffic - an ensemble drama with a star cast that includes husband and wife team, Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones - examines the social and financial effects of America's war against drugs. By earning $14.9m (£9.9m) over the weekend to reach number three, the film surpassed the expectations of many critics who believed it to be too dark a story to appeal to the mainstream American cinema-going public.

On Saturday, the adaptation of the British television series, Traffik, which has already picked up a string of awards, was honoured with two more prizes. The National Society of Film Critics gave Soderbergh the Best Director prize and Benicio Del Toro received the award for Best Supporting Actor. The film is also hotly tipped to receive several Oscar nominations next month.

Meanwhile, Mel Gibson's romantic comedy What Women Want grossed another $15.5m (£10.3m) to hold on to the number two slot, while Miss Congeniality starring Sandra Bullock and The Family Man with Nicolas Cage took the number four and five places.

Traffic is released in the UK on January 26.

webTitle: Crouching Tiger breaks UK box office records

fields.headline: Crouching Tiger breaks UK box office records
fields.trailText: After a record breaking opening weekend in the UK, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is to be given a wider release from this Friday
fields.body:
Double helpings of humble pie for those industry insiders who reckoned Ang Lee was committing professional suicide by returning East to shoot a film in the Chinese language. The resulting film Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon has just broken box office records for the largest opening weekend for a subtitled feature in UK cinema history.

A sweeping martial-arts epic of love and honour in Imperial China, Crouching Tiger opened last Friday to euphoric reviews and startling box office results. Released on 88 screens (a wide distribution for a foreign-language production), it scooped an unprecedented £629,198 over the three-day period.

Add on the £57,188 picked up from a series of preview screenings on New Year's Day and Lee's film has already clocked up a hefty £686,386 from British cinemas. Ironically the figure is far in excess of the sum wracked up by the opening weekend of Lee's last film, Ride with the Devil - a American civil war drama shot in the English language.

Spurred on by Crouching Tiger's success, distributors Columbia TriStar are planning to widen its release still further from Friday January 12. In the meantime the film has taken an impressive $19m (£12.6m) from the US box office and is already being hotly tipped as a frontline Oscar contender.

Already the film's backers are setting their sights higher than the Best Foreign Film Award (the customary reward for successful subtitled films). They believe the picture has a chance of beating out the likes of Cast Away, Traffic, Gladiator and Erin Brockovich to take the Best Film Oscar itself.

webTitle: Profit boost for set-top box maker Pace Micro

fields.headline: Profit boost for set-top box maker Pace Micro
fields.trailText: 10am: Pace Micro, which makes set-top boxes for digital TV, has reported a 41% rise in pre-tax profits, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Pace Micro, which manufactures set-top boxes for digital broadcasters BSkyB, Ondigital and NTL, has reported a rise of 41% in pre-tax profits to £17.9m in the half-year ending December 2

Profits were £12.7m for the same period last year and today's results exceeded market forecasts of £15m-16m.

The company has seen a 31% increase in turnover to £205.8m from £157.2m over the same period last year.

Shares in the manufacturer have risen 25.5p to 478p.

The manufacturer said the results had been achieved despite the toughest market conditions in years, including a shortage of manufacturing components.

webTitle: Leader: Book buyers had a beano at Christmas

fields.headline: Subtext messages
fields.standfirst: Book buyers had a beano at Christmas
fields.trailText: Book buyers had a beano at Christmas.
fields.body:
Optimistic parents who had hoped that their children might take to reading Dickens over Christmas got a rude awakening with the news that the bestselling book by a mile was something rather different: a guide to text messaging with mobile phones, a modest tome that sold 36,000 copies in the week before Christmas alone. The book - WAN2TLK? - is unusual, for a start, in that you need to have read it in order to understand the title. It is a sort of dictionary of the shorthand employed by teenagers to pack the maximum meaning into the 160 characters allowed in a text message.

You would have to be completely off-message not to have realised by now that text messaging has become one of the fastest-growing phenomena of all time, a feat achieved with virtually no marketing. An estimated 600m text messages are now sent in Britain every month and over 10bn worldwide. Dickens himself, it ought to be said, might not have disapproved. In fact, as an avid and expert exploiter of contemporary media, he might well have serialised his own novels through text messages rather than in the journals.

But anyone who thinks that the world is going to pieces because teenage buying has propelled a text messaging book to the top of the bestsellers would do well to look at the reading habits of nine- to twelve-year-olds. According to a list of bestsellers for this age group published in the Economist, the top six books included the following: second, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire: third, Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone: fourth, Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets - and fifth, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban. And what were first and sixth? It turns out that Harry Potter was caught in a DC Thomson sandwich. In first place was the Beano Annual 2001, and in sixth, the Dandy Annual 2001. Don't worry, Britain hasn't been turned upside down after all. God's in his heaven and all is right with the world.

webTitle: Comment: Fags and fiction

fields.headline: Fags and fiction
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: This year I will be giving up smoking. As I lit my last cigarette in 1983, this may not seem a hard resolution to keep, but it's not my personal consumption I'm worried about. As a novelist, I'm worried about that of my characters.
fields.body:
This year I will be giving up smoking. As I lit my last cigarette in 1983, this may not seem a hard resolution to keep, but it's not my personal consumption I'm worried about. As a novelist, I'm worried about that of my characters.

In fiction - including TV and films - cigarette smoking is what characters can do with their hands. It's often used as a shortcut to convey emotions such as anxiety, character traits such as rebelliousness or cynicism or to emphasise an overworked office or a sexual encounter. It's even used to denote class distinctions. As in life, it's something to do at moments of tension, after sex and if the characters are bored.

But this was how my daughter, then aged eight, explained Grease to me. She and her tiny friends saw Olivia Newton-John's transformation from wholesome highschool girl to leather-clad, highheeled vamp as: "First Sandy didn't smoke, then she did and then he fell in love with her again."

After a few decades of self-imposed restraint, Hollywood has now collectively resumed smoking on screen. With smoking rates rising at record speed in teenage girls, and supermodel Christy Turlington admitting to incurable emphysema due to smoking, I decided to think again about my characters' smoking habits.

The government can suppress advertising and sports sponsorship, but with Bridget Jones and about 10,000 hard-bitten fictional detectives chainsmoking through our consciousness, a new generation is being led more subtly to its early death than my father's, who at least had the excuse of being urged to calm their nerves by "lighting up" in the trenches of the first world war.

Once, in Casablanca, cigarettes were virtually a character in themselves, and Lauren Bacall' s opening line in To Have or Have Not was "Has anyone got a light?" But now, as James Walton, author of The Faber Book of Smoking says: "After being unfashionable in the 70s and 80s, fictional smoking is definitely on the increase." He thinks product placement by tobacco companies may be behind some of the current revival.

More people lighting up more cigarettes earlier may benefit tobacco company profits and anyone who tries to pretend that cigarette smoking isn't sexy is lying, if only to themselves. But I have watched my father die a painful death of smoking-related lung cancer, three of my children's grandparents died early of lung cancer or smoking-related diseases and my son is asthmatic, so I want cigarettes out of my family's life. It is, therefore, hypocritical of me to have smoking in my books.

The best way to give up smoking is not to start in the first place, which is why anyone with any influence at all - and writers do have an influence on people's lives - should, I believe, consider their responsibilities. Smoking is insidiously deadly in a way that more obvious dangers, such as alcohol, driving fast cars and dangerous sports often are not.

I recently asked a GP friend of mine what she found hardest in her job. "It's the smokers," she replied. "I've been here long enough to have favourite patients, and all the smokers among them are ill. Now when one comes in with a symptom that won't go away, my heart sinks."

But is it possible for a writer to have a "no smoking" policy in his or her fiction without distorting reality? I think it is, because no situation has to have smoking in it.

One invaluable lesson that authors learn from editors is the art of cutting. If there is any doubt over whether an element should be in a book or a film, ask yourself what the effect would be if it were to be removed.

There are many excellent films and novels in which smoking simply doesn't feature. They are no less "realistic". No reviewer or reader ever complains that the cigarettes are missing. No one notices.

Portraying cigarettes negatively in fiction is a wasted cause. It's much better not to have them there at all. Hollywood tries to have it both ways. It's mainly the baddies who smoke, but they are the sexy baddies.

Oddly enough, I find it harder to stop my fictional characters smoking than I did giving up the habit myself, but the easy option is never the route to the best writing anyway. If, as an author, I've got to think more carefully about the way I portray, say, anxiety, there is less chance of cliché.

If Chaucer, Shakespeare and Jane Austen could portray fully rounded characters without making them smokers, then so can I. And surely someone must be able to come up with a cynical detective who doesn't smoke?

 Alexandra Campbell's The Daisy Chain is published by Penguin in August

Once, in Casablanca, cigarettes were virtually a character in themselves, and Lauren Bacall' s opening line in To Have or Have Not was "Has anyone got a light?" But now, as James Walton, author of The Faber Book of Smoking says: "After being unfashionable in the 70s and 80s, fictional smoking is definitely on the increase." He thinks product placement by tobacco companies may be behind some of the current revival. More people lighting up more cigarettes earlier may benefit tobacco company profits and anyone who tries to pretend that cigarette smoking isn't sexy is lying, if only to themselves. But I have watched my father die a painful death of smoking-related lung cancer, three of my children's grandparents died early of lung cancer or smoking-related diseases and my son is asthmatic, so I want cigarettes out of my family's life. It is, therefore, hypocritical of me to have smoking in my books. The best way to give up smoking is not to start in the first place, which is why anyone with any influence at all - and writers do have an influence on people's lives - should, I believe, consider their responsibilities. Smoking is insidiously deadly in a way that more obvious dangers, such as alcohol, driving fast cars and dangerous sports often are not. I recently asked a GP friend of mine what she found hardest in her job. "It's the smokers," she replied. "I've been here long enough to have favourite patients, and all the smokers among them are ill. Now when one comes in with a symptom that won't go away, my heart sinks." But is it possible for a writer to have a "no smoking" policy in his or her fiction without distorting reality? I think it is, because no situation has to have smoking in it. One invaluable lesson that authors learn from editors is the art of cutting. If there is any doubt over whether an element should be in a book or a film, ask yourself what the effect would be if it were to be removed. There are many excellent films and novels in which smoking simply doesn't feature. They are no less "realistic". No reviewer or reader ever complains that the cigarettes are missing. No one notices. Portraying cigarettes negatively in fiction is a wasted cause. It's much better not to have them there at all. Hollywood tries to have it both ways. It's mainly the baddies who smoke, but they are the sexy baddies. Oddly enough, I find it harder to stop my fictional characters smoking than I did giving up the habit myself, but the easy option is never the route to the best writing anyway. If, as an author, I've got to think more carefully about the way I portray, say, anxiety, there is less chance of cliché. If Chaucer, Shakespeare and Jane Austen could portray fully rounded characters without making them smokers, then so can I. And surely someone must be able to come up with a cynical detective who doesn't smoke?  Alexandra Campbell's The Daisy Chain is published by Penguin in August comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Confessions of a former housing officer

fields.headline: Confessions of a former housing officer
fields.trailText: Comment: Novelist Ben Richards looks back on his years as a local authority housing officer, and the real-life characters that helped to inspire his first book.
fields.body:
I was a local authority housing officer for about three years, first in the London borough of Newham and then in the capital's Islington borough, before leaving for South America in 1991 to study the social housing policy of the military dictatorship in Chile.

When I returned to Britain, I was writing up my PhD thesis and decided to alleviate the boredom of analysing questionnaires by writing a novel.

The result was Throwing the House Out of the Window, published in 1995. It tells the story of Jamie Collins, a young and feckless housing officer who is plunged into a vicious racial harassment case which presents him with a series of moral dilemmas.

People often ask me how much of the book is based on things that really happened. Much of it is, although it is often difficult for me to know where reality ends and the imagination begins.

The title of the novel partly refers to a man who throws all his possessions from his flat window on his wedding anniversary. He builds up for this by playing Unchained Melody over and over again and then sitting on a window ledge with a bottle of scotch and a photo of his wedding day.

Meanwhile, the local kids scavenge below trying to catch the video. There was an incident like this on my patch but I cannot remember how much really happened, how much was embellished in office gossip and how much I later invented.

Although much will have changed since I was a housing officer, I am sure a great deal is the same. I tried to recreate this world in my novel - the sudden shift from the tedium of rent arrears to the tenant from hell who threatens to kill you unless you get him a transfer.

This goes to the heart of the problem of being a housing officer - as the principal point of contact you are held responsible for things that are frequently outside your control.

You would love to get a transfer for a difficult tenant, nothing would make you happier than to shunt him off to somebody else's patch, but you do not control allocations. You would be delighted to get the repair done, but do not control the contractor or building works.

I can remember a tenant who had lost his electricity supply and whose meat-packed freezer was defrosting. He was issuing a stream of threats to his housing officer - threats of the "I'm going to kill you" variety that we were in no doubt he would carry out - if his supply was not restored in half an hour. Fortunately, the power came back but this, of course, had nothing to do with us.

I also remember one irate character who was reporting his mother's repair and overheard me talking in the background about a void property - housing speak for an empty flat.

He became convinced I was calling his mum a void property. "Come out from behind that desk and I'll give you void fucking property, mate."

This sort of incident might then be followed up by somebody complaining their neighbour had trained her cat to sit and stare at her through the window.

The most common strategy for dealing with the mixture of stress and tedium is to deploy humour. One of the things I miss the most from the days when I worked in a housing office is the banter between colleagues, the way the banal and the eccentric, the ludicrous and the tragic would sometimes have us helpless with laughter.

The danger of this kind of humour is that it can lead to cynicism, a tendency to see all tenants as either moaners, timewasters or psychopaths.

In fact, most of the tenants on the estates were people struggling against considerable odds - poverty, racism, violence, inadequate services - to maintain a decent standard of living.

It was difficult sometimes not to become misanthropic, develop a siege mentality and be dismissive of real problems. It is greatly to the credit of most housing officers I worked with that they managed to avoid this trap.

There are aspects of life in the housing department I definitely miss. The question of working life presents the full-time writer with a paradox - the daily office interaction is a good way of maintaining your sanity and it provides ideas, stimulation, access to different narratives and dialogue.

Writing is a solitary activity but the writer must engage with the world. And no amount of warm white wine at tedious literary parties can compensate for the rich vein of material that is found in the world of work - particularly in the housing office.

 Ben Richards's first novel Throwing the House out of the Window was followed by Don't Step on the Lines, The Silver River and A Sweetheart Deal. He teaches development studies, specialising in South America, at University College London.

webTitle: Four years to restore rail passenger confidence

fields.headline: Four years to restore rail passenger confidence
fields.standfirst:
New report's findings revealed

Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: Passenger confidence in Britain's beleaguered rail network could take up to four years to restore, according to rail industry research published today.
fields.body:
Passenger confidence in Britain's beleaguered rail network could take up to four years to restore, according to rail industry research published today.

The Hatfield crash and speed restrictions imposed in the wake of the tragedy has had a massive effect on public confidence in the railways, the market research has shown.

The study was carried out on behalf of Railtrack and rail operators, a Railtrack spokesman said. It centred around what the rail industry needed to do in order to restore public confidence.

The research results come just one day after passengers faced fare rises on many routes, despite protests from transport groups. Some companies such as Virgin, east coast operator GNER and Thameslink froze fares following the disruption to services in the aftermath of the Hatfield crash last October.

A Railtrack spokesman said the report was carried out on behalf of the industry, including the Association of Train Operating Companies. "The report says that if the industry does nothing it would take four years for passenger growth to reach pre-Hatfield levels," he said.

"But if the industry regains public confidence quickly then it will happen much quicker." He continued: "The way to achieve that is to have robust and reliable timetables and that is what the industry is doing."

Vernon Hince, of the Rail, Maritime and Transport Union, called for a reassessment of the way the rail network is managed. On the Mori report, Mr Hince said: "It's very grim stuff, but we have been saying for some time that it was going to take a lot longer than new timetables to overcome the problems that the industry faces."

Brian Donohoe, Labour MP for Cunninghame South and a member of the Commons transport sub-committee, also called for a re-examination of the industry's structure. "I think there has to be change ... If there's a fundamental flaw to the system then it has to be looked at, and that's the evidence that we are receiving from the train operating companies themselves."

Richard Pout, policy officer for the Railway Development Society, said: "We are aware that in certain areas it will take some considerable time for the confidence to be restored. "As soon as the network is back to normal we want to see a lot of marketing and promotional activities to get passengers back on the railways."

The Rail Passengers Council condemned the fare rises, saying they were "incomprehensible" when passengers were still suffering problems.

Environmental transport group Transport 2000 warned that Britain's standard rail fares were among the most expensive in the world and said a standard open return fare between London and Manchester was now £150 - up by 50% in less than two years.

It said an annual real cut in rail fares could increase passenger numbers by 3% to 9% over 10 years. Speaking about the fare rise, Liberal Democrat spokesman for the environment, transport and the regions Don Foster said: "The only way to attract people back on to the railways is to provide them with accurate and reliable services and timetables."

Others, including Silverlink, South West Trains and Connex, increased some fares above the level of inflation - a move labelled "barmy" by Labour MP Gwyneth Dunwoody, chairman of the House of Commons transport committee.

webTitle: Rural young losing out as rich move in

fields.headline: Rural young losing out as rich move in
fields.trailText: The trend of rich people buying up all the available housing in the countryside and forcing poorer young families to move to cities is increasing dramatically, according to research. Paul Brown reports
fields.body:
The trend of rich people buying up all the available housing in the countryside and forcing poorer young families to move to cities is increasing dramatically, according to research.

The sale of rural council houses and a lack of housing association homes mean there is no accommodation for people setting up home for the first time - unless they buy at increasingly inflated prices. Four out of 10 new households in rural areas are unable to buy a home.

Mark Shucksmith, of Aberdeen University, told the geographers' conference in Plymouth: "Rural areas are now ruled by market forces, so the rich will live in the countryside and the poor in the urban areas. The social glue that holds rural communities together is falling apart.

"The original inhabitants which formed our idealised rural communities had an age balance of all generations - now these social networks of mutual support are increasingly being fractured. The old will have no one to look after them and the young will be without the support of their parents."

The situation has been made worse by the rich incomers taking over local communities by forming the majority on parish councils, being able to lobby against any new developments, especially preventing "village homes for village people".

The trend was becoming increasingly acute, with the incoming rich "protecting their version of a rural idyll by preventing new building and in doing so inadvertently threatening the social, cultural and economic sustainability of what they are keen to preserve."

The effect on young people was particularly severe, with those wanting to stay in the countryside having to live with their parents.

A survey of 60 18-year-olds in North Yorkshire found that by the age of 22 only one had managed to achieve a level of independence while staying in a rural location. The rest had either moved to a city or were continuing to live with their parents.

The trend had accelerated because of a failure to provide social housing. It was estimated that 80,000 affordable homes were needed in rural England between 1990 and 1995, but only 17,700 new social housing units were provided between 1990 and 1997.

Plans for affordable homes built by housing associations had to be approved by parish councils to receive government funding. These were often dropped because rich newcomers wanted to prevent all new building.

Professor Shucksmith said it was the Conservative housing policies that had meant that "only the wealthy can realise their dream of a house in the country, while others are having to settle for the suburbs or cities".

The government's recent rural white paper had set a target of 9,000 affordable homes a year being built in rural areas, but this was not enough to prevent a continuation of the trend.

webTitle: Liberty Surf set for takeover by Tiscali

fields.headline: Liberty Surf set for takeover by Tiscali
fields.trailText:
9.15: French internet service provider Liberty Surf is set to be snapped up by Italian rival Tiscali, writes Dan Milmo.
Jan 5: Liberty Surf in UK closure speculation
Jan 4 Liberty Surf tight lipped on merger
fields.body:
French internet service provider Liberty Surf is set to be snapped up by Italian rival Tiscali.

Shares in both companies were this morning suspended pending an announcement, which is expected to confirm the latest consolidation move in an overcrowded sector.

Liberty Surf is the second largest ISP in France, and is some way behind the European market leaders, such as T-Online, Tiscali and Wanadoo. Finding a strategic partner is seen as its best chance of survival.

Belgian telecoms operator Belgacom was the initial favourite to acquire the French company, but Tiscali has become a consolidator in the industry and recently bought Dutch competitor World Online.

Liberty Surf is said to be considering shutting down its London offices as a cost-cutting measure, although sources close to the UK operation have denied that the 140 jobs are at risk.

webTitle: Country of the month: China

fields.headline: Country of the month: China
fields.standfirst: Jane Pennington looks at life teaching in a country that can provide fulfilment and frustration in equal measure
fields.trailText: Jane Pennington looks at life teaching in a country that can provide fulfilment and frustration in equal measure.
fields.body:
Finding jobs | Salaries | Accommodation and Living Expenses | Classes and teaching methods | Visas and paperwork | Is China for me? | Useful websites

Introduction

Working in China is an adventure, but not one to everybody's taste. Eastern culture is so different from the west that a person must come here with an open mind and be prepared for a lot of frustration.

Finding jobs
English teachers are always in great demand in China, but it is difficult to find out what is available since the schools and universities will not spend money on advertising.

My own experience is that I got my first job in a primary school through a Chinese friend in the UK who used to teach there. Once there, I was contacted by the power plant where I now. For those for whom things don't fall so nicely into place, it is worth remembering that the VSO also recruits teachers for China. But once a teacher is working, offers will often come from other schools and workplaces.

Some people visit China on a tourist visa with the intention of finding a job and sorting out the paperwork afterwards. This is perfectly acceptable, but probably easier to do in the major cities such as Beijing and Shanghai as contacts are easy to find

In any documentation on TEFL working in China, it will say that you need a degree and TEFL qualifications, but in practice, this is not always the case. If you find work in a school you may not need previous experience or qualifications, but to work in a university, you will need a degree, though not necessarily TEFL qualifications. For teaching in a business environment, the decision depends on the company.

Salaries
The cost of living in China is very low and you will not earn very much - nobody comes to teach in China to get rich.

Chinese teachers traditionally earn only a low wage of about RMB450 per month, paid by the government and sometimes topped up by the school or university depending on how wealthy the establishment is. At the moment the exchange rate is about RMB12 to £1. A foreign teacher will probably earn between RMB1000 - 1300 per month.

Working in a business will give you a much higher salary, though still not high by European standards, particularly if you are actually recruited in China. Something in the order of RMB6000 - 10,000 would be usual.

Accommodation and living expenses
It is usual for accommodation to be provided on site free by the employer. In China, employees have traditionally lived at their workplace and, although this is slowly changing, this is still the case in the education sector. The quality of accommodation varies - although it is never of a very high standard.

Almost everyone in China lives in a flat consisting of a tiny kitchen, tiny shower room/toilet, living/dining room and two or three bedrooms. Flats above the ground floor always have a balcony but this is for hanging out your washing on and not for sitting comfortably!

Heating is found in flats north of the Yangtze River but air-conditioning is not a universal feature. Accommodation in the business sector is often of a significantly higher quality.

Workplaces often have canteens attached and you can live very cheaply by making use of these. It is difficult to eat alone at a Chinese restaurant as people usually share dishes and restaurants cannot cater easily for individuals but if you go out with a group of friends then RMB80 for 4 would be considered normal, though in a tourist area you would pay much more.

Classes and teaching methods
Classes in schools usually have a minimum of 60 students but 100 is not unusual. The situation is similar in universities, but in business, the situation will obviously vary from company to company

The traditional method for teaching English is grammar translation - with a lot of chanting. The Chinese government is trying to introduce more communicative practices such as pair and group work, using information gap activities etc, and although it is possible use newer methods in the classroom, it is often logistically difficult.

TEFL teachers in China are often told 'just to teach speaking and listening, not reading, writing or grammar', partly because the education system focuses heavily on exams and everyone has to take English exams, but it does make integrating the skills a great challenge.

Chinese teachers prepare their students to a formula, not varying from the course books and the students prepare for the exams by memorising everything possible - which means that what the students do not get is conversation beyond memorised dialogues.

If you plan to teach in China, it is a good idea to bring copies of your favourite books and cassettes with you since the schools will only have the national course books available (primary, junior and senior English for China).

Some publishers such as Longman and Cambridge University Press have agreements with Chinese publishers to produce cheap copies of often-outdated EFL books, but the paper quality is poor and they really amount to nothing more than photocopies and often you can only get the books but not the tapes, or vice versa.

Visas and paperwork
There is an enormous amount of official form filling in China with a payment to be made at each stage, but your employer should pay for all of this. If you work in the public education sector, the local foreign affairs office will know of your placement and be available for problem solving or queries.

It is advisable to bring some needles with you for any healthcheck, as you cannot always be sure that a doctor's needle has not been used before.

Is China for me?
As you may have realised, China is not an easy place to work in but because the people here are still not very used to foreigners, it makes for a more unusual place to work. Tourists usually stay in the main centres like Beijing, Shanghai or Xian and do not get a chance to meet 'ordinary' Chinese. English is incredibly important here and teachers in all subjects are rated highly. Because of this, there will always be someone to talk to. It is hard work and you cannot fight the authorities, you really must go with the flow. If you did not have an interest in psychology before working here, you will certainly acquire one.

It's a fascinating place where the reward will be experience not money.

Useful websites

teflchina.com - By far the best website for information on teaching in China, including job information and lists you can join.
Chinanow - a fine guide to city life in China, from finding your way around to discovering restaurants and things to do. Essential for researching where you'd want to be and for making sense of it all when you get there.

Jane Pennington is an English trainer at the Laibon B power plant in Guangxi in the People's Republic of China. You can email her here.

At the moment the exchange rate is about RMB12 to £1. A foreign teacher will probably earn between RMB1000 - 1300 per month. Working in a business will give you a much higher salary, though still not high by European standards, particularly if you are actually recruited in China. Something in the order of RMB6000 - 10,000 would be usual. Accommodation and living expenses It is usual for accommodation to be provided on site free by the employer. In China, employees have traditionally lived at their workplace and, although this is slowly changing, this is still the case in the education sector. The quality of accommodation varies - although it is never of a very high standard. Almost everyone in China lives in a flat consisting of a tiny kitchen, tiny shower room/toilet, living/dining room and two or three bedrooms. Flats above the ground floor always have a balcony but this is for hanging out your washing on and not for sitting comfortably! Heating is found in flats north of the Yangtze River but air-conditioning is not a universal feature. Accommodation in the business sector is often of a significantly higher quality. Workplaces often have canteens attached and you can live very cheaply by making use of these. It is difficult to eat alone at a Chinese restaurant as people usually share dishes and restaurants cannot cater easily for individuals but if you go out with a group of friends then RMB80 for 4 would be considered normal, though in a tourist area you would pay much more. Classes and teaching methods Classes in schools usually have a minimum of 60 students but 100 is not unusual. The situation is similar in universities, but in business, the situation will obviously vary from company to company The traditional method for teaching English is grammar translation - with a lot of chanting. The Chinese government is trying to introduce more communicative practices such as pair and group work, using information gap activities etc, and although it is possible use newer methods in the classroom, it is often logistically difficult. TEFL teachers in China are often told 'just to teach speaking and listening, not reading, writing or grammar', partly because the education system focuses heavily on exams and everyone has to take English exams, but it does make integrating the skills a great challenge. Chinese teachers prepare their students to a formula, not varying from the course books and the students prepare for the exams by memorising everything possible - which means that what the students do not get is conversation beyond memorised dialogues. If you plan to teach in China, it is a good idea to bring copies of your favourite books and cassettes with you since the schools will only have the national course books available (primary, junior and senior English for China). Some publishers such as Longman and Cambridge University Press have agreements with Chinese publishers to produce cheap copies of often-outdated EFL books, but the paper quality is poor and they really amount to nothing more than photocopies and often you can only get the books but not the tapes, or vice versa. Visas and paperwork There is an enormous amount of official form filling in China with a payment to be made at each stage, but your employer should pay for all of this. If you work in the public education sector, the local foreign affairs office will know of your placement and be available for problem solving or queries. It is advisable to bring some needles with you for any healthcheck, as you cannot always be sure that a doctor's needle has not been used before. Is China for me? As you may have realised, China is not an easy place to work in but because the people here are still not very used to foreigners, it makes for a more unusual place to work. Tourists usually stay in the main centres like Beijing, Shanghai or Xian and do not get a chance to meet 'ordinary' Chinese. English is incredibly important here and teachers in all subjects are rated highly. Because of this, there will always be someone to talk to. It is hard work and you cannot fight the authorities, you really must go with the flow. If you did not have an interest in psychology before working here, you will certainly acquire one. It's a fascinating place where the reward will be experience not money. Useful websites teflchina.com - By far the best website for information on teaching in China, including job information and lists you can join. Chinanow - a fine guide to city life in China, from finding your way around to discovering restaurants and things to do. Essential for researching where you'd want to be and for making sense of it all when you get there. Jane Pennington is an English trainer at the Laibon B power plant in Guangxi in the People's Republic of China. You can email her here.

webTitle: National Trust takes down-to-earth stance

fields.headline: National Trust takes down-to-earth stance
fields.trailText: Prefabs and semis could come under the spotlight as new chief says 'I'm no toff' and vows to pursue the common touch. David Ward reports
fields.body:
The National Trust could add a 1940s prefab or a 1930s semi to its property portfolio as its interest shifts away from the lives of rich men in their castles to those of the poor men at their gates.

Under the leadership of its first woman director in its 106-year history, it is also showing new interest in the lifestyle of the middle classes and their homes in the suburbs and towns of England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

"We haven't any plans [to buy a prefab or a semi] but the logic of our approach is that those are the kind of things we may well consider in the future," said Fiona Reynolds, who moved to the trust, one of the world's richest charities, this month.

She had previously spent two years as head of the women's unit in the Cabinet Office, which she regards as useful experience of the inner workings of government, and before that was at the Council for the Protection of Rural England for six years.

Ms Reynolds, 42, won the trust's top job because she offered a new leadership style and an agenda for evolutionary change which could cause shudders among the trust's 2.7m members, many of whom may still be in love with the aristocratic past.

"I am not a toff," she said. "I am a paid-up member of the middle classes. A lot of the messages I am giving are designed to show how we are relevant, how we are appealing to people, how we are reaching out to families, how we are telling the stories of ordinary people."

The trust already owns the council house in which Sir Paul McCartney grew up in Liverpool and an Edwardian semi in Worksop, Nottinghamshire.

But its most significant recent acquisition has been a workhouse in Southwell, Nottinghamshire, due to open to the public next year. The building has a certain style but is at the opposite end of the social scale from the Palladian mansions and grand estates with which the trust is usually associated.

When the purchase was announced in 1997, Ms Reynolds's predecessor, Martin Drury, said: "Young people find social history and the lives of poor and ordinary people far more absorbing than the privileged few represented by the typical National Trust country mansion."

Ms Reynolds will build on that trend as she seeks to unfold narratives of real lives to her members, threequarters of whom live in towns.

"The workhouse is an extraordinarily evocative place. When it is open to the public it will prove irresistible. It tells a very creepy story about the way we treated the poor and it immediately makes me think about our attitudes to the poor today and about how society addresses these questions.

"It is a very good example of how the trust is engaging with a very contemporary issue as well as part of our history. The reality is that these people had as important role in our past as the great families. Many people can identify more readily with ordinary people."

McCartney's house in Forthlin Road in Liverpool has proved very popular, despite strict controls on visitor numbers, and Ms Reynolds has been intrigued by the public's reaction.

"People go to the house because they are passionate about the Beatles. They come out full of personal reminiscences about the lino they had as a child. It is as much about bringing to life the suburbia that many of us grew up in as it is about a particular family or a particular person."

The trust's duty to conserve and protect its grand houses will remain. But the quest for relevance will build on a growing realisation that visitors want something that sparks memories or touches their lives and may often be more interested in the scullery maid than the lady of the manor.

"The areas which we are already developing around our properties are more human or involve social narrative," said Ms Reynolds. "We are getting very positive feedback on that. People really want to know how people lived, what went on below stairs, how the gardeners lived, whether their children went to school, how the estate was run. There is a natural curiosity about such people's stories and when we tell those stories we get fantastic feedback. It is about telling the story of all the people who contributed.

"If you take the classic National Trust estate - the great house, gardens and park - and think of the hundreds of people involved in one way or another, that is the fascinating story."

As the country's biggest private landowner, the National Trust is a major player in the countryside debate. The hunting row has bounced round its committee rooms in Queen Anne's Gate, London, with campaigners such as Robin Page and Lucinda Green still seeking to overturn the ban on stag hunting on trust land.

That ban was confirmed last year and Ms Reynolds, with political skills honed in the Cabinet Office, sticks firmly to the trust's stance that it has to be neutral in the arguments over hunting foxes.

But she is willing to get stuck into other rural issues and has the green credentials to do it. She has a Cambridge degree in geography and land management, and suggests she and the trust have the expertise to mediate between noisy rival factions and sometimes artificial divisions.

David Clark, MP for South Shields and in the 1980s a member of the National Trust's executive committee, yesterday hailed Ms Reynolds's appointment as "an inspired choice".

Statistics

The National Trust, founded in 1895, cares for 200 buildings and gardens, 600 miles of coastline and 240,000 hectares of land in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. It has 3,800 staff and 38,000 volunteers who help run its properties. Its ruling trust has 52 members.

Sources of income in 1999-2000:

Membership £60m

Legacies £34m

Investments £26.4m

Rents £21.5m

Grants £14.5m

Shops, etc £11.7m

Appeals etc £20m

Expenditure in 1999-2000:

Coast and countryside £43.8m

Historic buildings and collections £45.7m

Property management £20.2m

Acquisitions £12.5m

Gardens £10.7m

Conservation, maintenance and administration £15.7m

webTitle: Pollard's parting shot

fields.headline: Pollard's parting shot
fields.trailText: Leader column, Daily Express, Saturday January 6 2001
fields.body:
Leader column, Daily Express, Saturday January 6 2001

"Farmers are hardly the most popular group in Britain. Up and down the country areas are blighted by intensive farming practices. Couple this with subsidies the like of which no other industry can dream of and you have a recipe for unpopularity.

Knowledge of organic farming has moved on apace. Years ago, organic farmers were regarded as cranks. On most calculations, their methods were regarded as wasteful and inefficient.

Until now. Destroying the received wisdom, Professor Jules Pretty, head of Essex University's Centre for Environment and Society, has worked out that, in fact, organic farming is cheaper, costing £1.8 billion a year less than intensive farming.

Environmentalists are still sometimes caricatured as unworldly. Sainsbury's, which we praised yesterday for introducing biodegradable packaging, shows that that need not be so. More retailers will, if the Sainsbury's scheme is a success, follow.

Organic farmers, however, receive only £20 million of the £3 billion in farm subsidies. Nothing is more stupid - and, as Prof Pretty shows, self-defeating - than this failure to promote organic farming. Despite this short-termism, the future of farming is now clearly organic."

webTitle: What are you like? -  Ku Klux Grans

fields.headline: What are you like?
fields.standfirst: Ku Klux Grans
fields.trailText: Ku Klux Grans
fields.body:
Not old ladies dressed up in white sheets, rather very, very traditional and conservative housewives aged over 55. There are just under 2m of them in the UK and they believe that a woman's place is in the home, disagree with the euro, buy British wherever possible and dislike foreign food.

Typical beliefs: "Real men don't cry" and "health food is only bought by fanatics".

Daily Mail readers then? It will come as no surprise that more than 20% of Ku Klux Grans read the Mail, although 19% of them read the Sun. They are more likely to read the Daily Telegraph than other housewives, according to the national readership survey. Other regular reading material includes gardening magazines and Reader's Digest.

TV: Top shows include Songs of Praise - they make up 25% of the show's audience - daytime quizzes such as Fifteen to One and Countdown and long-running gameshows such as The Generation Game and Play Your Cards Right. Drama serials are also likely to win their vote.

Sport: Ku Klux Grans are more likely to watch snooker and cricket than other housewives - they account for nearly 30% of TV's green-baize watchers. Another favourite sport is indoor bowls.

Ads: This isn't a strong point. A typical Ku Klux Gran comment is: "I can never remember any of the ads - I like the ones with the animals though." Although 21% comment that ads are usually entertaining, 34% feel ad breaks are just too darn long.

Any other identifying traits? You know you're talking to a Ku Klux Gran when she says: "I've never been abroad and I'm not about to start taking holidays overseas now - I don't know what all the fuss is about," or: "I wouldn't know how to switch a computer on but it hasn't done me any harm - most people just use it for pornography anyway."

 Data supplied by MediaCom TMB

webTitle: Popstars publicity omits New Zealand flop

fields.headline: Popstars publicity omits New Zealand flop
fields.trailText: 8.45am: ITV's new music show Popstars has both good and bad precedents in Australia and New Zealand, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV's publicity pack for Popstars, the real-life music soap, focuses on the success of Bardot, the girl band formed for the Australian version of the show last year.

There is no mention of TrueBliss, the original Popstars band, which was put together by the format's creator for the New Zealand version of the show in 1999.

But then TrueBliss split up shortly before Christmas, after a long, slow decline from the heady days of mid-1999, when the five-piece girl band scored a number one single and album on the back of the Popstars TV show.

The New Zealand version of Popstars was a hit on state broadcaster TVNZ's TV2 channel in the first half of 1999.

ITV is hoping to follow in its footsteps when it launches Popstars this Wednesday.

But it will be disappointed if the success of the pop band is as shortlived as that of TrueBliss.

Initially the New Zealand band looked full of pop promise.

TrueBliss' debut single Tonight went straight to number one in the local pop charts in May that year, with a successful tour and number one album Dream following shortly afterwards.

But then things started to go wrong. Follow-up singles Number One and Freedom - a cover of the old Wham song - failed to reach the New Zealand top ten.

By the autumn of 1999, Dream had been consigned to the bargain bin of local record shops and TrueBliss' five twentysomething female band members were talking about getting day jobs to supplement their meagre showbiz incomes.

Sony was expected to release a second TrueBliss album early in 2000. But the record company dragged its feet about picking up an option to renew its contract with the band.

The writing was certainly on the wall by July last year, when it emerged that band member Carly Binding had quit to pursue a solo career, backed by Popstars creator Jonathon Dowling.

Another member of TrueBliss, Erika Takacs, has started out on a TV presenting career, fronting a TV2 pop chart show.

By the end of the 13th and final episode week, ITV hopes to have a pop sensation on its hands and at least one hit single.

But it will be Australia it will be looking to follow after that.

Bardot, the down-under girl band are still going one year on, after a number one single and album. The group have signed a multi-record deal with Warner Music Australia and are planning to release a new single next month, with a second album to follow.

Australian broadcaster Seven Network is planning a second series of Popstars, this time with a boy band.
