webTitle: Dyke urged to act after calling BBC 'hideously white'

fields.headline: Dyke urged to act after calling BBC 'hideously white'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke, the BBC's director general, clashed with his most senior non-white news presenter yesterday after describing the corporation as "hideously white".
fields.body:
Greg Dyke, the BBC's director general, clashed with his most senior non-white news presenter yesterday after describing the corporation as "hideously white".

Mr Dyke repeated his desire to increase the number of managers from minority backgrounds, but the Ten O'Clock News anchorman, George Alagiah, warned that his words must soon be matched by actions. "Many journalists will be saying that it is no longer good enough to identify a problem if he can't come up with solutions," he said.

He said he supported Mr Dyke's desire to address the problem. But he warned the BBC against playing the "numbers game" - staff should be promoted on merit, not simply because of their ethnic origin.

The debate was prompted by Mr Dyke's comments on BBC Radio Scotland last night. Speaking on The Mix current affairs programme, he showed frustration at the underrepresentation of ethnic minorities in the corporation, particularly at senior levels. He compared the organisation to the Metropolitan police, which was described as "institutionally racist" by the Macpherson report into the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence.

"I think the BBC is hideously white. I think the BBC is a predominantly white organisation," he said. "The figures we have at the moment suggest that quite a lot of people from ethnic backgrounds that we do attract to the BBC leave. Maybe they don't feel at home, maybe they don't feel welcome."

Just over 8% of BBC staff are from ethnic minorities, but only 2% of managers are non-white. "Our biggest problem is at the management level," Mr Dyke said. "I had a management Christmas lunch, and as I looked around I thought: we've got a real problem here. There were 80-odd people there and only one person who wasn't white."

Since taking over as director general last year, Mr Dyke, who used to work for a community relations council in London, has made clear his desire to tackle the lack of ethnic diversity at the BBC. His first big speech was about minority issues, and he pledged that 10% of its UK workforce and 4% of management would be drawn from ethnic minority backgrounds by 2003. He appointed Linda Mitchell, a black former journalist, to oversee progress, and signed up to the broadcasting industry's cultural diversity network.

Ethnic minorities are woefully under-represented in some parts of the BBC. In Scotland and Wales, the corporation has failed even to meet its own modest target of 2%.

The BBC said yesterday that work had already begun to improve the situation.

Patrick Younge, a commissioning editor for multicultural programmes at Channel 4 and a former BBC employee, agreed that the corporation had difficulty retaining non-white staff. "The BBC's problem is that it trains many black and Asian people in television but then loses them. I could not see where I was going so I went to Channel 4 and it happens a lot. They need a way of mapping routes through for aspiring junior managers."

webTitle: Law: Celebrities' right to privacy

fields.headline: Now you see us, now you don't
fields.standfirst:
The furore over the Zeta-Jones wedding photos has confirmed that people - even celebrities - have a legal right to privacy. But how, asks Marcel Berlins, will this affect the freedom of the press?

Special report: freedom of information
Special report: human rights in the UK
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The furore over the Zeta-Jones wedding photos has confirmed that people - even celebrities - have a legal right to privacy. But how, asks Marcel Berlins, will this affect the freedom of the press?
fields.body:
So now we know. There is such a thing as a legal right to privacy. Our judges have said so. But the irony is that the case that spelled it out was not about some sensitive, shrinking celebrity anxious to avoid prying paparazzi lenses or intrusive tabloid inquiries. On the contrary, the people seeking to assert their right to privacy had deliberately courted massive publicity and had been paid a huge sum of money to allow themselves to be seen in the world's media.

The problem was that the publicity that Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones received for their New York wedding in November wasn't exactly what they wanted. They asked the courts of England to rule that, even though they had sold off a part of their privacy for £1m, they were still entitled to the protection of the law. The judges, citing our new Human Rights Act, agreed.

The wedding of the year (until it was supplanted by Madonna's) was held at the Plaza Hotel under conditions of absurdly exaggerated security. The reason was not so much the possibility of gatecrashers as the far more horrifying threat of uninvited cameras. Douglas and Zeta-Jones had signed a contract giving OK! magazine exclusive rights to taking and publishing photos of the nuptials. Invited guests were sternly warned not to bring cameras; they were electronically frisked anyway. Everyone working at the wedding signed a draconian contract promising not to take snaps, on pain of unimaginable legal consequences if they disobeyed.

But some cameras did sneak in, including one whose portfolio of nine not very good photos found its way to arch-rival Hello! magazine, which, to OK!'s dismay, was to publish them three days before OK! went on sale.

And so to court. OK! raised several legal issues in its - ultimately unsuccessful - attempt to stop Hello! from publishing. But the point that raised the privacy issue came from the Douglases personally. They want to sue Hello! for damages for breach of privacy. But surely they had abandoned their right - or sold it - by allowing the ceremony and reception to be photographed, and the results published?

Not quite, said Lord Justice Sedley in the appeal court. They had insisted on a veto over what photos were to be used, "in order to maintain the kind of image which is professionally and personally important to them". By retaining that editorial control, they were in effect saying that any pictures other than those personally chosen by them invaded their privacy.

The appeal court decided that the newlyweds were likely to succeed in any claim for damages against Hello! for breach of privacy. Whether in fact they win their case and how much they will get if they do is for a future court to decide. What's important is that this was the first case in which an English court has specifically said that we now have a law of privacy to protect individuals. The second case may well come later today, with a decision on the claim of the two killers of James Bulger to be granted lifetime anonymity. The Human Rights Act gives them the right to be left alone, free from media prying, they say.

But there is another twist to the law. The right to privacy arises because Britain has incorporated the European Convention on Human Rights into our national laws. Article 8 says that "everyone has the right to respect for his private and family life". But a little way further is Article 10, which guarantees the freedom of expression and freedom of the press. When the media want to publish something - whether information or pictures - about someone's private life, the two are bound to clash.

The Human Rights Act exhorts the judges to have particular regard to freedom of expression when deciding which way to rule, and gives the media a public-interest defence against anyone trying to stop them from publishing. That still leaves the judges with a sensitive balancing act to perform, and it is by no means clear which way they will turn when faced with a free speech-versus-media intrusion dilemma.

Other countries in Europe which have had privacy laws for decades don't always provide clear-cut solutions. In France, celebrities - Catherine Deneuve, Isabelle Adjani and Brigitte Bardot among them - are used to going to court to complain that photographs have been taken of them without their consent, but the line between private and public occasions has often proved hard to draw.

Until recently, the French press has been particularly timid in revealing information about politicians, even where it would have been in the public interest. The late President Mitterrand's cancer, surely relevant to his capacity to carry out his duties, was kept from the nation virtually throughout his presidency, as was the existence of his daughter by a long-term lover - though that revelation might not have met the public interest test.

The French privacy laws have also had a chilling effect in an area that worries the British media - the investigation of wrongdoing and corruption. It is generally accepted that crooked businessmen and dodgy politicians are more easily able to escape scrutiny because of the deterrent effect of privacy laws.

In Germany, with its relatively recent experience of dictatorship, the right to free speech is treated with particular reverence. German judges are constantly having to balance it against individuals' claims that their privacy has been invaded. In one case, the court had to decide whether or not photos taken of Princess Caroline of Monaco in a restaurant were a breach of her privacy. What signals was she giving to the media? the court asked.

Put simply, if she and her companion chose a secluded table well inside the restaurant, not easily seen from the street, the message was: "Lay off, this is a private meal." If, however, they sat at a prominent table by the window, taking snaps of her would not infringe her privacy. The decision went in her favour because of where she decided to dine. Is this the kind of balancing act that our judges will have to perform each time a case comes before them alleging an invasion of privacy? Probably, yes.

When the Duchess of York sought advice on blocking publication in the English tabloids of pictures showing her cavorting topless and having her toes sucked by her "financial adviser", she was firmly told that there was no law of privacy that could help her. By contrast, in France, a magazine that published those pictures not only had to pay the duchess damages for infringing her privacy but was punished in the criminal courts with a fine. If a similar case were to come before an English court today, would she be able to stop such photos being published?

On one side of the argument, the pics were taken, without her knowledge or consent, when she was on a private holiday in France, staying in a private villa, by a paparazzo using a long-lens camera from an adjoining property. On the other hand, there was the importance of the freedom of the press, the fact that the duchess had previously milked the media for publicity when it suited her, and the legitimate public interest in knowing that a prominent royal had exposed her children, the Queen's grandchildren, to the sight of her poolside frolics.

Would she have won? Perhaps. Would Diana, Princess of Wales have succeeded in banning the photos of her working out in the gym if there had been a privacy law? In fact, Diana didn't know in advance of their publication, so she couldn't have stopped it. Such victims will now be able to sue for damages, but a lot will depend on how much they are awarded. If the judges start handing out large sums, it could have a big deterrent effect on the media.

The appeal court's decision in the Michael Douglas case gives a few - but only a few - pointers to the way judges will look at privacy cases in future. Basil Markesinis, professor of civil and common law at University College, London, an expert on the privacy laws of various European countries, praises Lord Justice Sedley's "bold" judgment. "German case law shows that a balancing act can work without resulting in a flood of claims or the suppression of free speech. It also shows how it can be done on the basis of logical criteria, rather than by relying on accidents of history and litigation, which is how English law in this area developed in the past."

But it is impossible to predict how effective the privacy law will be in shielding celebrities or other newsworthy people from media attention and exposure. It is boring, but necessary, to emphasise that each case will give rise to different factors to be weighed in the balance. We now have a privacy law. How it will work in practice is in the uncertain and unpredictable laps of the judges.

webTitle: Euro unfairly blamed for steel crisis

fields.headline: Euro unfairly blamed for steel crisis
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Corus, the British-Dutch steel producer, is expected to shut down plants in south Wales and Yorkshire - a move which will bring misery to thousands of families.
fields.body:
Corus, the British-Dutch steel producer, is expected to shut down plants in south Wales and Yorkshire - a move which will bring misery to thousands of families.

The British half of Corus is losing money and blaming the imbalance between the pound and the euro zone - where most steel exports go. The average loss in export earnings for the British steel industry since 1996 has been £68m per month.

But the weak euro is not exclusively to blame. An equal reason for the problems facing British steel is that the long Conservative years saw a dramatic reduction in steel consumption by comparison to other economies.

In the US, for many the exemplar of the new post-industrial service-based e-economy, the consumption of crude steel per capita in 1998 was 494kg per head. The equivalent figure in Britain was 288kg. Between 1989 and 1999 the US increased steel consumption by 28%. In Britain, steel consumption went down by 10%.

In 1990, 52% of the steel made in Britain was consumed in Britain. Today, that figure has fallen to 35%. The other two-thirds now has to be exported making steel firms far more vulnerable to exchange rate movements.

Other nations, such as America or some in Europe, have built or are building an e-economy on top of a thing-making economy. They are not seeking deliberately to undermine manufacturing, as happened in the 1980s and 1990s in Britain.

Instead, sensible nations sought and seek to add the necessary new value that comes from the knowledge economy without slowly throttling the thing-economy. We use, own, and need more products than ever before.

Why so few are made in Britain should be a question exercising policymakers. As the UK economy grows it still needs steel, but the steel now increasingly arrives in imported products such as washing machines, cars, and defence procurement.

Even if the euro were to strengthen dramatically tomorrow, the decline of Britain's capacity to make (which is not the same as assemble) things it consumes would still leave steel with massive problems.

There are some hopeful signs. Gordon Brown's public investment boost will, if properly channelled, require steel for the renewal of infrastructure which rotted under the Tories. EU steel makers pay up to 40% less than their UK equivalents for electricity.

Effective regional devolution could allow public bodies to be as ruthless as American states or German Länder in supporting manufacturing. It would be helpful if the discordant business organisations and unions claiming to speak for manufacturing could settle on some clear pro-manufacturing policies and jointly campaign for them.

Nigel Lawson once dismissed the producing economy by claiming that selling pounds for a profit was as good a contribution to the economy as making things and selling them for a profit. This anti-materialist philosophy took over British policy-making culture in the 1980s. It is still deeply rooted.

We need a new policy mix that pays as much attention to the thing-making economy as the pound-trading economy.

Britain should seek to match the US, Europe and the Asian tigers and start making things again.

That will help steel just as much as bringing the pound and euro into equilibrium.

 Denis MacShane is Labour MP for Rotherham and chair of the Commons steel group

webTitle: G2: John Sutherland on book stealing

fields.headline: Why books make thieves of us all
fields.standfirst: On the age of suspicion
fields.trailText: John Sutherland: On the age of suspicion.
fields.body:
Steal This Book was the title of Abbie Hoffman's 1970 hippy manual. One was tempted. More so than if one saw the instruction in Tesco to Steal This Can of Baked Beans. "Books," the book trade insists, "are different." No one ever said: "Where baked beans are burned, men are burned." Nor do mundane rules about meum et tuum apply.

I asked a colleague if she had any instructive stories on the subject of book stealing. Yes, she said. She once knew a guy in Foyle's who offered to get anything she needed "cut rate". He duly came out in Charing Cross Road at closing time with a bundle of volumes, looking shifty. They were pilfered, of course. "Loads of people here do it," he explained. "The pay's so lousy." The point is, she kept the books. But what, she asked herself, if he had dipped his hand in the till and given her a bunch of fivers? She would have shopped him and returned the stolen cash. But books were, somehow, "different".

Booksellers used to agree. Once upon a time, Blackwells accepted that needy Oxford students would plunder their shelves. The shop politely requested that, later in life, they should make a "conscience" payment for their shoplifting. Many did. Alas, a notice went up 20 years ago saying, effectively, no more Mr Nice Guy. Don't steal your book from Blackwells. It now prosecutes as brutally as Tesco.

I wouldn't misappropriate my neighbour's ox or ass. But, as my bookshelves witness, I have, over the years, been light-fingered about the printed word. As students we walked out of libraries with books up our jumpers, not with larcenous intent, but because check-out was such a hassle. The libraries turned a blind eye. Most of the books came back. We trusted one another. But, sometimes, one forgot.

If you want a measure of the evaporation of mutual trust in British society, consider libraries, or more specifically, the London Library, set up in 1841 by Thomas Carlyle and friends. The great Scottish grump was fed up with the British Museum and "the man with the bassoon nose" who invariably sat next to him (Karl Marx, one would like to think). Gentlemen like Carlyle wanted a library where they could range at will, unfettered by irksome security.

Notwithstanding the introduction of some discreet control on its front door, the London Library remains a trusting institution. Members continue to wander its shelves as unfettered as Carlyle did, and are waved in and out by the solicitous staff, with no more impolite poking in bags than he suffered. I wouldn't mind betting that Carlyle's shelves at the time of his death contained a couple of London Library books he had forgotten to return.

Much, however, has had to change at the London Library as a result of rising levels of theft. The current librarian, Alan Bell, divides book theft into two categories: misdemeanour and felony. Lesser breaches of the rules are, however, just as inconvenient for the members, he points out, when books vanish from circulation. Smart villains don't steal books. If valuable they will be property-marked and there are fewer reliable fences among antiquarian book dealers than among, say, jewellers.

The trick is to steal "plates" (pictures or maps). Plates are easily razored out. They are usually unstamped and can be disposed of through auction houses or antique shops. Many end up, behind glass, in living rooms.

The London Library and British Library, a couple of years ago, won a notable victory over a villain from Leeds who, in Yorkshire and then in London, was methodically gutting valuable books of their plates to pay his gambling debts. This "Yorkshire Ripper" got four years (in my view he should have got as much as the other one).

Book kleptomaniacs are odder fish. They usually have better taste than mere villains, Bell tells me. Damn them. Bell is a man of much learning, but a series of major thefts means that nowadays he has to be much more of a custodian than merely a knowledgeable curator of books. Modern librarians will know as much about security systems as incunabula. Libraries have changed and so has everything else (even the London Library).

The more "security" we have, the less secure we feel, because without trust, we're all criminal suspects. Every shop sees us as potential shoplifters; every rail company sees us as potential fare-dodgers; every bank as potential robbers and every airline sees us as potential bombers. Employers see us as potential misusers of the firm's computer. And perhaps we are (potentially) all those things. After all, we did steal that library book 30 years ago.

webTitle: Film: The best director scene

fields.headline: The best director scene
fields.standfirst: Cecil B Demented
fields.trailText: Cecil B Demented
fields.body:
Having kidnapped faded Hollywood starlet Honey Whitlock (Melanie Griffith), underground director Cecil B Demented (Stephen Dorff) explains the project he has cast her in.

"Now, our picture is called Raving Beauty. You play the insane owner of a failed art theatre who, along with her film fanatic boyfriend Lyle..."

Lyle (Adrian Grenier) enters, eyeing Honey lasciviously.

"Lyle," Demented barks, "come on over. And her violence-prone daughter Cherish..."

Cherish (Alicia Witt) walks in. Honey looks her up and down.

"Daughter?"

Cecil ignores his leading lady.

"Together, the three of you vow to start a revolution to destroy mainstream cinema..."

"I can't be in this movie."

A furious Cecil rounds on Honey.

"You dare to tell Cecil B Demented you refuse?"

"I am too young to play her mother."

I know how old you are."

Honey flinches slightly.

"Alright. Well, I just don't feel it. I am not motivated."

"How's this for motivation?"

webTitle: 'Enthusiasm' for six-term year

fields.headline: 'Enthusiasm' for six-term year
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Plans to double the number of terms in the English school year to six have met with an encouraging response, local government leaders claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Plans to double the number of terms in the English school year to six have met with an encouraging response, local government leaders claimed yesterday.

Many believed the authorities should make the leap together, according to Graham Lane, Labour education chairman of the local government association. He said the new school year could be in place as early as 2003.

Teaching unions and some Whitehall officials remained opposed to the LGA plans which would lead to a seven-week autumn term beginning in August, followed by a two-week break, then another seven-week term followed by a further fortnight's holiday over Christmas.

The first term of the new year would be six weeks long, with a one-week holiday coming after that. There would then be two more terms separated by a two-week break for Easter, and a final six-week term after another week off.

Exams would be held in the fifth term and in the final term schools would have the chance to do things currently squeezed off the timetable, Mr Lane said. The six-week summer holiday would also remain intact, a fact which ought to satisfy the unions.

Mr Lane was confident the plan would be adopted as there was a "lot of enthusiasm" in the responses. "What people are concerned about is that we all move together, that we don't have a piecemeal approach."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said: "This is shifting the deck chairs on the Titanic - there are so many problems to think about."

A spokeswoman for the Department for Education and Employment said: "We are taking a back seat on proposals for a four, five or six-term year. It is up to local education authorities to experiment if they want to."

webTitle: Letters: Tough on the causes of millionaires

fields.headline: Tough on the causes of millionaires
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's obsession with the super-rich (Leader, January 6) might be lessened if he studied the life of a previous leader of the Labour party, George Lansbury.
fields.body:
 Tony Blair's obsession with the super-rich (Leader, January 6) might be lessened if he studied the life of a previous leader of the Labour party, George Lansbury. The millionaire, Samuel Montagu, tried to curry favour with Lansbury by boasting that he was a socialist who gave a tenth of his riches to the poor. Lansbury replied: "We want to prevent you getting the nine-tenths."

Lansbury perceived, as Blair does not, that millionaires perpetuate inequality. Instead of giving them power in the Lords and influence in the Labour party, the prime minister should be pursuing policies to redistribute their wealth.
Bob Holman
Easterhouse, Glasgow

 I make my modest donation to the Labour party for just one reason: I believe that a Labour government is best for the country. Is it not possible that the recent much publicised donors made their contributions for just that reason too?
BGF Beadle
Kenilworth, Warks

 John O'Farrell (The big give away, January 6) attempts to justify New Labour's obeisance to millionare donors on the grounds that Labour should have the funds counter Tory propaganda about the rail crisis. Most people think Labour should have the policies to counter the Tories on this issue.
Jim Denham
Birmingham

 I have been a supporter of the Labour party for 55 years and, although an OAP, I make a small annual donation to the party of about £15. I do not do this in the hope of a peerage or to influence the policies of the party, I do it because I believe that the election of a Labour government is in the best interests of the country. If I were a billionaire, I would make an annual donation of at least £2m for the same reason.
Don Knight
Bronllys Brecon, Powys

 Could we not have a state funded system whereby parties receive money proportional to the number of votes they received at the last general election?

Such a system would eliminate the system of courting private donations and would give extra validity to the first past the post electoral system, because every vote would count. Even votes for runners-up would contribute funding to their parties.

To enable new parties to start up, limited private donations could be allowed for parties with less than 5% of the national vote.
David Vail
London

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: New paedophile fear in Belgium
fields.body:
New paedophile fear in Belgium

Arrest warrants have been issued against six alleged paedophiles, police in the south-east Belgian town of Bastogne confirmed yesterday after a paper said sexual abuse of a 14-year old girl was suspected.

La Dernière Heure reported that the accused included the girl's father and a doctor. Belgium was shocked in the mid-90s by the Marc Dutroux paedophile case.
AP, Brussels

Rally opposes race attacks

About 8,000 people, including some local leaders, held a protest rally yesterday in the east German city of Cottbus against recent hate attacks.

Brandenburg state, which surrounds Berlin, has lately seen three anti-foreigner or anti-Semitic incidents, two in Cottbus.
AP, Cottbus

Blasts go off in Iran's capital

Five explosions were heard in the area of Mellat Park in north Tehran yesterday, state radio said.

The opposition Mujahideen Khalq later claimed it had mounted a mortar attack on the state security forces' command near the park.
Reuters, Tehran

webTitle: Appeal by woman facing the hangman

fields.headline: Appeal by woman facing the hangman
fields.trailText: British and African judges are to hear an appeal this week by a white South African socialite sentenced to hang in Botswana for a killing described by the prosecution as embracing "the four Ls of murder - love, loot, lust and loathing".
fields.body:
British and African judges are to hear an appeal this week by a white South African socialite sentenced to hang in Botswana for a killing described by the prosecution as embracing "the four Ls of murder - love, loot, lust and loathing".

Sir John Blufeld from England and Lord Weir of Scotland will sit with three other Commonwealth judges - from Nigeria, Zimbabwe and South Africa - to constitute the Botswana appeals court, as stipulated under the former colony's judicial provisions.

If executed, Marietta Bosch will be the first woman to hang in Botswana for 30 years. She was sentenced to death a year ago for the murder of a close friend, Maria Wolmarans, whose husband she later married.

The appeal hearing begins on Wednesday, the fiftieth birthday of the mother of three. Bosch is represented by a British barrister, Desmond de Silva.

Marietta Bosch moved to Botswana with her first husband nine years ago and settled in a well-off area of the capital Gaborone where they became friends with Maria and Tienie Wolmarans.

Then Bosch's husband was killed in a car crash in 1995. Within months she started an affair with Mr Wolmarans. He promised to divorce his wife but apparently not quickly enough for Bosch.

In June 1996, she borrowed a pistol from a friend in South Africa, returned home and shot Mrs Wolmarans twice. Police were unable to solve the crime, but Bosch made what could prove to be two fatal mistakes.

She revealed her relationship with Tienie Wolmarans by ordering a wedding dress from a Pretoria designer, and she gave the murder weapon to her late husband's brother. His wife, Juliet - said in court to loathe Marietta Bosch - took it to the police.

After Bosch was arrested, Tienie Wolmarans married her, even though she was charged with killing his wife.

Isaac Aboagye, the high court judge in Botswana who sentenced Bosch to death a year ago, told her: "I have not been able to find one moral extenuating circumstance."

If the appeal is turned down, Bosch will still be entitled to a clemency hearing. Of the 14 death sentences in Botswana in the past decade, six have been commuted.

webTitle: Pinochet evades medical tests

fields.headline: Pinochet evades medical tests
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: General Augusto Pinochet defied a court order to submit to medical tests at a hospital in Santiago yesterday, and instead remained holed up with military allies in his seaside home.
fields.body:
General Augusto Pinochet defied a court order to submit to medical tests at a hospital in Santiago yesterday, and instead remained holed up with military allies in his seaside home, south-west of the Chilean capital.

Investigating judge Juan Guzman and a five-strong team comprising two psychiatrists, two psychologists and a neurologist had attended the Hospital Militar to conduct two days of examinations on the former dictator.

They were seeking to determine whether he would be mentally fit to stand trial for his alleged role in masterminding hundreds of kidnappings and murders during his 1973-1990 rule.

But Gen Pinochet, 85, and his legal team are refusing to cooperate with the medical examinations in the hope that they can stall questioning of the general, scheduled for tomorrow. The Chilean supreme court has ruled that the medical tests must precede the questioning.

In response to the refusal to be examined, human rights lawyers reiterated their calls for Judge Guzman to place Gen Pinochet under house arrest, to ensure that he will be questioned about his role in the executions known as the Caravan of Death.

"The Pinochet family said long ago that he was not crazy and would not submit to tests," said human rights lawyer Hugo Guttierez as he waited outside the Hospital Militar. "This is the result of a strategy that was decided months ago."

Gen Pinochet's defence had initially hoped to use the tests at the Hospital Militar to protect the former ruler from the courts. For months the team sought to have the medical exams conducted exclusively by the army-run institution.

That request, however, was denied by Judge Guzman, who determined that civilian institutions must verify all tests to avoid charges that Gen Pinochet's medical team would inject him with drugs to alter the results.

Judge Guzman's suspicion that Gen Pinochet was guilty of "doping" infuriated the general's defence, who requested that the judge be removed from the case because of what they called his "perturbed behaviour and lack of serenity".

Few people expect Gen Pinochet to appear today for the second day of scheduled tests. Yesterday, relatives of Pinochet victims holding placards with photos of their executed family members protested outside the hospital, as a lone armed guard patrolled.

According to Chilean press reports, the army is preparing to reinforce security at the Hospital Militar to give Gen Pinochet the option of using the building as a refuge from justice.

By declaring Gen Pinochet "suddenly ill", the military could then transport him to the hospital and refuse to have him questioned, citing his fragile condition.

This strategy has been used repeatedly by the Chilean army in the past to protect top officials facing murder and torture charges.

Many opponents of the Pinochet regime died in the Hospital Militar, including General Augusto Lutz, head of army intelligence, whose mysterious death was never cleared up.

"My dad said: 'If anything happens to me, don't take me to the Hospital Militar, because from there I will never leave alive'," said Patricia Lutz, his daughter.

"He was head of military intelligence, he knew there were strange operations going on inside. You have to remember that Pinochet had sophisticated chemists to destroy people," she said, referring to the regime's experiments with the nerve gas sarin.

webTitle: Dakar rally gathers Saharan war clouds

fields.headline: Dakar rally gathers Saharan war clouds
fields.trailText: Competitors in the 23rd Paris-Dakar rally roared unharmed into the disputed Western Sahara yesterday despite the threat of a resumption of Africa's last colonial war by the Polisario Front independence movement.
fields.byline: Rory Carroll in Western Sahara and  Gilles Trequesser  in Rabat
fields.body:
Competitors in the 23rd Paris-Dakar rally roared unharmed into the disputed Western Sahara yesterday despite the threat of a resumption of Africa's last colonial war by the Polisario Front independence movement.

Machine guns, silent for almost 10 years, were greased and mounted on jeeps in preparation for possible Polisario assaults against a long-established defensive wall hundreds of miles long and guarded by the Moroccan army.

An official from the United Nations mission in Layoune, the capital of occupied Western Sahara, said the situation was "very tense".

Ignoring the glint of enemy helmets, squads of Polisario sappers plotted at the weeekend to clear minefields and blast holes in the wall, allowing their mechanised infantry to race into Western Sahara from their bases in Algeria.

Morocco's decision to route this year's rally through Western Sahara, which it invaded in 1975 as the Spanish colonial authorities were pulling out, has infuriated the Polisario front. Its leaders accuse rally organisers of in effect endorsing the annexation of the region. The sight of more than 350 race and support vehicles rumbling across the desert from Goulimine to Smara through part of the rebels' home has been declared a provocation; tensions have grown steadily since a ceasefire was brokered in 1991.

A referendum on whether Western Sahara should be independent or integrated into its northern neighbour has been delayed by haggling about voter eligibility for nine years, during which time Morocco has consolidated its occupation despite UN resolutions supporting the Sahrawis' right to self-determination.

"The organisers of the rally have decided to cross our territory at a decisive moment in the evolution of our struggle," said the Polisario president, Mohammed Abdel Aziz.

The movement's military commanders have maintained a studied ambiguity about whether they would attack the rally's participants.

Morocco's leader, King Mohammed VI, has followed his late father, Hassan II, in claiming the barren but phosphate-rich land as part of his country's medieval empire.

Billions of pounds and 300,000 settlers have been poured into the territory.

Polisario fears being pressured into accepting limited autonomy in which 250,000 Sahrawis could be swallowed up by 30m Moroccans.

After a short-lived detente with King Mohammed, Algeria, where the independence movement is based, is believed to have given the green light for an offensive. Fresh supplies of food and fuel are being ferried from the Algerian town of Tindouf to four nearby Polisario camps, home to more than 100,000 people.

The UN special envoy for Western Sahara, the former US diplomat William Eagleton, said sending the rally there did not constitute "recognition of the sovereignty of either side over the territory, whose final status...remains to be determined".

He said: "Any hostile action by either party would constitute a gross violation of the ceasefire, and would only serve to undermine the ongoing efforts towards achieving an early, durable and agreed resolution of the dispute."

The failure of the UN mission to hold a referendum on the territory's status is a defeat for the organisation and its secretary general Kofi Annan. His personal representative, the former US secretary of state James Baker, invested years in attempting to resolve the issue.

The mood in the Polisario camps is for a return to war. A quarter of a century of waiting in exile to reclaim their homeland has seen their anger swell. Ahmed Zaid, deputy governor of the Smara camp, said the ceasefire had been a disaster. "We have been here in miserable conditions, with never enough water, food or medicine, for too long. We need to act."

Gilles Trequesser is a Reuters correspondent

webTitle: Trouble for another Bush cabinet choice

fields.headline: Trouble for another Bush cabinet choice
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: Linda Chavez, George W Bush's choice as labour secretary in his new cabinet, had an illegal Guatemalan migrant living in her home and gave her spending money for doing odd jobs, according to a TV programme.
fields.body:
Linda Chavez, George W Bush's choice as labour secretary in his new cabinet, had an illegal Guatemalan migrant living in her home and gave her spending money for doing odd jobs, according to a TV programme.

Ms Chavez is already under fire from unions and the women's movement.

The employment of illegal aliens was used by the Republicans to derail President Clinton's nominees in the past.

Ms Chavez suspected that the woman was in the US illegally, but did not consider she was employing her, according an ABC programme, This Week. But the revelation is likely to count against her at Senate confirmation hearings.

Along with John Ashcroft, nominated as attorney general, and Gale Norton, nominated as secretary of the interior, Ms Chavez is seen as vulnerable. It has even been suggested by some commentators that she is being offered as a sacrifical lamb so that other nominees get through easily.

Senate Democratic leader Tom Daschle of South Dakota said yesterday that if the allegations were true, Ms Chavez would face a serious problem getting confirmed.

Outside Congress, the AFL-CIO labour federation is to announce its opposition to the nomination tomorrow. Its president, John Sweeney, said yesterday that Ms Chavez had opposed almost every major labour reform of the past two decades from affirmative action to a minimum wage.

Ms Chavez, 53, a conservative columnist and former lobbyist for the American Federation of Teachers, was director of the US Civil Rights Commission under President Reagan and is the president of the Centre for Equal Opportunity which opposes affirmative action. She is the daughter of a housepainter and a restaurant worker.

In her columns she has referred to people who bring sexual harassment actions as "cry-babies" and challenged the idea that women face obstacles to advancement in business.

A spokesman for the Bush administration defended Ms Chavez yesterday: "She comes from a working-class background. She has a record of promoting the interests of working people."

When Ms Chavez met the press last week in Texas, she said: "I intend to keep faith with the men and the women who still work at jobs like those my parents held."

Ms Chavez is already under fire from unions and the women's movement. The employment of illegal aliens was used by the Republicans to derail President Clinton's nominees in the past. Ms Chavez suspected that the woman was in the US illegally, but did not consider she was employing her, according an ABC programme, This Week. But the revelation is likely to count against her at Senate confirmation hearings. Along with John Ashcroft, nominated as attorney general, and Gale Norton, nominated as secretary of the interior, Ms Chavez is seen as vulnerable. It has even been suggested by some commentators that she is being offered as a sacrifical lamb so that other nominees get through easily. Senate Democratic leader Tom Daschle of South Dakota said yesterday that if the allegations were true, Ms Chavez would face a serious problem getting confirmed. Outside Congress, the AFL-CIO labour federation is to announce its opposition to the nomination tomorrow. Its president, John Sweeney, said yesterday that Ms Chavez had opposed almost every major labour reform of the past two decades from affirmative action to a minimum wage. Ms Chavez, 53, a conservative columnist and former lobbyist for the American Federation of Teachers, was director of the US Civil Rights Commission under President Reagan and is the president of the Centre for Equal Opportunity which opposes affirmative action. She is the daughter of a housepainter and a restaurant worker. In her columns she has referred to people who bring sexual harassment actions as "cry-babies" and challenged the idea that women face obstacles to advancement in business. A spokesman for the Bush administration defended Ms Chavez yesterday: "She comes from a working-class background. She has a record of promoting the interests of working people." webTitle: Help for wife mutilated by husband

fields.headline: Help for wife mutilated by husband
fields.trailText: Zahida Perveen's husband cut off her nose and ears because he suspected her of seeing another man. He blinded her in one eye, too, she says. She was pregnant at the time.
fields.body:
Zahida Perveen's husband cut off her nose and ears because he suspected her of seeing another man. He blinded her in one eye, too, she says. She was pregnant at the time.

That was in 1998. Yesterday, Ms Perveen, 24, left to have medical treatment in the US to try to fix her mutilated face.

The brutal attack has outraged human rights workers who demand tougher penalties for the domestic violence prevalent in Pakistan.

"I wish they would do to my husband what he did to me," Ms Perveen said before leaving. Her husband was eventually convicted of attempted murder and sentenced to 14 years in jail - the maximum for this kind of crime.

But many others go free: police are reluctant to investigate cases of domestic violence and often fail to press charges.

In male-dominated Pakistan girls are generally married off at puberty to men chosen by their parents. The literacy rate is around 30% but among women it is believed to be closer to 5%. Most girls are taken out of school and put into servitude at a young age.

The pending medical treatment for Zahida Perveen - who gave birth to a baby girl in July 1999 - is being paid for jointly by Pakistanis living in the US and the Pakistan government, her lawyer, Naheeda Mehboob Ilahai, said.

So-called "honour killings" are rampant in Pakistan, where men, often husbands and brothers, kill women they say have harmed the public standing of the family. Their crime may be to sit next to a man other than a relative.

Pakistan's Human Rights Commission has documented hundreds of cases of brutal attacks against women, some accused of simply looking in the direction of another man. Successive governments in Pakistan have condemned the practice.

These killings "are immoral acts of cowardice", Attiya Inayatullah, minister for women's development in the military government, said at the weekend. "It is the most pervasive form of violence."

webTitle: Polls scare Barak into alliance with Peres

fields.headline: Polls scare Barak into alliance with Peres
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, turned at the weekend to a man he has sidelined for the past 18 months - Shimon Peres - to save him from defeat in the prime ministerial election on February 6.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, turned at the weekend to a man he has sidelined for the past 18 months - Shimon Peres - to save him from defeat in the prime ministerial election on February 6.

His belated interest in a rapprochement with the man awarded the Nobel peace prize for his efforts to bring peace to Israel was spurred by the opinion polls, which show the hardline challenger for the premiership, Ariel Sharon, winning half the votes.

The momentum could increase today when tens of thousands of rightwingers, many of them flown in from the US and Europe, converge outside Jerusalem's ancient walls to protest against the a proposal in the current US peace plan for the area that would divide the Old City between Israel and the Palestinians.

Mr Barak hopes that Mr Peres can help him persuade leftwingers and Arabs that he is still a peacemaker. But the prospect of a peace deal being agreed before Bill Clinton relinquishes the US presidency on January 20 seems all but dead, Israeli and Palestinian officials said yesterday. And any hope that the two sides might resume security cooperation soon was shrinking, too.

Israeli officials accused Palestinian military intelligence of recruiting the Jordanian man who bombed a Tel Aviv bus last month. That accusation cast a shadow over the security talks in Cairo between the CIA director, George Tenet, and Israeli and Palestinian officials.

The Israelis said the bomber, Abdallah Abu Jaber, a citizen of Jordan where Palestinians form a majority, was given the bomb by Palestinian agents in Nablus. He was working in Israel at the time.

The peace camp is hugely disillusioned with Mr Barak, and Labour party activists are afraid that a low turnout or spoiled ballots may give Mr Sharon victory by default.

Mr Barak's standing in the party is so low that he has to fend off calls from his cabinet ministers and a petition from party activists to step aside for Mr Peres.

Yesterday he was reduced to telling Israel Radio that he would fight the election even if he had only four supporters.

He is reaching out to Mr Peres as insurance. At the weekend the two appeared together on TV, promising to work for peace, just as Mr Peres worked with Yitzhak Rabin.

"The goal is not to become prime minister. It is to do the best for the state of Israel," Mr Peres said.

The Israeli press has speculated that Mr Peres could be rewarded with the post of foreign minister, a giant step up from the ministry of regional cooperation, where he has been languishing in recent months. He is also reported to have been promised a leading role in the peace negotiations.

"I am not looking for a job," he maintained. "I am convinced we have to work together for the good of the country."

The effort to unite the centre and left is intended to counter today's rightwing show of strength in Jerusalem. The organisers say they have raised hundreds of thousands of dollars abroad, provoking a debate on the right of Jews living outside Israel to influence policy.

They have also roped in some high-powered supporters who accuse Mr Barak of betraying all Jews by contemplating compromises in Jerusalem.

"Jerusalem is the identity of all the Jewish people," said the sometime Soviet dissident Natan Sharansky, who has helped to mobilise Israel's 1m Russian immigrants against concessions to the Palestinians. "Our argument is that this government is out of step with the will of the people."

webTitle: Blair 'proud to have won backing of the wealthy'

fields.headline: Blair 'proud to have won backing of the wealthy'
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair said yesterday that far from being embarrassed he was "absolutely proud" to have won the backing of wealthy business people who make donations to the Labour party.
fields.body:
Tony Blair said yesterday that far from being embarrassed he was "absolutely proud" to have won the backing of wealthy business people who make donations to the Labour party.

And he rejected calls for state funding of political parties on the grounds that voters would not stand for it.

Mr Blair said on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost: "I think I probably speak for any political leader of any political party when I say that I would be delighted if we never had to raise a single penny piece in political funding. But I don't think the support is there from the public."

Making a determined effort to regain ground lost because of last week's news of three £2m gifts, the prime minister told David Frost: "Providing the proper transparency and rules are there - and for the first time, we are actually introducing rules - we have got to recognise it is not a bad thing, it is a good thing."

However, as new details about donations emerged, Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, joined demands for more state funding to restore public confidence after what he called the "megabucks" controversy.

"That is not good for the political process," said Mr Kennedy. "It is just going to turn people off. If people felt there was transparency about their politics, they might feel better about politics."

When it emerged yesterday that one of the trio - probably Mr Ondaatje - had sent his cheque from the tax haven of Bermuda, the Conservatives renewed their claims of hypocrisy.

"Labour has always postured as whiter than white," Ann Widdecombe complained on GMTV's Sunday programme.

But Mr Blair had plainly taken a decision not to apologise when he made his annual New Year appearance on the Frost sofa.

"I am absolutely proud of the fact that we have got successful entrepreneurs and disaffected Conservatives who look at the state of the Conservative party and say, 'It is hopeless, it is incapable of governing the country properly', and support the Labour Party," he said.

Activists and MPs within the Labour party have also been troubled by the scale of donations made by Lords Sainsbury and Hamlyn, and the Anglo-Canadian financier, Christopher Ondaatje, ahead of the general election.

"It looks a bit bad, in fact sometimes it looks a bit tacky," the GMB union leader, John Edmonds, admitted yesterday.

Labour is divided over the issue of party donations. Both factions agree that Millbank initially mishandled the Hamlyn donation. But some MPs are angry that the media has given them no credit for embracing the Nolan/Neill anti-sleaze reforms on party funding which come into force on February 16 - and were resisted by the Tories.

Labour backbencher Peter Bradley twisted that knife yesterday when he announced that he received a letter from the Metropolitan police confirming that a 10-month investigation into an alleged hacking into Tory party computers had produced no evidence of a crime.

The investigation was launched after the MP for The Wrekin revealed in 1999 that a large donation to Tory funds from the party treasurer, Michael (now Lord) Ashcroft, had come from the tax haven of Belize.

Mr Bradley said yesterday that the claim was a smokescreen to distract attention from the Belize link. He has written to the police asking for details of who requested the investigation, how much it had cost and whether anyone would be charged with wasting police time.

Both the Tory and the Labour partys are fundraising hard in the hope of having all the £15-20m election budgets which this week will be officially "capped" for the first time. Yesterday's newspapers reported that Labour's war chest contains £10m and that six gifts between £100,000 and £450,000 have also been received.

Millbank did not comment other than to say it "has taken a lead in reforming party funding, which is why since 1995 we have declared all donations over £5,000 and banned foreign donors. The party goes to considerable lengths to ensure all our donors are eligible under the rules and there is no suggestion that the rules have been broken in any way".

webTitle: Girl, 7, killed in plunge over 250ft falls

fields.headline: Girl, 7, killed in plunge over 250ft falls
fields.trailText: The mother of a seven-year-old British girl who was swept over a 250ft waterfall in South Africa last week has finally been informed of her daughter's death after being herself knocked unconscious while trying to rescue the child.
fields.body:
The mother of a seven-year-old British girl who was swept over a 250ft waterfall in South Africa last week has finally been informed of her daughter's death after being herself knocked unconscious while trying to rescue the child.

South African police said Bethany Park, from Rochdale, Greater Manchester, slipped from wet rocks on a viewing area at Lisbon Falls in Mpumalanga province on Thursday. Her mother, Amanda, jumped in and grabbed hold of her.

The two were swept about 30ft down the fall when it appeared that Mrs Park hit her head on a rock and lost hold of her daughter. Bethany was swept more than 150ft over the main fall.

"The little girl tried to jump from one rock to another when her foot slipped and she fell in," said police captain Charle Beukes. "Her mother tried to grab her and both went over one of the top two waterfalls. But the mother become trapped on a rock near the edge of the third one, bumping her head heavily."

Bethany's father, Courtney, dragged his daughter from the water and attempted to give her mouth to mouth resucitation but in vain.

Mrs Park, 32, was saved when she was trapped by a rock on the lip of the last fall, but she was so badly injured that it took several hours to rescue her. She was taken to a Pretoria hospital by helicopter.

Police said Mrs Park was not informed of her daughter's death until the weekend because she was heavily sedated after emergency surgery to her back.

The family was on holiday, visiting Mr Park's brother, who works in Johannesburg. The couple also have a three year-old daughter, Abigail.

Mpumalanga's tourism minister, Calvin Gilsellan, said there were warning signs at the Lisbon Falls, but they could be difficult for a child to understand. "After a thorough investigation we will decide what must be done. If fences can secure the falls, they will be erected," he said.

Bethany was the second young British tourist to die in a freak accident in South Africa last week. Cara Weaver, 14, was killed in Cape Town on Wednesday when she was caught in the mechanics of a cable car as she prepared to abseil off Table Mountain.

webTitle: Deals plea to keep peace process alive

fields.headline: Deals plea to keep peace process alive
fields.standfirst:
Unionist hardliners try to force Trimble out of power sharing
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: All sides warned yesterday of the danger of the Northern Ireland political process falling apart if some consensus on demilitarisation, paramilitary decommissioning and policing is not found in the next few weeks.
fields.body:
All sides warned yesterday of the danger of the Northern Ireland political process falling apart if some consensus on demilitarisation, paramilitary decommissioning and policing is not found in the next few weeks.

Hardliners within the Ulster Unionists are set to call a crucial meeting of the party's ruling council around the end of the month to try and force the leader, David Trimble, to pull out of the power-sharing Stormont government if the IRA has not made serious progress on disarmament.

Sir Reg Empey, a Trimble ally on the moderate wing, warned: "Everybody is getting sick and tired of the endless dance around the issue. Republicans have got to decide whether they want this process to work or whether they are going to keep on playing games.

"They agreed on paper last May to put their weapons beyond use so why don't they just do it? The longer they drag this out the more difficult they make it to sustain and grow support for the Good Friday agreement."

Republicans, who are blaming Tony Blair for the deadlock, want a substantial security scaledown, particularly in heavily fortified south Armagh, while both Sinn Fein and the largest nationalist party, the SDLP, want a much more radical overhaul of policing than the police bill which could lead to a delay in implementing planned reforms.

Gerry Kelly, the IRA bomber turned senior Sinn Fein politician, claimed: "The British government is in danger of bringing about the breakdown of the institutions and the whole agreement."

The SDLP policing spokesman, Alex Attwood, denied he had less room for flexibility due to heightened pre-electoral competition with Sinn Fein, but insisted his party must be able to offer young nationalists a degree of confidence in the reforms before it could take its seats on the new police board.

He wants assurances on a number of matters, including the neutrality of the future police emblem and the flying of flags, the merger of special branch and CID, the closure of Gough barracks in Armagh, the phasing out of the full-time reserve and entry of garda officers into the new service.

Mr Attwood is also keen to see credible, independent investigations into the murders of lawyers Rosemary Nelson and Pat Finucane, and Portadown Catholic Robert Hamill.

"We want to be able to join the police board and negotiations are far from over," he said. "There are a whole series of meetings going on and progress has been made. But this issue is so central to nationalists that we need to have a credible degree of confidence before we go in, or the whole thing could unravel in months and young Catholics will then not join the new service."

A senior government source denied that reforms would be put on ice if the SDLP refused to nominate representatives to the police board by the end of the month, but agreed any postponement would have practical consequences.

The 19-strong board, of which 10 members will be politicians, is scheduled to be in place by the beginning of February, so that it can oversee the first batch of recruits in April.

"It is over-egging the pudding to say reforms would be shelved," said the source. "However, the SDLP say they want a new police service as soon as possible but they are holding it up."

Sir Reg Empey was critical of the SDLP for not backing the police bill, contrasting it with the risk Ulster Unionists took in sharing power with Sinn Fein even though they were unhappy over the lack of IRA decommissioning.

"The SDLP have not, as yet, had to take a difficult decision as we have done," he said. "It is indefensible for them to continue to hang back. As Patten commission member Maurice Hayes said, 'It's better to have 90% of something than 100% of nothing'.

"They are going to have to make up their minds or the government should call a halt to the reforms. What is the point of going through torturous change if we still don't know if they will support it?"

Tensions within loyalism were also growing as the Shankill Road Ulster Freedom Fighter leader, Johnny Adair, awaited a sentence review commission decision, due tomorrow, on whether he will be let out of jail. Either way there are fears of renewed violence between Protestant paramilitaries which could spill over into attacks on Catholics.

The finger was pointed at the UFF's associates, the Ulster Defence Association, for the murder of a former senior member from east Belfast, George Legge, stabbed and dumped in a field on the outskirts of the city on Saturday after an alleged row over drugs.

And there were fears of a split in the Ulster Democratic Party, the political wing of the UDA/UFF, the biggest loyalist paramilitary grouping in Northern Ireland, with many of its grassroots said to have turned against the Good Friday agreement.

The UDP leader, Gary McMichael, son of the murdered UDA chief John McMichael and a staunch supporter of the 1998 peace accord, said he would have to consider quitting if the party changed its policy.

Tensions within loyalism were also growing as the Shankill Road Ulster Freedom Fighter leader, Johnny Adair, awaited a sentence review commission decision, due tomorrow, on whether he will be let out of jail. Either way there are fears of renewed violence between Protestant paramilitaries which could spill over into attacks on Catholics. The finger was pointed at the UFF's associates, the Ulster Defence Association, for the murder of a former senior member from east Belfast, George Legge, stabbed and dumped in a field on the outskirts of the city on Saturday after an alleged row over drugs. And there were fears of a split in the Ulster Democratic Party, the political wing of the UDA/UFF, the biggest loyalist paramilitary grouping in Northern Ireland, with many of its grassroots said to have turned against the Good Friday agreement. The UDP leader, Gary McMichael, son of the murdered UDA chief John McMichael and a staunch supporter of the 1998 peace accord, said he would have to consider quitting if the party changed its policy.

webTitle: US marathon run with all mod cons

fields.headline: US marathon run with all mod cons
fields.trailText: With his plan to run across America for charity, he hoped to follow in the footsteps of his film hero Forrest Gump.
fields.body:
With his plan to run across America for charity, he hoped to follow in the footsteps of his film hero Forrest Gump.

In the movie, Gump attracted growing attention from the public and media from his epic run. But yesterday, former army commando Mark Llewhellin, admitted taking a few short cuts.

Mr Llewhellin, 26, from Haverfordwest, had set a goal of running 2,000 miles from Denver to San Francisco in a little over two months to raise money for the Caldwell Trust, a British-based charity that works with terminally ill children.

He started on September 6, but after catching flu in Utah, he hitched a 380 mile ride across the Arizona border.

He also ditched his tent after finding it too heavy and the hospitality of the Americans too hard to resist. Mr Llewhellin spent most of his nights staying free in comfortable hotel rooms after a nocturnal visit by a bear made it too risky to camp out.

There was also little need for the bulky food rations in his pack after fast-food restaurants offered him free meals for most of the run, resulting in him gaining weight rather than losing it by the end of his trip.

"Forrest started running and just decided to keep on going but I knew exactly what I was doing," said Mark, who returned home four weeks ago.

"I set myself the target of running across the States to prove to myself I could do it. But because a sponsorship deal with the NSPCC fell through at the last moment I started the run with just $150 in my pocket. I had to rely on the generosity of the people I met and they did not let me down."

He added: "Despite all the training in Wales, leaving Denver was the hardest thing. It's called the Mile High City, and as I set off it took me to 10,000 ft. I wasn't used to running at that altitude and with my pack there were places where I couldn't do more than walk. I soon realised I was carrying too much stuff."

Mr Llewhellin took 60 days to complete his journey, which is expected to raise around £500 for charity.

webTitle: Man's death in hostel fire prompts murder inquiry

fields.headline: Man's death in hostel fire prompts murder inquiry
fields.trailText: A man was killed in an arson attack on a hostel for homeless people yesterday.
fields.body:
A man was killed in an arson attack on a hostel for homeless people yesterday.

A fire started at the Kendal hotel, in Cumbria, in the early hours. Cumbria police believe it was started deliberately in a second floor bedroom and have launched a murder inquiry.

The fire spread to the first and third floors of the hostel which adjoins a nightclub.

Firefighters rescued the 62-year-old man, but he was unconscious and later died in hospital.

He was believed to be from County Antrim, although police said he was a long-term resident at the hostel and had previously lived in Carlisle. He will be identified today.

A 41-year-old local man was arrested and questioned yesterday and police said they were expecting to make more arrests. The owner of the hostel said that 18 months ago, someone had set fire to a bed in an upstairs bedroom.

Eight people lived at the hostel, situated off Kendal's main street. Police said it was one of very few hostels in Kendal, a town which is a key Lake District tourist destination.

Two other people from the hostel were thought to have been treated by paramedics, but police said the majority of residents appeared to have been out at the time of the fire.

The Department of Social Security said the hostel residents were an example of a local authority social services practice of finding bed and breakfast accommodation for people on housing or unemployment benefit.

The department would not comment on the safety of such arrangements.

webTitle: Police set sights on Yardies' gun dealers

fields.headline: Police set sights on Yardies' gun dealers
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in Britain
fields.trailText: A network of unlicensed gun dealers are charging black gang members £250 for the loan of a weapon and demanding double the fee if someone is shot, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A network of unlicensed gun dealers are charging black gang members £250 for the loan of a weapon and demanding double the fee if someone is shot, it emerged yesterday.

It is believed that a small number of dealers can be linked to almost all so-called Yardie-style killings which are blighting inner city areas in London, the west Midlands and Manchester.

Detectives in some of the areas worst hit by the violence are to concentrate much of their efforts this year in tracing and prosecuting those who hold the weapons.

Commander Michael Fuller, in charge of Operation Trident in London, said it was impossible to say how many dealers existed. But he said it had become apparent that many of the shootings in London this year were carried out with the same weapons.

In London last year there were 13 such murders and some 34 attempted murders. He said: "What we are seeking to do a lot more is to identify the armourers. If we are able to take these people out, it will help starve the market. There are not that many weapons out there."

Commander Fuller said gunmen were hiring weapons for £250-£300 but were forced to pay up to £500 if the weapon was used.

The attacks could be mostly linked to drugs and there was evidence that the black gangs were moving out of the capital and into the provinces.

He also said that the weapons are often held by wives or girlfriends and appealed to them to come forward, promising that they would be saving lives.

In the summer the Metropolitan police announced that an elite unit - codenamed Operation Trident - would focus all its efforts on cutting the number of murders in black gang disputes in London. Previously Trident, made up of some 160 officers, had looked at all gun crime in the capital.

Since then more than 50 armed operations have taken place. In November Scotland Yard put on display a collection of more than 30 weapons it had seized.

Among them was a Mac 10 sub-machinegun, capable of firing 20 rounds a second, and a variety of powerful handguns.

But between Christmas Day and New Year's Day 11 shootings took place in London, an explosion of violence which police are linking to a crack cocaine turf war among gangs based around Hackney, east London, and Tottenham, north London.

One of the great difficulties for detectives trying to infiltrate and gain information is the loose and disorganised nature of the Yardie gangs.

Extreme violence can be triggered by a trivial dispute, such as a gang member's girlfriend being barred from a nightclub.

It is believed that many of the hitmen travel from Jamaica, where the Yardies are a dangerous and powerful force.

Police and Home Office officials have held talks in an attempt to limit the number of suspected Yardies entering Britain.

webTitle: Branson looks at an alternative lottery

fields.headline: Branson looks at an alternative lottery
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson is considering the launch of a non-profit making game to rival the National Lottery.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson is considering the launch of a non-profit making game to rival the National Lottery.

The plan is a fall-back position for Sir Richard, whose People's Lottery lost out in the contest against Camelot for the next licence to run the national lottery at the end of last year.

He will meet lawyers tomorrow before deciding whether to challenge that decision through the courts.

Sir Richard is also considering legal action to recoup the estimated £30m spent on his attempt to win the licence during last year's protracted and often farcical bidding process. "The National Lottery Commission said in its judgment that it was basically too risky to change operators, so you have to ask, 'why put us through all this in the first place?'" said one of Sir Richard's advisers.

Sir Richard was shocked by the judgment in late December which overturned an earlier decision naming the People's Lottery as preferred bidder. Lawyers for the People's Lottery believe it may be able to force a judicial review based on the fairness and legality of the commission's U-turn.

A spokesman for the People's Lottery said Sir Richard had been encouraged to consider an alternative lottery by support from the public since December's announcement.

"We've had an enormous number of calls and letters suggesting we launch an alternative lottery for good causes and we have a team of lawyers looking into it," he said.

He also pointed to the poor sales of National Lottery tickets during recent weeks. The new year Big Draw jackpot game sold less than 25m tickets, compared with 80m at the end of 1999.

The People's Lottery was left smarting on Friday after a request to publish the two rival bids in full was turned down by the commission.

The commission also rejected a request for a meeting with executives from the company today.

People's Lottery chief executive Simon Burridge accused the commission of making a derisory response to its request and was sharply critical of the commission's chairman, Lord Burns, for failing to sign the letter himself. "Lord Burns has gone on the record as saying that the decision was the result of a fair and open evaluation," Mr Burridge said.

"Given that the commission's response fails to address any of the substantive issues we raised, it is impossible to judge whether the process has indeed been either fair or open."

The People's Lottery maintains that during the lifetime of the seven-year licence it would raise £770m more for good causes than Camelot.

A spokesman for the National Lottery Commission said the regulator had already given its reasons for awarding the licence to Camelot, and was not under any pressure to explain itself further.

"It is incumbent upon us as a public body to make sure that we have explained any decisions we make and we have done so in black and white, in plain English and in detail," he said, referring to the six-page statement of reasons issued with the judgment in December.

webTitle: Comment: Roy Hattersley: My high life with Sally Greene

fields.headline: My high life with Sally Greene
fields.standfirst:
That night I was included among New Labour's beautiful people

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: That night I was included among New Labour's beautiful people.
fields.body:
In the light of recent reports, I feel it necessary to make a formal statement about my relationship with Sally Greene - described in last week's papers as "a well-known hostess in London high life". Our association began entirely innocently when she asked me to join the advisory committee of one of her theatres. Among the other members were Dame Shirley Porter, Tim Renton (a Tory arts minister who had retired hurt) and Lord Attenborough. At the first meeting Dame Shirley announced that she was "not prepared to be associated with failure" and I complained about her unprovoked assault on the principle that had guided my whole life. Ms Greene did not laugh. If the advisers met again, I did not hear about it.

Years passed. Then my old friend Harry Evans invited me to a party to mark his wife's appointment (that is the right word) as a Companion of the British Empire. The celebration took place at a house in Cheyne Walk, which I now realise belonged to Ms Greene. Unfortunately, when we met at the door I failed to recognise her. So it may be all over between us. But at least - thanks to the reporters who had the humiliating job of standing in the rain and identifying the guests as they arrived - I was included for the first (and almost certainly the last) time among New Labour's beautiful people.

I felt it necessary to clear my name when I read that Ms Greene "hosted" a birthday party for Peter Mandelson and - as if that were not incrimination enough - is also married to Robert Bourne, the man who is about to buy the dome. No doubt I also met Mr Bourne (whom I must, like all decent journalists, describe as a "multimillionaire property developer") on the night of the Tina Brown-Evans CBE fest. But neither he, nor anyone else I spoke to on that occasion, made me a corrupt offer. I was, however, subject to threats. John Mortimer told me that my determination to vote for a fox hunting ban could only result in the destruction of my libertarian reputation.

So I can argue - without risking allegations of bias or prejudice - that recent newspaper stories about Ms Greene and her husband are squalid nonsense designed to suggest that the Mandelson party was connected with Mr Bourne's acquisition of the dome. Much as I disapprove of Mr Mandelson's politics, I have always admired his intellectual agility. But not even he, at his Machiavellian worst, could have arranged for the Legacy consortium (which Mr Bourne runs) to come second in the competition to buy the site of the Greenwich fiasco and then persuade Nomura (who originally won the bid) to pull out so that Bourne could have a clear run. Yet that is what the people who peddle the party's stories want you, gullible reader, to believe.

Peter Mandelson is a big boy and has proved to be a resilient minister. I am perfectly prepared to leave him to look after himself. My concern is what the story reveals about modern politics. The battle between the parties ought to be concerned with great issues of principle - the nature of the society that the rival philosophies hope to create and the way in which the better life, which they both promise, can be brought about. Because of the death of ideology, the political battle is now more and more concerned with trivia. And, as the Greene-Bourne-Mandelson story illustrates, even the attempts to make trivial mischief are often dependent on innuendo rather than information.

I do not suggest that deferential journalists should feel it their duty to suppress the personal indiscretions of politicians. What concerns me is the prominence now given to stories that should be consigned to gossip columns. I know that when the Conservative party (or the newspapers that support it) choose to fight on the high ground of policies and performance, New Labour wins. Even so, the constant recourse to what thinking people realise is the last refuge of defeated politicians must do the Tories and their allies immense longterm harm. It makes them look, as indeed they are, bereft of a decent idea.

It is usually a person called Andrew Lansley who appears on television to imply some wrongdoing. He makes such a habit of questioning the honour of his opponents that he reminds me of George Wigg, Harold Wilson's personal nark. I can think of no greater criticism. But last week it was Peter Ainsworth, the shadow culture secretary, who was put up to make the statement, which was carefully designed to be damaging without being libellous. He questioned the "judgment" of the party participants and talked about the "impression" of cronyism. When, 50 years ago, becoming an MP was my greatest ambition, I did not realise that such demeaning behaviour would become part of the job. My one consolation is that politics is only conducted in that fashion by people who know that they are already beaten
