webTitle: Comment: An unnecessary election

fields.headline: We are being put through an unnecessary election
fields.standfirst:
Labour should see out a full five-year term before going to the polls

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour should see out a full five-year term before going to the polls.
fields.body:
Is the glass (as Tony Blair asks plangently, gulping his way through Water with Frost) half empty or half full? How much has his government achieved - and how much more is there left to achieve? Questions with only one incontrovertible answer. Whichever way you hold the glass, there's always one-fifth missing inside. That is the price of this unnecessary election.

Will the reckoning come in April or May? Our prime minister dimples and talks time scales: four years to get the police up to strength; six, seven, eight years to restore the NHS; 10 years to transport nirvana. He does not think to fit these aspirations to any electoral schedule: and the odd thing is that nobody thinks to ask him why. He assumes - and we assume - a spring election. However long his span in elected power, he is voluntarily throwing away a year of it.

Normally, of course, there would be no cause for wonder. The British system, in its unreformed flexibility, hands governments a tactical pearl beyond price. Prime ministers can choose the date to their own best advantage. They can jump at a sunshine spot or hang on till the end in the hope that something will turn up. Mr Blair, bathed in sunshine, is only playing the game as usual. But there is nothing usual about his current gameplan.

The choices, he says, are between enduring economic stability and boom and bust, between investment in public services for the long term and lurching cut-backs. Fine. How, though, are those choices burnished by a dive to the polls in April? The economy, on his own recognisance, will be just as stable in 2002. The investments pouring into hospitals and schools will have had 12 more months to deliver results. There is nothing, on the high ground of policy, to make 2001 prime balloting time.

Rather the reverse. Chat to ministers in private and they profess to see only one beast in the forest. Not the crouching tiger Hague and a resurgent opposition: they're only marginally less dismissive of that proposition than their Tory shadows (who have already abandoned hope - and much continuing interest in politics). No, the hidden dragon is apathy. Public opinion polls are one thing, byelection turnouts quite another. Over and over again, given a chance, people stay at home. If they do that in April, then majorities will flake away. Somehow the faithful have to be stirred.

Yet writing in 2001 as election year is a bizarre way to go about it. The very worst byelection results, through decades, come when voters are called out for mere political convenience, when they feel they're being taken for granted. Why bother? And Mr Blair is well set to make this the "Why bother?" general election. He won't be dissolving parliament because he has to (a certainty that, in itself, stokes a little drama and thus interest): he'll be going though the motions of convenience.

Whenever those motions start, of course, there is always a price to pay. A row about party funding that makes politicians seem grubby. A thin Westminster programme stocked with the cheap curfews of vote-grabbing. A nervy hysteria that infects debates. They are with us already: they lower spirits and respect. But they also inflict the one kind of punishment Tony Blair doesn't need. They make him look shifty.

Take the commitment on your party pledge card from 1997. New Labour promises - solemnly promises - to cut the time between arresting and sentencing juvenile offenders. Has that been done? No. Why not? Because it was a pledge for a "five-year parliament" - and this one will run only for four.

Take the trailed shelving of RUC reform, on which Irish progress depends. Why shelve it? Because time is running out and the Belfast parties can't agree. Which time is that, then? The time between now and that general election. Ah! once again, Ulster peace plays second fiddle.

Take - beyond such finite things - the hailing of Gordon's "brilliant" economy for all eternity. Isn't there a hint here, around the edges, of fret as America wobbles close to recession? Buy euphoria now while stocks last?

But maybe the wonkiest element of the lot comes when the PM is obliged to set one timescale against another. He is, he says earnestly, for Europe in principle and for joining the euro in principle. Principle is an earnest word. But time, otherwise racing towards April, is here the sluggard of decision.

Can we have an election where ( pace Brown) Europe isn't much discussed, lies in the long grass? Then have it in April. Could we have an election where, willy-nilly, there had to be a hard-edged debate about the single currency? Absolutely: in April, 2002, when the euro is coins and notes, not a paper calculation, when every voter going to Spain for Easter week has to pay for tapas with euros changed at Thomas Cook's. When reality bites.

Journalists like elections. They get you out of the office. Editors like elections. They still put up circulations (a bit). Politicians like elections they feel sure to win. There is thus no let or hindrance to the spring sprouting just over our horizon. It is ordained. But what will happen is not what need happen: and - in detail or the broad - it betokens nothing good.

Which country in Europe has the lowest electoral participation? Switzerland (which also opens its polling booths most relentlessly). Which great western democracy is most ashamed of its paltry turnout? America, where academics lament what they call a process of "permanent election" that, every two years of fund-raising frenzy, puts the balance of power in pawn.

George W has no hap but to go the same way. That is the nature of the permanent election.

webTitle: Water firms fear law could endanger supply

fields.headline: Water firms fear law could endanger supply
fields.standfirst: Lobbyists claim environmental rules would increase charges
fields.trailText: The water industry will today claim that important elements of the government's draft water bill could lead to higher charges and loss of supply.
fields.body:
The water industry will today claim that important elements of the government's draft water bill could lead to higher charges and loss of supply.

Water UK, the industry's trade body, will tell the Commons environment select committee that the bill, as drafted, would have "unacceptable effects on the service water customers receive and the prices they will be expected to pay".

Pamela Taylor, chief executive of Water UK, said she would be calling for a rethink of the proposals to change the water abstraction regime - the system of licences allowing companies to take water from rivers and aquifers.

She said the changes, which put time limits on new abstraction licences and rescind unused licences, were designed to protect the environment. "But we think they will threaten the security of the country's water supply - which is another way of saying that your water could be cut off - and they will increase costs to customers."

Ms Taylor said the industry would have to replace curtailed licences with others to guarantee supply. The new licences are expected to last for 15 years while unused licences, often held in reserve in the event of droughts, could be revoked if not used for four years.

"The industry will want - will need - to build new abstraction facilities and pipelines," Ms Taylor said. "But these infrastructure investments will be short-lived. This is the essence of the new regime, short-lived licences.

"Shorter payback period of new or old infrastructure will increase costs, which will increase customer bills," she said. "In brief, the new abstraction regime protects the environment, and the price is that there could be supply shortages and higher water bills."

The water companies also want the bill to include legislation to force the industry regulators - Ofwat, the environment agency, the drinking water inspectorate and the environment minister - to work together to reach decisions which balance the environmental, consumer and economic needs.

They claim that under the present system, regulators each fight to protect their own corner, resulting in decisions where one interest group wins at the expense of another.

Water company executives feel that during the last price review, consumers clearly won at the expense of the industry. They are concerned about the bill's emphasis on short term measures at a time when the industry had to plan and build infrastructure which might have to last for up to 100 years.

Ms Taylor said: "We need long-term planning by all regulators and the industry."

She called on the government to set up a national forum to consider the longer term issues affecting customers and the environment.

She wants collaboration between regulators to be overseen by the department of the environment, transport and the regions. "Government, eventually, is responsible for deciding trade-offs and making choices after it has sponsored a transparent debate with our customers." she said.

The industry has plenty of time to lobby ministers and MPs. There was no water bill in the Queen's speech.

webTitle: Business: Tax evaders are not like Robin Hood.

fields.headline: Tax evaders are not like Robin Hood.
fields.standfirst:
They take from all of us and don't give any back
Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: They take from all of us and don't give any back.
fields.body:
Globalisation is breaking down frontiers around the world. For the first time in centuries, freedom is a reality for most people in most countries.

But freedom, both political and economic, can only serve all citizens when exercised responsibly and fairly. Disappearing borders for business, in an environment where law enforcement systems are mostly still anchored in national territories, enable powerful players to seek advantage by abusing freedom to the disadvantage of others.

One of government's most urgent tasks in the 21st century is to create a framework that will allow economic and political freedom to flourish in a climate of fairness.

The stakes are high, and so are the temptations to resort to dirty practices. Bribery and corruption, price-fixing cartels, large scale tax evasion and other abuses of free markets are all part of the dark side of globalisation.

Together, they create a multibillion-dollar drain on the global economy, distorting world trade and the allocation of capital and services.

Why isn't there more of a public outcry against such unfairness? Mostly because abuses of this sort happen out of sight of ordinary citizens. Take illicit tax evasion: by undermining democratically elected governments' ability to raise money through taxation, tax abusers shift financing burdens unfairly on to the shoulders of honest taxpayers.

Deprived of legitimate tax revenues, governments are forced to cut back on social and infrastructure projects that their citizens have voted for or to raise extra taxes to pay for them.

But despite the large sums involved, the effects of tax evasion are thinly spread across the broad body of consumers and taxpayers, with the result that no single individual feels real pain. As we all know, it isn't most people's instinctive reaction to jump to the defence of tax inspectors.

But cheating on taxes isn't some kind of latter day Robin Hood exercise. Make no mistake: when the taxman is cheated, injustice is perpetrated on large numbers of citizens in a subtle, almost invisible manner.

It is against this background that the OECD, an intergovernmental body comprising 30 nations, has launched a drive to address abuses related to globalisation. Through various programmes we are fighting to improve global governance by cracking down on bribery and corruption, price-fixing and fiscal practices that distort competition.

We can't succeed on our own, even though our membership spans Europe, north America and the Asian Pacific. We need cooperation with other countries, and particularly with countries in the developing world.

That's why the OECD, in co-operation with the Commonwealth Secretariat and at the invitation of the government of Barbados, is organising a two day conference on harmful tax practices in Barbados today and tomorrow. At this meeting we will be asking offshore financial centres in the region to join the OECD in trying to bring more transparency and fairness to the global financial system in order to fight against tax evasion. A similar regional conference is planned to take place in Tokyo in February.

Both meetings will build on work that has been going on at the OECD since 1998. As other nations achieve a better understanding of what we are aiming at, international support is growing.

Last June, 29 non-OECD countries took part in an OECD ministerial conference on harmful tax practices and expressed their willingness to work with us. Eight offshore financial centres, including Bermuda, the Cayman Islands and the Isle of Man, have agreed to cooperate with us to eliminate distorting tax practices.

Ultimately, we are convinced that international cooperation to eliminate such tax practices will help to underpin freedom in a global economy.

The tax man is unlikely ever to become most citizens' choice as their best-loved public figure. But by curtailing tax evasion, we hope to pave the way for tax reductions which will make him less unpopular. It is, after all, ordinary taxpayers, in developed and developing countries, who will eventually benefit from these efforts. For globalisation to succeed, freedom and fairness must go hand in hand.

 Seiichi Kondo is deputy secretary-general of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development

webTitle: G2: Profile of Charles Clarke MP

fields.headline: Man with a mission
fields.standfirst:
You've probably never heard of Charles Clarke. But one thing singles him out from countless innocuous Labour MPs - he might be their next leader. John Kampfner meets an arch-operator

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: You've probably never heard of Charles Clarke. But one thing singles him out from countless innocuous Labour MPs - he might be their next leader. John Kampfner meets an arch-operator.
fields.body:
I have this strange hunch. It goes like this. Tony Blair wins the next election, stays on through the whole of the next parliament and then stands down six months into his third term. It is Christmas 2005. The economy is recovering from a mini-recession. The halo has slipped from the chancellor. The man who succeeds Blair is not Gordon Brown. He is bearded and in his mid-50s, and until 2001 wasn't even in the cabinet: he is Charles Clarke.

This theory may be far-fetched but some Labour MPs are also suggesting it as an outside bet. It's all the more curious because, on the face of it - literally - Clarke is not an obvious New Labour man: "I don't know what arch-Blairites look like," he says. "I never had a call saying, would I shave my beard off, would I not talk to journalists. I never had a call saying, 'You've got to check what you say with us'."

The others must have done - the people who are nominally his seniors, such as Stephen Byers, Alastair Darling and Geoff Hoon. Were their promotions to the cabinet linked to the disappearance of their facial hair? "I've no idea, you'd better ask them. One of the things I'm least qualified to give advice on is fashion."

Clarke has taken off his scuffed shoes - shades of Mo Mowlam, perhaps. His suit is a bit rumpled. It is late in the afternoon and he is pouring wine in his seventh-floor room at the Home Office. He is relaxed, but alert. He's the one who has been attacking William Hague over police and race on the airwaves. He's the one piloting four important pieces of legislation into the new, almost certainly brief, parliamentary session.

No other minister will spend anything like as much time at the dispatch box this winter. The issues are central to the government's agenda, and are controversial - vehicle crime, private security services, a criminal justice bill on alcohol-driven yob violence, and the reintroduction of that much-derided mode of trial bill.

This man is no libertarian. He blames the Thatcher years for many, but by no means all, of society's ills. "I do think the 'no such thing as society' culture is deeply embedded in a whole generation of people. A key strategic goal of the Labour government is to rebuild community and society in all its senses. But this can't be changed overnight."

In the meantime, punishment should be tough. So does he agree with his boss, Jack Straw, that a liberal legal establishment is part of the problem? "I'm surrounded by lawyers. My boss is a lawyer. His boss is a lawyer. My fellow ministers of state are lawyers. We have lawyers all over the place."

Straw, he says, has "a far more profound experience of the legal profession and the individuals involved". That is quintessential Clarke: almost agreeing with what his boss says. "The thing that dominates me isn't that the Bar Council or Law Society are liberals, more that they're about the self-interest of the legal profession rather than the interests of society as a whole."

He makes a good fist of defending the mode of trial bill, which shifts several categories of crime from jury trial to magistrate. It was rejected last time by the House of Lords, but the government seems determined to push it through. The only people attacking the government, Clarke maintains, are lawyers; their motives are purely self-interest. "The more I see of the criminal justice system, the more I think many of its practices are completely indefensible."

You don't come across many in the second echelon of government, a mere minister of state, with such self-assurance. His rank is, in any case, anomalous. He secured his seat, Norwich South, months before the '97 election. Blair has promoted him as fast as he can. A decent cabinet place next time around is as near to a dead cert as you get in politics. "All these people who claim to know about election dates, reshuffles - it's complete bollocks: people just don't know."

He should know. He was chief-of-staff to Neil Kinnock during the wilderness years, taking no prisoners as they fought off Militant and battled, to use the historical shorthand, to make Labour electable. Part of that, he says, is self-restraint. Like so many of his colleagues from their opposition days, he sees much of the media, especially the tabloids, as endemically hostile. It is, he insists, extremely difficult to float interesting ideas in public. "The constraint on politicians isn't imposed by Tony Blair or anyone else. You have to be very, very careful - if you're serious about power - about how you talk about things."

And what about the "faceless wonders" - the advisers as described by John Prescott, and the various anonymous denunciations of ministers? "Your phrase, not mine," he says. "In general, the quality of the people around the leadership is very good. But there were some people, it is well known, who made it their business to argue on behalf of their principles in ways which were negative." He pours himself another glass of office regulation red, and smiles. "Some of those are no longer there."

So what does he believe in? What is his political philosophy? An obvious question, you might think, but this arch-fixer, arch-doer, seems stumped. He comes up with the need to build a strong society, to get the voluntary and state sector working together, and the need to re-establish "leadership in society", to end the "walk on by" culture. "Many people don't feel the confidence to lead their communities." As for economics, the key element is abolition of poverty. What about the word that dare not speak its name - redistribution? Does the Labour government believe in it as part of creating a more fair society? "I would say yes. It must do."

He knows his way around. He combines a joviality and supreme self-confidence that, some might say, goes with the territory of public school and Oxbridge education. His father, Sir Richard "Otto" Clarke, was a Labour figure who rose through the postwar public sector to become the top civil servant at Tony Benn's Ministry of Technology.

Clarke wishes his father were still alive so they could compare notes. He could have done with help during the many tragicomic Kinnock moments. Clarke didn't take prisoners then, and ruffled many a feather as, under his leader, Labour suffered two defeats on the trot. The period after '92 was his lowest point. Clarke ran his own lobbying firm, and failed several times to win a seat.

As a not-so-new backbencher, it didn't take long for him to be noticed. Within months he had signed a parliamentary motion backing the strike at British Airways - the most prominent non-leftwinger to do so. Eyebrows were raised. He was called in. Word was he hadn't quite grasped parliamentary procedure - an unlikely story.

So what did happen? He laughs raucously. "If you want to know, it was a total fuck-up on my part." He recalls being accosted by Ken Livingstone and Bill Morris in the central lobby at Westminster, and urged to put his name to a piece of paper. He says he thought they were talking about the principle of union consultation.

So if not then, what about another perfect piece of political positioning a year later when a letter he wrote to the then social security secretary Harriet Harman, attacking cuts to lone-parent benefits, was leaked to the Observer? "I have thought about positioning. Positioning is an interesting question. The assessments I made in that letter were correct. The only thing I regret is that it was leaked. Many people today believe I leaked it to promote myself. Actually, I haven't done that kind of thing at any point."

He didn't vote against the measure, though. "I'm a loyalist. I've always believed it's much more effective to make your argument for change from inside the family than outside. That's a tactical judgment."

So does he consider himself a Blairite? "I'm not quite sure what it means." But the intertwining of the Kinnock and Blair teams is now stronger than ever. The John Smith years are increasingly seen by them as an aberration. Clarke was an early supporter of Blair's bid for the leadership in 1994. "How shall I put this? Labour won the election in 1997 as a result of his leadership," he says. He sheds few tears for Brown's frustrated ambitions. "It's by no means clear that under any other leader it [the victory] would have happened as well."

He awards praise to the chancellor for his management of the economy. But if Brown might not have had what it takes to lead the party a few years back, does he now? What about that supposed deal that sees Blair standing down at some point over the next few years for his old chum? "I don't see how there can be a pre-agreed inheritance, in the sense that the people who will decide will be the party by its constitutional processes.

"Of course, the party listens to its leaders. But one of the things I learnt very much when I worked for Neil is that they listen to their party only to a point, and they don't like their prerogatives being trampled on too much. If anybody tries to say to the party at any point in the next 10 years, 'You ought to choose x,' it would be a very mistaken thing to do. I'd be absolutely amazed if either Tony or Gordon, if you're talking about a pre-agreement, thought anything other than what I've just said."

That does not take much decoding. Brown is not, in Clarke's view, a shoo-in. Others in and around the cabinet might agree with him. So who would be the alternative? The obvious choices for many in the party are Straw or David Blunkett. So, what about this long-shot theory about Clarke himself? Had he heard it from other MPs? "I don't think that they'd be so bold as to say that to me." I did not take that as being a resounding "no".

Everything goes in cycles, and the youthful and clean-cut appeal of Blair might eventually give way to an older, more in-your-face school of politics. Still, the only imminent leadership election, Clarke says, will be for the Tories. He would be happy to give them advice. When he took over Kinnock's office, he consulted Richard Ryder, who had run Margaret Thatcher's office in opposition in the late 70s. So what would he say now to Sebastian Coe, William Hague's right-hand man? "My advice would be: get rid of your leader. I never had much time for him."

He is relaxed, but alert. He's the one who has been attacking William Hague over police and race on the airwaves. He's the one piloting four important pieces of legislation into the new, almost certainly brief, parliamentary session. No other minister will spend anything like as much time at the dispatch box this winter. The issues are central to the government's agenda, and are controversial - vehicle crime, private security services, a criminal justice bill on alcohol-driven yob violence, and the reintroduction of that much-derided mode of trial bill. This man is no libertarian. He blames the Thatcher years for many, but by no means all, of society's ills. "I do think the 'no such thing as society' culture is deeply embedded in a whole generation of people. A key strategic goal of the Labour government is to rebuild community and society in all its senses. But this can't be changed overnight." In the meantime, punishment should be tough. So does he agree with his boss, Jack Straw, that a liberal legal establishment is part of the problem? "I'm surrounded by lawyers. My boss is a lawyer. His boss is a lawyer. My fellow ministers of state are lawyers. We have lawyers all over the place." Straw, he says, has "a far more profound experience of the legal profession and the individuals involved". That is quintessential Clarke: almost agreeing with what his boss says. "The thing that dominates me isn't that the Bar Council or Law Society are liberals, more that they're about the self-interest of the legal profession rather than the interests of society as a whole." He makes a good fist of defending the mode of trial bill, which shifts several categories of crime from jury trial to magistrate. It was rejected last time by the House of Lords, but the government seems determined to push it through. The only people attacking the government, Clarke maintains, are lawyers; their motives are purely self-interest. "The more I see of the criminal justice system, the more I think many of its practices are completely indefensible." You don't come across many in the second echelon of government, a mere minister of state, with such self-assurance. His rank is, in any case, anomalous. He secured his seat, Norwich South, months before the '97 election. Blair has promoted him as fast as he can. A decent cabinet place next time around is as near to a dead cert as you get in politics. "All these people who claim to know about election dates, reshuffles - it's complete bollocks: people just don't know." He should know. He was chief-of-staff to Neil Kinnock during the wilderness years, taking no prisoners as they fought off Militant and battled, to use the historical shorthand, to make Labour electable. Part of that, he says, is self-restraint. Like so many of his colleagues from their opposition days, he sees much of the media, especially the tabloids, as endemically hostile. It is, he insists, extremely difficult to float interesting ideas in public. "The constraint on politicians isn't imposed by Tony Blair or anyone else. You have to be very, very careful - if you're serious about power - about how you talk about things." And what about the "faceless wonders" - the advisers as described by John Prescott, and the various anonymous denunciations of ministers? "Your phrase, not mine," he says. "In general, the quality of the people around the leadership is very good. But there were some people, it is well known, who made it their business to argue on behalf of their principles in ways which were negative." He pours himself another glass of office regulation red, and smiles. "Some of those are no longer there." So what does he believe in? What is his political philosophy? An obvious question, you might think, but this arch-fixer, arch-doer, seems stumped. He comes up with the need to build a strong society, to get the voluntary and state sector working together, and the need to re-establish "leadership in society", to end the "walk on by" culture. "Many people don't feel the confidence to lead their communities." As for economics, the key element is abolition of poverty. What about the word that dare not speak its name - redistribution? Does the Labour government believe in it as part of creating a more fair society? "I would say yes. It must do." He knows his way around. He combines a joviality and supreme self-confidence that, some might say, goes with the territory of public school and Oxbridge education. His father, Sir Richard "Otto" Clarke, was a Labour figure who rose through the postwar public sector to become the top civil servant at Tony Benn's Ministry of Technology. Clarke wishes his father were still alive so they could compare notes. He could have done with help during the many tragicomic Kinnock moments. Clarke didn't take prisoners then, and ruffled many a feather as, under his leader, Labour suffered two defeats on the trot. The period after '92 was his lowest point. Clarke ran his own lobbying firm, and failed several times to win a seat. As a not-so-new backbencher, it didn't take long for him to be noticed. Within months he had signed a parliamentary motion backing the strike at British Airways - the most prominent non-leftwinger to do so. Eyebrows were raised. He was called in. Word was he hadn't quite grasped parliamentary procedure - an unlikely story. So what did happen? He laughs raucously. "If you want to know, it was a total fuck-up on my part." He recalls being accosted by Ken Livingstone and Bill Morris in the central lobby at Westminster, and urged to put his name to a piece of paper. He says he thought they were talking about the principle of union consultation. So if not then, what about another perfect piece of political positioning a year later when a letter he wrote to the then social security secretary Harriet Harman, attacking cuts to lone-parent benefits, was leaked to the Observer? "I have thought about positioning. Positioning is an interesting question. The assessments I made in that letter were correct. The only thing I regret is that it was leaked. Many people today believe I leaked it to promote myself. Actually, I haven't done that kind of thing at any point." He didn't vote against the measure, though. "I'm a loyalist. I've always believed it's much more effective to make your argument for change from inside the family than outside. That's a tactical judgment." So does he consider himself a Blairite? "I'm not quite sure what it means." But the intertwining of the Kinnock and Blair teams is now stronger than ever. The John Smith years are increasingly seen by them as an aberration. Clarke was an early supporter of Blair's bid for the leadership in 1994. "How shall I put this? Labour won the election in 1997 as a result of his leadership," he says. He sheds few tears for Brown's frustrated ambitions. "It's by no means clear that under any other leader it [the victory] would have happened as well." He awards praise to the chancellor for his management of the economy. But if Brown might not have had what it takes to lead the party a few years back, does he now? What about that supposed deal that sees Blair standing down at some point over the next few years for his old chum? "I don't see how there can be a pre-agreed inheritance, in the sense that the people who will decide will be the party by its constitutional processes. "Of course, the party listens to its leaders. But one of the things I learnt very much when I worked for Neil is that they listen to their party only to a point, and they don't like their prerogatives being trampled on too much. If anybody tries to say to the party at any point in the next 10 years, 'You ought to choose x,' it would be a very mistaken thing to do. I'd be absolutely amazed if either Tony or Gordon, if you're talking about a pre-agreement, thought anything other than what I've just said." That does not take much decoding. Brown is not, in Clarke's view, a shoo-in. Others in and around the cabinet might agree with him. So who would be the alternative? The obvious choices for many in the party are Straw or David Blunkett. So, what about this long-shot theory about Clarke himself? Had he heard it from other MPs? "I don't think that they'd be so bold as to say that to me." I did not take that as being a resounding "no". Everything goes in cycles, and the youthful and clean-cut appeal of Blair might eventually give way to an older, more in-your-face school of politics. Still, the only imminent leadership election, Clarke says, will be for the Tories. He would be happy to give them advice. When he took over Kinnock's office, he consulted Richard Ryder, who had run Margaret Thatcher's office in opposition in the late 70s. So what would he say now to Sebastian Coe, William Hague's right-hand man? "My advice would be: get rid of your leader. I never had much time for him."

webTitle: Publicity blitz for Xbox, Microsoft's late gaming entry

fields.headline: Gates play
fields.standfirst: Publicity blitz for Xbox, Microsoft's late gaming entry
fields.trailText: Publicity blitz for Xbox, Microsoft's late gaming entry.
fields.body:
Microsoft yesterday unveiled the Xbox, its eagerly anticipated games console which has been hyped as a threat to the dominance of Sony's PlayStation.

Bill Gates, Microsoft's chairman, said the system would be launched in Europe next year accompanied by a publicity blitz. It was unveiled at the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

"Xbox is the future of video gaming," he said. "With its breakthrough technology and incredible graphics capabilities, the console will set the standard in gaming for years to come."

Games manufacturers are hoping the Xbox will give new impetus to an otherwise sluggish market.

PlayStation2, Sony's upgraded console launched at the end of last year but was beset by delays and component shortages.

Sandy Duncan, vice-president of Xbox Europe, said more than 200 games companies are developing titles to coincide with the launch.

The package will include a front-loading DVD tray, and four game controller ports; players may also be able to connect voice-activated headsets to the unit.

Mr Gates had little reason for cheer elsewhere, however, as the 19 US states pursuing the break up of Microsoft said they would push ahead even if the new justice department under the incoming president, George W Bush, backs off.

A top economic adviser to Mr Bush has criticised antitrust enforcement under President Bill Clinton.

"We hope and assume that the Bush administration would fully pursue the Microsoft case through all stages, including the supreme court, if that's necessary," said Iowa attorney general Tom Miller, leader among the 19 states acting as co-plaintiffs with the federal government.

"However, if for some reason they don't, we have made a commitment to pursue this case to the end."

webTitle: Comment: The politics of protest have revived

fields.headline: Comrades, we're back
fields.standfirst:
Leftwingers have found their voice again, after years in the wilderness. The politics of protest have revived

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Leftwingers have found their voice again, after years in the wilderness. The politics of protest have revived.
fields.body:
My decision to commit myself to leftwing politics came at an awkward time. Not only because I was 15, which meant socialism had to vie for my attention with girls, skincare and A-levels, but because, spanning 1984 and 1985, it coincided with the gradual, grinding defeat of the miners' strike. For months I had heard podiums pounded to a familiar tune - if the miners lost it would signal a massive setback for the left. Then they lost and, amid all the hot air that blew through loudspeakers at the time, this bleak assertion seemed to hold more than a whiff of truth.

As the miners returned to work the despondency of having attached myself to a lost and noble cause set in. Advising against despair, older activists convinced me that this was little more than the periodic bump and grind of the class struggle. We were now moving into a "downturn", they explained, when the right would make ideological headway and the left would be on the defensive. But as sure as the sun would rise in the east, they insisted, things would improve. Confidence to resist attacks on living standards, working conditions, discrimination, low pay and no pay would return. There would, they asserted confidently, be an "upturn".

Waiting for the upturn, over the past 16 years, has felt like being cast as one of Beckett's tramps waiting for Godot. Unsure of when it would turn up or what it would look like even if it did, there was little to do but hope. There were, of course, isolated events to savour, like the repeal of the poll tax, Nelson Mandela's release and Livingstone's victory in London. But each one promised more than it could possibly have delivered - the swallows were sighted, but the summer never came.

Until now that is. For there is a fragile but discernible sense that the tide is beginning to turn. Gradually, unevenly and erratically comes anecdotal and empirical evidence of a mood swing. An indignant, stroppy strain of political optimism which suggests that resistance is worthwhile, change is possible and alternatives desirable. The upturn is here.

I am all too well aware that this may be the wishful thinking of a believer whose dream has been too long deferred. At first glance the omens are not brilliant. Under the most rightwing Labour government ever, industrial action remains incredibly low not just in comparison with our past but also with almost every other country.

So why the optimism? Firstly because campaigning is producing results. Pensioners received this year's increase through protest, not patronage. The same is true of students in Scotland and tuition fees. And while the number of days lost through strike action dropped between 1998 and 1999, the number of ballots on industrial action doubled. Of those on strike action, 95% showed majorities in favour; of those on action short of a strike, the figure was 91%. In nine out of ten cases, according to the Trade Unions Trends survey, they won all or some of their demands. Part of this is undoubtedly down to a booming economy. But the upshot is that it elevates protest from the kneejerk moral response of a minority to a practical means of improving the lot of the many. When people win or see others win they gain in confidence and the likelihood is that they will fight again.

It is also producing results at the polls, where a persistent voice has emerged to the left of Labour. After the Scottish Socialist party saved its deposit in the Falkirk West byelection John Curtice, the deputy director of the ESRC Centre for Research into Elections and Social Trends, wrote: "What is notable is that this is the fifth byelection in a row in which a candidate standing under a socialist label has passed the 5% threshold. It is easily the best record for the far left in postwar Britain."

Anecdotally, it feels as though, after years of struggling to get people to even sign petitions and attending meetings that could have been held in a broom cupboard, the left is no longer just talking to itself. Last month more than 1,000 people turned up in central London to a meeting about an obscure but pernicious trade agreement, the General Agreement on Trade in Services, with more left outside pleading to come in. Reclaim the Streets activists bringing the City to a standstill; local meetings to support asylum seekers of several hundred strong; large anti-racist meetings in Bristol - these are snapshots of recent times that contribute to a bigger picture.

The vista is hazy. A mood is, by its nature, undefinable and unquantifiable. But it is also pervasive. We are not talking barricades in the streets here. But from the growing self-assertion of black and Asian communities following the Lawrence report to a commonsense view, born from bitter experience, that the railways were a privatisation too far, this shift to the left will be widespread, substantial and stubborn.

Paradoxically, the left have Labour to thank for some of this. While it is the government they are usually fighting, it is partly because there is a Labour government that they have a chance of winning. There was never any point trying to appeal to the Tories' better nature because they never had one. But there are expectations that come with Labour - equality, fairness, social responsibility - which no amount of rebranding can dispel. With an election due this is a point both the left and Labour would do well to remember. Claiming that there is no significant difference between New Labour and the Tories is a convenient refrain - it is also untrue and unhelpful. Claiming that the left is insignificant makes a good soundbite - but it will not motivate the base Labour needs to maintain a decent majority.

Unlike previous upturns, this new wave of militancy will neither be union-led nor necessarily reflected in any substantial way within the Labour party. Labour has neutralised its internal levers of democracy. The quarter of a century or so since the last upturn has left a generation with only an abstract notion of what trade unions are for and a transformed workplace of part-timers, teleworkers and contract casuals who are non-unionised.

The days of gauging leftwing opinion by charting resolutions to conferences are over. Unlike the last one in the 70s, this new phase will not have the century-old traditions of the Labour and trade union movement, but nor will it have the bureaucracy and conservatism that come with them. With new technologies and less structure it will move faster and with more volatility. It will be more female and less white, but also economically more privileged.

Its emergence will present opportunities for the left but also massive challenges. At the first sign of summer some will be tempted to bask in the sun only to get burned from over-exposure. The upturn may be here. But now they have to work out what kept it away so long and what we can do to make sure it stays.

webTitle: 2000 a record year for management buyouts

fields.headline: 2000 a record year for management buyouts
fields.trailText: Top-end management buyout deals reached a record of just under £20bn last year but could begin to tail off in 2001, according to KPMG Corporate Finance.
fields.body:
Top-end management buyout deals reached a record of just under £20bn last year but could begin to tail off in 2001, according to KPMG Corporate Finance.

KPMG said yesterday that, in a buoyant private equity market, the value of the 150 management buyouts, management buy-ins and institutional buy-outs reached £19.95bn, up 39% on the £14.38bn of 149 similar deals in 1999.

Almost half the value - £9bn - came from public companies going private in the wake of unacceptable stock market ratings, with five more worth £1.36bn incomplete by the end of the year. The top two buyouts last year - MEPC at £3.5bn and United Biscuits at £1.5bn - took this route.

Two others - General Healthcare at £1.3bn and Rank Hovis McDougall at £1.1bn - were worth more than £1bn, while two-thirds of the total were worth more than £250m each.

KPMG said the final quarter of 2000 saw no decline in activity but the value of deals fell by 38%, with the largest the £507m buyout at Powell Duffryn, the engineering group.

Charles Milner, UK head of private equity at KPMG Corporate Finance, said: "2000 was another record year for fund raising. Looking forward to 2001, some commentators have suggested that the pri vate equity market place will have a tougher time. The debt markets are showing signs of greater caution and this is undoubtedly a critical factor in putting deals together.

"However, with economic fundamentals sound, substantial funds available for investment and with continuing restructuring as companies and markets consolidate, we firmly believe that the outlook is far from bleak."

 The initial public offering market is likely to remain in hibernation this week despite positive sentiment surrounding the US Federal Reserve's surprise interest rate cut, say analysts. No companies are scheduled to price in the second week of January.

webTitle: Safe surfing on the internet

fields.headline: The technology is open, but that means thieves can break in, and that's what they did this Christmas
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The technology is open, but that means thieves can break in, and that's what they did this Christmas
fields.body:
One of the difficulties with running a website is the openness of the technology. Our friends at Teenfront.com learned this over the Christmas period when hackers from a rival teen site broke into the portal's chatrooms and began posting messages stating that the site was being taken over by their company and that the chatrooms were going to be closed down in the New Year.

Teenfront.com, in which Rools has invested cash, immediately lost a couple of hundred chatterers who believed the messages. Most of them have since come back, so Teenfront.com has not suffered any permanent damage. The team is now keeping a vigilant eye out for chat thieves.

On a slightly different scale, the threat from hackers is even more vital to ourselves as an online payments, billing and account management service. Just before Christmas a hacker broke into a popular US retail site and stole over a quarter of a million credit card details. While there is no real direct risk to consumers, as it is typically the retailer then the banks that pay, ultimately the cost is passed on to them.

At the coalface, we can see just how much more can be done to protect people from the risk of online fraud, and Rools is simply one of a number of companies with a certain technical solution. The difficulty faced by banks and payment processors at the moment is that credit card issuance and processing has become a global standard. This makes it very difficult to act unilaterally.

Uncertainty over how the market will develop has meant that banks are investing in many different systems and start-ups with the apparent aim of covering all possibilities.

One of the best known developments is SET, or Secure Electronic Transaction, which aims to increase online credit card transaction security. However, we have come across a real lack of enthusiasm for some of these big initiatives from the banks, and particularly for SET. One concern is that by the time these big initiatives come to market, technology will have moved on to the extent that the security offered will be no better than that offered by credit cards at the moment.

In the meantime we and other companies like us will continue to offer secure online payment services, and our friends at Teenfront.com will continue to deal with the much less complex security threat of chatroom hackers.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools, a service that enables teenagers to shop online

webTitle: Monday briefing

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Spirits group Diageo has been considering a £4bn bid for Foster's to bolster its Guinness brewing operations.
fields.body:
Observer

Spirits group Diageo has been considering a £4bn bid for Foster's to bolster its Guinness brewing operations. Foster's, based in south Australia, also has big wine operations which interest new Diageo chief Paul Walsh following its $8.2bn acquisition with Pernod of Seagram's spirits and wine business before Christmas. Foster's is the UK's number two beer brand, with over £1bn sales and 8.2% of the market, behind Bass's Carling Black Label.

Toyzone, the e-tailing toy company controlled by PR guru Matthew Freud, conceded at the weekend that it would struggle to survive as an independent business.

Sunday Times

Sir Rodney Walker, recruited to rescue the Wembley stadium project, plans to cut the £410m construction loan it requires by as much as 25%, and to increase the cash contribution from the FA. One of the biggest savings will be to build the hotel and office buildings to only the "shell and core" stage - a move that will save £25m.

Staff at Marks & Spencer have been asked to take unpaid leave as the retailer moves into the post-sale season. M&S is thought to have had yet another disappointing Christmas. A spokeswoman confirmed that staff were being asked to take time off but said that it was normal business practice.

At least one in 10 partners at PricewaterhouseCoopers faces the axe. One of the biggest shake-ups in accountancy will cost about £80m in compensation. Partners are estimated to earn about £400,000 a year each, and can expect average pay-offs of £800,000.

Sunday Telegraph

North American firms are eyeing up Enterprise Oil, with one considering an all-paper bid valuing Britain's biggest exploration and production independent at £3.4bn. Interest in Enterprise Oil follows Italian oil and gas group Eni's agreed £2.7bn takeover of Lasmo last month.

Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Group and AMP, the Australian life insurer, are believed to be locked in a dispute over Virgin Direct and VirginMoney.com, the two companies' financial services joint ventures. The row centres on differing plans over how to realise value from the businesses.

M&G, the fund manager owned by Prudential, has built a dominant stake in a quoted cash shell company and intends to use it as a vehicle to bid for underperforming companies or to bully firms into restructuring. M&G, which is run by Michael McLintock, has paid around £4.6m for a 29.8% stake in Lionheart, an Aim-quoted shell which has around £11m in cash.

Mail on Sunday

Sainsbury has suffered a fresh profits blow after sales failed to take off in the run-up to Christmas, say industry insiders. Sources say like for like sales, excluding the effect of opening new stores, will show an increase of 1%-2% compared with 4% for Tesco. Sainsbury's described the report as "speculation".

Sunday Express

At least four leading Premier League bosses plan to oppose any decision that would give NTL the rights to screen top football matches on a pay per view basis for a second time.

Sunday Business

Vodafone, the world's largest mobile phone operator, has bought a 35% stake in Mexico's second largest wireless company, Grupo Iusacell, for about $1bn. Iusacell has more than 1.5m subscribers. The acquisition will partner Vodafone with US group Verizon, which has a 37% stake in Iusacell. The UK and American groups are also partners in Verizon Wireless, the biggest US mobile phone company.

Electricity company Powergen is understood to be a bid target for a number of European power groups, including E.ON of Germany.

IoS

Abbey National, the high- street bank whose future seems to be up for grabs, has taken a radical step. It has ditched the umbrella logo on its new stores and may abandon it. The company is trying to forge a £27bn merger with the Bank of Scotland but faces strong opposition from Lloyds TSB.

webTitle: Business: Ministry of Sound expands

fields.headline: Globally clubbable
fields.standfirst: Ministry of Sound expands
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Sound looks set to move further from its underground roots with plans for a global chain of branded clubs.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Sound looks set to move further from its underground roots with plans for a global chain of branded clubs.

The burgeoning dance music empire run by James Palumbo is in discussions to license the Ministry of Sound brand to Luminar, the stock market-listed-nightclub group. If agreement is reached, the Ministry could end up in 50 cities around the world.

The deal would forge links between the once achingly trendy nightclub at south London's Elephant & Castle and the achingly naff Hippodrome, in Leicester Square, which is owned by Luminar.

Talks between the two are said to be at an early stage but are likely to be in the shape of an alliance rather than a takeover. Insiders said the deal made sense because it combined the operational skills of Luminar with the powerful Ministry of Sound brand, which has been the launchpad for a music label, a clothing business, a magazine and a slew of other merchandising. It has already taken its club nights overseas.

In May, Luminar became the biggest nightclub operator in the UK when it sealed the £370m takeover of Northern Leisure. It runs 50 clubs and bars under the Chicago Rock brand.

The Ministry of Sound opened its doors in September 1991, and has turned clubbing into a corporate enterprise.

It has a radio show running on the three Kiss dance music stations which is syndicated internationally - including to J-Wave, Tokyo's biggest music radio station, with a potential audience of 39m listeners.

Ministry of Sound also has a website featuring dance music news, free downloads, club information and a shop.

webTitle: Business: Blue Circle falls to £3m bid from Lafarge

fields.headline: Blue Circle falls to £3m bid from Lafarge
fields.trailText: Blue Circle, Britain's leading cement maker, will today give up 175 years of independence and accept a £3bn cash bid from Lafarge, the French building materials group.
fields.body:
Blue Circle, Britain's leading cement maker, will today give up 175 years of independence and accept a £3bn cash bid from Lafarge, the French building materials group.

The Blue Circle board, which fended off a hostile bid worth 450p a share from Lafarge in May last year, met last night to agree a 495p offer that will make the aggressively expanding French group the world's biggest cement maker.

The deal, worth £4.8bn as Lafarge is taking on Blue Circle's £1.8bn debt, will make the enlarged Anglo-French group an integrated business making cement, aggregates and concrete in the UK.

Lafarge bought materials group Redland for £1.8bn three years ago.

It follows the takeover of Rugby, the cement maker, by RMC, a concrete producer, a year ago and represents the latest stage of consolidation in the industry.

The new offer, heralded by Bertrand Collomb, Lafarge's chairman, last month, is marginally short of the 500p-plus initially sought by his rival, Rick Haythornwaite, Blue Circle's chief executive.

It will effectively cost the French group no more than its failed bid of last year, according to industry sources, because Lafarge retained a 22.6% stake in Blue Circle - bought at a price worth 439p a share ex-dividend.

Blue Circle shareholders, who enjoyed a £800m return of capital last year, will be paid the full 495p - as will Lafarge's advisers, Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, who took on a 9.8% stake that Lafarge was forced by Canadian regulators to divest.

But the offer will cost the French group an average 470p a share or €7.5bn - the same, after the single currency's appreciation, as its lapsed offer of May 2000. Under takeover panel rules, Lafarge was debarred from making another hostile bid for a year.

"There's no real win-win situation in life but, in this case, Blue Circle shareholders are getting a better price worth £2.4bn and Lafarge is not paying any more for a better-performing business," insiders said.

Sources close to both companies insisted that little or nothing stood in the way of the agreed takeover which comes after substantial progress made by Blue Circle since it issued a shock profits warning in the autumn of 1999.

Synergy savings, estimated at €125m last May, are now said to be worth around €100m because Mr Haythornwaite has succeeded in squeezing out more costs than he promised.

Last month, in an upbeat trading statement, he said that savings should surpass his £29m target, operating profits from the group's Asian businesses - the source of its original woes, would be at least £45m and disposals worth £400m would be achieved this year.

The deal gives Lafarge a far greater geographical spread, notably in Asia and south America, and a greater ability to take on the Swiss group, Holderbank, with whom it is tussling for control of Cimpor, the Portuguese cement maker.

webTitle: Soccer boss's court tactics

fields.headline: Soccer boss's court tactics
fields.trailText: One of the most colourful characters in British sport will swap his football manager's dugout today for the plaintiff's bench in the high court.
fields.body:
One of the most colourful characters in British sport will swap his football manager's dugout today for the plaintiff's bench in the high court.

Former safecracker George Reynolds, who now spends part of his £300m kitchen furniture fortune on running Darlington FC, is to conduct his own legal claim for wrongful arrest.

Famous for trying to reduce "barmy" football wages, the self-made millionaire has dispensed with lawyers in the civil action against Cleveland police.

He will conduct his own case at the high court in Middlesbrough, with the help of statements from 14 officers, including an assistant chief constable.

Mr Reynolds, who went straight after serving a four year jail sentence for safe-blowing in the 1960s, is bringing six wrongful arrest actions against the police over an incident nine years ago.

He was arrested and held in police cells overnight in 1992 on three charges of threatening criminal damage, which were later dropped.

Mr Reynolds, 64, has worked between business commitments since the incident to gather evidence.

He said: "I have gathered a huge amount of documentation to show I was wrongfully arrested, detained and charged."

His case accused Cleveland police of arresting him without properly checking the private complaint against him, ignoring release requests from his solicitor, and failing properly to evaluate the strength of the evidence against him.

Mr Reynolds, born in poverty in Sunderland, used his ice cream van to transport gelignite during his safecracking days, but used his prison term to educate himself and proved a successful businessman after release.

He said: "I consulted several leading barristers, who wanted £60,000 to represent me - and I was certainly not going to hand over that sort of money when I can do just as good a job myself."

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Drugs arrest for Euan officer
fields.body:
Drugs arrest for Euan officer

A 25-year-old police officer from south London, who arrested the prime minister's son, Euan Blair, last July for being drunk and incapable, was last week arrested for alleged possession of cocaine.

Courts disarray as strike looms

Crown and magistrates courts expect disruption from today as crown prosecution service administration staff take action over pay. They expect to strike on January 17 and 18.

Train fares on slow climb

The first week of the year saw rail fare rises from train operators, including London Underground and Silverlink. The environmental group Transport 2000 said annual cuts in fares could boost passenger numbers by 9% over 10 years.

Peckers' spire gets a patent

A wood-clad church spire at Great Henny, Suffolk, built to attract amourous woodpeckers intent on hammering out their mating signals, has proved so successful a decoy the idea is to be patented to save other structures hit by avian drilling.

Imagine tops song poll

John Lennon's song Imagine was voted Britain's favourite number one single in a TV poll by the Observer and Channel 4.

£7.5m jackpot

Two shared Saturday's £7.5m National Lottery jackpot with winning numbers 6, 16, 23, 34, 35, 40 and bonus 37. Lottery Extra numbers were 11, 16, 20, 26, 31 and 36. There were no winners. Thunderball numbers were 6, 7, 19, 24, and 32, and Thunderball was 9.

Man charged on death crash

A man was charged last night over the death of a mother of two killed in a crash with a vehicle being chased by police. Hamid Gani, 30, of Acton, west London, will appear before Ealing magistrates today charged with causing death by dangerous driving.

Tempers are rising

More than 10% of Britons admit to losing their temper at least once a day, according to a report released today. And 80% of people polled believed the UK has become an angrier society in the last decade, the survey for BBC 1's On the Edge showed.

Blushes spared

A charity calendar featuring a naked priest has been shelved at the request of the Bishop of Galway, who branded it"inappropriate". Fr Olan Rynn, 27, was pictured wearing only his clerical collar and covering his modesty with a Bible.

Sweet smell of excess

Where people live influences body odour, according to writer Kevin Gould. He also pointed out that pineapple contained an enzyme called bromelain, which was good at digesting carbohydrates and thus helped sweeten sweat.

webTitle: Fayed arrests complaint upheld

fields.headline: Fayed arrests complaint upheld
fields.trailText: The police complaints authority has criticised the Metropolitan police over the way it arrested Mohamed Al Fayed, owner of Harrods, for the alleged theft of gemstones and other precious items from a safe deposit box belonging to his arch-enemy, Tiny Rowland.
fields.body:
The police complaints authority has criticised the Metropolitan police over the way it arrested Mohamed Al Fayed, owner of Harrods, for the alleged theft of gemstones and other precious items from a safe deposit box belonging to his arch-enemy, Tiny Rowland.

The police watchdog said it was wrong to detain Mr Fayed and five of his employees in March 1998 without first investigating alleged payments by Mr Rowland to the former security chief at the Knightsbridge store, Bob Loftus. It was Mr Loftus who made the original allegation that Mr Fayed had ordered his staff to break into the safe deposit box.

The PCA inquiry, launched after Mr Fayed complained, also upheld a complaint that the force failed to investigate alleged financial dealings between Mr Rowland and Mr Loftus.

The Metropolitan police said it was aware of the PCA's decision but said the officer involved had retired and would not be disciplined.

Both of the complaints, made in March 1999, were upheld against Detective Chief Superintendent Jeffrey Rees, who was in charge of the investigation. Complaints were also made against Commander Niall Mulvihill and Assistant Commissioner David Veness, but they are being considered by the Home Office.

A spokesman said it would be inappropriate to discuss the complaints against the other two officers because they were still being investigated.

Mr Fayed, his private secretary, Mark Griffiths, bodyguard Paul Handley-Greaves, former Harrods director of security John Macnamara, John Allen and Colin Dalman were arrested over the alleged break-in to the safe box at the store three years earlier. No charges were brought against the five.

The PCA investigation, led by Northamptonshire's chief constable, Christopher Fox, found that Mr Rees sought advice from the crown prosecution service before deciding on the arrests.

"Ultimately, however, the decision fell to Mr Rees and it was his responsibility," Duncan Gear, PCA member, said in a letter to Mr Fayed's solicitors. "The investigating officer considers, and the authority agrees, that the officer should have investigated this aspect regardless of what he was told. This aspect of your client's complaint is, accordingly, upheld."

According to the PCA, Mr Fayed's complaint also raised the question of whether Mr Loftus was under suspicion of involvement in the alleged break-in.

The PCA report said that Mr Rees did not arrest Mr Loftus - even though an independent witness "clearly placed" him at the scene of the alleged offence - because he was the main prosecution witness and had made the initial allegation.

The PCA said that had Mr Rees not retired from the force last year, he would have received advice concerning his decision not to arrest Mr Loftus, and would have faced a disciplinary charge for neglect of duty for failing to investigate the financial relationship between him and Mr Rowland.

In March last year Mr Fayed told the high court he had "no personal responsibility" for the disappearance of the gems, but paid Mr Rowland's widow, Josephine, £1.4m in damages after accepting responsibility as the owner of the store for the opening of the box.

Yesterday Mr Fayed said: "I am delighted that our complaints have been upheld. These arrests should not have been made. The allegations of theft were false.

"The damage to me and to various members of Harrods staff caused by the wrongful and wholly unwarranted arrests is incalculable."

"Ultimately, however, the decision fell to Mr Rees and it was his responsibility," Duncan Gear, PCA member, said in a letter to Mr Fayed's solicitors. "The investigating officer considers, and the authority agrees, that the officer should have investigated this aspect regardless of what he was told. This aspect of your client's complaint is, accordingly, upheld." According to the PCA, Mr Fayed's complaint also raised the question of whether Mr Loftus was under suspicion of involvement in the alleged break-in. The PCA report said that Mr Rees did not arrest Mr Loftus - even though an independent witness "clearly placed" him at the scene of the alleged offence - because he was the main prosecution witness and had made the initial allegation. The PCA said that had Mr Rees not retired from the force last year, he would have received advice concerning his decision not to arrest Mr Loftus, and would have faced a disciplinary charge for neglect of duty for failing to investigate the financial relationship between him and Mr Rowland. In March last year Mr Fayed told the high court he had "no personal responsibility" for the disappearance of the gems, but paid Mr Rowland's widow, Josephine, £1.4m in damages after accepting responsibility as the owner of the store for the opening of the box. Yesterday Mr Fayed said: "I am delighted that our complaints have been upheld. These arrests should not have been made. The allegations of theft were false. "The damage to me and to various members of Harrods staff caused by the wrongful and wholly unwarranted arrests is incalculable."

webTitle: Obituary: Lord Lovell-Davis

fields.headline: Lord Lovell-Davis
fields.standfirst: As an early Labour political strategist, he helped Harold Wilson win four general elections
fields.trailText: As an early Labour political strategist, he helped Harold Wilson win four general elections.
fields.body:
Lord Lovell-Davis, who has died aged 76, was a deeply reluctant Labour life peer who was sent to the Lords by Prime Minister Harold Wilson in Febrary 1974 so that he could make him a junior minister in the department of energy. Like many other ministers regarded as Wilson groupies, he was sacked when James Callaghan took over the premiership the following year.

Lovell-Davis always regretted his decision to join an institution he regarded as an absurd anachronism, especially as he had abandoned a lucrative business career in media management in order to take the shortlived job. In spite of this, he remained a loyal backbench workhorse for Labour until a few weeks before his death.

But if that sounds merely worthy, it would be wrong. Peter Davis - his name before he acquired the title - had a major hand in turning Labour into an election-winning machine during the Wil son years. Together with David Kingsley and Denis Lyons, he formed a triumvirate of unpaid experts from the world of PR, advertising and the media to perform much the same function for Wilson that the Mandelsons, Folletts and Goulds performed for Tony Blair. They were known, not without irony, as the Three Wise Men.

Confirming that New Labour is not as new as it thinks, Davis and his colleagues managed to persuade the party to accept serious, professional opinion-polling as part of the party's electoral armoury. In doing so, they were the first to identify Bob Worcester, of Mori, as the best in the business, and hired him.

Having helped to win the 1964 and 1966 elections, the trio ran into controversy over their 1970 campaign. This involved an initial attack on Ted Heath's shadow cabinet as "Yesterday's Men", to be followed up by a portrayal of Wilson's team as the "New Men". The scheme included puppets of the Heathites dumped in a dustbin, and was widely criticised as distastefully personal. More importantly, Wilson did not like it, and vetoed the whole thing. As Davis used to point out, more in sorrow than in anger, Labour went on to lose.

He was still working for the party in 1974, when Heath called his ill-fated "who governs Britain?" election. But a few days into the campaign he suffered a serious heart attack, and was rushed to hospital. Unaware of what had happened, the prime minister begged him to return to work. The foolhardy Davis discharged himself, and resumed the daily strategy meetings at Wilson's house in Lord North Street, Westminster.

Davis only revealed the truth after the election was won; Wilson was appalled, and sent him home. But not for long. Soon afterwards, the prime minister phoned again to say he wanted Davis to take a peerage and accept a job in his government. The ever-loyal Davis agreed under protest.

After he was sacked by Callaghan, Davis got some of his own back with a series of articles for the Sunday Times about the perils of being a minister in the Whitehall jungle. One of them, headed Too Civil By Half, described exactly the kind of tactics employed by Sir Humphrey Appleby in the Yes Minister television series. (In fact, Davis had been approached for advice by one of Yes Minister's creators, Tony Jay, and ended up reading all the scripts for the first series, helping to make the implausible bits more plausible.)

These are the bare bones of a not-insignificant career as a political backroom boy, who had sprung from a lower middle-class family in north London. He began adult life as an engineer in Coventry during the blitz, following an early education in Finchley and later at King Edward VI school, Stratford-upon-Avon. In constrast to his political profile, Davis was an extrovert figure - tall, handsome, attractive to women (whose company he loved) and possessed of great charm and humour. Even in old age, he kept the air of a pleasingly laddish matinée idol.

During the war, he served as an RAF Spitfire pilot, although the conflict ended shortly after he completed his training, and he spent most of his military career on an airbase in the Egyptian desert. The isolation brought out his enterprising spirit, and, before long, he was organising leave trips for bored servicemen all round the eastern Mediterranean, using Lancaster bombers as airliners and booking his customers into otherwise empty hotels in Cyprus, Lebanon, Greece and the upper Nile. He negotiated the deals himself, ferrying himself round in a little Harvart trainer.

Returning to Britain in 1947, Davis read English at Jesus College, Oxford, gaining an introduction to journalism on the undergraduate magazine, Isis. There he also met his future wife, Jean Graham, later to be a talented children's broadcaster. They married in 1950, and had one son and one daughter. All, and two grandchildren, survive him.

webTitle: Obituary: Mejla Hlavsa

fields.headline: Mejla Hlavsa
fields.standfirst: Czech rock musician whose band embodied the spirit of the velvet revolution
fields.trailText: Czech rock musician whose band embodied the spirit of the velvet revolution.
fields.body:
Mejla Hlavsa, who has died of cancer at the age of 49, was a legendary rock musician who did not choose the anti-regime role that was thrust upon him, but accepted it graciously and, through his music, became a figurehead in the movement which eventually overthrew communism in Czechoslovakia.

The founder, songwriter and bass guitarist of the psychedelic rock band, the Plastic People Of The Universe, he first achieved international fame when he was arrested and imprisoned - along with three other band members - in 1976, for "organised disturbance of the peace". The future Czech president Vaclav Havel was among the domestic and international intellectuals and artists who voiced their outrage, and so it was that the Plastics' trial galvanised the human rights movement Charter 77, which fuelled the velvet revolution some 22 years later.

"Vaclav was the engine of the efforts," Hlavsa told the Guardian in a 1998 interview. "The band itself had no political ambition, and we didn't intend to destroy communism through our music. If we helped, we are only too glad." The words of Epitaph, a song from the first Plastics' album, Egon Bondy's Happy Hearts Club Banned, are a poignant legacy of the gravel-voiced musician: "It's too late now to protest/ I've been laid to rest."

Hlavsa was born in Prague to a bankclerk father and a housewife mother. Coming from a generation that considered western-influenced music highly suspicious, and saw long-haired men as "hooligans", they thoroughly disapproved of their son's musical aspirations.

He first developed his passion for rock music in the early 1960s, when his brother Vaclav, nine years his senior, started bringing home rock 'n' roll recordings which had mostly been smuggled into the country. He formed his first band at the age of 14. In 1967, he heard the first Velvet Underground album; he later told friends it was "to influence the rest of my life".

He formed the Plastics a month after the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia in August 1968, which crushed the Prague Spring. The name was taken from the Frank Zappa song, Plastic People, and a quotation of Andy Warhol: "I love everything that is plastic, I would love to become plastic." The band was dismissed by the Czech communist daily, Rude Pravo, as "long-haired, neurotic drug addicts and mental cases who take delight in the grossest of perversions and deliberately sing vulgar, anti-social songs".

When the Plastics' official status was revoked, they refused to give up, playing impromptu concerts under the guise of cultural theory lectures, often in village halls and secret locations. The quietly subversive Czech spirit meant they were never short of an audience.

Their lyrics were smuggled out of Bohemia in samizdat form, their music dubbed and redubbed onto bootleg cassettes, and distributed often via diplomatic channels. Havel lent the Plastics his farmhouse at Hradecek, and offered advice on lyrics when their songwriter was arrested by the secret police.

In 1998, Hlavsa said the Plastics felt "more like a guerrilla group than a rock 'n' roll band", when, in 1974, fans, arriving in the southern town of Ceske Budejovice for a concert, were set on by police, who clubbed them before herding them onto trains back to Prague. Many were expelled from university as a result. Despite the difficulties the Plastics faced, including their arrests, trials and imprisonments in 1976, they continued to perform underground, finally splitting up in 1987.

In 1992, the now President Havel took Lou Reed, a founder member of the Velvet Underground, to a club in downtown Prague where Hlavsa was playing in the Velvet Underground Revival band. Hlavsa recalled the occasion: "Lou was really impressed. He said: 'These guys know all my songs better than I do.' I said to Lou: 'My dream's come true, now I can die.' Lou said: 'Don't do that, my friend, it would be a tragedy."'

In 1997, Havel held a Plastics' reunion concert at Prague castle to celebrate the 20th anniversary of Charter 77. It was the band's first ever official concert, in contrast to their usual rundown venues with equipment cobbled together from junk. A major tour of the Czech Republic followed, and a New York concert in the summer of 1998 was hailed with rave reviews. That September, Hlavsa performed alongside his hero, Lou Reed, at the White House, in front of the Clintons and President Havel. He had had to borrow a smart jacket for the occasion from a Prague neighbour. A new album was due to be recorded later this year.

Latterly, Hlavsa bemoaned how materialistic the new Czech society had become, but insisted his only aim was to "make music, not money or politics". He will be remembered for his modesty, kindheartedness and charm, as well as his gift for storytelling.

He is survived by his mother, his wife Jana, the daughter of the Czech writer and philosopher Jiri Nemec and Dana Nemecova, of Charter 77, and their two children.
