webTitle: Obituary: Cyril Taylor

fields.headline: Cyril Taylor
fields.standfirst: Pioneering doctor who brought community medicine to Liverpool
fields.trailText: Pioneering doctor who brought community medicine to Liverpool.
fields.body:
Dr Cyril Taylor, who has died aged 79, was a general practitioner in Liverpool who pioneered the concept of NHS health centres to serve the widest interests of local people. Always committed to democratic health provision, he was a member of a delegation of socialist doctors who, in 1946, met Nye Bevan, then preparing to establish the National Health Service, to urge him to resist the demands of the medical establishment.

Cyril was brought up in a Jewish family at New Brighton, on the Wirral; they had changed their name from Zadesky to reflect his father's profession. As a boy, he was active in the Jewish Youth Movement but moved from zionism towards socialism in his late teens, and, as a sixth former at Wallesey grammar school, joined the Communist party. He left in disillusion after the Hungarian uprising of 1956.

Cyril studied medicine at Liverpool University, where he was famous for eating sandwiches during dissection lectures. He graduated in 1943, having worked as a student treating survivors of Dunkirk at the Alderhay medical receiving centre. A job at Walton hospital, Liverpool, was followed by national service, during which he became major in charge of the British hospital in Khartoum.

In 1949, Cyril went to work as medical officer with the Liverpool Shipping Federation but was sacked because of his politics. Though the BMA protested, he did not get his job back. So, in 1950, he set up shop at his house in Liverpool, where he practised, singlehandedly, as a GP.

Cyril put his belief in equal opportunities into action, not only at his surgery but by becoming a Labour councillor for Liverpool's Granby ward from 1965-80, and chair of the social services committee between 1970-80. He was quick to recognise the links between health and inequalities, and became involved in issues such as housing and rent tribunals, housing cooperatives, fluoridation, facilities for people with disabilities, and the setting up of the Liverpool association for the disabled. He believed strongly in cooperation between social services and health, something that primary care groups are trying to achieve today.

In 1977, Cyril moved into his pride and joy, the Princes Park health centre, in Toxteth. There, he created what could be called "the spirit of Princes Park", where health fairs, writers' workshops, poetry workshops, embroidery groups and plays, as well as a vast number of health projects, flourished.

In 1977, he was appointed to a royal commission on the NHS, which reported in 1979. During that decade, he helped create GP attachments for medical students, believing it was vital to give them experience in the real world of medicine.

Last year, Cyril was awarded the prestigious Duncan Medal, of the Liverpool University department of sociology, and, in his acceptance address, remembered his early life as a GP. At one practice, the surgery was drawn across the living room, with his family on one side and him on the other; another was located in a cellar, where the consulting room was separated from the waiting room by a plywood sheet.

Blessed with a wry sense of humour, Cyril recognised the need for a joke alongside the stethoscope and prescription pad. He kept a little book of patients' misquotes, including someone who confessed to "having a cyst on my aviaries" and another who declared "me tart's got TB and I've got to be scraped".

For Cyril, politics and medicine were the stuff of life, and his kindness and generosity were expressed in the unstinting time he gave to his patients, many of whom became his friends. He was president of the Socialist Health Association for a decade from the mid-1980s and active in the Labour party until his death.

He is survived by a son and daughter, his wife Pat, his partner Sylvia, with whom he lived for 12 years, and her three daughters.

webTitle: Leader: China and Taiwan seem to be making up

fields.headline: Straits talking
fields.standfirst:
China and Taiwan seem to be making up

Special report: Taiwan and China
fields.trailText: China and Taiwan seem to be making up.
fields.body:
Small steps sometimes lead to big changes, just as big steps sometimes precede immobility. If the current deadlock in the Middle East illustrates the latter, the cautious thaw now under way in the Taiwan straits may be a stunning example of the former. Almost unnoticed in the outside world, China and Taiwan have started a rapprochement that could be the outstanding event of 2001.

The visible element was the authorisation for boats to travel between the Chinese mainland and Taiwan's two daughter islands of Quemoy and Matsu. Smugglers have been plying the straits for years. Direct travel between Taiwan and the mainland is not yet permitted. So some say the change is meaningless, since it only legalises what was already happening, and makes no progress in other areas.

This is too mundane. Behind the scenes, a bigger shift is happening. Although Taiwan long accepted officially that it belonged to China, in recent years the drive for independence has grown. Its champions won the presidency last year, much to the chagrin of Beijing, which had tried to intimidate Taiwan's voters with military sabre-rattling. Faced by the new reality, Beijing is modifying its policy. It used to talk of "one country, two systems", meaning that when Taiwan rejoins the mainland politically, it can maintain its capitalist system. Now it says the formula can be loosened to give Taiwan even greater rights than Hong Kong.

For his part Taiwan's pro-independence President Chen is also making interesting noises. He is no longer resisting China's calls for direct links with the mainland. The opening of what the two sides call the "mini-links" between Quemoy and the mainland may be followed by links with Taiwan itself. At the moment, travellers from Taiwan to the mainland have to go by a roundabout route. Connections between two places happen everywhere in the world, and the fact that places trade or have travel links does not mean they are about to fuse or merge. But for Taiwan to accept greater ties with China is significant politically, just as the impact on China of greater contact with relatively rich Taiwan could be radical psychologically.

President-elect Bush needs to note the change. Much of United States strategy in Asia, as well as his own missile defence plan, are aimed at defending Taiwan. That may be becoming unnecessary.

webTitle: Prince's hunting fall gives royals another PR knock

fields.headline: Prince's hunting fall gives royals another PR knock
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the hunting debate
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The Prince of Wales increased the royal family's winter of discontent at the weekend when he fell off his horse during a fox hunt in Derbyshire on Saturday and broke a bone in his left shoulder.
fields.body:
The Prince of Wales increased the royal family's winter of discontent at the weekend when he fell off his horse during a fox hunt in Derbyshire on Saturday and broke a bone in his left shoulder.

Although the accident was said by royal aides to be minor and will not affect the prince's schedule of public engagements, it was the latest mishap to affect members of the royal family in what is being seen as a disastrous fortnight in public relations terms.

The prince fell from his horse on wet and slippery ground near Ashbourne while hunting with the Meynell and South Staffordshire hunt.

He clambered back into the saddle, but after the hunt finished he was taken to the Queen Elizabeth medical centre in Nottingham, where an x-ray examination revealed that he had fractured the acromium, a small bone near the shoulder blade.

The prince's arm was placed in a sling but the fracture is expected to heal itself within a few weeks. He was said yesterday to be resting at his country home, Highgrove, in Gloucestershire.

The accident follows the admission by Buckingham Palace last week that Princess Margaret had suffered a second stroke amid newspaper allegations that she was depressed about her state of health.

There was also an incident involving the Princess Royal, who was said to have been rude to a pensioner who was trying to present a home-made basket of flowers to the Queen Mother outside Sandringham church on Christmas Day.

The Queen spoke of her younger sister's health after attending church on the royal estate at Sandringham in Norfolk.

Asked about the princess's health by well-wishers in a crowd of about 100 people, the Queen said: "She is getting better."

Further tabloid revelations about Prince Andrew cavorting with topless women on a beach while on holiday in Thailand over the new year have prompted even normally sycophantic newspapers to test their readers' reactions with strong personal criticism, questioning the long-term prospects of survival for the family in its current role.

Reports of Prince Charles's accident prompted listeners to call the BBC yesterday morning to ask why no mention had been made of the health of the fox.

webTitle: Monks 'tortured pupils'

fields.headline: Monks 'tortured pupils'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: child protection
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Members of an order of Roman Catholic monks have been accused of physically and sexually abusing boys at a residential school in Scotland, including giving them electric shocks by making them grasp the exposed wires of a generator, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Members of an order of Roman Catholic monks have been accused of physically and sexually abusing boys at a residential school in Scotland, including giving them electric shocks by making them grasp the exposed wires of a generator, it emerged yesterday.

Police in Stirling confirmed that a report had been sent to the procurator fiscal after a three-year inquiry into St Ninian's school at Gartmore in Stirlingshire, which was run by the De La Salle Brothers.

Former pupils at the school, which closed in 1982, have alleged they were tortured, beaten and sexually molested by a number of the monks and civilian staff.

A spokesman for the order said all the allegations were vigorously denied, and the home had been run in an "exemplary" manner.

A Glasgow lawyer has launched a parallel civil action against the De La Salle brothers on behalf of 11 former pupils of the school, which housed boys sent from children's panels across Scotland who were deemed too disruptive to stay at home.

Cameron Fyfe said papers had been lodged at the court of session in Edinburgh.

Former pupil Christopher Fearns, 34, now a social worker, was sent to the school when he was eight. He has alleged that he was beaten with a riding crop two or three times a week for four years.

"They were constantly beating us," he said. "They told us they'd beat the devil out of us. One brother whipped me with a horsewhip. He'd tied knots in the end to make it even more painful and I was beaten solidly for 10 minutes.

"I was battered so many times on my head and ears I cannot hear a thing on my left side, and I've undergone extensive surgery because of it. There was a field next to the school with an electric fence. I saw the monks, on a number of occasions, forcing boys to grasp it until they cried out in pain."

The allegations come four months after a Catholic nun, Sister Marie Docherty, was convicted on four charges of cruelty against girls at Nazareth children's homes in Scotland in the 1960s and 1970s.

A spokesman for the Catholic church in Scotland, Father Danny McLoughlin, said any allegations of abuse must be taken seriously. "It is important when serious allegations like these are made that they are fully investigated by the appropriate authorities." he said. " The bishops of Scotland have made it clear that they view the protection of children and vulnerable adults as a priority."

John McCormick, a Glasgow-based lawyer representing the De La Salle order, said the monks had cooperated fully with police. "Nobody has been charged," he said. "The allegations are vigorously denied.

"All the evidence available to me indicates that St Ninian's was run in an exemplary manner. Unlike those making the allegations and their advisers I will reserve any further comment until after the results of the civil action are known."

It is understood that the Central Scotland police report into St Ninian's covers a period between the mid 1960s and 1982. It follows a lengthy inquiry launched after a complaint by a former pupil, and contains detailed allegations of physical and sexual abuse made by 12 boys.

Allegations have been made against seven monks and five civilian staff. Two of the monks have since died and the others, now aged between 68 and 92, have retired.

The report alleges boys were frequently subjected to sexual fondling and a range of "punishments". Several boys mentioned an electrical device, described as a type of generator, which was kept in the boot room. According to the report, boys were made to hold on to a pair of wires leading from the machine, which administered electric shocks.

A Central Scotland police spokesman said yesterday: "We have recently concluded a lengthy investigation into allegations of abuse at St Ninian's school, which resulted in a comprehensive report being submitted to the procurator fiscal at Stirling for his consideration."

webTitle: US call to ban cigarette sales

fields.headline: US call to ban cigarette sales
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: Cigarettes should be available only to those already addicted to them and should no longer be sold for profit, according to the man who framed the Clinton administration's tobacco policy.
fields.body:
Cigarettes should be available only to those already addicted to them and should no longer be sold for profit, according to the man who framed the Clinton administration's tobacco policy.

The radical strategy, explained in a book by David Kessler, the former head of the powerful food and drug administration, will send shivers through the tobacco industry, which is still reeling from successive class action awards made against it on behalf of lung cancer sufferers. Dr Kessler says the industry should be dismantled and cigarettes sold only in plain wrappers on a non-profit basis to existing addicts.

The proposed strategy comes just after the publication of figures showing that cancer rates have fallen over the last decade by 16% in California, the state with the toughest anti-smoking laws, compared with 2.7% elsewhere in the United States.

Dr Kessler's new book, A Question of Intent: A Great American Battle with a Deadly Industry, suggests that there is now no other way to deal with tobacco than dismantle the tobacco companies as they now stand and allow them to operate only as a regulated organisation, similar to a public utility, able to supply cigarette addicts but not allowed to market their product. The money paid by smokers would be used only to cover the costs of production and transport.

"Although nicotine and cigarettes have to remain available, you cannot ethically and morally allow companies to make a profit," argues Dr Kessler, who is now the dean of the Yale University medical school. He believes that if the profit motive were removed from the equation, the industry would gradually die. Without a profit, the powerful tobacco industry would be unable to lobby politicians as successfully as it has in the past.

Dr Kessler tells how he was once told by Hillary Clinton: "I really admire what you are doing. It's Orwellian to say that nicotine is not a drug."

Her husband Bill was more reluctant to tackle the issue, he says, arguing that the Democrats' stance on tobacco and gun control had cost them control of Congress. However, Dr Kessler was able to persuade the president to mount an aggressive campaign against marketing cigarettes to children.

Whether Dr Kessler's suggestions will have much resonance within George W Bush's administration is another matter. Shares in tobacco companies rose as news of Mr Bush's victory was confirmed.

webTitle: Minister admits watchdog is not Shipman-proof

fields.headline: Minister admits watchdog is not Shipman-proof
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: A government minister yesterday admitted its new body to help health authorities and trusts root out failing and criminal doctors would not stop another Harold Shipman.
fields.body:
A government minister yesterday admitted its new body to help health authorities and trusts root out failing and criminal doctors would not stop another Harold Shipman.

The health minister John Hutton's comments came within hours of Tony Blair's assertion that the national clinical assessment authority (NCAA), and the new regular appraisals of doctors, would "make a considerable difference" and give the authorities "the best possible chance" of stopping someone like Shipman, who is suspected of killing more than 300 of his patients.

"It is going to allow us to take action very quickly where either a hospital or a GP practice knows something is wrong or something is revealed about a particular doctor behaving in a particular way," the prime minister said on television. "We will be able to sort out very quickly whether there is a real and substantial difficulty and address the problem.

"Along with the new annual appraisals for doctors ... this will make a considerable difference."

But the NCAA, details of which will be announced today, will be only an advisory body. It can help health authorities and hospital trusts speed up action against suspect doctors, but it cannot initiate anything. It is a watered-down compromise from the assessment centres for dodgy doctors which the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, proposed 18 months ago, and which the British Medical Association rejected as "sin bins', saying they would stigmatise doctors.

Although the BMA wel comes the NCAA instead, it does not believe it will help prevent doctors who are minded to murder. "It is nothing to do with Shipman. To pretend this announcement is something to deal with such cases is misleading," said a spokesman.

Mr Hutton conceded on Sky News later that the NCAA would not be able to weed out potential criminals like Shipman.

"Shipman was a mass murderer," he said. "What we need to make sure is that we have a better set of systems in place to detect concerns about death rates, patients dying in GPs' premises and practices."

The NCAA would "help us deal more promptly with concerns that patients might be expressing about the clinical practices of GPs, and allow us to provide extra support to GPs. We will also be able to reassure public confidence in primary care. I think it is very, very important that we act now to reassure patients and the public about the competence of primary care practices".

If health authorities or trusts feel they have a problem with a doctor, they will be able to ask the NCAA for help. The authority will attempt to speed things up, so that the doctor can be referred for a performance assessment to the GMC, for instance. But crucially, the doctor will not be publicly removed from his job.

A spokeswoman for the Department of Health said the authority would "provide a single central rapid response to cases where concern is raised".

But although the description "alert centre" is being used, those on the alert will still have to be the doctor's employers. Unless they realise something is wrong, then nothing will happen.

webTitle: Blair switches target

fields.headline: Blair switches target
fields.standfirst:
Fight to motivate core vote begins

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday fired the starting gun for the 2001 general election with an aggressive defence of his government's economic achievements and a warning that, if re-elected, he would rather be right than popular.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday fired the starting gun for the 2001 general election with an aggressive defence of his government's economic achievements and a warning that, if re-elected, he would rather be right than popular.

In a rare admission that he may have taken his inclusive middle England politics too far since 1997, the prime minister declared: "The biggest single thing I have learned is that you can't please all the people all the time. But in the end it's less important to be liked than to do the job to the best of your ability" - and let the voters decide, now almost certainly on May 3.

Some senior ministers interpreted his remarks as confirming what one called "an end to the big tent philosophy" that saw Labour court the Sun and Daily Mail, not least over Europe, until last month's row over the EU's Nice summit.

Blair aides insisted that the prime minister's attitude had been toughened by the fuel protest in September and by his own refusal to bow to popular pressure for petrol tax cuts. But Downing Street's rhetoric is increasingly concerned to remotivate Labour's heartlands vote.

With Whitehall this week unveiling a series of financial incentives to recruit - and retain - teachers ("saints and heroes", Mr Blair called them), doctors and nurses, police officers and other key workers in boom areas, No 10 said his core message on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost was "stability in the economy versus the old Tory boom and bust, investment in public services versus cuts in public services".

Claiming that Labour would enter the campaign for the first time as the party best able to manage the economy, Mr Blair admitted mistakes - notably last year's 75p rise for pensioners - but denied that postponed investment in schools, transport and hospitals were among them.

As ministers were again obliged to intervene to maintain standards in the NHS, Mr Blair cited "real improvements" in schools, 16,000 more nurses since 1997 and a rise in police numbers across England and Wales for the first time in seven years. They are up by 440, according to revised figures out next week, with even stronger recruitment in major cities such as Manchester and London due to be reported in February thanks to extra funds, officials later predicted.

"Within four years, I want to have more police employed in this country than ever before, and we have got the money to do it," Mr Blair said in a tribute to public sector staff who have often felt neglected.

His combative tone goaded the Tories - dismissed by Mr Blair as divided, lost and "utterly hopeless" - into a sharp response. They claimed that Labour has collected an extra £25bn in "stealth taxes" - £670 a year from the average family - but has wasted the money instead of improving schools, roads and hospitals.

A £1.5m nationwide poster campaign, to be unveiled tomorrow by William Hague and Michael Portillo, will ask voters "You've paid the taxes, so where has the money gone?" - specifically "where are the police, [NHS] operations, teachers and trains?"

The Tories too are gearing up for a May 3 poll. One Hague aide, armed with a list of allegedly unfulfilled Labour pledges, said there were "a lot of floating voters sloshing around in the middle" and quipped: "Even if our polls go down to 20% but there is only a 30% turnout at the election we will win."

Despite the prime minister's brave words that is the scenario that haunts Labour: if Mr Hague can motivate the Tory core vote between 30% and 35% while disappointed Labour voters stay at home, vote nationalist, Lib Dem or Green, the 179-seat Commons majority produced by Mr Blair's 44%-31% lead in 1997 could be brutally cut back.

Though Mr Blair yesterday praised Gordon Brown's "brilliant stewardship," the Lib Dem Treasury spokesman, Matthew Taylor, later took a stab at the chancellor's record where he is weakest among Labour's own core vote, the "heartland" supporters most likely to abstain.

Mr Taylor produced figures to suggest that Mr Brown had deliberately underestimated his budget surplus by an average of £8bn a year since 1997; had overestimated unemployment levels by an average 225,000 a year (thus saving a windfall £1bn-2bn a year); and had underestimated economic growth by £18bn a year and therefore tax receipts by an annual £7bn. Mr Taylor said: "Gordon Brown's Prudence is about to be dumped in favour of Lady Bountiful. Brown has been seduced by the Tory tax-cutting agenda."

Many Labour MPs would privately agree, although Mr Blair reminded them yesterday that past Labour governments had "come in, spent money because they wanted to improve public services, found they couldn't do it and had to cut back".

webTitle: Britain seeks u-turn over Iraq bombing

fields.headline: Britain seeks u-turn over Iraq bombing
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The British government, in a policy u-turn, is to propose to the incoming US administration that the bombing of targets over southern Iraq should be stopped.
fields.body:
The British government, in a policy u-turn, is to propose to the incoming US administration that the bombing of targets over southern Iraq should be stopped.

British and US planes have enforced no-fly zones along Iraq's northern and southern borders since 1992. In the past two years alone, they have dropped more than 100 bombs, mainly against Iraqi air defences.

The bombing, in what is sometimes called the "forgotten war", has led to an unknown number of civilian casualties. Hans von Sponek, the former UN humanitarian coordinator, writing in the Guardian last week, said that 144 civilians had died in the no-fly zones because of the bombing.

The two no-fly zones were imposed by the US and Britain after the Gulf war in what was described as a humanitarian effort to protect the Shi'ites in the south of Iraq and Kurds in the north.

However, they are not backed by any UN security council resolution and do not include flights by Iraqi helicopters. Iraq is now flying civilian aircraft over the zones.

The official British line is that there are no plans to change the approach to Iraq and that British foreign policy is determined independently of the US. In the Guardian last week, Peter Hain, the Foreign Office minister, strongly defended the no-fly zone policy.

But in reality, the whole of US-British policy towards Iraq is under review as a result of the impending arrival of a new US administration. Among the top foreign policy issues the new president, George W Bush, will have to contend with is how to deal with the renewed confidence of the Iraqi dictator, Saddam Hussein.

Mr Bush is expected to take a tough line, given that his father was president at the time of the Gulf war and that his secretary of state, Colin Powell, commanded the Allied forces. Gen Powell has spoken of the need to "re-energise" US policy towards Iraq.

But only Britain and the US remain enthusiastic about maintaining sanctions and France, among others, has criticised the continued bombing of southern Iraq.

In an attempt to deflect criticism, the British government has been looking behind-the-scenes at the introduction of so-called "smart" sanctions and an end to the southern no-fly zone.

The no-fly zone was meant to counter Saddam Hussein's assault on the southern Shi'ites by denying him air space. But the Iraqi campaign of repression has effectively ended because the anti-Saddam opposition in the towns and among the Marsh Arabs has been quelled.

The Ministry of Defence, which has spent more than £800m policing the zones, is increasingly uneasy about the possibility of an RAF pilot going down, and the bombing has led to public concern, especially after evidence that victims have included civilians.

The British government is proposing to retain the no-fly zone in the north because it argues the threat remains to the Iraqi Kurds.

Although ready to consider fresh policies, Britain does not intend to let up on Saddam, seeing him as a serious threat to world stability.

Downing Street has been increasingly toying with the idea of switching from a blanket ban that has exceptions to sanctions that specify a narrow band of prohibited goods, mainly weapons.

UN reports have shown that the sanctions have resulted in a high civilian death toll, especially among children.

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, said yesterday a rethink of British and UN policy towards Iraq was "absolutely necessary".

"Ten years of inertia is no substitute for effective policy," he said.

Also under consideration will be sanctions that target the regime more effectively by trying to limit the ability to travel and hitting overseas bank accounts, though such measures have proved difficult to achieve in the past.
fields.bodyText: The British government, in a policy u-turn, is to propose to the incoming US administration that the bombing of targets over southern Iraq should be stopped. British and US planes have enforced no-fly zones along Iraq's northern and southern borders since 1992. In the past two years alone, they have dropped more than 100 bombs, mainly against Iraqi air defences. The bombing, in what is sometimes called the "forgotten war", has led to an unknown number of civilian casualties. Hans von Sponek, the former UN humanitarian coordinator, writing in the Guardian last week, said that 144 civilians had died in the no-fly zones because of the bombing. The two no-fly zones were imposed by the US and Britain after the Gulf war in what was described as a humanitarian effort to protect the Shi'ites in the south of Iraq and Kurds in the north. However, they are not backed by any UN security council resolution and do not include flights by Iraqi helicopters. Iraq is now flying civilian aircraft over the zones. The official British line is that there are no plans to change the approach to Iraq and that British foreign policy is determined independently of the US. In the Guardian last week, Peter Hain, the Foreign Office minister, strongly defended the no-fly zone policy. But in reality, the whole of US-British policy towards Iraq is under review as a result of the impending arrival of a new US administration. Among the top foreign policy issues the new president, George W Bush, will have to contend with is how to deal with the renewed confidence of the Iraqi dictator, Saddam Hussein. Mr Bush is expected to take a tough line, given that his father was president at the time of the Gulf war and that his secretary of state, Colin Powell, commanded the Allied forces. Gen Powell has spoken of the need to "re-energise" US policy towards Iraq. But only Britain and the US remain enthusiastic about maintaining sanctions and France, among others, has criticised the continued bombing of southern Iraq. In an attempt to deflect criticism, the British government has been looking behind-the-scenes at the introduction of so-called "smart" sanctions and an end to the southern no-fly zone. The no-fly zone was meant to counter Saddam Hussein's assault on the southern Shi'ites by denying him air space. But the Iraqi campaign of repression has effectively ended because the anti-Saddam opposition in the towns and among the Marsh Arabs has been quelled. The Ministry of Defence, which has spent more than £800m policing the zones, is increasingly uneasy about the possibility of an RAF pilot going down, and the bombing has led to public concern, especially after evidence that victims have included civilians. webTitle: Greenspan - a guru but not a god

fields.headline: Greenspan - a guru but not a god
fields.trailText: The modern world has its own Olympians and there is no doubt who is the Zeus in this pantheon: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the US Federal Reserve.
fields.body:
The ancient Greeks believed their world was ruled by gods and goddesses living on the summit of Mount Olympus. There was a god of the sea, Poseidon; a goddess of love, Aphrodite. From this lofty pinnacle, the Olympians decided the fate of mortals, rewarding the good and punishing the wicked.

They were very like human beings, apart from being endowed with superhuman powers. But in a world vulnerable to war, pestilence and disaster, the rulings of the Olympians provided an explanation for when life got tough.

The modern world has its own Olympians. Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, is a new Olympian, as is Horst Köhler, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund. Mike Moore, director-general of the World Trade Organisation, is another, along with Bill Gates, Rupert Murdoch and a host of lesser deities. While there seems to be no candidate for the new Aphrodite, there is no doubt who is the Zeus in this pantheon: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the US Federal Reserve.

When he acted last week to cut half a point off US interest rates it was the equivalent of a thunderbolt hurled down from on high. Such was the faith in this god of gods that the markets instantly stopped selling shares and began buying truckloads instead. Greenspan had spoken. All would now be well.

The reaction of the financial markets is fascinating, for two reasons. First, it is in flat contradiction to the orthodoxy of the past quarter-century, namely that policymakers have little control over economic activity, and that when they do try to meddle they do more harm than good.

Yet here we had the situation where the mood in the markets changed simply because a central banker had loosened monetary policy by half a point. This belief in the omnipotence and omniscience of technocrats was supposed to have died out in the mid-70s, but is apparently alive and well in the dealing rooms of Wall Street and the City.

As John Llewellyn of Lehman Brothers put it recently: "Investors and traders typically pore over policymakers' utterances with an almost unimaginable intensity, revealing a belief in the effectiveness of policymaking that the policymakers, or at least their advisers, rigorously deny."

This does not mean policymakers are powerless. Take the following example. A government comes into power committed to a policy of "education, education, education". Three and a half years later, the number of applications for post-graduate teaching courses is down 16.1% on the year and some schools are going on four-day weeks. Clearly, there is a shortage of people willing to sell their labour to the government for the going rate.

The solution is to raise salaries. There is a mismatch between demand and supply - the culmination of decades in which increased workload and the decline in teachers' pay have made the job less attractive. In a perfect market either the salaries of teachers would rise to attract and retain more or consumers of education would take their custom elsewhere. Given that the government is a monopoly employer and, for most, a monopoly provider, it can buck the market.

But the problem can only be resolved by making them work harder, importing teachers from overseas, cutting the length of the school week, or a combination thereof. Even then, it is only a short term solution. Teachers of economics, assuming that there are any left, might like to get their A-level students to sketch out some demand and supply curves for teachers to see why this is the case.

Resolving a market failure in education is one thing; assuming Greenspan can play god is quite another. Increasing the supply of teachers is a two-dimensional problem; steering the global economy away from recession involves making sense of the decisions of millions of individual economic agents. This would be impossible even if they behaved rationally, but they do not. After the bail-out of Long Term Capital Management in the autumn of 1998, we were assured that the markets had learned their lesson. But this weekend rumours are swirling around about exactly which US institution managed to lose so much money that Greenspan was forced to take emergency action.

The Fed chairman is a clever man, but his attempts to manipulate macroeconomic policy amount to little more than a shot in the dark. Even in the days when policymakers were shielded from global events by tariff barriers and capital controls, it was absurd to believe that by pulling a few levers the economy could be kept in a state of perfection.

Freed trade

Today, with most of the barriers to trade and money torn down, it is impossible for central bankers and finance ministers to know what the effects of any policy move will be. A cut in interest rates should stimulate demand, but if individuals and firms believe the move is a portent of hard times, it may encourage them to save, rather than spend. Even if it does boost demand, some of the additional spending may leak out in the form of higher imports.

Greenspan knows this. The Fed is privately putting it about that the rate cut was not prompted by signs of distress but by the need to reassert its psychological hold over the markets. This has the ring of truth about it. Greenspan's one real weapon is his ability to generate confidence, particularly among those who are the true believers in the myth of his invincibility - the practitioners in the financial markets.

But as with the ancient Greeks, the time comes when faith starts to wear thin. It is becoming clearer that the US faces two structural problems - overinvestment by companies and an orgy of debt-financed spending by consumers.

Over-investment explains the spate of recent profit warnings, an intensification of a trend that has been under way for two years: the fact that too much of the capital spending during the heady days of the boom was not profitable. This explains why inventories are piling up and why the real long-term threat to the US is not inflation but deflation.

Up to a point, the extra supply has been soaked up by consumers' live-now, pay-later approach, but this only works when lenders and borrowers are willing. When banks are reluctant to extend credit and consumers are trying to rebuild their savings, cutting interest rates is - to coin a phrase - pushing on a piece of string.

The Fed was right to cut rates, and there will be further cuts before the year is much older. But to believe anybody is really in control of the global economy is as fanciful as believing that winter begins when Persephone descends into the underworld. That may be a scary thought, but it is the way that it is.

webTitle: Britain's growing band of religious hermits

fields.headline: Britain's growing band of religious hermits
fields.standfirst:
Church attendance may be declining, but increasing numbers of people are opting for a regime of spiritual contemplation in solitude

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Church attendance may be declining, but increasing numbers of people are opting for a regime of spiritual contemplation in solitude.
fields.body:
Rising numbers of lay people are choosing to live a solitary life of prayer and contemplation, according to Church of England sources.

At a time when church attendance is in decline, applications to live a contemplative life, in the style of the saints of the early church, have increased.

However, whereas the Syrian St Simeon Stylites prayed on top of a 60ft pillar for 36 years, modern ascetics rarely live a totally reclusive existence.

Dominic Walker, bishop of Reading, said: "There is a growing interest in the solitary life. It is not necessarily living as a recluse - although there are a few anchorites - it is more that people feel they are being called to a greater consecration of their lives to God. Most are living normal lives but, with people living in more loosely structured communities, it is much easier to be solitary."

The bishop, who acts as spiritual director for a number of contemplatives, added: "There is a solitary living in my own area who has a hermitage in her garden. Her husband seems to be quite sympathetic."

Strangely, while increasing numbers of Anglicans are attempting to follow the medieval rules of solitary living laid down by St Benedict, the Roman Catholic Church is reporting a decline in applications to join contemplative religious orders or tolive as solitaries. "We can only think of three [hermits] living in this country,"said Tom Horwood, spokesman for the Catholic Media Office.

Community work

Some religious orders combine a life of contemplation with community work. A group of American Franciscans - the Friars of Renewal - recently moved in to a dilapidated church hall in Canning Town, east London, to set up a small monastery ministering to people on a council estate.

Dressed in their grey habits and sandals and with long, bushy beards, the friars can even be seen ministering to the locals' spiritual needs by holding regular sessions in a pub.

Father Richard, the 31-year-old leader, said: "Everyone seems to be so angry here compared with New York. It's much worse in some ways. We have had rocks thrown at us but generally the welcome has been friendly enough. Kids look up at us in the street and say, 'Are you Jesus?' and our standard response is, 'No, we're just working for him'."

The number of societies for lay contemplatives is growing. There is the Fellowship of Solitaries, which has about 300 members, the Association of British Contemplatives, the Companions of Jesus Crucified, and even an organisation called the Order of Consecrated Virgins.

In the US there is an urban hermit movement, some of whose members retreat to their Manhattan apartments after a day behind their Wall Street computer screens for evenings of prayer, reading and quiet thought.

Eve Baker, newsletter editor of the Fellowship of Solitaries, who is married to a retired clergyman and lives in Brecon, Powys, said: "There is a dissatisfaction with institutional religion, which seems to dwindle these days. We speak very much of a vocation to solitude - just as there are vocations to the priesthood so there are vocations to an interior life of contemplation.

"We have people from all walks of life, including teachers, nurses - there seems to be a lot of solitude in nursing - even gravediggers. There is a certain wish to withdraw from the rush of everyday life."

The fellowship is ecumenical and has Catholics, Quakers and Pentecostalists as well as Anglicans. Its information leaflet states: "For the genuine solitary the perception of God is not likely to come through other people - none of us know where we may be led. It is rather like falling in love. It has the same element of adventure. Perhaps the genuine solitary falls in love with God."

Many are married and have families but interest is rising mostly among the elderly who perhaps have more time and a greater wish to withdraw from society.

Life of prayer

One is Olive Stephens, an 80-year-old spinster and former infants teacher in Chatham, Kent, who recently took vows to the consecrated single life at her local church after a year of study. Her vicar, Philip Hesketh says: "This sort of thing was common in the early church and now it seems to be happening in the 21st Century too. Olive lived an active life in our church but did not feel completely fulfilled. She follows a disciplined life of prayer. We think Olive is the first person since the Reformation in the Rochester diocese to consecrate her life in this way."

To an outsider, little in Miss Stephens' life would appear to have changed. She still lives in her council house, watches television - especially Dad's Army and The Good Life - goes shopping and attends church.

But now she also gets up at 4.30am to follow the rule of St Benedict and pray for two hours.

Her decision had much to do with previous frustrations and traumas in her life. She said: "I had a very strong maternal instinct but I never married. Now I feel I have been called to be a spiritual mother. I feel complete in a way I never did before. I realised I had to let go of all the children I never had. I asked Jesus if I could be his fiancee and he said yes. I have become a bride of Christ.

"I feel I have a fairly normal life. It is not a sacrifice to me, just that my interests have changed. I may be the first person in Rochester diocese to go through with this but it is happening all over the country, requests are coming in at one a month. It seems to be particularly women who are interested. Perhaps men are different."

webTitle: TV and Radio: Mark Lawson's column

fields.headline: A likely story
fields.standfirst: It's January, so our television screens are awash with new dramas. Fresh plot twists may be hard to come by, but  Mark Lawson finds much to admire in three of the big-budget contenders for our attention
fields.trailText: It's January, so our television screens are awash with new dramas. Fresh plot twists may be hard to come by, but there is much to admire in three of the big-budget contenders for our attention.
fields.body:
The hardest part of writing is the start. (I previously deleted four variations on this sentence.) But the novelist has at least 50 pages and the movie-writer 30 minutes to win the interest of the audience. In the 60s and 70s, when television was a novelty, the TV scriptwriter may have had half-an-hour's grace. These days, fighting hundreds of rival networks and alternative uses of the box, the only argument within the profession is whether you have five or ten minutes to forestall a switch-off. Some young pessimists say it's a mere minute.

This attrition rate makes me nervous for In a Land of Plenty, a vastly expensive, ten-part drama adapted from a novel by Tim Pears.

The trick in selling an epic story - In a Land of Plenty follows one family across the last five decades of the 20th century - is to establish the scale and implications at the beginning. This is why so many family sagas flashback from a funeral, jury verdict or impending suicide at the beginning.

This structure has become a narrative default. As readers and viewers, we've all become used to the opening moments in the nursing home as the ancient crone croaks something enticing along the lines of: "If my father hadn't landed on Mars, I wouldn't be sitting here 50 years later in Morocco with the fraud squad and the prime minister banging on the door." Then there are three dots on the page or fuzzy lines on screen and we're in wartime London.

It's easy to understand why new talent wants to resist this standard format, but I fear that any other approach undersells what's coming. Adapter Kevin Hood and director Hettie Macdonald begin In a Land of Plenty with a beautiful but confusing mosaic of frames. We're then with a young married couple in the 50s. The drama feels small, domestic and period, which is merely a fraction of what it will eventually be.

Halfway through the episode, you begin to sense what's being sown.

Stuffy factory owner Charles Freeman (Robert Pugh) obsessively impregnates his wife Mary (Helen McCrory), creating a large and rivalrous set of siblings and fuelling frustrations in his wife, who dreams of being a Plath-like poet.

After 50 minutes, it seemed a potential hit. But after ten, I'd thought it a disaster. This worries me because TV serials are like the 100 metres race: the start is everything.

In television, new drama is as associated with January as repeats are with August. In Judge John Deed, GF Newman, the guvnor of the modern police series with Law And Order, upgrades to the legal big-wigs.

On both the bookshelves and on television, the legal thriller has been one of the most powerful forms of the last decade. Now, with most barrister storylines used up, judges have become the subject, allowing the genre to apply for an extension.

As writer and producer of Judge John Deed, Newman has created a clever twist on the cop genre. The maverick detective is now a character so overdone that TV had to turn to a dull stickler, Inspector Barnaby, in The Midsomer Murders. But once the enemy of the rule-book becomes a High Court judge, a clapped-out narrative banger can go back on the forecourt with a tempting price-sign.

In casting which smartly underlines the transplant taking place, Judge Deed is played by Martin Shaw, still dashing around the video stores as a cop in The Professionals. Glossier and more populist than Newman's earlier work, the piece tempts comparison between what was possible in television in the 70s and what is tolerated in the 90s.

Newman's signature cynicism is still present; there's plenty of contempt for court. The judge is desperate to conduct his own forensic investigation of the body fluids of the attractive defence QC and connives with the Met police chief while jousting at their fencing club. Yet these offences against his profession are undertaken in good causes: helping his daughter to protest against GM crops, freeing a black defendant who has shot his daughter's killer.

Some will think the guvnor has gone soft, but he retains a rare skill for involving narrative and dialogue.

Appropriately, Judge John Deed is itself on trial. This one-off episode tests public tolerance of a series. But, if this offering doesn't justify the full term, then, as a litigant once remarked, I'm a banana.

Tonight's conclusion of the two-part drama The Innocent is another twist on television law stories, in that both plaintiff and defendant in a rape case are barristers. Sexual assault is an attractive plot for fiction because the accused and the accuser's differing accounts offer a particularly stark example of the way in which all drama hopes to tease the viewer with two possible explanations.

And yet rape is also a dangerous subject for fiction - rivalled only by race in this respect - because of the dilemma over whether the outcome should reflect reality or hope. In life, a probable majority of rapists go unprosecuted or unconvicted. But a drama which reflects this reality may seem to be endorsing a bloke's right to poke who he wants. Writer Jan McVerry's attempt to solve this problem in the final segment tonight is a fascinating technical exercise.

 In a Land of Plenty, Wednesday, 9pm, BBC2 Judge John Deed, Tuesday, 8pm, BBC1 The Innocent, tonight, 9pm, ITV.

By the book

One of the most reliably entertaining items for consumer series such as Watchdog is the short film in which a reporter tries to follow the instruction manual for a new video recorder or computer.

In America of late, there's been a trend for handbooks to the human personality, suggesting that a husband or wife can be run like a car, or that a co-operative toddler can be constructed by following numbered steps. Living By The Book (Wednesday, 9pm, Channel 4) has had the idea of running a consumer test on these instruction manuals for people.

In the first show, a focus group of three young British women test out The Rules, an American bestseller which tells single females how to snare a husband in 35 steps, which are broadly variations on the old advice to keep them keen by treating them mean. Intercourse, weekday dates and home-cooked meals must only be offered to a man according to a strict timetable constructed by two stern and now very rich Americans, Ellen and Sherrie.

Sandi Scott's film contains the funniest dating scenes since There's Something About Mary. Having constructed a theology of attraction, Ellen and Sherrie preside like the Holy Inquisition over video diaries kept by the trio of British rule-users.

"This what you get if you cook on a Monday night for a man you've known for a month!" shrieks one of the American rulers, noting that the guy is looking frightened. Urged to refuse a sunshine holiday with her beau because the rule-book is still confiscating passports at this stage, one of the testers insists on travelling.

"Talk about the weather", she is warned, "not your relationship." Regrettably, I fear that this lethally funny documentary will increase rather than reduce sales of The Rules. But anyone who understands the handbook for their video recorder should watch this skewering of the attempt to impose protocol on procreation.

But the novelist has at least 50 pages and the movie-writer 30 minutes to win the interest of the audience. In the 60s and 70s, when television was a novelty, the TV scriptwriter may have had half-an-hour's grace. These days, fighting hundreds of rival networks and alternative uses of the box, the only argument within the profession is whether you have five or ten minutes to forestall a switch-off. Some young pessimists say it's a mere minute. This attrition rate makes me nervous for In a Land of Plenty, a vastly expensive, ten-part drama adapted from a novel by Tim Pears. The trick in selling an epic story - In a Land of Plenty follows one family across the last five decades of the 20th century - is to establish the scale and implications at the beginning. This is why so many family sagas flashback from a funeral, jury verdict or impending suicide at the beginning. This structure has become a narrative default. As readers and viewers, we've all become used to the opening moments in the nursing home as the ancient crone croaks something enticing along the lines of: "If my father hadn't landed on Mars, I wouldn't be sitting here 50 years later in Morocco with the fraud squad and the prime minister banging on the door." Then there are three dots on the page or fuzzy lines on screen and we're in wartime London. It's easy to understand why new talent wants to resist this standard format, but I fear that any other approach undersells what's coming. Adapter Kevin Hood and director Hettie Macdonald begin In a Land of Plenty with a beautiful but confusing mosaic of frames. We're then with a young married couple in the 50s. The drama feels small, domestic and period, which is merely a fraction of what it will eventually be. Halfway through the episode, you begin to sense what's being sown. Stuffy factory owner Charles Freeman (Robert Pugh) obsessively impregnates his wife Mary (Helen McCrory), creating a large and rivalrous set of siblings and fuelling frustrations in his wife, who dreams of being a Plath-like poet. After 50 minutes, it seemed a potential hit. But after ten, I'd thought it a disaster. This worries me because TV serials are like the 100 metres race: the start is everything. In television, new drama is as associated with January as repeats are with August. In Judge John Deed, GF Newman, the guvnor of the modern police series with Law And Order, upgrades to the legal big-wigs. On both the bookshelves and on television, the legal thriller has been one of the most powerful forms of the last decade. Now, with most barrister storylines used up, judges have become the subject, allowing the genre to apply for an extension. As writer and producer of Judge John Deed, Newman has created a clever twist on the cop genre. The maverick detective is now a character so overdone that TV had to turn to a dull stickler, Inspector Barnaby, in The Midsomer Murders. But once the enemy of the rule-book becomes a High Court judge, a clapped-out narrative banger can go back on the forecourt with a tempting price-sign. In casting which smartly underlines the transplant taking place, Judge Deed is played by Martin Shaw, still dashing around the video stores as a cop in The Professionals. Glossier and more populist than Newman's earlier work, the piece tempts comparison between what was possible in television in the 70s and what is tolerated in the 90s. Newman's signature cynicism is still present; there's plenty of contempt for court. The judge is desperate to conduct his own forensic investigation of the body fluids of the attractive defence QC and connives with the Met police chief while jousting at their fencing club. Yet these offences against his profession are undertaken in good causes: helping his daughter to protest against GM crops, freeing a black defendant who has shot his daughter's killer. Some will think the guvnor has gone soft, but he retains a rare skill for involving narrative and dialogue. Appropriately, Judge John Deed is itself on trial. This one-off episode tests public tolerance of a series. But, if this offering doesn't justify the full term, then, as a litigant once remarked, I'm a banana. Tonight's conclusion of the two-part drama The Innocent is another twist on television law stories, in that both plaintiff and defendant in a rape case are barristers. Sexual assault is an attractive plot for fiction because the accused and the accuser's differing accounts offer a particularly stark example of the way in which all drama hopes to tease the viewer with two possible explanations. And yet rape is also a dangerous subject for fiction - rivalled only by race in this respect - because of the dilemma over whether the outcome should reflect reality or hope. In life, a probable majority of rapists go unprosecuted or unconvicted. But a drama which reflects this reality may seem to be endorsing a bloke's right to poke who he wants. webTitle: Cornish Eden project blooms

fields.headline: Tropic zone  Cornish project blooms
fields.trailText: The Eden Project in Cornwall yesterday closed to the public, three months before it officially opens, after welcoming nearly 500,000 visitors who have paid just to see it being built.
fields.body:
The Eden Project in Cornwall yesterday closed to the public, three months before it officially opens, after welcoming nearly 500,000 visitors who have paid just to see it being built.

The £80m project, funded by the millennium commission, is based around two giant biomes which will house tropical and semi-tropical plants in a former claypit near St Austell.

The man behind it, Tim Smit, decided to open Eden last May so visitors could watch the building of the greenhouses, the largest in the world.

The original expectation was that 250,000 people might visit and it would be open until October. But it was decided to extend the opening until yesterday, the last possible date before the site is cleared for the extension of the visitor centre and the mass planting of the thousands of bushes, trees and shrubs.

In all, over a period of 34 weeks 498,942 people each paid £3 to go to the visitor centre and take a short ride on a train towed by a tractor, which allowed them to look at the biomes across the floor of the pit.

Although people came from all over the country, and abroad, most they have been from south-west.

Mr. Smit has attempted to tie local people into the project, with as many of the 400 jobs on site as possible being advertised through the St Austell job centre. The project is sifting through 3,000 applications for the remaining 200 posts on offer.

However, Eden aims to be not just a visitor attraction but a serious centre of scientific research, and has also applied for planning permission for a 200-bed hotel.

Mr Smit said yesterday: "We have brought together a team here in Cornwall which can stand comparison with any in the world. The fact that the local community refers to 'our Eden' is undoubtedly the reason for our success."

In contrast to the dome's figure of 12m, and to the relief of the millennium commission, the project has a comparatively modest target for its first year of proper opening of 750.000 visitors, which would make it Cornwall's most popular attraction, ahead of Land's End.

It will reopen to the public on March 17.

webTitle: G2: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Somerset
fields.trailText: Somerset
fields.body:
Recently, I was told of a West Country village of some 2OO dwellings. Domestic heating oil is delivered there by 10 different suppliers. This means that any one of 10 different tankers may thunder along any of the approach roads at any time on any day. The implications for overcrowding and consequent accident risk on narrow rural roads, for pollution, and for the sheer waste of resources are obvious.

Then I was told of the length and complexity of the chain that links producer to consumer in the case of, for example, meat. The calf is born. Eighteen months later the "finished" animal is transported by road, sometimes for a distance of over 100 miles, to the abattoir. Often, the packaging plant is some distance away - another road journey. The packaged product then travels to the wholesaler and thence to the retailer, probably an out-of-town hypermarket, from which the chosen cut is taken, necessarily by car, to the consumer's home.

It is not surprising, then, that the price of meat to the consumer can be some 15 to 20 times that paid to the farmer. My two informants are committed to shortening the chain between producer and consumer. Their new company, "Wellieboot", aims to help people who live in the country to combine their buying power.

A pilot scheme has identified one supplier of domestic heating fuel and contacted 50 villages. Where several residents in one place combine to have their oil delivered by one supplier on one day, real economies are made. How much more might be achieved on similar lines with deliveries of food and other essentials.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Composer Of The Week | Ghost Houses
fields.body:
He was Jewish and jolly, two characteristics which so irritated Richard Wagner that he dismissed the music of Jacques Offenbach as "a dungheap in which all the swine of Europe wallowed". These strictures barely touched Offenbach's 20-year reign at the Bouffes-Parisiennes theatre, where he happily guyed fellow musicians and the conventions of the Second Empire. Donald Macleod runs through some of his vast output in Composer Of The Week (9.0am, Radio 3).

One of the best-established traditions in Britain throughout the 20th century was the destruction of key parts of its architectural heritage. At the peak we were losing eight historic houses a month and there are still hundreds under threat. In this week's Ghost Houses (3.45pm, Radio 4), Charlotte Smith visits the sites of some of these vanished treasures to hear from people who knew them, beginning at Clumber Park in Nottinghamshire, once regarded as a second Chatsworth.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Weekend TV

fields.headline: Casualties of war
fields.trailText: Rebel Heart | Titans
fields.body:
I have never really understood the phrase "the luck of the Irish" mainly because they have never seemed that lucky to me. The Tudor Conquest of Ireland, Dana, the plantation of Ulster, no potatoes, Dana, the influence of the Roman Catholic Church, the Troubles, Brad Pitt's Irish accent in The Devil's Own, the weekend invasion of Dublin by stag and hen parties, Dana. Luck doesn't seem to be a very Irish thing, the country's performance in the Eurovision Song Contest notwithstanding. (And even then, they've got Eurovision to thank for Dana).

This unluckiness may go some way to explain why the nice but naive Ernie Coyne, hero of Rebel Heart (Sunday, BBC1) constantly looked on the verge of tears. Despite his belief in a free Ireland, he had a feeling in his water that all would not go well with the Easter Rising. He was right.

Alongside Tom O'Toole (owner of a porn star name and a suitably blue movie moustache too), a spunky girl called Ita (who, in a Joanna-Lumley-on-a-desert-island moment, made leggings from a portrait of Queen Victoria) and a cheeky chap called Kelly (played by the excellent Frank Laverty), Ernie watched as his hopes were shattered and brothers in arms gunned down.

Beautifully filmed with an exceptional cast and fine dialogue, Rebel Heart presented the bloody messiness of armed conflict, all stuttering rifles, barked orders and barricaded windows. It showed the intransigence of those in command on both sides and the ambivalence of those fighting on the ground. It smoothly portrayed the misinformation and countermanding which scuppered the republicans and the non chalant attitude of the British Army to their own injured men. It also demonstrated that the first casualty of war is - inevitably - truth.

(The Germans had landed! The Turks were coming! Ernie told other fighters, as he himself had been told. Brave and resourceful Ita questioned if he had seen them himself, shaking his belief in the pedigree of his information. She later got shot for her troubles).

There has been much controversy surrounding Rebel Heart since the right-leaning press learnt of the (supposed) politics of its writer, Ronan Bennett. After seeing the first episode, it is clear that this controversy has been generated by people who hadn't even seen it since there is no political bias in the drama. What's more, it's evident that those who whipped themselves up into a frenzy know little about television drama.

The fundamental problem with Rebel Heart isn't its "Ireland for the Irish" sentiments - because it doesn't have any - it is that it starts in the wrong place and time. The story of the middle-class Coyne's progress from well-to-do apathy into passionate belief in an Irish republic would have been engrossing and irresistible. Characters could have been honed and polished with plot inexorably leading to a disastrous denouement. (Such an approach worked rather well in Titanic after all).

Instead, Rebel Heart began with what could have been the last episode of a serial you had missed the rest of. It had fight after fight in which people of whom we knew little - and cared less - died. Rather than mourn characters whom we had grown to like, respect or indeed hate - the socialist O'Toole was pretty magnetic as was the principled commander Ceannt - one merely rued the future absence of the actors who played them. Hardly a great incentive for tuning in next week.

(And for those who have an in-depth knowledge of Irish history, it might have been abundantly clear why Bill Paterson was doing a Connery and maintaining his Scottish accent whilst playing an Irishman, but for those of us without, it was not).

As the serial develops, it's evident that those who would go onto become major figures in Irish republicanism - Michael Collins, Cathal Brugha - will come to the fore but after such a disappointing start, their rise to notoriety may well go unnoticed.

In Titans (Sunday, Sky One), Aaron Spelling's steamy saga of duplicitous rich people, we got a gratuitous butt shot of Starship Troopers' Casper Van Dien, Yasmin "Baywatch" Bleeth in a bikini and Victoria Principal gazing meaningfully into her ex-husband's eyes. Shoulder pads and oil companies may be out but with a Reaganite about to move into the White House and a recession on the way, it's like the 1980s all over again. All we need now is a Dana comeback and Armageddon will be upon us. Joy.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Noah Wyle's work experience

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous.
fields.body:
Noah Wyle in Swing Kids (Thomas Carter, 1993)

Who? The guy from ER who isn't George Clooney, Wyle had a few minor film roles before landing the part of posh doctor John Truman Carter III in the hospital drama. He's merely dabbled in movies since, but when you've got a starring role on an incredibly popular and critically respected TV show then you'd probably be tempted to play it safe as well (after all, for every Clooney there's a dozen David Carusos).

So Wyle appeared in the indie drama The Myth of Fingerprints (1997) alongside Julianne Moore and Roy Scheider, before playing Apple computer guru Steve Jobs in 1999 TV movie The Pirates of Silicon Valley, and a translator in nuclear-peril potboiler Fail Safe (1999), directed live on American TV by Stephen Frears. His next role will be as a physics teacher in the baroque-sounding Donnie Darko, which is about a teenage boy who lives in a fantasy world after surviving a freak accident.

The role: Emil, ex-king of the Swing Kids - German teens who dug hep sounds by the likes of Duke Ellington - who then becomes a leading member of the Hitler Youth.

Best line: When another Swing Kid calls him a traitor, Emil claims "I am not a traitor, I just wised up. You will too."

Cringe factor: Moderate. At least he makes no attempt at a German accent.

Other wannabes: Christian Bale as Swing Kid Thomas, Sean Pertwee as "Gestapo Arresting Berger" and Martin Clunes as Bannfuehrer.

Critical judgement: Rita Kempley in The Washington Post observed that "Swing Kids is a bad idea whose time has not come: a nutty anti-Nazi a go-go for teenagers."

Also not starring in: 1990 TV movie Blind Faith, and 1991 melodrama Crooked Hearts.

 Swing Kids, 3am Monday 8 January, Carlton Cinema.

webTitle: Law: Marcel Berlins' Writ large

fields.headline: Last of the entertainers
fields.trailText: Marcel Berlins: George Carman was a consummate jury advocate, as everyone has pointed out. But his death also ends a long and honourable English tradition. He was pretty much the last of a breed that has now become extinct - the courtroom performer.
fields.body:
 George Carman was a consummate jury advocate, as everyone has pointed out. But his death also ends a long and honourable English tradition. He was pretty much the last of a breed that has now become extinct - the courtroom performer. A couple of years ago, I did a series of radio programmes on the great trial advocates. Edward Marshall Hall, from the early years of the last century, represented the old-fashioned theatrical advocate, full of dramatic gestures, cheap but potent rhetoric and the ability to shed real tears.

Carman was my inevitable choice to illustrate contemporary advocacy at its finest. Gone were the exaggerated mannerisms and flowery language of the past - today's juries would have found Marshall Hall's antics absurd. Carman's advocacy was of an altogether quieter style. He was not physically imposing; he didn't have a particularly sonorous voice, and didn't move around much.

Yet his performance could be mesmerising, and witnesses he cross-examined were often genuinely scared of him. He was, like Harold Pinter, a master of the pause, allowing a witness's dubious answer to remain in the air for a while, giving the jury a chance to savour it, before pouncing on it and exposing its shortcomings.

Sir Sydney Kentridge QC has the same quiet, understated but magnetic presence, but he has always addressed judges, not juries. On his day, only Gilbert Gray QC, now in his early 70s, could match Carman's performing skills before a jury. Today, there is a uniform greyness about jury advocacy.

Go into any courtroom and prepare to be bored. That's not to say that there aren't some excellent advocates around. But their advocacy is of a different nature to Carman's. Sure, all the salient points are properly conveyed to the jury and opposing witnesses are astutely and severely cross-examined. What's lacking is style, originality, flair, the ability to come up with a memorable phrase, charisma.

The death of George Carman must have received more coverage in the media, tabloids included, than that of any barrister before him. He was the only practising lawyer known to a wide general public. So who now is the most famous lawyer in the land? (I exclude those whose fame comes from other activities, such as Tony Blair or Clive Anderson.)

Michael Mansfield QC, I suggest. I would have said Helena Kennedy QC, but she is no longer mainly known for her barristerial work. Cherie Booth QC gets much noticed for her legal work, but mainly because of her spousal link.

 Rifling through the newspapers I missed while away, I came across a story proclaiming the imminent televising of the courts - appeals and other proceedings which involve only lawyers and judges, not trials with witnesses. I remain sceptical, not because there are any convincing objections to such filming but because I can't see it making commercial sense.

What people want to see are dramatic trials. Appeals and the like tend to be immensely tedious, based as they are primarily on legal arguments. Even superficially gripping cases, like the appeals in the Pinochet affair, boiled down to a bunch of barristers, day after day, monotonously reading dozens of other judgments and making obscure legal points in low voices. Who would watch?

 I am alarmed that solicitors may in future be allowed to advertise their services by cold calling. At present, they can advertise all they want on paper, but not make direct approaches in person or by telephone. But the Law Society's council are considering lifting that ban.

You have been warned. Ring, ring. "Is that Mrs Sucker? I'm delighted to tell you, Mrs Sucker, that we are currently operating in your area, and that you have been chosen as the recipient of a special offer, open for a limited time only. In order to introduce our services to you, Mrs Sucker, we will be offering two court cases for the price of one.

And, Mrs Sucker, as a free introductory gift, we will take eviction proceedings against a tenant of your choice, or, if you prefer, draw up the prenuptial contract for any marriage you may be contemplating."

Edward Marshall Hall, from the early years of the last century, represented the old-fashioned theatrical advocate, full of dramatic gestures, cheap but potent rhetoric and the ability to shed real tears. Carman was my inevitable choice to illustrate contemporary advocacy at its finest. Gone were the exaggerated mannerisms and flowery language of the past - today's juries would have found Marshall Hall's antics absurd. Carman's advocacy was of an altogether quieter style. fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • A letter writer, page 19, January 3, referred to what he called Ernest Bevin's famous remark about the Tories comparing them to vermin. The remark properly belonged to Aneurin Bevan. He made it in a speech at Belle Vue, Manchester, on July 4 1948. He recalled the effects of means tests, then went on: "That is why no amount of cajolery can eradicate from my heart a deep burning hatred for the Tory party that inflicted those experiences on me. So far as I am concerned, they are lower than vermin..."

webTitle: Letters: Admit you have failed, Mr Hain

fields.headline: Admit you have failed, Mr Hain
fields.trailText: The issue of Iraq in 2001 is too critical for the future of its people, Europe's relations with the Middle East and the standing of international law for us to remain silent about Peter Hain's article (I fought apartheid, I'll fight Saddam, January 6).
fields.body:
 The issue of Iraq in 2001 is too critical for the future of its people, Europe's relations with the Middle East and the standing of international law for us to remain silent about Peter Hain's article (I fought apartheid, I'll fight Saddam, January 6).

We write from privileged experience since we were charged by the UN secretary general to oversee the oil-for-food programme soon after its inception, from 1997 until last year. We both resigned in protest against what we perceive as a failed Iraq policy, with all its tragic human consequences, and the violation of international law.

Arguing for an end to economic sanctions is not at all about "propping up a dictator". Have sanctions targeted the proper parties? No. Have sanctions imposed in 1990 retained their legality? The UN Charter, the International Covenants on Human Rights and a host of other treaties allow only one answer: they have not.

Peter Hain is indeed "ducking the debate". We all know, professionally and personally, how difficult it is to admit failure. What a powerful and honourable signal Hain would send, if such awareness of failure would translate into courage for change.

Hain has been hiding behind a smoke-screen for a long time with his defence of an indefensible policy conducted with little respect for facts. "Iraq was a threat to humanity and this threat is real now," he maintains. This is a house of cards held aloft by those who want to maintain the status quo. Disinformation is morally and legally also indefensible. Hain's reference to UN resolution 688 as the legitimisation for the "no-fly-zones" in Iraq is an example. This resolution makes no reference to a right to take over Iraqi airspace, resulting in the tragic killing of civilians as detailed in the 1999 UN security reports.

Hain repeatedly stresses that those who oppose sanctions offer no alternative. This is false. Both of us, for example, have said time and again that the UN security council should delink economic sanctions from the disarmament debate while imposing arms controls on Iraq and those countries which wish to sell arms to Baghdad, keeping in mind resolution 687, paragraph 14, which calls for the establishment in the Middle East of a zone free of weapons of mass destruction; we have argued that the hidden agenda of hardline geo-strategic interests be dropped and a dialogue be started; we have also argued that the unrealistic demand for quantitative disarmament be replaced by negotiations on weapon systems containment.

We, too, fight against "appeasement of oppression". Ours, however, is a fight against the violation of international law by the UN security council and the sacrifice of innocent civilians as pawns.
Denis Halliday
UN Humanitarian Coordinator for Iraq 1997-98 HC von Sponeck
UN Humanitarian Coordinator for Iraq 1998-2000

 "You simply have to notify the UN" to export food and medicines, writes Peter Hain. The tortuous bureaucracy of the UN is beyond the scope of a letter. Exporting anything takes many months, on the UN's own admission.

If a patient needs medicine it is needed immediately. I was threatened with prosecution by the Department of Trade and Industry for taking a small package of chemotherapy to Iraq for a surgeon with cancer - who had worked here for many years saving the lives of British children.

A London-based Iraqi sent insulin in a Jiffy bag to his diabetic brother in Baghdad. It was returned by the Post Office with a request for an export licence. Before the licence was granted, his brother had died.
Felicity Arbuthnot
London

 Peter Hain's concern for the Kurds in Iraq would be touching if he extended it also to the Turkish Kurds. His support of UN resolutions imposed on Iraq would be more credible if he adopted the same attitude to those against Israel. His opposition to Iraqi weapons would be more justified if he condemned Israel's nuclear capability. Condemning Saddam Hussein is one thing but getting at him through the innocent children of Iraq is another.
June and Tony Freke
Newbury

 Peter Hain claims that the bombing of northern Iraq by British and US aircraft was "in support of security council resolution 688, which called on Iraq to end its repression of Kurds and the Shia".

Nowhere in the resolution is there even a hint about using force against Iraq. But it makes the point that "all member states" are committed to "the sovereignty, territorial integrity and political independence of Iraq and of all states in the area". So this is UN permission to bomb Iraq, is it?
Brian Cloughley
Thornhill, Dumfriesshire

 Peter Hain has some nerve comparing the sanctions on Iraq to the sanctions imposed on apartheid South Africa. Whereas in South Africa it was the oppressed people who themselves called for sanctions to be imposed, there has been no such call from the Iraqi people. Whereas sanctions actually hurt white South Africa, they stand no chance of ousting Saddam. Indeed, sanctions have brought appalling hardship upon the people of Iraq and have served only to strengthen Saddam's grip on power.
Timothy Walker
London
