webTitle: Letters: Hats off for the naked

fields.headline: Hats off for the naked
fields.trailText: I was appalled to read (Letters, January 5) of the incarceration of Russell Higgs and Vincent Bethell for being unclothed.
fields.body:
 I was appalled to read (Letters, January 5) of the incarceration of Russell Higgs and Vincent Bethell for being unclothed. As a sculptor of the nude figure, I am struck by society's hypocrisy when dealing with the body. We profess to be liberal-minded and are exposed to blatant sexual imagery in advertising, and yet the sight of the unclothed body (especially male) sends us into moral outrage. If we are not careful, the unclothed body will be the preserve solely of the pornographer.
Ian Rank-Broadley
Stroud, Gloucs

 The solution to Simon's hat problem (Simon Hoggart's Diary, January 6) is for him to wear the next hat he finds. I wear hats that have been abandoned in my bookshop: the most interesting thing is how much better received I am wearing a white hat with a maple leaf on it than a hat of my choice.
Margaret Squires
St Andrews, Fife
quartobooks@tesco.net

 I have followed the correspondence regarding the complex way the folk of Bristol converse with each other (Letters, January 6, and passim). I now understand why I fail to make much sense of Julie Burchill most Saturdays.
Steve Little
Lytham St Annes, Lancs

 I am surprised that no one has yet quoted: "deese gott'n whur dee casn't back'n, asn't?" - loosely translated as: you've got (your car) in a position from which you cannot reverse it.
Andy Bebington
Croydon

 Hearing that Prince Charles had "broken a small bone in his shoulder" falling from his horse during a fox hunt, I could not avoid uttering a quiet "Good!" Did I hear several million echoes?
Doug Bates
Exeter

PS: I trust long-term damage was done to neither the prince nor the fox.

webTitle: Letters: Payroll vote

fields.headline: Payroll vote
fields.trailText: Your report (Clergy want employee rights, January 2) is misleading and inaccurate in its brevity. There are very few clerical members of the MSF union.
fields.body:
 Your report (Clergy want employee rights, January 2) is misleading and inaccurate in its brevity. There are very few clerical members of the MSF union. Late last year some of them drew media attention to the relatively low level of national stipend.

Most us are content to be on God's payroll and find that He meets our needs as promised. As for "unfair dismissal by bishops", again most of us find our fathers in God as encouraging, trusting and supportive as they can be.
Rev Roger Derbridge
Woking, Surrey

webTitle: Letters: Harold Shipman

fields.headline: Seeking mistakes and motives in the Shipman case
fields.trailText: Your leader on Harold Shipman (January 6) begins to explore the supervision that already exists when doctors certify the deaths of their patients.
fields.body:
 Your leader on Harold Shipman (January 6) begins to explore the supervision that already exists when doctors certify the deaths of their patients. All deaths are registered with the registrar of births and deaths and those that proceed to cremation require the signature of two further doctors.

One of these may be a GP from another practice; but the third person is a medical referee appointed by the local authority and health authority. This role is usually carried out by the local consultant in public health who knows the local doctors and the circumstances in which they work and who provides continuity between hospital and the community. Both registrar and medical referee are in ideal positions to monitor the pattern of deaths and to identify unusual circumstances. Why was this supervision deficient in the case of Harold Shipman?
Dr Peter Stott
Tadworth, Surrey

 Sex and money never explain serial killing (Does mother's early death offer pointer to GP's state of mind?, January 6). The six serial killers and the 60 murderers I treated in Parkhurst prison tell a radically different story. All killers are driven by one thing only - buried rage.

The Home Office and the psychiatric establishment fervently disagree. They believe criminals are born evil. The abundant evidence that persuading violent prisoners to confront their earlier traumas leads to their becoming non-violent - the story of my five years at Parkhurst - is buried.
Dr Bob Johnson
Consultant psychiatrist
York
DrBob@jnf.org.uk

 Surely one question raised by the case of Dr Harold Shipman is whether the doctor who attends a patient who dies should sign the death certificate. Suppose instead the attending doctor had to call another doctor - randomly chosen by the authorities - to explain the circumstances of the death, and the second doctor could ask questions about what had happened. If such a system had been in place for Shipman, sooner or later some doctor would have started asking awkward questions.
Frank Desmond
London

 The seven recommendations of Professor Richard Baker's inquiry into the Shipman case do not include the obvious need to end the system of self-regulation enjoyed by the General Medical Council.

This body, which regulates such long-serving members as Dr Shipman, proudly claims to be "protecting patients, guiding doctors", whereas, in reality, it is a law unto itself. As it decides the innocence or guilt of its own members, it acts as judge in its own case, in contravention of the European Convention on Human Rights.

Will the Shipman case bring about the end of this abusive system, as the Lawrence case did for the police?
Timothy Haley
Rodemack, France

webTitle: G2: The 'affluenza' trauma

fields.headline: The price of happiness
fields.standfirst: Jessie O'Neill charges millionaires $1,000 a day to help them with the trauma of having lots of money. She spoke to  Peter Lennon  about her theory of 'affluenza'
fields.trailText: Jessie O'Neill charges millionaires $1,000 a day to help them with the trauma of having lots of money. She spoke to Peter Lennon about her theory of 'affluenza'.
fields.body:
Like Scott Fitzgerald's Daisy, all-American Jessie O'Neill's voice is "full of money". She is the daughter of a Cadillac salesman and grand daughter of Charles "Engine Charlie" Wilson, Eisenhower's defence secretary and onetime head of General Motors. Her public voice nowadays speaks of nothing but money and the affliction it brings to millionaires: affluenza, she calls it.

Jessie O'Neill founded Affluenza two years ago. Its aim is to deal with the distress excessive dollars can bring to the wealthy. Speaking from snowy Milwaukee she is impressively articulate in defence of her cause and entirely unselfconscious about its inherent absurdities. She was 28 when her mother died, leaving her $3m. "I mishandled it," she says. "Already going through a first divorce after a brief youthful marriage, I turned to drugs and drink. But I discovered my experience was more the norm than not."

She married again, had two daughters and ran a charter business on Lake Michigan with a 53ft yacht her mother had left her. "My husband, who died in 1996 was an alcoholic," she says. "My parents were alcoholic. I think people in some gruesome way marry their parents".

Ten years ago she went back to college and took a master's degree in psychology and counselling. Her thesis was The Psychology of Affluence, which was turned into a book, Golden Ghetto, The Psychology of Influence, in 1996. Her father then died, leaving her another $2m. Affluenza beckoned again.

But the book, which at first had a limited appeal, attracted letters from millionaires, saying "no one has ever talked about this before". So she founded her charity, which gives two- to five-day courses for fees of around $1,000 per day.

O'Neill defines affluenza as "dysfunctional or unhealthy relations with money or wealth or the pursuit of it". She has worked out a curriculum which she hopes to get into schools. It is called: The Grace of Money and the children learn Emotional Literacy Around Financial Matters.

The severest symptoms of affluenza, she says, come with sudden youthful inheritance. She lists the symptoms: the inability to delay gratification or tolerate frustration; loss of future motivation: "Who wants to get up and go to work every day if you don't need money?"

She says she is fighting "the myth of the American dream that money brings happiness ... You don't have to have a lot of money to have an unhealthy relationship with money. The mother who blows her pay cheque on make-up and clothes and then does not feed her children has an unhealthy relationship with money."

O'Neill's activities take a deep turn into paradox: she offers scholarships to those who cannot afford her fees. But if they cannot afford the fees, how can they be suffering from affluenza? Again, the answer is that any kind of unbalanced relationship with wealth will qualify.

But O'Neill reveals is also inspired by another apprehension among rich Americans: the fear of violence. Not necessarily perpetrated by the poor, but by their own discontented children. "The violence we are seeing is really making people sit up and take notice," she says, fearing that America might be in danger of "in some horrible way breeding generations of psychopaths.

From psychopathic inbred violence, O'Neill is aware of a baleful outside world with no sympathy for the distress wealth brings. She is well used to the proposition: "If it distresses you so much, just give me your money." But she is also aware of a more entrenched hostility to the rich, which she blames on the new "wealthism".

I point out that in the process of getting wealthy there must be victims, so why should the unsuccessful be sympathetic? O'Neill says this is unfortunately the way it works: "Of course we can't expect people who hate us to want to help us," she says. "There is so much fear now between the classes."

The one surprising missing element is religion, usually vital to the American crusader. "I don't follow a particular religious path," she says, "but I believe we are all on this earth for a reason." So this is not the philosophy of a sect.

But what is wrong with the perfectly acceptable mechanism for creating a just society: massive taxation of the rich? "I don't like to get too political," says O'Neill. "But I certainly think the wealthy should be taxed in proportion to the amount of money they have. Taxes are non-directed philanthropy, and we favour philanthrophy. But certainly, we don't pay our teachers enough and we don't pay our day care workers.

fields.bodyText: Like Scott Fitzgerald's Daisy, all-American Jessie O'Neill's voice is "full of money". She is the daughter of a Cadillac salesman and grand daughter of Charles "Engine Charlie" Wilson, Eisenhower's defence secretary and onetime head of General Motors. Its aim is to deal with the distress excessive dollars can bring to the wealthy. Speaking from snowy Milwaukee she is impressively articulate in defence of her cause and entirely unselfconscious about its inherent absurdities. She was 28 when her mother died, leaving her $3m. "I mishandled it," she says. "Already going through a first divorce after a brief youthful marriage, I turned to drugs and drink. But I discovered my experience was more the norm than not." She married again, had two daughters and ran a charter business on Lake Michigan with a 53ft yacht her mother had left her. "My husband, who died in 1996 was an alcoholic," she says. webTitle: Arts: Profile of rapper Eminem

fields.headline: 'You think I give a damn about a Grammy? Half you critics can't even stomach me...'
fields.standfirst: Eminem loathes the music industry. So how can he be up for four awards?  Dorian Lynskey  reports
fields.trailText: Eminem loathes the music industry. So how can he be up for four awards? Dorian Lynskey reports.
fields.body:
When Eminem leaves the Staples Center in Los Angeles on February 21, after the Recording Academy's 43rd annual Grammy awards, he will have made his mark even if he goes home empty-handed. The world's biggest rapper - real name Marshall Bruce Mathers III - has already earned himself a place in Grammy history as the most controversial nominee to date, garnering four nominations (including best album) for a CD that features the lines: "You think I give a damn about a Grammy? Half you critics can't even stomach me, let alone stand me."

The hand that Eminem has bitten is now attempting to feed him.

Within hours of their announcement last Wednesday, the nominations were providing further material for his intensely self-referential lyrics. The Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation mooted the idea of organising a protest at the ceremony. "What this says is a little scary," said its spokesman, Scott Seomin. "It's about murdering, stabbing, slitting throats and putting women in the trunks of cars. It's about violence."

In fact, The Marshall Mathers LP, Eminem's 9m-selling second album, is about a whole lot more than that. Notably, on tracks including The Real Slim Shady, The Way I Am and Criminal, it's about the media and the music industry, taking potshots at critics such as Timothy White, editor of the trade magazine Billboard. What better way for the stuffy Grammies to take a walk on the wild side than rewarding somebody who regards them with such contempt?

Britain's own Brit awards may be conservative, but the Grammies make them look revolutionary. Even Nirvana, an alternative rock act that conquered the mainstream, went unrecognised by the academy until 1996, after Kurt Cobain, their frontman, had committed suicide. Last year, eight awards went to Carlos Santana, the veteran guitarist.

But now it seems that the academy is going all-out for credibility. With a never-ending list of niche categories (best traditional tropical Latin album, anybody?), most big-selling acts get a chance of bagging a gong, but the Grammies' true colours are displayed in the shortlist for best album. This year, refreshingly, such middle-aged establishment favourites as Steely Dan and Paul Simon have to duke it out with Beck's Midnite Vultures and Radiohead's Kid A, as well as Eminem.

Of course, it's perilously difficult to retain your edge once you have begun schmoozing the suits. Just ask Everlast, the white rapper-turned-bluesman who is one of Eminem's foes. After Grammy recognition for his rough-edged, low-key debut album, he turned in a slick, self-consciously adult follow-up with a guest spot from ... yes, Carlos Santana.

It's unlikely that Eminem can be tamed so easily. In fact, he has more in common with Radiohead, his fellow nominees. Both have followed breakthrough albums with uncommercially extreme discs that somehow sold even more. Most importantly, both have proved remarkably resistant to flattery, greeting fame and adoration with undisguised disdain. But even Radio head's Thom Yorke wouldn't go quite as far as the line in The Way I Am where Eminem spits: "I'm so sick and tired of being admired that I wish that I would just die or get fired."

In a sense, Eminem has already proved he can hang on to his credibility. On Kill You, the first track on The Marshall Mathers LP, he sneers: "They say I can't rap about being broke no more/They didn't say I can't rap about coke no more." Critics claimed that the instant success of his debut album, The Slim Shady LP, would distance him from his subject matter - the desperate nihilism of America's poverty-stricken white underclass. Then it turned out that the complications of fame had only made his mood worse and inspired an even more misanthropic sequel.

If you're hunting for precedents, skip his hip-hop peers and consider Kurt Cobain, another white blue-collar superstar prone to depression. Nirvana followed their critically acclaimed, 10m-selling Nevermind album with the abrasive In Utero, whose sarcastic working titles included Verse Chorus Verse and Radio Friendly Unit Shifter. The catch, of course, is that within a year of its release an anguished Cobain had put a shotgun in his mouth.

Similarly, the feting of Eminem has a twist in the tail. His turbulent personal life is inextricably tangled with his music, lending a sharper edge to such album highlights as the haunting stalker tale Stan and the grotesquely compelling Kim, in which he acts out a murderous showdown with his (now estranged) wife. For the listener, it's win-win: you get to admire one of the greatest lyricists that pop has recently produced and also feel the voyeuristic thrill of an accident waiting to happen. Eminem's fans will demand yet more extremity on his third album, but at what cost to the man himself?

The Grammy president, Michael Greene, has said: "This is probably the most repugnant record of the year, but in a lot of ways it's also one of the more remarkable records of the year." He is being disingenuous - the repugnance is essential to the appeal. Greene is like a trendy dad peering around his offspring's bedroom door.

At least Eminem is smart enough to realise that the Grammies are rewarding the phenomenon rather than the music and, more unpleasant still, the fact that the unhappier he is, the more people like him. In fact, he is probably already writing a song about it.

webTitle: Women: The age of dissent

fields.headline: NY blues
fields.trailText: Michele Hanson: What is the point of resolutions? They only show that no one can stick at anything. I tried one last year, as soon as my lovely new kitchen had been installed. I vowed to keep the new worktops clean.
fields.body:
What is the point of resolutions? They only show that no one can stick at anything. I tried one last year, as soon as my lovely new kitchen had been installed. I vowed to keep the new worktops clean. Why pay an arm and a leg for fabulous blue worktops with sparkly bits in, if you can never see them? For a whole week, the worktops were clear. Now they are hardly visible. Sometimes a chink of sparkly blue shines through. I am disappointed but at least I can still breathe normally.

Yesterday I rang my friend Mavis. She answered gasping for breath. What was the matter? Had she just galloped up the stairs? No, it was the smoking. She had resolved to give up. Every morning she resolves to give up. She fails every time. On Christmas Day, she scuttled to the newsagent's. "Thank God you're open," wheezed Mavis, and bought more stinking cigarettes.

Has she tried acupuncture? Yes, the thing fell into her ear. Patches? Yes, her leg swelled up. Hypnotism? Yes, but that didn't work, either, because Mavis was convinced she might say something rude, or reveal some awful fantasy or other, then the hypnotist would be able to blackmail her for life. Has she tried drugs? Yes. American tranquillisers from the doctor which make you give up smoking. They didn't. Every product on the market? Yes. Nothing worked.

So Mavis lies in bed listening to her chest. It sounds like the boiler at first, but then she realises it's her lungs. "There's only one way to give up smoking," says Mavis glumly. "Die."

Can it be that difficult? I asked Rosemary. She is always resolving to give up smoking, but something awful always comes along to make her desperate for a puff. She breaks her leg, her Auntie's ill, she can't find a new home, the builders drive her mad, there's tension and drama at work. But she keeps trying.

She, too, has tried every known cure, even group therapy. "My name is Rosemary," she said, "and I am powerless to control my addiction." Then everyone threw their cigarettes and lighters on to a great funeral pyre and plinky-plonky music was played. Rosemary stopped smoking for three whole days.

But at least her worktops are immaculate. So are Mavis's. They may have grubby lungs, but they do have clean kitchens. So our resolution is ... no resolutions.

webTitle: Women: Do teenagers crave perfect breasts?

fields.headline: The silicone generation
fields.standfirst: Last week, the papers were full of the tale of Jenna Franklin, the 15-year-old girl who sees breast implants as the secret of success (and whose parents offered to pay for them). But is she alone in believing the world revolves around perfect breasts, or is her story that of countless other young women?  Anita Chaudhuri  and  Crystal Mahey  find out what teenagers really think
fields.trailText: Last week, the papers were full of the tale of Jenna Franklin, the 15-year-old girl who sees breast implants as the secret of success (and whose parents offered to pay for them). But is she alone in believing the world revolves around perfect breasts, or is her story that of countless other young women? Anita Chaudhuri and Crystal Mahey find out what teenagers really think.
fields.body:
Perhaps more than any other demographic, teenage girls are true, if not downright ardent, believers in the concept of the quick-fix solution. This is the premise on which generations of us have shelled out small fortunes on spot creams and curling tongs, and why books on spells are enjoying cult status among schoolgirls. Now, though, there is a new miracle cure, one that carries a higher price tag than the old get-a-boyfriend-by-Friday gimmicks: breast implants.

The current furore surrounding 15-year-old Jenna Franklin and the refusal of a surgeon to give her breast implants before she reaches the age of 18 is just one case among many. According to the Channel 4 documentary Perfect Breasts, to be shown tomorrow night, Franklin is part of "the silicone generation", a growing army of teenagers who believe their lives will be transformed through the acquisition of perfect breasts.

Franklin's motivation for wanting to undergo surgery as soon as possible is nothing if not hopeful. "I want to be famous. And I don't think you can be famous without boobs. When I'm going out and I've got to get dressed up, the world's over for me." Her parents, not uncoincidentally both employed in the cosmetic surgery industry, were happy to shell out the £3,250 required for the operation, but it looks as if their daughter still has a long wait ahead of her.

"I had thought about having my breasts enlarged when I was 12," she says, " but when I was about to turn 15, I saw so many people having it done that I wanted mine bigger as well. Every other person you see on television has had implants. If I want to be successful, I need to have them, too."

This perceived link between perfect breasts and success appears to be all-pervasive. Kay, a 19-year-old singer who recently had surgery and also appears in the documentary, believes it to be true. "Because of the career I want, I need to look my best. Sex sells. Most girls in the music industry at the moment have had it done. Even if your music's not good, if you look great then the men are going to buy your stuff anyway."

Thankfully not everyone accepts this viewpoint. "You have to have talent to be successful, not breasts," argues Tanya, 16. "It might be true that certain people got signed to record labels, or are TV presenters, because of their breasts instead of their raw talent, but then where's the success in that? If people are going to have breast implants just so they can get on in certain industries, they might as well just sleep their way to the top."

Sociologists may scratch their heads and come up with theories of cleavage oppression propagated by pubescent icons such as Britney Spears, assorted Spices and All Saints, Lara Croft and the monstrous creature from the Triumph bra commercial. But media images are not solely responsible for the current outbreak of cleavage envy, as the findings of two recent surveys show.

One, conducted by BUPA, noted that one in five British children have such a poor image of themselves that they would consider cosmetic surgery. Another, from teen website Wowgo, found that two-thirds of girls aged between 12 and 14 wanted cosmetic surgery to make them feel happier and stop them being bullied. Most wanted breast implants added or fat removed. Last year, 2,000 girls under 18 had breast implant surgery.

Psychologist Petra Boynton has carried out extensive research into young women and body image, and has studied different responses to images of "perfect" breasts. "What was most disturbing was how women recoiled from images of 'normal' breasts, such as those of different sizes, and responded positively to the perfect, airbrushed ones from glamour magazines, referring to those as 'normal'.

You can blame the celebrities publicly sporting implants, but that is to take a certain level of power away from teenage girls themselves. They do invent their own idea of what looks good. The current trend is to be slim and large-breasted; a few years back it was the waif look. The difficulty is providing girls with a forum where they can talk about their fears and insecurities, and give them positive feedback about themselves."

Boynton is opposed to girls under the age of 18 undergoing the surgery. "The biggest psychological risk is that these girls believe their life will alter beyond belief after surgery. But if they are already experiencing such an extreme level of body dissatisfaction, then it's unlikely they will overnight get the self-esteem to go out and face the world. You really need to look at the underlying causes of low self-esteem." She warns that if these aren't sorted out, the most likely scenario is for a woman to try to solve her problems with more surgery, to other areas.

Getting this message through to young women is not going to be easy. "Breast implants are like having sex; no one can say that a girl isn't ready at 16 because all girls are different," says Lucy, 17. "It's hard for teenage girls, boys can be really spiteful sometimes. If you have a small chest and boys are always laughing at you because of it, calling you names, you start to believe you're worthless. Implants are a good idea because they help girls gain confidence and that's important."

Some feminist academics would agree with her. Ever since we entered what Naomi Wolf called "the surgical age", women of all ages have been seeking to boost their confidence in the operating theatre. Kathy Davis, author of Reshaping the Female Body: the Dilemma of Plastic Surgery (Routledge), has spent years interviewing women who have undergone surgery. She argues against the notion that these women are "cultural dupes", vainly attempting to fulfil the fantasies of lovers, husbands or surgeons. For the most part, she asserts, women want cosmetic surgery not to attain an impossible standard of beauty, but to be perceived as normal.

Charmaine, 21, spent her teenage years yearning for implants. "When I was 17, I really wanted to be a model. My friends told me I had the looks but I was scared to pursue it because I had such a small chest. All my friends were big-breasted and when we walked about college, it was as though boys were interested in them but not me. They told me I was being paranoid but I knew I wasn't because of the name-calling. I just wanted to have big breasts and be normal. I was really unhappy and thought about implants. I'm glad I didn't have them."

So what of the teenage boys in this equation, what do they think? "Yeah, of course it's important for girls to have big breasts," says Michael, 16, seemingly without shame. "When you go to a club, or you're walking down the street, and you see a girl with a nice body - you know, big breasts, hips, all the curves in the right places but not fat - you've got to try to get her number, because that's the type of girl you want to be seen with. But if you've got a girl with no breasts, people are going to think it's because you're not man enough to get a real girl, then you will get cussed hard."

With comments like this, is it any wonder teenage girls find themselves turning to surgery? Boynton doesn't agree. "The whole point of being teenage is that you're supposed to be full of angst. It's all about finding yourself and your own identity, discovering your body and how you look as a woman. Most of the women I know, when they look at old photos of themselves, are very surprised. Most say: 'Hey, I wasn't that bad after all!' "

Another, from teen website Wowgo, found that two-thirds of girls aged between 12 and 14 wanted cosmetic surgery to make them feel happier and stop them being bullied. Most wanted breast implants added or fat removed. Last year, 2,000 girls under 18 had breast implant surgery. Psychologist Petra Boynton has carried out extensive research into young women and body image, and has studied different responses to images of "perfect" breasts. "What was most disturbing was how women recoiled from images of 'normal' breasts, such as those of different sizes, and responded positively to the perfect, airbrushed ones from glamour magazines, referring to those as 'normal'. You can blame the celebrities publicly sporting implants, but that is to take a certain level of power away from teenage girls themselves. They do invent their own idea of what looks good. The current trend is to be slim and large-breasted; a few years back it was the waif look. The difficulty is providing girls with a forum where they can talk about their fears and insecurities, and give them positive feedback about themselves." Boynton is opposed to girls under the age of 18 undergoing the surgery. "The biggest psychological risk is that these girls believe their life will alter beyond belief after surgery. But if they are already experiencing such an extreme level of body dissatisfaction, then it's unlikely they will overnight get the self-esteem to go out and face the world. You really need to look at the underlying causes of low self-esteem." She warns that if these aren't sorted out, the most likely scenario is for a woman to try to solve her problems with more surgery, to other areas. Getting this message through to young women is not going to be easy. "Breast implants are like having sex; no one can say that a girl isn't ready at 16 because all girls are different," says Lucy, 17. "It's hard for teenage girls, boys can be really spiteful sometimes. If you have a small chest and boys are always laughing at you because of it, calling you names, you start to believe you're worthless. Implants are a good idea because they help girls gain confidence and that's important." Some feminist academics would agree with her. Ever since we entered what Naomi Wolf called "the surgical age", women of all ages have been seeking to boost their confidence in the operating theatre. Kathy Davis, author of Reshaping the Female Body: the Dilemma of Plastic Surgery (Routledge), has spent years interviewing women who have undergone surgery. She argues against the notion that these women are "cultural dupes", vainly attempting to fulfil the fantasies of lovers, husbands or surgeons. For the most part, she asserts, women want cosmetic surgery not to attain an impossible standard of beauty, but to be perceived as normal. Charmaine, 21, spent her teenage years yearning for implants. "When I was 17, I really wanted to be a model. My friends told me I had the looks but I was scared to pursue it because I had such a small chest. All my friends were big-breasted and when we walked about college, it was as though boys were interested in them but not me. They told me I was being paranoid but I knew I wasn't because of the name-calling. I just wanted to have big breasts and be normal. I was really unhappy and thought about implants. I'm glad I didn't have them." So what of the teenage boys in this equation, what do they think? "Yeah, of course it's important for girls to have big breasts," says Michael, 16, seemingly without shame. "When you go to a club, or you're walking down the street, and you see a girl with a nice body - you know, big breasts, hips, all the curves in the right places but not fat - you've got to try to get her number, because that's the type of girl you want to be seen with. But if you've got a girl with no breasts, people are going to think it's because you're not man enough to get a real girl, then you will get cussed hard." With comments like this, is it any wonder teenage girls find themselves turning to surgery? Boynton doesn't agree. "The whole point of being teenage is that you're supposed to be full of angst. It's all about finding yourself and your own identity, discovering your body and how you look as a woman. Most of the women I know, when they look at old photos of themselves, are very surprised. Most say: 'Hey, I wasn't that bad after all!' "

webTitle: G2: From Andersen Consulting to Accenture

fields.headline: If the name fits ....
fields.standfirst: It was highly profitable and one of the world's best-known companies. So why has Andersen Consulting spent $100m giving itself a new name that means nothing and has met with widespread derision? And what will happen to the old company baseball caps?  Oliver Burkeman  investigates
fields.trailText: It was highly profitable and one of the world's best-known companies. So why has Andersen Consulting spent $100m giving itself a new name that means nothing and has met with widespread derision? And what will happen to the old company baseball caps? Oliver Burkeman investigates.
fields.body:
The baseball caps were always going to be a problem. In the supercharged, work-hard-play-hard atmosphere of the modern management consultancy, a company baseball cap - not to mention a company fleece and a company sports bag - is almost as crucial for the job as a sharply tailored suit or a faint air of superiority.

So when the venerable giant Andersen Consulting announced that it would, from this month, prefer to be known as Accenture - with the accent on the acc, please, and an unpronounceable squiggle over the t - there will have been celebration among certain manufacturers of merchandise, at least.

Apart from the own-label clothing, there were the signs outside 178 offices across the world to think about, millions of sheets of headed notepaper, coffee mugs, and a costly advertising campaign which has swamped the broadsheet press and numerous big-city billboards in recent weeks.

"Just to give everyone a minimum number of business cards to be going on with, we had to print six and a half million," says Ian Watmore, Accenture's UK managing partner, sounding a little overawed. And with good reason: the estimated total cost of this apparently cosmetic bit of image-meddling currently stands at $100m (£60m).

Accenture executives, well-trained in the art of turning jargon of dubious provenance into convincing-sounding sentences, were on hand to explain the name change. "As Accenture, we are putting a greater accent on the future as we reposition our organisation to become a market maker, builder and architect of the new economy," says Joe W Forehand, Accenture's chief executive officer. The truth is a little more mundane: an arbitrator's judgment last summer forced a name change to distinguish the company from its former sister, the accountants Arthur Andersen, and so Andersen Consulting was pushed, instead of jumping, aboard what has become the big-business bandwagon of the moment: the corporate rebranding.

Like fugitives vanishing without trace, or streets where grisly murders have occurred, the unwieldy behemoths of the old economy are falling over each other to reinvent their identities, to sound fresh and lean and approachable and unconnected to their histories.

Last year's clutch of more or less preposterous examples saw part of National Power rise from the ashes as Innogy, and part of the old British Gas coyly announce that forthwith it would prefer to be known as Lattice. The aerospace and defence electronics group Thomson-CSF, incorporating Racal, opted for Thales, the name of a Greek philosopher who - alarmingly, perhaps, for the company's customers - believed that everything was made of water.

Friendly dairy firm Unigate, having sold off its milk-producing arm, announced that it was going to call itself Uniq - pronounced, but confusingly not spelt, unique. ("Uni for Unigate, q for quality," explains chief executive Ross Buckland. "Ninety per cent of people pronounce it correctly.") When Andersen Consulting needed to do something similar, it did what any sensible firm would do in the paranoia-fuelled climate of 21st-century business: it called in the consultants.

An unassuming blue-and-white building on Clerkenwell Green in London has been the nerve centre of much of this energetic corporate reinvention. This is the UK headquarters of Landor Associates, the world's largest naming consultancy; Nike, Coke and Pepsi have all passed through the doors of one of its offices in recent years in search of a makeover, as has BP for its current "Beyond Petroleum" sunflower rebranding, and it was to Landor that Andersen Consulting went, too.

A name change had been forced upon the company, but there were other good reasons for a change of identity. Profits - this being management consultancy - were in rude health, but Andersen had been associated with a string of controversial consultancy contracts, at the London Stock Exchange, the Department for Social Security, where it had been forced to pay back £23m for bungling its overhauling of the National Insurance computer system, and Wessex regional health authority. And then there was the general perception of an overly hierarchical, lumbering dinosaur. "We all called them Anderson androids," says one former consultant with a rival firm. "There was a sense that they were all clones."

The process that followed - entitled, suitably self-consciously, BrandStorming, drew on Landor's expertise but also on the hunches of Andersen's own employees. "You're trying to create something that is OK, that doesn't cause people to snort with derision, and yet at some future point will still feel OK," says Ian Watmore. "Andersen Consulting had sounded sharp and modern, but frankly over the years it had become a handicap."

Ultimately, despite the millions spent on high-powered consultants, it was a name thought up by Oslo Andersen partner Kim Petersen that was chosen. It cost nothing save Petersen's reward, a trip to the Andersen Consulting Match Play Golf Championship in Melbourne. (This is another key doctrine for those employing management consultants: always ignore their findings.) The other 2,676 names suggested from Andersen's 65,000 staff are officially confidential, but a few have leaked. They included the Future Creation Group, Global Junction, Deep Thought, Mind Rocket and, a little disconcertingly, Global Curves.

Already, the result is being mocked within the industry, and the company being referred to as "Ace Ventura" after Jim Carrey's bungling movie pet detective. "Personally, I think it's dreadful," says one senior management consultant at another firm, characteristically insisting upon anonymity. "It's too long, and frankly it sounds pretentious."

In short, critics imply, the name is a superficially authoritative sounding word masking dark caverns of mindboggling meaninglessness (ironically, some might say, making it the perfect expression of the management consultant's craft). The bizarre greater-than symbol is a Silicon Valley-inspired flourish, redolent of internet companies such as online share dealers *Trade and the advertising company E>Tize.

After the flash of inspiration comes the grunt-work: the long, expensive, technical quest to ensure that the name is not already trademarked and that a suitable internet address is still available. "Virtually every word in the English dictionary has been registered as a web domain name suffix, which is why, progressively, you find all the new company names are not dictionary words," says Charlie Wrench, managing director of Landor London.

"I actually think this helps make them less faddish: existing words have an association with a time and place, but Xerox, Kodak and Nike don't - so brand owners can imprint their own associations on the brand more easily."

But most crucial is checking that the new name doesn't mean some thing obscene in a foreign language. Naming consultants have an urban folklore all their own, full of the classic mistranslation nightmares that haunt their sleep: the Nova car, meaning "doesn't go" in Spanish markets; likewise the Pinto, found to refer to tiny male genitals in Brazilian slang; and the cola slogan "Come Alive With Pepsi!", supposedly translated into Chinese as "Pepsi: Brings Your Ancestors Back From The Dead."

"I remember one we did recently where we chose the name, and we were happy with it," recalls Wrench with a shudder, "until we discovered that in one of the key markets, Poland, it meant 'armpit smell'."

Not a decade ago, the amount of money and effort spent on rebranding would have been unanimously dismissed as the most self-indulgent navel-gazing, and it's not hard to find even senior management consultants who still think it is. But this is the age of the brand: from breathless boosters such as the management guru Tom Peters to the anticorporate writer Naomi Klein, a consensus is emerging that it is brands, not commodities, that are the real centres of economic value.

Tommy Hilfiger, the ultra-hip clothing label, manufactures no clothing at all; Virgin is nothing but a logo. This heady environment has spawned its own evangelists, such as Scott Bedbury, marketing chief in his time for both Nike and Starbucks: "A great brand taps into emotions [and] emotions drive most, if not all, of our decisions," he says. "A great brand is a story that's never completely told. A brand is a metaphorical story that's evolving all the time, [and] stories create the emotional context people need to locate themselves in a larger experience."

In this weird, unanchored, brand-driven world, almost any expenditure on rebranding suddenly seems not simply justified but unavoidable. If value inheres solely in the brand, rebranding is anything but cosmetic: it offers a brief shot at a complete transformation.

"Momentarily, everybody will be thinking about your company with far greater mental activity than they did six months ago," says David Haigh, managing director of Brand Finance, a consultancy which assesses the worth of individual brands. "And in that moment you have an extraordinary opportunity to clad it with meaning." It is an opportunity, also, for the wrong meanings to become attached, as BA's disastrous tailfin-led rebranding demonstrated.

But it is not all airy theory. Back at Accenture, there is the small problem of what to do with the branded clothing of Andersen Consulting. Much of it has been donated to charities. "We took the view that if it was useful to somebody we'd give it away," says Watmore. Which is generous, of course, but there aren't many other options: within a year, the company will be banned from using the Andersen Consulting name at all, and the entire future of a multi-billion-dollar multinational company will rest on a word that, five months ago, didn't even exist.

Or, at least, it probably didn't: if, months after the new baseball caps have been distributed, Accenture should turn out to be a term of abuse in some obscure Peruvian street slang, or a deeply offensive curse in a previously undocumented dialect of rural Finnish, the future of global management consultancy might turn out rather different than expected.

webTitle: Separated twin may soon leave hospital

fields.headline: Separated twin may soon leave hospital
fields.standfirst: More about Jodie and Mary, the conjoined twins
fields.trailText: The parents of the surviving conjoined twin, Jodie, could be allowed to take their baby girl back home to the Maltese island of Gozo in a matter of weeks, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The parents of the surviving conjoined twin, Jodie, could be allowed to take their baby girl back home to the Maltese island of Gozo in a matter of weeks, it emerged yesterday.

Doctors are pleased with the progress of the five-month-old whose parents, Michaelangelo and Rina Attard, are able to push her in a pram around the hospital complex where she is being treated.

Although St Mary's hospital in Manchester says the baby will probably continue to be treated there until the spring or summer, a close family friend, Tony Hubble, said she could be discharged in "weeks rather than months".

Mr Hubble said yesterday: "She is a beautiful little girl who is beginning to resemble her mum. She has eyes like saucers and looks like an ordinary, healthy girl."

Jodie was separated from her twin Mary in a 20-hour operation in November. Her parents had opposed the procedure on religious grounds because they knew it would inevitably lead to the death of the weaker of the girls. Surgeons had argued that it was better to operate and save Jodie because both girls would inevitably die if nothing were done about their condition. They were able to carry out the separation only after a lengthy legal battle, and could not say for certain that it would not leave Jodie disabled.

Last month, the parents spoke for the first time about Jodie's progress. At first she did not smile, making them afraid that something had gone wrong. But when the doctors stopped administering morphine, she settled, they said.

Mrs Attard said: "We are very happy - she likes to try to talk with us and she smiles at people and at us. It makes us encouraged for the future. She is going to be a real fighter."

Last month, Adrian Bianchi, a paediatric consultant who helped perform the separation, said Jodie was now a "bright, alert and interested child". She was likely to be able to live a completely normal life. At first doctors had believed that it could be 12 months or even up to five years before Jodie would be well enough to return to Gozo.

Mr Hubble said: "No date had been set for Jodie to be discharged but she is much further forward than anticipated. She is putting on weight as would be expected with any normal child."

The Attards now take her from the intensive care unit for a half hour or so at a time and take her in a pram around the hospital and its grounds. They spent Christmas with Jodie in the hospital.

Since the publicity around the case, the Attards have been inundated with gifts and messages of goodwill. They have spent many weekends with Mr Hubble and his family at his Staffordshire home, and an appeal fund to support Jodie through further treatment has topped £350,000 and could reach £500,000 by Easter. The cloud on the horizon is Mary's funeral. Her parents need to chose between returning to Gozo without Jodie to lay her sister to rest, or waiting until Jodie is well enough to travel.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Eat Drink Man Woman | Excalibur | The Siege
fields.body:
Eat Drink Man Woman
(Ang Lee, 1994)
8pm, FilmFour

A succulent celebration of the spices of life - food and love - in this fragrant and witty romantic comedy cooked up by Ang Lee. It's set almost tangibly in his homeland of Taiwan and stars Sihung Lung as a widowed master chef and father of three unmarried daughters. As their romances begin to threaten his cosy world, he continues to express his love via the wok, aglow with emotional-comfort food. Watch, and drool.

Excalibur
(John Boorman, 1981)
8pm, Sky Cinema

Boorman seems to have got lost in the mists of time with this confusing version of the Arthurian legend: the narrative is all but engulfed by whizz-bang visuals. However, the images are often brilliant, there are savage battles, curious sex (armour-clad Nigel Terry, pictured, roasting by the fire with Helen Mirren), and Nicol Williams's Merlin is just dotty.

The Siege
(Edward Zwick, 1998)
10.10pm, Sky Premier

Muslim terrorists are bombing New York and the forces of law and order are trying to catch them. It may sound crass but Zwick, director of Glory and Courage Under Fire, extends the drama into more interesting areas. The goodies are Denzel Washington's FBI man, Annette Bening's National Security operative and Bruce Willis's gung-ho army general, and their confrontations over issues of civil liberty and the limits of security measures are as gripping as the explosive stuff. Until the final slide into comic-strip resolutions, it's crunchy and intriguing.

Easy Rider
(Dennis Hopper, 1969)
10.30pm, FilmFour

The 60s cult classic, epitome of road-movie-druggy-harmony. Cue Steppenwolf's Born To Be Wild, Peter Fonda's leatherclad Captain America, Dennis Hopper's dippy-hippy and Jack Nicholson's freewheeler, all astride Harley Davidsons to die for and running slap-bang into redneckland. Laszlo Kovacs's photography lingers on the choppers on the road from California to New Orleans mardi gras; and on the ugliness the riders can't escape. Fonda sounds the death knell: "We blew it," he says.

The Siege (Edward Zwick, 1998) 10.10pm, Sky Premier Muslim terrorists are bombing New York and the forces of law and order are trying to catch them. It may sound crass but Zwick, director of Glory and Courage Under Fire, extends the drama into more interesting areas. The goodies are Denzel Washington's FBI man, Annette Bening's National Security operative and Bruce Willis's gung-ho army general, and their confrontations over issues of civil liberty and the limits of security measures are as gripping as the explosive stuff. Until the final slide into comic-strip resolutions, it's crunchy and intriguing. Easy Rider (Dennis Hopper, 1969) 10.30pm, FilmFour The 60s cult classic, epitome of road-movie-druggy-harmony. Cue Steppenwolf's Born To Be Wild, Peter Fonda's leatherclad Captain America, Dennis Hopper's dippy-hippy and Jack Nicholson's freewheeler, all astride Harley Davidsons to die for and running slap-bang into redneckland. Laszlo Kovacs's photography lingers on the choppers on the road from California to New Orleans mardi gras; and on the ugliness the riders can't escape. Fonda sounds the death knell: "We blew it," he says.

webTitle: Indicted tycoon heads for victory in Thai election

fields.headline: Indicted tycoon heads for victory in Thai election
fields.trailText: Thailand's political future appeared uncertain yesterday after provisional results from Saturday's general election showed that voters had backed a billionaire tycoon who has been indicted for lying about the extent of his wealth.
fields.body:
Thailand's political future appeared uncertain yesterday after provisional results from Saturday's general election showed that voters had backed a billionaire tycoon who has been indicted for lying about the extent of his wealth.

Television exit polls combined with unofficial results indicated that the opposition Thai Rak Thai (Thais Love Thais) party of policeman-turned-telecoms magnate Thaksin Shinawatra could gain as many as 257 of the legislature's 500 seats.

The incumbent prime minister, Chuan Leekpai, conceded defeat yesterday despite revotes being ordered in several constituencies and investigations into vote-buying expected in dozens of others.

"The result is quite clear," he said. "I believe the people have freely made their choice and we respect that decision. My party will not be involved in the next government."

If the final results, which are not expected for weeks, confirm the exit poll predictions it will be the first time in Thai history that one party has held an absolute majority.

However, Mr Thaksin has said he wants a stable base of at least 320 seats, so he is likely to continue coalition talks with a couple of minor parties.

But it remains unclear whether Mr Thaksin, who formed his party only 18 months ago as a vehicle for his personal political ambitions, will be able to enjoy a mandate to govern a country still struggling to recover from the economic crisis that broke in 1997.

The national counter-corruption commission ruled last month that Mr Thaksin had tried to hide the extent of his wealth by transferring assets worth millions of pounds to his driver and maid while he served in government prior to the economic crisis.

It is now up to Thailand's constitutional court to pass final judgment, which might take several months. If it upholds the commission's verdict then Mr Thaksin will be forced to resign and will be barred from public office for up to five years.

Mr Thaksin maintains his innocence. "I know myself that I'm innocent," he said yesterday. "This is not a corruption case. This is a misreport [of assets] which is not a big deal for a political career. I feel comfortable. I think the constitutional tribunal court will give me fair treatment."

Analysts say the election results strengthen Mr Thaksin's position because he can claim that Thais voted for him in their millions, despite knowing of his alleged misdeeds.

"He will argue that the constitutional court has no right to overturn the mandate given to him by the electorate," said Sunai Phasuk, a political scientist at Chulalongkorn University in Bangkok.

Mr Thaksin fought the campaign on promises of debt relief for poor farmers, a 1m-baht (£15,400) grant to every village and not to follow so rigidly the International Monetary Fund reform programme. Mr Chuan lost a lot of support because of his failure to stand up to the IMF.

The Nation newspaper said yesterday that Mr Thaksin's victory marked a new era in Thai politics.

"This is the first time big business and conglomerates will run the country. Other countries might have movie stars or former prisoners as their presidents, but Thais have decided to pick a billionaire. They probably entertain the hope that they too will be rich like their leader."

webTitle: Drive to sign up 70,000 helpers as census looms

fields.headline: Drive to sign up 70,000 helpers as census looms
fields.trailText: In what is claimed to be the biggest peacetime recruitment operation ever undertaken in the UK, the government will this week begin the process of enlisting almost 70,000 foot soldiers to help statisticians carry out the task of drawing up the most up-to-date profile of people living in this country.
fields.body:
In what is claimed to be the biggest peacetime recruitment operation ever undertaken in the UK, the government will this week begin the process of enlisting almost 70,000 foot soldiers to help statisticians carry out the task of drawing up the most up-to-date profile of people living in this country.

The year 2001 is census year, when households throughout England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are required by law to fill out the detailed forms whose raw data is used by central and local government for planning and policy making.

The aim of the exercise is to provide accurate information on the numbers of people in the UK, where they live and what their needs are.

In England and Wales alone the census is costing £225m. Forms will have to be delivered to some 24m households and the Office for National Statistics is seeking part-time recruits to do the necessary legwork.

Parallel censuses will take place at the same time in Scotland and Northern Ireland, using similar forms but with question variations that reflect local needs.

The recruitment drive for the England and Wales census is due to get under way in a blaze of publicity in central London before rolling out across the rest of the country in a series of awareness-raising roadshows over the following two weeks.

The enumerators, or census takers as the ONS is keen for them to be known, will be paid £318, rising to £398 in parts of London, for the equivalent of two weeks' work between March 20 and May 21.

Equipped with large yellow bags bearing the census logo "Count me in", their task will be to hand deliver the bar coded forms and make follow up calls to households that have not returned them after census day, April 29.

They will also be asked to make notes of derelict or unoccupied properties as part of the exhaustive statistical exercise.

Recruits, who will work mainly at weekends and in the evening, will be required to be good communicators, meticulous, community spirited and able to keep to deadlines. With the exception of 1941, a census has been taken every 10 years in Great Britain since 1801.

Householders will this year be required to answer a series of around 50 questions on everything from education and employment activity to the number of rooms in their home and the lack or otherwise of amenities such as central heating and inside toilets.

Failure to make a completed return can lead to a £1,000 fine. More than 400 people were prosecuted in the wake of the last census in 1991 when the final tally, achieving a 98% coverage of the population, was affected by the aftermath of the poll tax protests.

The nature of questions asked down the years has changed from census to census, reflecting changes in society and technological advances.

For the current census, new questions on general health and unpaid personal carers have been added.

In England and Wales the ethnic group categories used 10 years ago have been extended to include Irish, mixed ethnic group, black British and Asian British - a development that has caused anger in parts of Wales, where there have been protests at the absence of a separate Welsh tick box on the census form.

Although householders in Wales can choose to fill in a Welsh language form and will be allowed to write the word Welsh in the tick box marked "other", the ONS and government officials are keen to head off any revolt against taking part in the survey.

The director of census, Graham Jones, was in Cardiff yesterday to hammer home the message that Wales will lose out economically if the census figures are wrong.

Rhodri Morgan, first minister of the national assembly for Wales, has already warned that any boycott or burning of census forms would deny the Welsh people their entitlement to extra money to tackle poverty and employment.

Plaid Cymru, which has led the chorus of anger over the issue, insisted yesterday that it was not advocating that people should not fill in their form. But a spokesman said the party was determined to rectify the situation.

webTitle: National Trust takes down-to-earth stance

fields.headline: National Trust takes down-to-earth stance
fields.standfirst: Prefabs and semis could come under the spotlight as new chief says 'I'm no toff' and vows to pursue the common touch
fields.trailText: Prefabs and semis could come under the spotlight as new chief says 'I'm no toff' and vows to pursue the common touch.
fields.body:
The National Trust could add a 1940s prefab or a 1930s semi to its property portfolio as its interest shifts away from the lives of rich men in their castles to those of the poor men at their gates.

Under the leadership of its first woman director in its 106-year history, it is also showing new interest in the lifestyle of the middle classes and their homes in the suburbs and towns of England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

"We haven't any plans [to buy a prefab or a semi] but the logic of our approach is that those are the kind of things we may well consider in the future," said Fiona Reynolds, who moved to the trust, one of the world's richest charities, this month.

She had previously spent two years as head of the women's unit in the Cabinet Office, which she regards as useful experience of the inner workings of government, and before that was at the Council for the Protection of Rural England for six years.

Ms Reynolds, 42, won the trust's top job because she offered a new leadership style and an agenda for evolutionary change which could cause shudders among the trust's 2.7m members, many of whom may still be in love with the aristocratic past.

"I am not a toff," she said. "I am a paid-up member of the middle classes. A lot of the messages I am giving are designed to show how we are relevant, how we are appealing to people, how we are reaching out to families, how we are telling the stories of ordinary people."

The trust already owns the council house in which Sir Paul McCartney grew up in Liverpool and an Edwardian semi in Worksop, Nottinghamshire.

But its most significant recent acquisition has been a workhouse in Southwell, Nottinghamshire, due to open to the public next year. The building has a certain style but is at the opposite end of the social scale from the Palladian mansions and grand estates with which the trust is usually associated.

When the purchase was announced in 1997, Ms Reynolds's predecessor, Martin Drury, said: "Young people find social history and the lives of poor and ordinary people far more absorbing than the privileged few represented by the typical National Trust country mansion."

Ms Reynolds will build on that trend as she seeks to unfold narratives of real lives to her members, threequarters of whom live in towns.

"The workhouse is an extraordinarily evocative place. When it is open to the public it will prove irresistible. It tells a very creepy story about the way we treated the poor and it immediately makes me think about our attitudes to the poor today and about how society addresses these questions.

"It is a very good example of how the trust is engaging with a very contemporary issue as well as part of our history. The reality is that these people had as important role in our past as the great families. Many people can identify more readily with ordinary people."

McCartney's house in Forthlin Road in Liverpool has proved very popular, despite strict controls on visitor numbers, and Ms Reynolds has been intrigued by the public's reaction.

"People go to the house because they are passionate about the Beatles. They come out full of personal reminiscences about the lino they had as a child. It is as much about bringing to life the suburbia that many of us grew up in as it is about a particular family or a particular person."

The trust's duty to conserve and protect its grand houses will remain. But the quest for relevance will build on a growing realisation that visitors want something that sparks memories or touches their lives and may often be more interested in the scullery maid than the lady of the manor.

"The areas which we are already developing around our properties are more human or involve social narrative," said Ms Reynolds. "We are getting very positive feedback on that. People really want to know how people lived, what went on below stairs, how the gardeners lived, whether their children went to school, how the estate was run. There is a natural curiosity about such people's stories and when we tell those stories we get fantastic feedback. It is about telling the story of all the people who contributed.

"If you take the classic National Trust estate - the great house, gardens and park - and think of the hundreds of people involved in one way or another, that is the fascinating story."

As the country's biggest private landowner, the National Trust is a major player in the countryside debate. The hunting row has bounced round its committee rooms in Queen Anne's Gate, London, with campaigners such as Robin Page and Lucinda Green still seeking to overturn the ban on stag hunting on trust land.

That ban was confirmed last year and Ms Reynolds, with political skills honed in the Cabinet Office, sticks firmly to the trust's stance that it has to be neutral in the arguments over hunting foxes.

But she is willing to get stuck into other rural issues and has the green credentials to do it. She has a Cambridge degree in geography and land management, and suggests she and the trust have the expertise to mediate between noisy rival factions and sometimes artificial divisions.

David Clark, MP for South Shields and in the 1980s a member of the National Trust's executive committee, yesterday hailed Ms Reynolds's appointment as "an inspired choice".

Statistics

The National Trust, founded in 1895, cares for 200 buildings and gardens, 600 miles of coastline and 240,000 hectares of land in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. It has 3,800 staff and 38,000 volunteers who help run its properties. Its ruling trust has 52 members.

Sources of income in 1999-2000:

Membership £60m

Legacies £34m

Investments £26.4m

Rents £21.5m

Grants £14.5m

Shops, etc £11.7m

Appeals etc £20m

Expenditure in 1999-2000:

Coast and countryside £43.8m

Historic buildings and collections £45.7m

Property management £20.2m

Acquisitions £12.5m

Gardens £10.7m

Conservation, maintenance and administration £15.7m

webTitle: Full horror of jail raids revealed

fields.headline: Full horror of jail raids revealed
fields.standfirst: Amnesty alarm as hunger strikers near death in wake of assault on Turkish prisons dominated by leftwing factions
fields.trailText: Amnesty alarm as hunger strikers near death in wake of assault on Turkish prisons dominated by leftwing factions.
fields.body:
The black smoke hanging over Turkey's prisons has gone, and the gunfire has stopped. But more than two weeks after security forces stormed prisons across the country to regain control of dormitories run by leftwing inmates, the problems continue.

Hundreds of prisoners are on hunger strike, with many reportedly prepared to die for their cause. While the government is trumpeting the triumph of the law, human rights groups have received reports of the torture and beating of prisoners transferred to smaller cells.

Negotiators who tried to mediate between the state and the prisoners before the violence say they have been used.

"We were deceived by the government," said Mehmet Bekaroglu, a member of the parliamentary human rights commission. "Now there is a frightening silence."

Thirty prisoners and two soldiers were killed in four days of clashes at the jails just before Christmas. The prisoners were devoted members of violent far left factions. Many of the security force members who intervened used excessive force. It was a lethal combination.

Operation Return to Life began on December 19 after more than a year of preparation. Detailed plans had been made to move thousands of inmates into new jails where they are housed in small cells rather than large dormitories.

At Bayrampasa prison in Istanbul, armed paramilitary police and soldiers took up positions on the roof, and began trying to force their way into dormitories by smashing holes in the walls and ceilings.

Accounts from surviving inmates have been brought out of prison by lawyers. They cannot be independently confirmed, but their stories are consistent.

"They saw us stand up and they started firing at us," said Hamide Ozturk, a convicted member of the Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front (DHKP-C), who was in the women's ward. "After the shooting they started to bombard us with all kinds of bombs. They threw smoke bombs, sound bombs [an explosion where the main by-product is noise], nerve gas and pepper gas. We constantly answered them with slogans and insults.

"They kept shouting: 'Surrender or we will kill all of you.' We said: 'Come and kill us all if you like, but we will never surrender'."

What happened next is the subject of bitter debate. The government says that after several hours of clashes the prisoners refused to give in and began setting themselves on fire. The survivors say they were deliberately burned out of their dormitories with incendiary devices, and that several inmates died in the flames.

"The fire quickly spread all over the dormitory," said another DHKP-C prisoner, Suna Okmen. "Beds and furniture began to catch fire. The people could not breathe because of the gas bombs and the smoke. It was like being in an oven.

"Our hair began to catch fire, and because we had barred the door we were unable to get out. We forced the door open...and those who were still able to stand up had to drag us out. [The soldiers] had water cannons, if they had wanted to they could have put the fire out. All they did was watch."

The paramilitary police have given a different account. There is evidence that in some prisons the DHKP-C ordered its members to practise self-immolation rather than surrender.

"What terrified us most was seeing the leaders pouring flammable liquids on to the militants and setting them on fire with their own hands," said a gendarme quoted in the local press. "We were too far away to be able to intervene...we were under fire from makeshift bombs and guns."

One television image showed a woman handcuffed to a wall with her flesh on fire, but it is impossible to give a full account of what really happened.

Eventually the security forces achieved their objectives, and at Bayrampasa the prisoners were forced into the open.

"They surrounded us, attacked us and tried to pull us apart," Suna Okmen said. "They took us to other parts of the prison, beat us, kicked us, slapped us, swore at us and then collected us together."

The authorities insist they used no more force than was necessary. They have displayed an armoury of home-made weapons, including flame throwers, recovered from the burned-out dormitories.

"The situation we faced before the operation was like a stick which was dirty at both ends," said the minister of justice, Hikmet Sami Turk. "We did not know which end of the stick to touch. But now I can say comfortably that we picked the right end."

The control that the DHKP-C and other radical leftwing groups exercised in the prisons had been broken. For years, they had been running the dormitories as indoctrination camps. Prison officials said they had been unable to enter some areas inside the jails for nearly a decade.

"Terrorist organisations have been brainwashing our young people," Mr Sami Turk said. "Human rights will now be respected in all prisons. The necessary measures will be taken to ensure this is done."

But pressure groups, including Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International, have expressed alarm at the situation, while lawyers, human rights activists and relatives of prisoners say they have been inundated with allegations of abuse.

Some reports say prisoners who refuse to sing the national anthem have been badly beaten. Doctors say they have been denied access to the post-mortem examination reports of those who died.

So far more than 1,000 people have been transferred to new "F-type" prisons, where inmates are held in cells for up to three people. The government describes the prisons as a fresh start for a system which had degenerated into chaos.

Most diplomats in Ankara believe the authorities are sincere in their efforts to stamp out torture and ill-treatment in jails. But critics say the F-type prisons are being used to implement a regime of isolation. "In no way do these prisons meet international standards," said Jonathan Sugden of Human Rights Watch. "Both in terms of their architecture and especially in terms of the way they are run, there are serious causes for concern."

During the prison transfers, some inmates say they were beaten, others that they were raped with truncheons. The justice ministry has said it will investigate, but it refused to discuss the issue with human rights groups, and turned down their requests to visit the new jails.

The next stage of the crisis is looming. Hundreds of prisoners are on hunger strike, some reportedly for more than 70 days. Doctors expect deaths soon. The government initially said it would force medical experts to intervene, but it seems to have changed its mind.

"At this point, these young people are responsible for their own lives," the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said. "The state has done what was in its power."

The prison situation has also had wider repercussions. Human rights groups have been warned that criticism of the F-type prisons could be a criminal offence. Meanwhile, there have been running battles between leftwing demonstrators and the police, and yesterday police arrested 34 people after they tried to lay a black wreath outside the building of Mr Ecevit's Democratic Left party, according to the state-run Anatolian news agency.

fields.bodyText: The black smoke hanging over Turkey's prisons has gone, and the gunfire has stopped. But more than two weeks after security forces stormed prisons across the country to regain control of dormitories run by leftwing inmates, the problems continue. Hundreds of prisoners are on hunger strike, with many reportedly prepared to die for their cause. While the government is trumpeting the triumph of the law, human rights groups have received reports of the torture and beating of prisoners transferred to smaller cells. Negotiators who tried to mediate between the state and the prisoners before the violence say they have been used. "We were deceived by the government," said Mehmet Bekaroglu, a member of the parliamentary human rights commission. "Now there is a frightening silence." Thirty prisoners and two soldiers were killed in four days of clashes at the jails just before Christmas. The prisoners were devoted members of violent far left factions. Many of the security force members who intervened used excessive force. It was a lethal combination. Operation Return to Life began on December 19 after more than a year of preparation. Detailed plans had been made to move thousands of inmates into new jails where they are housed in small cells rather than large dormitories. At Bayrampasa prison in Istanbul, armed paramilitary police and soldiers took up positions on the roof, and began trying to force their way into dormitories by smashing holes in the walls and ceilings. Accounts from surviving inmates have been brought out of prison by lawyers. They cannot be independently confirmed, but their stories are consistent. "They saw us stand up and they started firing at us," said Hamide Ozturk, a convicted member of the Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front (DHKP-C), who was in the women's ward. "After the shooting they started to bombard us with all kinds of bombs. They threw smoke bombs, sound bombs [an explosion where the main by-product is noise], nerve gas and pepper gas. We constantly answered them with slogans and insults. "They kept shouting: 'Surrender or we will kill all of you.' We said: 'Come and kill us all if you like, but we will never surrender'." What happened next is the subject of bitter debate. The government says that after several hours of clashes the prisoners refused to give in and began setting themselves on fire. The survivors say they were deliberately burned out of their dormitories with incendiary devices, and that several inmates died in the flames. "The fire quickly spread all over the dormitory," said another DHKP-C prisoner, Suna Okmen. "Beds and furniture began to catch fire. The people could not breathe because of the gas bombs and the smoke. It was like being in an oven. "Our hair began to catch fire, and because we had barred the door we were unable to get out. We forced the door open...and those who were still able to stand up had to drag us out. [The soldiers] had water cannons, if they had wanted to they could have put the fire out. All they did was watch." The paramilitary police have given a different account. There is evidence that in some prisons the DHKP-C ordered its members to practise self-immolation rather than surrender. "What terrified us most was seeing the leaders pouring flammable liquids on to the militants and setting them on fire with their own hands," said a gendarme quoted in the local press. "We were too far away to be able to intervene...we were under fire from makeshift bombs and guns." One television image showed a woman handcuffed to a wall with her flesh on fire, but it is impossible to give a full account of what really happened. Eventually the security forces achieved their objectives, and at Bayrampasa the prisoners were forced into the open. "They surrounded us, attacked us and tried to pull us apart," Suna Okmen said. "They took us to other parts of the prison, beat us, kicked us, slapped us, swore at us and then collected us together." The authorities insist they used no more force than was necessary. They have displayed an armoury of home-made weapons, including flame throwers, recovered from the burned-out dormitories. "The situation we faced before the operation was like a stick which was dirty at both ends," said the minister of justice, Hikmet Sami Turk. "We did not know which end of the stick to touch. But now I can say comfortably that we picked the right end." The control that the DHKP-C and other radical leftwing groups exercised in the prisons had been broken. For years, they had been running the dormitories as indoctrination camps. Prison officials said they had been unable to enter some areas inside the jails for nearly a decade.
