webTitle: Whitehall tried to smear comedian

fields.headline: Whitehall tried to smear comedian
fields.standfirst:
Minister denies he was behind email asking for 'dirt' on Mark Thomas
All the latest media news at www.mediaguardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The government was last night embroiled in a dirty tricks row after an official memo alleged that a minister wanted civil servants to dig up damaging information to "rubbish" the radical Channel 4 comedian Mark Thomas.
fields.body:
The government was last night embroiled in a dirty tricks row after an official memo alleged that a minister wanted civil servants to dig up damaging information to "rubbish" the radical Channel 4 comedian Mark Thomas.

Richard Caborn, the trade minister, denied the allegation, claiming that he had been misinterpreted by an official, who had since been disciplined.

Thomas has written to the prime minister Tony Blair calling for an investigation to establish whether Mr Caborn has broken the code of conduct for ministers.

The comedian said: "If Caborn wants to smear me, this is a waste of taxpayers' money and time. This is the type of behaviour you would expect from undemocratic regimes, not from a government which promised to be whiter than white."

A batch of Whitehall emails has revealed how officials sought to counter the threat of Thomas's criticisms of controversial government support for British exporters during long-running skirmishes.

They also show how the comedian irked officials, one of whom dubbed him "an out-and-out nutter", when he publicised the activities of a Whitehall organisation, the export credit guarantee department (ECGD), in his television series.

The row centres on an email on May 3 last year in which an unnamed ECGD official wrote: "Thomas is back on the tele in the autumn (by the way, [name of official deleted] also said that Caborn wants him to gather as much background/dirt on him in order to rubbish him)."

Yesterday, Mr Caborn appeared to shift the blame on to the unnamed official who wrote the email. The minister said he was "unaware of the contents of this email, and since the contents came to light, the official concerned has received a warning over the incident".

He said he had never asked for dirt to rubbish the comedian, but had merely "made a purely procedural request for background on Mark Thomas and his programme, as a result of the programme's continuing interest in the ECGD and its projects".

Thomas's show, a hybrid of comedy and investigation, has for five years used humour and stunts to highlight political issues and scandals, from arms sales to Indonesia to American spying on Britons.

Two programmes looked at the ECGD, for which Mr Caborn is responsible. The department provides British exporters with credit and insures them in case foreign buyers default.

Thomas criticised ECGD plans to support the construction of the Ilisu dam in Turkey, by a consortium including Balfour Beatty, that will make more than 25,000 Kurdish people homeless.

He was also scathing about official aid for selling military equipment, efforts to wipe out debt in developing countries, and the secrecy surrounding the ECGD.

The comedian has used the new Data Protection Act to obtain the internal memos about himself from government departments, for a programme to be broadcast tonight, the first of a new series of The Mark Thomas Product.

This "anti-Big Brother" act gives citizens the right to see information about themselves that is contained in files held by the government and other bodies so they can check it is accurate and is not being misused.

The names of officials who wrote the emails have been deleted by the government to preserve their privacy.

In one ECGD email, an official wrote: "Mark Thomas appears to be an alternative comedian who specialises in investigatory journalism." Another official replied: "Thomas is certainly 'alternative' - but I wouldn't go so far as to call him a 'comedian' - the bloke is an out-and-out nutter - and he more or less agreed he was when he rang me later." Another email says: "We ought not to give Thomas 'chatting' time given what an inquisitor he is.

"And we should do our best to 'help' to get [Caborn] away if he stays verbal jousting for too long."

The memos show how the ECGD grappled with different tactics to defend its activities. Last January, a civil servant wrote to a senior ECGD official: "You have said that we should attempt to close him down - and put all correspondence through the minister for trade [Mr Caborn]."

Later that day, another official replied: "I understand from [name deleted] that Mr Caborn has now reversed his view about starving Thomas of information. He now wants us to be as open as possible."

In an email in October 1999, an official had noted: "Thomas's main thrust is to demonstrate that ECGD is a secretive organisation throwing (without scrutiny) millions of pounds at third world dictators - generally to help them buy arms or dodgy projects (hence Ilisu).

"I argued that ECGD now had a policy of disclosing information wherever it was possible to do so - but there were a raft of good political and commercial reasons why we could not reveal everything to everyone."

A month later, an official argued that the ECGD could release the minimum of information to Thomas to "starve [him] of material to bounce off, but against that he could make quite a lot of play with our refusal, as it were, to engage his case - our silence will be implied to be hiding something, and will fuel accusations of secrecy, evasiveness and unwillingness to be open with the public or answer their questions."

The ECGD official added: "His measure of success is how much publicity and storm he generates, so he's not going to be put off by anything we say - he's not interested in the truth, only in making us look stupid/secretive etc."

In another memo, a Whitehall mandarin last year warned John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, that Thomas sought to provoke the authorities in "a confrontational, aggressive and head-on manner".

Campaigns of a TV stuntman

 Pursued the former Tory minister William Waldegrave in a tank asking him to help export it to Iraq during the controversy over selling military equipment to Saddam Hussein.

 Ambushed a train carrying nuclear waste with 40 protesters dressed in military uniform in a hoax terrorist attack. A Whitehall official privately conceded that his "criticisms of security flaws may be found to be valid".

 Induced Jack Straw, the home secretary, to call police to frisk a multiple sclerosis sufferer at his Blackburn surgery when he falsely believed that he was smoking cannabis to ease his pain. The sufferer's roll-up merely contained tobacco.

 Took groups of people to view artworks in stately homes to highlight how the public found it difficult to see paintings and other art that were supposed to be on open display in return for tax exemptions.

 Devised an elaborate scheme to secretly film Indonesian military chiefs admitting their government tortured dissenters.

 Proposed turning pornographic articles written some years ago by the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, into a film. Mr Campbell refused to grant him the rights.

Export credit guarantee department official email, January 22 1999

"The bloke is an out and out nutter - and he more or less agreed he was when he rang me later If, however, Mark Thomas has the gall to ring me again for a reaction (I can't think that he will) he will probably get one!! (off the record of course)."

ECGD official, July 17 2000

"[name deleted] suspects there will be a Mark Thomas doorstep tomorrow. We ought not to give Thomas 'chatting' time given what an inquisitor he is. And we should do our best to 'help' to get [trade minister Richard Caborn] away if he stays verbal jousting for too long."

ECGD official, May 3 2000

"Thomas is back on the tele in the autumn (by the way, [name deleted] also said that Caborn wants him to gather as much background/dirt on him in order to rubbish him)."

ECGD official, January 22 1999

"Mark Thomas is certainly 'alternative' - but I wouldn't go so far as to call him a 'comedian'."

DTI official, January 14 1999

"Some of you might recall that this prat (sorry, highly entertaining comedian) tried one on DTI before."

ECGD official, July 10 2000

"Thomas said that when he was doing a concert for Marxism Today last Friday, he mentioned to one of the organisers that he sometimes rings up for a chat - the organiser apparently beamed profusely and said: 'At last we're finally reaching the upper echelons of power!' Thomas thought this was funny - I don't know why!"

webTitle: Civil servants demand safeguards on Labour's electronic database

fields.headline: Civil servants demand safeguards on Labour's electronic database
fields.trailText: January 8 2001: Safeguards for civil service impartiality were yesterday demanded by former senior Whitehall officials and MPs following the Guardian's disclosure of government plans to develop a powerful electronic information and rebuttal system.
fields.body:
Safeguards for civil service impartiality were yesterday demanded by former senior Whitehall officials and MPs following the Guardian's disclosure of government plans to develop a powerful electronic information and rebuttal system.

Leaked cabinet office documents described the aim of the Knowledge Network Project, as it is officially known, as explaining `the government's core message' so that the public could get `the full facts without going through the distorting prism of media reporting'.

Critics of the hi-tech project yesterday raised questions about what effect it would have on the impartiality of the civil service and the accountability of government.

They expressed fears that a system intended to make the running of government more efficient and professional could be used for party political purposes.

The system, a descendant of the Excalibur database the Labour party used during the 1997 election, opens a new chapter in the relationship between the Labour government and the civil service .

The project, devised by Frank Dobson's former spin doctor, Joe McCrea, recommended that the database included the `best five arguments and the best three facts' for every key government policy, as well as the `key quotes, key facts and rapid reaction to attacks on departmental policy and practice'.

One former senior cabinet office civil servant, Sir Peter Kemp, told the BBC yesterday: `The question is whether civil servants and the rest will actually be able, or indeed allowed, to put out totally objective material.' If the new machinery meant civil servants could not put out the `four bad facts' as well as the three good ones, then, `I think we may be in trouble.'

The idea of trying to cut out the `distorting prism of the media' was mistaken, he said, since it was media reporting that kept democracy alive.

Jonathan Baume, head of the civil service union the First Division Association, said there were clear rules for civil servants and the government's information service, and the Knowledge Network would help modernise work that was already being carried out.

But he warned: `What would be difficult is if this system was hijacked in some way to be used for party political purposes. The danger would be if people who had access to it, which must clearly include special advisers, would then misuse this information for party purposes.'

The home secretary, Jack Straw, defended the system as a sensible use of new information technology systems, and said it was consistent with traditional political debate. He also insisted that it was no threat to opposition parties, because Labour had doubled the state aid they received, in the interest of fairness.

`This is information which is going to be used publicly any way, and is available publicly,' Mr Straw told the Guardian. `This is about material which is used for public argument. In the end, for all the benefits of IT systems, political argument comes down to the frailty of human beings. There is no machine that has yet been found that gets round that.

`This should be seen in the context of the amount of public money given to opposition parties. We are ensuring that the opposition is funded effectively, in ways that the Tories never provided for us.'

Mr Straw added: `That is why, by the way, we had to resort to things like blind trusts, and special advisers had to work for tuppence ha'penny.''

For the Conservatives, John Redwood denounced the system as a fresh scandal, with millions being spent on what he called spin doctors threatening politicisation of the civil service . `Not content with bulldozing our constitution, Mr Blair now seems to want to undermine one of its linchpins - the political neutrality and independence of officials,' he said.

webTitle: Officehours: Sec's tips

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst:
16. Visibility

<A HREF="http://www.workunlimited.co.uk/">Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: 16. Visibility
fields.body:
You're fed up. No one ever asks for your opinion, you don't get invited to join project teams, and some people in the organisation don't even know your name! Well, it's a tough world, and if you're being passed over, it could be that you are simply not visible enough. Beavering away silently at your desk won't always guarantee your just rewards. So resolve to raise your profile in the firm and make sure everyone knows your value.

 Why don't some people know your name? Is it because you're not using it? Check out internal telephone lists and change them if they have you down as "HR secretary" instead of "Helen Harris". When you answer the phone, give your name not the boss's. And next time you spend hours working on a report, print on the cover: "Report compiled by Helen Harris." Sell yourself.

 Get out of your office. Have a hit list of other departments, and work your way through them. Find reasons to visit them, and make sure they know who you are and what you do. You could set up an informal work-shadowing system with them, so all staff get a better idea of the company's functions.

 If project teams are being set up, and you'd like to contribute, then volunteer. Don't wait to be asked. And if you see a part of your boss's job that you could take on, go in and ask for it. Everyone is busy, so the onus is on you to get yourself noticed.

 How is your body language? If you're a bit of a mouse, take lessons or study others who have got it right. Walk confidently, and with a purpose. Always keep eye contact with people, and give a firm handshake. Walk into rooms with your head held high; don't sneak in, looking at the ground.

 In meetings, greet everyone brightly and look as though you're meant to be there. Never sit through a meeting in silence. Even if you only say: "Yes, I think Mark's point is important," or "Can we open a window?"

 Your boss can help to raise your profile, so get them to make sure senior managers know who you are. If your boss isn't already aware, draft a "skills and achievements" document, which shows both what you have done and what you can do.

 So go on - the new year is a great time to start. Draft an action plan headed "Me plc" and start selling your skills to your organisation. They'll be amazed when they find out what you can do - and they'll wonder why they never thought of you before.

 Penny Cottee is editor of Executive PA magazine.

Don't wait to be asked. And if you see a part of your boss's job that you could take on, go in and ask for it. Everyone is busy, so the onus is on you to get yourself noticed.  How is your body language? If you're a bit of a mouse, take lessons or study others who have got it right. Walk confidently, and with a purpose. Always keep eye contact with people, and give a firm handshake. Walk into rooms with your head held high; don't sneak in, looking at the ground.  In meetings, greet everyone brightly and look as though you're meant to be there. Never sit through a meeting in silence. Even if you only say: "Yes, I think Mark's point is important," or "Can we open a window?"  Your boss can help to raise your profile, so get them to make sure senior managers know who you are. If your boss isn't already aware, draft a "skills and achievements" document, which shows both what you have done and what you can do.  So go on - the new year is a great time to start. Draft an action plan headed "Me plc" and start selling your skills to your organisation. They'll be amazed when they find out what you can do - and they'll wonder why they never thought of you before.  Penny Cottee is editor of Executive PA magazine.

webTitle: Officehours: WPM

fields.headline: WPM
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: • The celebratory season may be over for others but here at Office Hours the party's just beginning. Today marks the first birthday of the Guardian's Office Hours supplement, and therefore is an open invitation to poison our livers still further by imbibing leftover toddy and consuming unhealthy amounts of chocolate cake. Those of you who missed the deadline for Christmas presents are also offered a second stab at appeasing WPM with your gifts. As before, no bribe is too big or small to fit into the letterbox of the usual address ...
fields.body:
 The celebratory season may be over for others but here at Office Hours the party's just beginning. Today marks the first birthday of the Guardian's Office Hours supplement, and therefore is an open invitation to poison our livers still further by imbibing leftover toddy and consuming unhealthy amounts of chocolate cake. Those of you who missed the deadline for Christmas presents are also offered a second stab at appeasing WPM with your gifts. As before, no bribe is too big or small to fit into the letterbox of the usual address ...

 And - as if by some sort of divine intervention - there are still more reasons to get your pressies packaged and posted. A press release reaches WPM detailing that today is National Thank You Day. According to recent survey by Royal Mail, the majority of people say thank you at least 10 times a day. "Not enough," say you ungrateful sods in reply.

The research also says that 70% of respondents felt that other people do not express their gratitude with the frequency most people demand. WPM was about to tell the complainants where to stick it, but then she read on: a staggering 82% believe that manners are not as good as they used to be. Come to think of it, her fan mail laced with gratitude has been a bit slow recently. She is prepared to forgive the slackers on receipt of her well-earned box of choccies.

 A second press release from the Department of the Bleedin' Obvious claims that staff would prefer to have more "Duvet Days" - where they can trade a day 0f work for one in bed without having to lie to their bosses about being sick. Amazingly though, the powers-that-be prefer this type of honesty to the untruths we're used to spouting.

 WPM was initially horrified to hear news that British secretaries are going Dutch (she always thought you should screw friends and partners for every penny). However, further investigation reveals that it is not equal rights that is so tempting but Holland itself.

Apparently, the picturesque canals, windmills and higher standard of living of the Netherlands is teasing away our top PAs. London secretarial agency Crone Corkill reports that the demand from Dutch companies for British employees is easily matched by the enthusiasm of candidates to move to the Netherlands.

Crone Corkill business development manager Julie Holmes, who worked for several years in Amsterdam and speaks fluent Dutch, says: "The Netherlands is a great place to try working abroad for the first time - the culture is open, friendly, youthful and classless. And, of course, so many people speak English, language is not a problem."

And don't forget, workplace stress can be easily suppressed by a trip to your local coffee shop in your lunchbreak. Though from WPM's brief stint in Amsterdam, she seems to remember it's not the cappuccinos they're famed for.

 Oh, for the days when computers were just a dull shade of off-white! The advent of these newfangled i-Macs with their fruit-themed colours ("apple", "strawberry", "blackcurrant", etc) just put extra pressure on the WPM wardrobe as she makes the everyday effort to ensure she doesn't clash with her hardware.

But now news arrives that this colourful contribution to our daily lives can have positive emotional and psychological benefits for employees and improve productivity. According to new research by PC World - which enlisted the help of a leading colour therapist to advise on the effects that different colour computers can have on staff - common workplace ailments such as stress and low motivation can be alleviated just by choosing the right coloured monitor.

Blue computers are recommended for highly strung employees, violet is said to stimulate the imagination and mind, and white is supposed to focus the mind and encourage clarity of thought. Interestingly, WPM's screen is a sort of dull shade of grey and she herself is always in a sort of abject misery at work. What can all this mean?

 Many thanks to all those diligent diaryists who submitted entries in our hunt for a secretarial columnist. Hundreds of you told us tales of your working week and the hard - nay disastrous - lives you lead. WPM was thrilled that you all showed such an interest and was looking forward to comparing notes in return emails but time constraints meant that it wasn't to be and that she can't reply to you all individually. Even more sadly, only one could be selected. She should be gracing these pages in a matter of weeks.

webTitle: Is a pension more trouble than it will turn out to be worth?

fields.headline: Is a pension more trouble than it will turn out to be worth?
fields.trailText: In the wake of Equitable Life closing to new business, and fears that at least one million of its policyholders will be short-changed, growing numbers of people are looking at alternatives to pensions.
fields.body:
In the wake of Equitable Life closing to new business, and fears that at least one million of its policyholders will be short-changed, growing numbers of people are looking at alternatives to pensions.

Many are concerned about high charges, poor management and low returns. Apart from Equitable Life, the industry is tainted by a selling scandal when thousands were coaxed out of company pension schemes into worse performing personal plans.

When it comes to pensions, timing is everything. If you have not started early enough, or are rich enough to stash away vast sums later in life, a pension could be a complete waste of money. The huge rise in buy-to-let mortgages is partly fuelled by those who see property as a more reliable investment than a pension. Others are planning to rely on investments such as ISAs.

Legal & General, which expects to be one of the main providers of the new stakeholder pensions, says a 25-year-old, could expect a £12,000 annual pension when aged 60, for a contribution of £100 a month. But the cost of extra premiums needed to achieve this at a later age soon mounts up. A 40-year-old, for example, would need to pay an extra £214 a month, while a 50-year-old would be paying an extra £800.

"We recommend the earlier the better," says Legal & General's pensions marketing manager, Andy Agar. "If you are in your 40s it is almost too late." He says he would recommend an ISA alongside a pension plan, but he warns there is always a danger this could be spent too early.

Christine Hawkins, a partner with Horsham-based Independent Financial Advisers (IFA), Principles in Practice, says she is seeing an increasing number of women who have left it too late to start a pension. "Some women I see, often in their 40s, find themselves alone, perhaps through divorce. They realise they need a pension, but it is not always worth it. They would be better off putting money into investments such as ISAs where they have greater control and flexibility."

While no independent financial adviser will say pensions are worthless, many admit that their clients are demanding alternatives. Craig Wetton, marketing manager with Bath-based IFA Chartwell Investment Management, says: "The fact that pensions don't meet every need is something we've been conscious of even before Equitable Life. Single premium payments have gone down and many feel having a number of ISAs will be more important to them." He says there is anger among some clients of retirement age that annuity rates are often less than they expected.

Wetton says Chartwell favours clients who put money into in investment trusts alongside a pension. Investment trusts have low charges and in the past have tended to deliver better returns than many unit trusts. These trusts often do not pay commission to salesmen, although this does not affect Chartwell, since it charges fees.

Apart from an ISA, other investments are taxed, while pensions offer tax relief.
John Rutter, an IFA of Lancashire-based Donald Rigg Insurance Brokers says:
"The main benefit with a pension is the tax advantages, but those thinking about retirement need a holistic approach with other investments than just a pension."

While the pensions industry has been knocked for its high charges, the government believes stakeholder pensions will be far more affordable and flexible. But these plans, which are targeted at those earning between £9,500 and £21,600, have their critics. Rutter says: "It is all very well the government saying they want to encourage people to make pension provision. But a lot of these people will be spending all their earnings on the here and now and the amounts they could pay into a stakeholder plan will not make enough of a difference."

Others have criticised stakeholder plans for being misleading and confusing. There is uncertainty over the government's proposed pension credits, which are meant to give incentives for modest earners to save. But it means people will have to take decisions without knowing the impact these credits will have on their retirement income. Decision trees - which are shown on official stakeholder literature - have also been attacked. Some feel these could produce unrealistic expectations and allow unqualified staff to advise on pensions.

webTitle: Halifax blasts big four banks

fields.headline: Halifax blasts big four banks
fields.trailText: The battle to wrest control of current accounts from the big four banks will escalate today when Halifax will accuse them of making £1bn a year from their 27m customers, while Abbey National attacks some of Britain's biggest names for making it difficult for customers to move their accounts.
fields.body:
The battle to wrest control of current accounts from the big four banks will escalate today when Halifax will accuse them of making £1bn a year from their 27m customers, while Abbey National attacks some of Britain's biggest names for making it difficult for customers to move their accounts.

Lloyds TSB, HSBC, Barclays and NatWest, owned by Royal Bank of Scotland - the big four - control 75% of the current account market. Halifax and Abbey both want to take their customers, who statistically are more likely to divorce than change banks.

Halifax, which has less than 5% of the current account market, points out that the Cruickshank report into banking competition said the average current account balance was £1,175. Halifax assumes the big four have £27bn on deposit in the accounts on which they pay out £27m of interest a year. Halifax says it would pay out £1.08bn a year under the terms of its new current account.

The second, on overdrafts, is based on research by NOP which found that 11.5m big four customers are in the red for 80 days a year and face 18% in interest rates. Halifax said its overdraft would save customers £64m a year. Taken together, customers of the big four would be £1.14bn better off it they moved accounts. Abbey, which is also trying to win current account customers with a free overdraft for a year, will accuse NatWest and Lloyds TSB, which wants to take it over, of breaking an industry-wide agreement to exchange information about direct debits and other account details in 10 days.

Lloyds said it was surprised by the Abbey findings, while NatWest insisted it was meeting the industry agreements.

Lloyds TSB said: "We encourage people not to keep their money in current accounts and move into savings accounts. Current accounts are about convenience. We've got three times the number of branches [of the Halifax]".

webTitle: Review: Googoosh

fields.headline: The Iranian Madonna breaks her silence
fields.standfirst:
Googoosh
Wembley Arena, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Googoosh
Wembley Arena, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Now here's a plot for an unlikely movie. Religious fundamentalists take over the US, and pop music is banned. Madonna retreats to her apartment in New York and stops singing, but right across the country her devotees defy the authorities by secretly playing bootleg tapes of Like a Virgin and American Pie. Two decades later, she is finally allowed out of the country to perform abroad, and is treated like a returned goddess by tens of thousands of exiles.

Shift the start of that tale back to Iran in the 1970s and the ending to Wembley Arena at the weekend, and that's the story of Faegheh Atashin, better known as Googoosh, the pop icon of the pre-Ayatollah Khomeini era and still Iran's best-selling artist, although she wasn't allowed to perform or record for 21 years.

"She's not just Madonna for us," explained a teenager in the wildly emotional Wembley crowd. "She's Michael Jackson and George Michael, too. I hadn't been born when she was forced to stop singing, but you can't live in an Iranian family without hearing her all the time."

On stage, in a blitz of flashing lights, came a lady of 50 with shoulder-length blonde hair, wearing a glittery gold blouse and gold skirt. She stared out into the audience and looked as if she was about to burst into tears, then held out her hands to show they were shaking, before falling to her knees. Many in the crowd, who had paid up to £250 a ticket, simply wept back.

Every Iranian in town seemed to be here, from the elderly to young children, businessmen in suits, and women wrapped in expensive fur coats, more suited to a Tehran party back in the Shah's era than to Wembley in 2001. These wildly emotional scenes continued for five minutes before Googoosh managed to say a word.

There followed a marathon re-run of her hits from the 1970s, the era before the mullahs banned the western-influenced pop culture of discos and mini-skirts. She started with an upbeat, declamatory song dealing with love and exile, then moved on to a slow, equally emotional ballad, then a burst of Iranian 1970s hand-clapping disco.

For a woman banned from singing for two decades, then allowed to give shows in North America last year, she was in remarkably good voice, and showed even more remarkable stamina. Much of her material was straightforward 1970s pop, given an eastern-tinged Iranian edge, but the jollity was mixed with ballads that edged towards chanson and even Piaf territory.

She veered between the brash, the vulnerable and the sensitive, and she was little helped by the garish setting and the insensitive band bashing away on synthesisers and percussion. Googoosh has had a tough life. In the Shah's era, there were stories of attempted manipulation and harassment from those in power. Since the revolution, she has been forced to choose between exile and keeping quiet, abandoning her career.

For me, as an outsider, the best sections were those when she sang only with piano, or when she announced "a new setting for an old favourite", and showed the delicacy in her voice when backed only by a flamenco-influenced acoustic guitar. But the Iranians around me, cheering her on as fireworks exploded onstage, would doubtless disagree.

webTitle: Business: CBI renews call for rate cut

fields.headline: CBI renews call for rate cut
fields.trailText: The Confederation of British Industry is today urging the Bank of England to follow the US Federal Reserve and cut interest rates as a defence against a slowdown in the global economy.
fields.body:
The Confederation of British Industry is today urging the Bank of England to follow the US Federal Reserve and cut interest rates as a defence against a slowdown in the global economy.

With the Bank's monetary policy committee set to take its monthly decision on Thursday, the employers' organisation called for a pre-emptive 0.25 percentage point cut in the cost of borrowing to 5.75%.

The CBI said it was the first time since June 1999 that it had lobbied for a rate cut, but that its move was justified by fears that the mood of unease could lead to a mothballing of investment plans. However, a majority of City analysts believe that the MPC is likely to leave borrowing costs on hold this week following recent mixed signals about the strength of the economy.

Nick Reilly, chairman of the CBI's economic affairs committee and managing director of Vauxhall Motors, said: "The CBI has been arguing for some time that the next move should be down.

"Now, after weighing the pros and cons, we believe the time is right for a quarter-point cut. There is a need to boost business confidence at a time of economic uncertainty when firms may be hesitating over investment plans.

"Taking pre-emptive action now would support the sectors most at risk from a global slowdown, especially manufacturing and tourism."

Rates have been left at 6% since February last year, although two members of the MPC, DeAnne Julius and Sushil Wadhwani, voted for a cut at the December meeting. The CBI said inflation had been below the government's 2.5% yardstick since April 1999, and that rates could be cut without putting the target in jeopardy.

Roger Bootle, economic adviser to services firm Deloitte and Touche, said that rates were likely to fall to 5% by the end of the year, but that an immediate cut seemed unlikely.

webTitle: Keep calm in a crisis

fields.headline: Keep calm in a crisis
fields.standfirst: Stuck in a train when you should be at work? The important thing is not to panic, says Judi James
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Stuck in a train when you should be at work? The important thing is not to panic, says Judi James.
fields.body:
Have the rail troubles turned you into a philosopher? Because that was the story, according to the press. Stricken commuters were continually described as being "philosophical" about the delays, meaning - I suppose - we stood in overcrowded carriages quoting Nietzsche and Aristotle. I heard little of this ilk during my own six-hour Intercity nightmares - unless a phrase like: "Oh Christ, not another f---ing delay. For f---k's sake" is attributable to Socrates.

Of course this all adds to up to more stress, and especially more stress at work. Work stress is funny old business. We can take all the deadlines and office politics. We can even cope with cancelled trains and four-hour detours via Scunthorpe. In the main, we are clever, resourceful, resilient people, us workers. What makes us crack, though, (usually) are the minor-league players: those petty, unnecessary aggravations of office life and commuting.

It's the clapped-out equipment that fails to perform. Or the hand-drier in the loos that blasts water all over the crotch of your suit. It's the knuckle-cracking or nose-picking colleagues, or the way your boss only emerges with urgent work for you to do at around 5.15 every evening.

I coped admirably with the six-hour train trip, but not when the buffet ran out of everything except parsnip and carrot crisps. And the lights kept flickering like a disco. Plus my pull-along suitcase started rebelling and bucking around like a bronco when I tried to make the dash from one platform to another. It's the smaller things that get you wired. The things that would normally make you laugh, except suddenly you've lost your sense of humour and want to kill. Anger that is badly managed turns to rage.

So how to cope if the going gets tougher, travel-wise? Delays are threatened until Christmas but the into the life of every commuter a few delays must fall. Here are some simple tips to help you avoid the onset of rail rage:


 Take books and glossy magazines. Don't read any smug articles on Work/Home life balance, or Nigella Lawson teaching you how to bake fairy cakes. These will put you in denial. The truth is, you have no home life - at least not for the foreseeable future.

 Don't chat to other commuters. This is ok to fill the odd ten minutes but long-delay chatter and small-talk can be tiring. Use the time to meditate. This is a great opportunity to think and take stock.

 Do a spot of in-seat calisthnetics. Tense and relax every muscle in your body, moving systematically from toes to head. This will also help you get rid of stress.

 Write letters to friends. Aim to make them laugh.

 Close your eyes and pretend you're Harry Potter on the Hogwart's express, off to start a new term.

 Or even start writing a novel yourself. By this time next year you could be the new J.K.Rowling.

 Enter competitions in magazines and newspapers. You may win a prize for your efforts, rather than indulging in useless fuming.
 Use the time to plan you future career. Get a sheet of A4 paper and start to log greater goals as well as smaller ones. Visualise how you would like work life to be like in five year's time. Where do you want to go? Who do you want to be? Dismiss nothing for being too ambitious. Write targets down, then start to pen steps and strategies for achieving those goals.

 Or just write all your Christmas cards.

 List all the things you are unhappy with in your job and divide them into two columns: Surmountable and Insurmountable. Write strategies for dealing with the surmountable ones first. Then study the Insurmountable list. These are the things you are going to have to let drop. Decide to stop moaning about them. Don't allow them to ruin your life. Change your attitude to them. Learn to tolerate things that you can't change. Including travel delays.

 Use positive affirmation techniques. Repeat pacifying phrases to yourself to re-programme your subconscious, like: 'I feel calm, confident and in control'.

 Do a people study. Learn more about body language from your fellow passengers. Don't stare, but be perceptive. Watch posture, gestures and facial expressions. You have a unique chance to monitor signals from people under pressure and about to crack. Just don't become one yourself.

webTitle: Officehours: Downwardly mobile

fields.headline: Downwardly mobile
fields.standfirst:
Gone are the days when you started work on the first rung of the ladder and moved up. Now people will trade in stress for a sideways or even downward move, says Kate Hilpern

<A HREF="http://www.workunlimited.co.uk/">Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Gone are the days when you started work on the first rung of the ladder and moved up. Now people will trade in stress for a sideways or even downward move, says Kate Hilpern.
fields.body:
This time last year, Maureen Hudson was a highly qualified, highly paid communications manager for an international firm. Today, she is a less qualified, lower-paid secretary for a smaller firm. "What went wrong?" is the most common reaction to her story. But the reality is that the 44-year-old made the career move out of choice.

Recruitment agencies including Office Angels and Reed report that downshifting from being the boss to the PA is increasingly common, and that January is the most prevalent time for taking the plunge.

Why? Hudson opted for the "new year, new life" because of the stress of her managerial position. "Secretarial work seemed the perfect solution because it holds far less responsibility than a managerial position, yet it holds enough responsibility to still be stimulating," she explains.

Initially, Hudson made the decision to leave her job because she wanted to set up a website, "but the pressure wound up being even more severe than the managerial job. Although I may well go back to pursuing it one day, I've decided that, for the time being, I want a job where there remains plenty of challenge - for example in IT and communication - but little stress. When I leave the office now, I don't have to think about work until the following morning."

Mek Rahmani, chief executive of Deskdemon.com, a website aimed at management support professionals, increasingly hears such tales. "What we are witnessing is an increase in people wanting the same level of 'drive' in their role, but a lower level of accountability," he says. "That's why we refuse to refer to the move from manager to secretary as 'downshifting'."

Betsy Jaffe, president of US consulting firm Career Continuum, even claims that for some managers, becoming a secretary can be an ambitious option. "The 90s' rush to create 'flatter' organisations and to get rid of 'jobs for life' led to companies knocking rungs out of career ladders. What they were essentially saying is 'goodbye to the ladder and hello to the chequerboard.' In other words, today's career moves need to be sideways, forwards, diagonal and sometimes even backwards," she says.

Once people feel "stuck" in a position that's not right for them, says Jaffe, that's the time to make their move - not necessarily upwards - but to another post, even in another company, where they have a different range of learning experiences. "It's the breadth of skills rather than sta tus that increasingly count in today's working climate," she insists. "If you can show, as many secretaries do, that you can do everything from arranging company conferences to running personnel, it could potentially count for more in the long run than a series of specialised, blinkered managerial jobs."

A further reason for her career move, says Hudson, is the level of contact she now has with people. "I am far more involved with colleagues and clients - and on a far more equal footing - than I ever have been in previous roles," she explains.

Likewise, Judy Briers, 35, swapped her job as manager in a major stationery firm for PA in an insurance company because she felt she had no life. "I was on contract to work 40 hours a week, yet it wasn't uncommon for me to be working 60. Some weeks, I rarely saw my children. My best friend, who is a PA, had been telling me for years that unpaid overtime is far less common in her profession, and one day last year I woke up and took her advice. I haven't looked back."

The latest Quality of Work/Life Survey carried out by the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (UMIST) found that 86% of managers claimed long hours were adversely affecting their relationship with their children, and a further 79% said the hours were putting pressure on their relationship with their partner.

Professor Cary Cooper, the organisational psychologist who headed the survey, says: "PAs and secretaries certainly aren't immune from being asked to do regular overtime, but studies show such requests are far less likely than for managers. It's one of the reasons graduates who value their work/life balance are increasingly turning to secretarial work."

In fact, research by the UMIST recently found that 55% of secretaries not only work reasonable hours, but that 55% are key users of flexible working - often including working partly from home. "This provides the opportunity to spend more time with the kids, to study, to stop spending so much time commuting, to prevent boredom or simply to work less," says Paul Jacobs, communications officer at Office Angels. "It also enables people to take advantage of their body clock. Some people, for instance, work much better in the evening than in the morning."

Dr Jane Sturges, research fellow at London University's Birkbeck College, believes the increase in bosses-turned-secretaries is because "today's job-seekers - particularly women - have different incentives than previous generations". So when your friend beams, "My new job is amazing. I've got a company sports car, a huge corner office and stacks of money coming in. Who could ask for more?", you're more likely than ever to reply, "Me, actually."

Nevertheless, cautions Eileen Stillwell, 52, who gave up her job as a secondary school teacher to spend more time with her children, becoming a secretary isn't always a smooth transition. "It's a very ageist sector and the newer you are to it, the more you're likely to suffer," she explains. "I approached nine recruitment agencies in search of a secretarial job. The more honest ones actually admitted that my age would go against me, despite having good qualifications and a continuous work record. In the end, I felt I had no choice but to go back to my original job."

Meanwhile, Blue Arrow, the recruitment agency, warns anyone about to downshift to think carefully about the inevitable drop in income. "We've found that people tend to underestimate how much money they need to maintain the lifestyle they enjoy. The reality usually hits them after about three months into their new role, and is often an unwelcome shock," says communications director Charles Walker.

David Kasmir, group HR director at employment agency Manpower, adds that, "Anyone thinking of downshifting shouldn't be naturally authoritative. You can get away with being bossy as a manager, but you'll have little hope as a secretary. It can be a knock to the self-worth to discover people no longer do what you ask."

Cooper also concedes that natural power-seekers may not make it. "If you've opted to downshift because you want less responsibility, you must be careful not to let your intrinsic drive push you into being power-orientated in your new role. It's not uncommon for ambitious, bright downshifters to find themselves subconsciously upshifting again in no time."

Yet he remains confident that the downshifting trend will not wane. Workers in the UK are among the most unhappy in the developed world, according to a recent study by the University of Warwick, with only Hungary and Japan bigger whingers still. "That's why," says Cooper, "I believe that there will eventually come a day where stories of downshifting won't even raise an eyebrow."

webTitle: Review: Barbara Dennerlein

fields.headline: Barbara Dennerlein
fields.standfirst:
Jazz Cafe, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Jazz Cafe, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
For all its incandescent sermonising power and roaring volume, the Hammond organ can sometimes be strangely dispiriting - like being stuck at a bar with a non-stop talker. Barbara Dennerlein, the young Munich-born jazz organist who turned an early obsession with the veteran American Hammond-preachers into a reputation as one of the world's leaders on the instrument, isn't always invulnerable to these snags. But she hasn't copied the master Hammond-blasters she must have spent her childhood listening to.

Although the instrument's dominant repertoire (gospel-like wailing, rhythm and blues) is certainly Dennerlein's too, it is often shrewdly woven into original materials. Moreover, her harmonic sense and ear for fresh melody can make even the most road-battered blues sound like she only just thought of it.

Dennerlein played with Britons Phil Lee on guitar and Martin Drew on drums. Drew was cannily effervescent while Lee was in full flow, and the group's sense of united purpose was considerably the sharper for it. She dedicated her first piece to bluesman Jimmy Smith, a mid-tempo blues right out of the amaze-your-friends-on-the-Hammond kit, but opened it with a stealthy walking bassline of accelerating swing on the pedals (Dennerlein's balletic footwork is one of the attractions of her gigs), attacked it amicably over Drew's unerring backbeat, then took it out into flying double-time.

In the early stages, for all its seamless virtuosity, the show sounded as if it might slip into Dennerlein's downside - an over-dependence on Hammond hot-licks, and a shortage of dynamic contrast that can blunt the impact of even the most telling phrases.

But on the Latin follow-up to the opener, Dennerlein sounded increasingly relaxed in her layering of the music's harmonies and choppy polyrhythmic chord-playing. She replaces the rawness of a bluesman like Jimmy Smith with sophisticated inner voicings that work when she lets them breathe, and, although a fairly anonymous ballad passed by with little trace, a rearrangement of the Stones' Satisfaction was a triumphant journey from slow funk via sly pedalwork to roaring rhythm and blues.

A slow, raunchy blues and a fast, beboppish one displayed Dennerlein's range from the rugged to the flat-out jazzy. When she had the mostly young audience hand-clapping to another bluesy groover in the finale, it was as if the soul-jazz 1960s had never gone away. Which, of course, it didn't.

webTitle: Review: NYO/Mark Elder

fields.headline: NYO goes massive in Manchester
fields.standfirst:
NYO/Mark Elder
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
NYO/Mark Elder
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Every year the National Youth Orchestra starts afresh after Christmas. Schoolchildren auditioned all over the country assemble for an intensive rehearsal period, and a week later they are expected to present a concert on a professional level. That expectation of professionalism is, of course, built on a very long tradition. The orchestra has been doing this for more than 50 years now: there is a distinguished history of truly memorable concerts that each new group of players feels it must match. By and large they succeed, but the odds against them for the first concert of the year are considerable.

Among the additional odds is, of course, the necessity to include as many players as possible. So you can have the kind of line-up that most of us associate with those notorious gargantuan concerts of the 19th century: eight oboes when two are called for, and so on through all sections except the strings.

This is all well and good, and it gives everybody a go, developing in even the youngest members the experience that will so quickly turn many of them into first-rate musicians. But it does not make it easy for anybody to secure the kind of delicate balance and shifting colour needed in a work like Respighi's Pines of Rome. There was the glow and the glitter and the enthusiasm that has made the NYO famous - but it was easy to think poor Respighi was being taken for a ride.

Things were different in the first symphony of Sibelius, though. This was obviously where the most intensive work of the week had been focused. Plainly, more care had been put into the impossible task of sorting out ways to adapt the music to the needs of such a massive band. It was astonishing to witness the clarity of the carefully honed details in a work that can so easily run off the rails. Much of the solo-playing was of breathtaking beauty; the ensemble colours were often marvellously balanced. Mark Elder guided these forces with considerable skill and gave much reason to believe that this year's vintage of the NYO will match the standards set over the years.

webTitle: Pricey home seller's packs move closer

fields.headline: Pricey home seller's packs move closer
fields.trailText: The introduction of the controversial home seller's pack moves forward a step closer today with the second reading of the government's homes bill.
fields.body:
The introduction of the controversial home seller's pack moves forward a step closer today with the second reading of the government's homes bill.

The packs, which sellers will legally required to put together, are a key feature of the new legislation. They could cost up to £750 each to prepare, but are typically expected to cost around £350.

They must include the title documents, answers to standard pre-contract enquiries, replies to standard search enquiries, planning and building regulation consents, any warranties and guarantees for work carried out on a home, a draft sale contract and a report on the condition of the property.

But, a number of Labour MPs are worried at the potential cost these could add on to cash-strapped home sellers in poorer regions. In some parts of the UK negative equity is commonplace and there are still properties selling for under £10,000.

The government believes the packs will speed up sales and cut the risk of gazumping, but gazumping happens predominantly in affluent areas and Trevor Kent, a former president of the National Association of Estate Agents, has warned that the scheme could be a vote loser for Labour.

Joe Ashton, MP for the former mining constituency of Bassetlaw, has suggested that the bill should be amended so that owners of homes below the value of £50,000 could be exempt from having to produce the packs.

The housing minister, Nick Raynsford, has yet to decide if this is to be taken on board.

The packs have, however, received the grudging approval of the mortgage lenders trade body, The Council of Mortgage Lenders, the CML. It initially had been strongly opposed to the idea.

A spokeswoman said the CML had felt the pack could present problems and that they had not been sufficiently tested, since the government only held a Bristol pilot study with the packs, when it paid for the cost.

webTitle: Officehours: The inside track

fields.headline: The inside track
fields.standfirst: The retail sector
fields.trailText: The retail sector
fields.body:
The retail sector is one of the UK's biggest employers, accounting for one in nine of the workforce. It is also one of the fastest growing - more than a fifth of jobs created in 1999 were in retail.

Such rapid expansion in the tightest labour market for more than a generation should be pushing up wages but it is not. While average wage rises are about 5%, in retail they are 3.5%. This is true behind the scenes as well as on the shopfloor. Even in central London, secretarial salaries in retail lag around £1,000 behind other sectors.

The consequence of low wages and far from brilliant conditions is rapid staff turnover. About half the staff employed in retail leave every year. This figure is way above even those sectors such as nursing, which are said to be in a recruitment crisis. Part of the problem is that the employers themselves are under considerable financial pressure. Like manufacturing, retail is suffering a long-term slide independent of the rises and falls of the economy.

One of the reasons for this is consumer pressure. With the rise of e-commerce, customers shop longer and harder and are looking for bigger and better bargains. They are also wise to sales, and prepared to wait for bargains. Value for money has overtaken conspicuous consumption.

There are some pluses for employees, however. Low wages and high turnover make retail a youthful sector. Real managerial responsibility can be attained by the mid-20s, if you are prepared to wait a short space of time.

And despite the pressures, the retail sector does, on occasion, produce some of the more progressive employee development programmes. Asda, for example, has a community service scheme that trains staff in team-building through work on environmental neighbourhood projects. And B&Q has an impressive record in combating ageism with its experienced DIY enthusiasts at hand. It makes a point of hiring older men who understand what they are selling, rather than youngsters desperate to leave retailing.

webTitle: Charities pull funds out of arms firms

fields.headline: Charities pull funds out of arms firms
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Two of Britain's biggest development charities, Oxfam and Christian Aid, will today disclose that they are pulling their pension funds out of arms and tobacco companies and nuclear power.
fields.body:
Two of Britain's biggest development charities, Oxfam and Christian Aid, will today disclose that they are pulling their pension funds out of arms and tobacco companies and nuclear power.

The charities, which have a combined investment clout of £53m, will launch a socially responsible fund aimed at strengthening their influence over causes they oppose. The initiative is seen as the start of a much wider move by other charities to use their financial muscle on ethical issues.

Last night Martyn Tyler, Christian Aid's financial director, said he thought three other leading UK charities were interested in the scheme.

The specialist ethical investment firm, Friends Ivory and Sime, which is managing the scheme, aim to quadruple the fund to £200m within six months by recruiting other charities. Documents outlining the scheme will be sent to other pension funds today.

Andrew Pendleton, a Christian Aid spokesman, said the linchpin of the scheme was a policy of regular meetings with companies to "encourage them to improve their ethical performance on key issues such as labour conditions, human rights, climate change and other aspects of sustainable development".

Mr Pendleton added: "The aim is to realise the power of pensions, so we can be inside the boardrooms as well as outside them with our placards."

Partly for legal reasons, the Balanced Socially Responsible Investment (SRI) Fund will retain pension investments in firms dealing with genetically modified crops, petrochemicals and controversial labour practices abroad. But Friends Ivory and Sime is understood to be recruiting extra staff to meet 100 companies yearly to discuss policies, with a "heavy focus" on 20 of these firms.

Mr Tyler said: "The ultimate step, if argument does not work, is disinvestment."

The partnership between Oxfam and Christian Aid has taken three years to finalise. Oxfam's pension fund is valued at £40m, while Christian Aid's stands at £13m. The partnership arose out of the realisation that many UK charities are, in effect, subsidising practices of which they and many of their donors disapprove - for instance, investing pension funds worth tens of millions into firms dealing in the arms trade, GM crops, petrochemicals, tobacco, powdered baby milk and mining.

To put their project together, the two charities had to manoeuvre within a thicket of legal and professional restraints. British pension funds control an estimate £850bn of assets and account for 35% of the London stock market. According to the Ethical Investment Research Service, 60% of stocks do not meet ethical criteria.

The charities work within the Pensions Trust, which runs its portfolio on a market basis but offers its 80,000 pension scheme members an ethical option that blacklists ethically-questioned investments.

However, some charities are prevented from investing all their funds in ethical stocks because investment returns from some of these are considered unsound.

Most of the Pension Trust's assets have been jointly managed by financially orthodox firms like Legal and General, Schroders, Fidelity, Capital, and Henderson, together with Friends Ivory and Sime. The new scheme puts the funds exclusively under management by Friends Ivory and Sime.

Mr Pendleton said:"The SRI fund squares with the ethics of the organisation while also fulfilling our fiduciary duty as investors. The principle of the scheme is to use the money we have available to invest, to make our views known to companies that need to improve the way they operate."

webTitle: Officehours: Seasonal affective disorder

fields.headline: Beating the winter blues
fields.standfirst: Half a million people suffer from depression at this time of year. As  Mabel Msonthi  discovers, employers can't afford to be complacent
fields.trailText: Half a million people suffer from depression at this time of year. As Mabel Msonthi discovers, employers can't afford to be complacent.
fields.body:
With its characteristic cold spells, short days and long nights, it could barely go unnoticed that mid-winter has arrived. It wouldn't be so bad if we pegged our working hours to the sunrises and sunsets, but in a nine-to-five day, darkness permeates both the morning and the evening, resulting in a distinctly depressed workforce.

Seasonal Affective Disorder (Sad) is a winter depression that affects an estimated half a million people in this country every year, according to the Sad Association. While it would be easy to view Sad as an elaborate excuse for workers to stay at home and watch hours of daytime TV, recent research has stressed the reality of the problem.

For many people it is seriously disabling, preventing them from functioning normally without continuous medical treatment. For others, it is a mild although still unpleasant condition causing discomfort but not severe suffering - in short "winter blues".

A leading UK recruitment agency, Pertemps, has issued a warning to employers to take the winter blues seriously. The agency's research reveals that more than 70% of office workers suffer from mild depression and half admit to a decline in productivity as a result - yet they rarely take time off for fear of being labelled lazy.

Sad is particularly prevalent in December, January and February, triggered by short daylight hours and lack of sunlight. Certain workers are more vulnerable to Sad - lighting in call centres, for example, is kept dim so as not to interfere with computer screens. Shift-workers are among those most affected by bad lighting and are therefore more prone to Sad.

Helen Quinn, branch manager of Pertemps in Manchester, has a member of staff affected by the disorder. "Once winter sets in, I notice a marked change in her - she's constantly in a negative mood and her skin tone is duller. By watching closely, I can help. It doesn't hurt me to allow a person to leave 15 minutes early so they can attend an aerobics class that will help take their mind off any depression, or catch an earlier bus to get home in a little less darkness," says Quinn.

One well-touted remedy for Sad is light therapy - effective in up to 85% of diagnosed cases. This involves exposure for up to four hours a day to very bright light - at least 10 times the intensity of ordinary domestic lighting.

But Diane Sinclair, employee relations adviser at the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development, warns that such a step should be taken with caution because "employers are not medical practitioners. Light therapy can cause irreparable damage to employees with existing sight disorders. While we recognise that workers are waking up and travelling to and from work in darkness, we advise managers to seek out practical solutions in the first instance, for example trying to give employees a lunchbreak during natural periods of light."

Alternative solutions to Sad include psychotherapy, counselling, or any complementary therapy that helps the sufferer to relax and accept the illness and cope with its limitations. Diversions also help, and jetting off on a winter holiday to the sun, or skiing are glamorous, albeit temporary ways of combating Sad.

Jennifer Eastwood is chairwoman of the Sad Association and also works as a PA at Imperial College London. "I suffer from Sad and my boss helps by allowing me to work later in the day when I'm feeling my best. We are undoubtedly in a nine-to-five work culture, which surprises me because my experience of observing the average office is that no one is productive for the first couple of hours. More often than not people start the day by drinking coffee and discussing last night's episode of EastEnders, only really becoming active towards midday. Employers who fail to recognise the importance of Sad could be throwing away millions of pounds every year."

What you can do

Employers

 Ensure staff can speak openly with managers and hold a session to raise awareness.

 Ensure staff sit in sunlight and do not work in windowless, annexed offices.

 Install cool white or natural daylight tubes.

 Create a coffee room with lightboxes for Sad sufferers. Maximum UK lighting levels are 500 lux, whereas Sad sufferers need 2,500 lux for treatment.

 Hold pay reviews and morale-raising social events during the winter as they can act as a psychological boost.

Employees

 Invest in a lightbox.

 Always take a full hour for lunch and go for a brisk walk to soak up more natural light.

 Eat bean soups or casseroles for lunch. These provide long-lasting energy and contain tryptophan, an amino acid that is converted into serotonin - a mood enhancer - in the body. Other foods containing tryptophan include bananas, meat, fish, eggs and cheese.

 Take a winter holiday in the sun or go skiing. Light increases in intensity when it is reflected off snow.

webTitle: Officehours: Profile of Bluewater's marketing analyst

fields.headline: Counter culture
fields.standfirst: As the January sales hit their peak, Tara Atkinson tells Tom Twentyman why she is more interested in who is visiting the stores than what they have to offer
fields.trailText: As the January sales hit their peak, Tara Atkinson tells Tom Twentyman why she is more interested in who is visiting the stores than what they have to offer.
fields.body:
While many people have to drag themselves away from the shops, Tara Atkinson has to drag herself to them - every day. Atkinson, 29, is the marketing analyst at the UK's largest shopping centre, Bluewater, near Dartford in Kent.

With around 320 stores, including national chains and owner-operator units, Bluewater is shopping heaven. In keeping with the rest of the retail world, and despite its out-of-town location, it is in the middle of that annual explosion of bargain-hunting known as the January sales.

Atkinson is the woman charged with observing changes at this time of year. Not just the "lots of lovely big sale bags, but people seem more determined, as opposed to strolling leisurely around," she says.

The volume of visitors - 166,000 on the busiest day - doesn't peak at the weekends, either. "Instead, they're evenly spread throughout the week. Which is good news for us, as it's easier to plan and manage the staffing levels for our guest services, like valet parking or the children's creche."

The number-crunching doesn't end there. She also tracks the footfall figures, using the output from equipment situated around Bluewater, recording, at 15-minute intervals, the ebb and flow of human traffic.

These are combined with data Atkinson collects from each business using a computer programme called Daily Sales Advantage (DSA). "Sales and footfall together are the key indicators of how Bluewater is performing," she explains.

Each Monday there is a marketing meeting at which Atkinson updates colleagues on her investigations into the past seven days of trading, and evaluates the effects of any promotional activity such as advertising campaigns, fashion shows or music festivals. She looks for trends or patterns forming, and their likely causes. The weather can be a factor in her findings: she'll log on to the Met Office website and add summaries of the daily conditions and temperatures to the report.

When she's back at her computer, the phone rings frequently with individual shop managers enquiring about comparable information from the previous week, or the corresponding time last year. "It gives them meaningful feedback. Plus, they'll share anecdotal evidence with us - they're on the ground, as it were, seeing things for themselves, so it's a two-way thing."

For Atkinson, the most enjoyable part of the job is supplying training on DSA to incoming retailers, or new employees in existing outlets. "It's easy to use. All in all, it takes me only about half an hour to talk through what they need to do." (Showing an admirable level of devotion to the task, she prefers to visit them, rather than the other way round. Only in the name of her work, you understand).

Marketing is the thread that runs throughout her career, including four years with Thomson Holidays. She has been employed by Lend Lease, the management company behind Bluewater, since June 1999 - the centre had opened only that March - and started as a temp, spending four weeks on general admin, assisting PAs throughout the office. "That was close to a month-long interview, really," she says. "I got to know how Bluewater operates, the team here learnt about me, and it was a nice way of doing it."

Her progress was swift. She became PA to the marketing director, and within two months her current role had been created and offered to her. Atkinson believes she has been fortunate - "right place, right time" - but the speed at which events changed for her meant she had to adapt to a faster-paced environment than she had experienced in the past. "My background meant I was used to coping with fixed patterns of demand - very different to retail, which is reactive, and quite specialised."

Starting at Bluewater made her feel "like a child let loose in a candy store. I am completely addicted to shopping," she admits, happily.

During her first couple of months, she spent most of the lunch hours scanning the malls. "But I've got that down to not every day now!"

After some thought, she says the biggest disadvantage of her surroundings is that she has absolutely no excuse to offer anyone if she is late with a birthday card or gift. When temptation does cross her path, however, Atkinson is careful to avoid committing all her spending to plastic. "I have got a credit card, and it can be convenient. But I make sure the amounts don't build up too much, and even as a child, my philosophy was always to save up for something until I could afford to buy it."

Working in shopping heaven, and remaining financially solvent? Now that's a level of self-control you just can't put a price on.

fields.bodyText: The introduction of statutory home sellers' packs, which have been under attack from a number of people, including Labour MPs, moves a step closer today with the second reading of the government's Homes Bill. The packs are expected in general to cost around £350, but they could cost up to £750. Each pack will have to include the title documents, answers to standard pre-contract enquiries, replies to standard search enquiries, planning and building regulation consents, any warranties and guarantees for work carried out on the home, a report on the condition of the property and a draft sale contract. Some Labour MPs are angry at the cost the packs could add on to cash-strapped home sellers in poorer regions of the country. In some parts of the UK negative equity is commonplace, and there are still properties selling for under £10,000. Joe Ashton, MP for the former mining constituency of Bassetlaw, has suggested that the Bill should be amended in order that owners of homes below the value of £50,000 could be exempt from having to produce a pack. The housing minister, Nick Raynsford, has yet to decide if the government will accept this amendment. The packs have now received the grudging approval of the mortgage lenders trade body, the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML). Initially it had been strongly opposed to the idea. The CML has decided it was fighting a losing battle and now feels it is highly likely the packs will be introduced. A spokeswoman said the CML had felt the packs could present problems and that they had not been sufficiently tested. webTitle: New deal to save Equitable

fields.headline: New deal to save Equitable
fields.standfirst:
Sale could follow agreement by policyholders to forgo increasing returns

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sale could follow agreement by policyholders to forgo increasing returns.
fields.body:
A compromise deal that would cap the black hole at Equitable Life could revive the sale of the troubled mutual insurance group, it emerged yesterday.

The possibility of a successful sale was revived this weekend. It emerged that one of the leading policyholder lobby groups was prepared to offer Equitable a way of limiting its liabilities for the guaranteed annuity policies which had deterred previous bidders.

A buyer for the entire outfit, which is in the process of being broken up, might improve the fortunes of the customers, who face the prospect of lower returns from their policies. It is understood that a number of potential bidders have already approached the negotiating table even though the auction of Equitable was officially abandoned last month.

Speculation is mounting that Prudential, the last of the previous bidders, might be prepared to reopen talks, along with Aegon, the Dutch group which was once regarded as a bidder for the 238-year-old insurer.

At a meeting with the management of the insurer this week, the Equitable Life Action Group is thought to be prepared to offer a deal under which the insurer pays a one-off payment into their combined pot of assets. In return the 90,000 customers will forgo their rights to the higher returns promised to them by the law lords.

This, according to one senior City source, would help to solve one of the key hurdles which had turned bidders away in the past as, in effect, bidders would then know the size of the so-called black hole left by the broken pledge to guaranteed annuity holders.

The financial services authority, which has come under fire for its role in the Equitable debacle, indicated this weekend it was closely involved in the future of the group. "We are very much involved in various discussions about the future of the Equitable. These include meetings with a number of firms who've expressed an interest and policyholder groups. Our objective is to get the best possible outcome for policyholders as a whole," a spokesman for the FSA said.

Equitable, the oldest mutual insurer in the world, put itself up for sale in the summer after the law lords ruled it had treated holders of its guaranteed annuity policies unfairly. But, while more than a dozen potential bidders expressed an interest in Equitable at the outset, none of them put a concrete bid on the table, apparently because of the unknown scale of the bill needed to pay the guaranteed annuities.

A successful sale is by no means certain, however, as talks are also taking place with various groups about breaking up Equitable into a number of parts. The £150m sale of one part of the business was announced before Christmas and the group is also discussing the sale of its asset management, sales team and administration businesses.

Equitable said last night: "Our priority must be to generate value for policyholders".

Prudential, which refused to comment yesterday on the possibility of it submitting a bid for Equitable, was the last potential bidder to pull out of the process, which led to surprise events last month when Equitable closed its doors to new business. Any bidder for Equitable would now need to take into account the potential damage inflicted to the once highly regarded brand.

The other difficulty faced by completing a sale is that the Equitable Life Action Group is only one of a number of groups representing policyholders. It is unclear whether its reported plan is backed by other groups or whether it would be adopted by Equitable, sources said.

webTitle: Review: Lisa Milne/ Sarah Connolly

fields.headline: Lisa Milne/Sarah Connolly
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The soprano Lisa Milne and mezzo Sarah Connolly are two of the brightest young stars in the British opera firmament. Yet their joint recital at the Wigmore Hall on Friday, with pianist Julius Drake, was a disappointment - not because the singing of either of them was ever less than accomplished (indeed, it was often superb) but because the programme they had put together never really took off or showed their talents to best advantage.

It was designed as a homegrown affair: a trip through the English tradition from Purcell to Noel Coward, with an excursion to the Hebrides for a selection of folk songs, in Majorie Kennedy-Fraser's arrangements with harp, played by Sioned Williams. There was nothing wrong with that plan in principle but, by concentrating on unfamiliar repertoire at the expense of favourites, they failed to avoid the danger of mediocrity - it was only too obvious why a number of these songs remain little known.

There could be no complaints about the three Purcell settings that began the programme, though: they were the only true duets of the evening, and were presented with a natural stylishness that perfectly pointed up the neat contrast between the two singers' timbres: Milne's open, affecting tone set in relief against Connolly's endlessly fascinating, dark-hued sound, which she used to great effect in four of Ivor Gurney's songs.

Gurney is an unjustly neglected composer. His version of John Masefield's By The Bierside, which Connolly and Drake built to a terrifying climax, is a little masterpiece, and well worth a place in this selection. But most of what followed was less convincing.

Neither Milne's three Delius songs, with their effortfully tortuous melodic lines over self-consciously chromatic accompaniments, nor Connolly's group of Herbert Howells's insipid lyrics left any lasting impression. And, though Milne sang her groups of Hebridean songs either side of the interval very characterfully, there were too many of them and all of Williams's artistry could not disguise the commonplaces of the harp accompaniments.

So it continued. Vaughan Williams's Four Last Songs (Connolly) only fitfully recapture the invention of his earlier vocal writing, and neither Peter Warlock nor Roger Quilter (Milne) were shown to best advantage by the selections here.

Connolly's account of Vaughan Williams's setting of Shakespeare's Orpheus With His Lute lit up the sequence briefly, Rubbra's In Dark Weather (Connolly again) darkened it, and by the time the final group of Coward songs was reached, something a little livelier was long overdue: both singers finally gave a glimpse of the well-honed theatrical instincts which had been put on hold until then.

Connolly also provided a sample of her own piano playing in World Weary, while Milne showed how versatile she could be in a beautifully timed version of Twentieth Century Blues, and the two singers dovetailed expertly in Nina From Argentina.

Too little indulgence too late, though.
