webTitle: Getting yourself a nicer Isa

fields.headline: Getting yourself a nicer Isa
fields.trailText: Did you get your fingers burnt last year from holding a technology Isa? If so, you weren't alone, as thousands of people are nursing losses. But it is important to remember that Isas remain sound investments, if viewed over the long term, and are a way of saving tax-free.
fields.body:
Did you get your fingers burnt last year from holding a technology Isa? If so, you weren't alone, as thousands of people are nursing losses. But it is important to remember that Isas remain sound investments, if viewed over the long term, and are a way of saving tax-free.

But, with the investment markets set to recover slowly, no one should see an Isa as a short-term bet. Most suggest money should be tied up for a minimum of five years.

There are a number of investment trends being tipped by the experts as likely winners in 2001 and while not all are in agreement, there are some common themes. In particular, global, European and smaller UK companies are viewed as good bets for a winning Isa.

So, which are the likely Isa winners this year?

Philip Saunders, director of Isa provider Investec says avoid anything "faddish". "I would steer clear of any exotic themed fund, such as those claiming to be focusing on ecology or whatever. Stick to broad-themed Isas such as those covering Europe."

He says the improving euro is good news for Isa investors who choose a European fund. For those looking to the UK, he recommends funds that focus on stocks outside of the FTSE 100. "We offer an opportunities fund, which looks at smaller to medium sized companies This is volatile but offers good potential."

Robin Stoakley, sales director for Schroders, agrees that Europe is one of the best areas for growth and that smaller companies in the UK are a good tip, but he also insists that thematic Isas remain good buys. "We expect one of our best sellers to be our medical discovery fund, which focuses on a range of healthcare sectors including bio-technology."

If you are completely bamboozled by the choice of Isas on the market, it is worth seeing an independent financial adviser to point you in the right direction. Some will charge a fee, others will be paid a commission if you buy on their recommendation.

Terry Reed, a financial adviser in Bishops Stortford, says his first piece of advice to anyone would be to ignore "headline rates used in advertising". He says these snapshot figures are often misleading.

For recommendations, Mr Reed says that many of Fidelity's global funds have performed well and also favours a "fund of funds" approach. "I've been recommending Portfolio Fund Managers to my clients who want a safe option", he says.

He adds anyone who has just a small amount of money to invest, should take advantage of a mini-cash Isa, since these can be opened with as little as £1.

Another adviser, Alan Lakey of Highclere Financial Services in Hemel Hempstead, says he has seen several clients who have had bad experiences with technology Isas this year.

"One client came to see us who had borrowed money on a credit card to put into a technology Isa. They've lost a lot of money that they are now struggling to pay back. They'd have been a lot better off with a building society."

But, Mr Lakey says for a client who does want some risk, he would suggest Japan, and in particular, Gartmore's Japanese growth fund.

But, not everyone is steering clear of technology. Michael Aaron of Milton Keynes advisers David Aaron Partnership, says that the technology crash will mean the stocks are now far better value: "There are plenty of good holdings still and the lower cost can be good for those prepared to wait."

Of course, these are just a few suggestions, so be prepared to put in some research of your own, so for more background information on ISAs, keep checking out the information supplied on Money Unlimited.

webTitle: Review: Victoria Morton

fields.headline: Morton's Scotland - a sexy utopia
fields.standfirst:
Victoria Morton
Sadie Coles HQ, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Victoria Morton
Sadie Coles HQ, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
If we did not have bodies, we might experience abstract painting as pure spiritual revelation. But we inevitably find ourselves thinking of Jackson Pollock's line as a cowboy's lasso or as a drunk's trail of piss on the floor. Whatever we look at, we bring to it a wealth of association; even something as apparently non-referential as the colour pink has a history that could fill a book. This makes abstract painting a lot of fun for artists today, who can play on its seriousness and bring it down to size, pointing out its unacknowledged sexual suggestiveness, insisting that it is (as the abstract expressionists went to such extremes to deny) a pretty decoration, a colourful thing to put on the wall.

Victoria Morton does this with great panache. Her paintings frolic with the different associations of different kinds of patterning. They evoke both the big space of landscape and the textures of softer, lighter, indoor stuff: boas, costume jewellery, buttons and the unreal colours of party clothes - a silvery turquoise, a shimmer of blue.

Based in Glasgow, this young artist seems to have a systematic ambition to reimagine the Scottish landscape. You can see it quite clearly and richly in her art: her pictures, with their cascades of green, brown and feathery blues and reds, make you think of forest and pheasant. At the same time, you think of parties, dresses, decorations, silks and velvets. Natural and luxuriantly synthetic at the same time, her Scotland is a sexy utopia.

Morton's paintings also unexpectedly evoke the abstract expressionist Arshile Gorky, who was born in Armenia and emigrated to the US in the wake of the Armenian genocide, then later committed suicide. Gorky's abstract paintings, with their falls and gusts of colour, are drenched in memories of the lost landscape of his childhood. In a far more optimistic way, Morton seems to emulate his art in her own imaginary, unreal landscapes.

She pictures a land that might be, rather than one lost forever. These are paintings you will remember when you go walking across the violet moors and through the velvet heather.

 Until January 20. Details: 020-7434 2227.
